PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Middle East: Australian Military Personnel
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The hasty deployment of Australian military personnel to the Middle-East at the request of the President of the United States has involved Australia in an undeclared war with potentially disastrous consequences for Australia and the people of the Middle-East.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will:
Immediately withdraw all Australian military personnel from the Middle East and pursue a foreign policy designed to secure justice and human rights for all of the people of the Middle-East.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Air Landing Fee: New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament:

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the proposed air landing fee for regional and commuter airlines landing at Sydney Mascot Airport during peak times discriminates severely against people in rural Australia and will force many airlines to either revise their schedules, cancel flights or increase passenger fares to cover this additional financial impost of the Federal Labor Government. This will result in less accessibility for country businessmen and travellers alike, will increase the costs of business for rural people and threatens the viability of many smaller airlines who provide valuable services to rural towns. We therefore call on the Federal Government to abolish all plans for the introduction of this discriminatory fee and allow commuter airlines to continue to provide their full range of services to towns throughout New South Wales.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecommunications: Future Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned shows that there is widespread community concern over the introduction of competition into Australia's telecommunications industry, and that ordinary consumers may be faced with higher prices and reduced services as a result. In particular, we are concerned about the impact on the affordability of telephone services for low income earners and rural consumers.
The petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should introduce legislation to:
(a) protect ordinary consumers from increasing prices and decreasing service and to ensure that the telephone remains an affordable utility
(b) clearly define community service obligations of all telecommunications providers

(c) ensure that, regardless of the structural arrangements, a strong and viable government telecommunications carrier is maintained and continues to provide a universal, affordable service to all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Middle East
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:

Their Opposition to the despatch of three Australian warships to the Middle East, which is part of an unnecessary militarisation of the region, and which contributed to the likelihood of all-out war. The increasing military buildup in the Middle East does not contribute to a resolution of the conflict. The conflict can only be resolved by regionally based diplomatic means. Whilst we unambiguously oppose the acquisition of territory by force and Iraq's military takeover of Kuwait, we note that current actions against Iraq have not been applied in similar circumstances, such as the annexation of East Timor by Indonesia.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
The Australian warships in the Middle East be withdrawn immediately.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated and Violent Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:
The petition of citizens of Australia points out:

that all State Governments, States Attorneys-General, most women's groups and the majority of men in Australia, including significant numbers of members of Parliament, are totally opposed to the importation and distribution of `X' and excessively violent `R'-rated video pornography in Australia;
that most `X'-rated material available in Australia is imported;

that the Federal Government, by its Customs power under the Constitution, and not the Australian Capital Territory Government, is solely responsible for controlling the importation of this pornographic material;
that by continuing to allow the importation of such pornographic material, the Federal Government is neglecting its responsibility to the women, children and families of Australia.
Your Petitioners, therefore, request the Senate to:
1. Ban `X'-rated pornographic material at the point of entry into Australia;
2. Exclude from the `R'-rating all gratuitously violent material.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Mining and Export
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, 15 sitting days after today, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Determination of Application No. 2 made under section 72 of the Privacy Act 1988, be disallowed.
I seek leave to make a short statement on the concerns of the Committee with this instrument and with the work of the Committee during these sittings.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This determination was made by the Privacy Commissioner under procedures in the Privacy Act to grant exemptions from operation of the Act. The Committee has received representations that its principles were breached by defects in the conduct of statutory procedures preceding the making of the determination. These defects included alleged denial of natural justice and the right to be heard and invalid changes to the statutory requirements. The representations also argued that the determination itself was uncertain in its effects of operation, granted wide and unreviewable discretions and was more suitable for enactment by Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: It is usual at the end of each sitting for the Chair of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances to speak briefly on the operations of the Committee and to incorporate in Hansard a statement relating to these operations. During these sittings the Committee scrutinised 881 disallowable instruments of delegated legislation under its principles to ensure that such instruments comply with parliamentary propriety and personal liberties. This is the largest number of instruments ever examined by the Committee during a sitting. Of these, the Committee detected what appeared to be defects in some 171 instruments-almost 20 per cent of the total. The Committee wrote to Ministers and other makers of delegated legislation expressing its concerns at these defects. In 38 cases the law maker agreed to amend the parent Act or the instrument to meet these concerns. In other cases, the Minister or others undertook to provide or improve explanatory statements, provide numbering and citation, or take administrative action. In the remainder of cases the Minister provided advice which satisfied the Committee.

The Committee is grateful for the high level of cooperation that it received from Ministers. The Committee has noted some areas of continuing concern involving aspects of delegated legislation. These are set out in the accompanying statement. The Committee is grateful to colleagues in the Senate for their continuing support of the parliamentary ideals expressed in the Committee's non-partisan technical legislative scrutiny. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a brief summary of the concerns of the Committee and a statement on the work of the Committee during the sittings.
Leave granted.
The summary read as follows-
DETERMINATION OF APPLICATION NO. 2 MADE UNDER SECTION 72 OF THE PRIVACY ACT 1988

This Determination was made under provisions which enable the Privacy Commissioner to grant waivers from compliance with the Privacy Act following an application, publication of the application, and other procedures involving public consultation. The Determination exempts the Director of Public Prosecutions from provisions of the Act.

The present instrument was tabled in the Senate on 26 November 1990, apparently in lieu of an earlier tabling of a generally similar instrument on 15 November 1990. The textual differences in the two copies appear to be intended to place the technical drafting validity of the instrument beyond doubt. However, it is not this aspect about which the Committee is principally concerned.

The Committee has received representations about the Determination from three organizations, including the Australian Privacy Foundation and the Communications Law Centre. These two organizations are listed as making submissions to the Privacy Commissioner during the processes leading to the making of the Determination and appear to have taken part in hearings on the matter.

The basis of these representations is that the Determination breached the principles of the Committee in a number of ways. Some of these are not directly concerned with matters normally raised by the committee. Nevertheless, because of the importance of their subject matter, the Committee has decided to write to the Privacy Commissioner.

One suggestion is that the Determination was not validly made because the required hearings were fundamentally flawed in that natural justice and the right to be heard was denied to organizations representing state and federal government employees. The required advertisement by the Commissioner which publicised the application for relevant exemption from the Act by the DPP mentioned only that the proposed exemption was for the DPP to disclose certain information to professional disciplinary bodies and the Victorian Mental Health Review Board. During the resulting hearing the commissioner widened both the scope of the inquiry and the scope of the Determination beyond that set out in the advertisement, to include the Commonwealth Public Service Commission and the State and Territory employer organizations as bodies to which the DPP may disclose information.

In addition, it was suggested that the Determination may trespass upon personal liberties because it allegedly does not indicate clearly how widely the DPP could or would disseminate the information and does not list the bodies to which the information can be disseminated. The submissions also argued that discretions given to the DPP were so wide as to require review of their merits. It was also argued that the Determination expanded powers granted under the Act, and that such expansion should be effected by amendment of the parent Act.
SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES STATEMENT OF WORK OF COMMITTEE DURING BUDGET SITTINGS 1990

The operations of the Committee over these sittings have been characterised by the high volume of delegated legislation which has come before it for scrutiny. Delegated legislation authorised by Acts of Parliament was made by Ministers administering every Department of State, by the larger statutory authorities, by the High Court, the Federal Court, the Family Court and by other tribunals. Almost all of the more important programs of the Government rely on delegated legislation to provide finer details and technical requirements, particularly where frequent changes to these are necessary. Delegated legislation often provides for changes in the level of taxes, levies, fees and charges. Some delegated legislation made by the executive incorporates other material, which in a number of cases is thousands of pages long.

There is a duty on the Parliament to ensure that this material, which is no less Commonwealth law than Acts of the Parliament itself, complies with the high standards of parliamentary propriety and personal liberties upon which the Parliament properly insists for Acts. The Regulations and Ordinances Committee acts on behalf of Parliament to scrutinise all delegated legislation in close detail. The Committee draws to the attention of the Senate cases where there are significant defects in an instrument, often placing a protective notice of disallowance in order to preserve its option to recommend this final sanction. However, it is only in rare cases that this is necessary. Ministers and officials normally agree to amend the offending instrument to meet the concerns of the Committee. In other cases Ministers agree to amend the parent Act, take administrative action or advise the Committee on special circumstances relating to the instrument.

During these sittings Ministers have agreed to amend no fewer than 38 instruments to meet the concerns of the Committee. This does not include undertakings to provide or improve Explanatory Statements, provide numbering and citation or take administrative action. Many of these undertakings have been to amend an instrument in a number of ways.
This is a high level of cooperation from Ministers, and represents a commitment by them to the parliamentary ideals of the Committee.

The following table sets out the broad categories of instruments which have come before the Committee during the four months of the present sittings. The categories are necessarily broad. This is because there are more than 100 different series of delegated legislation, the great majority of which have a poor standard of numbering and citation. Even these broad categories do not indicate the extent of the reliance by the executive on delegated legislation. For example, the Statutory Rules series alone, most of which are regulations, are made under parent Acts administered through all Departments of State. The Territory ordinances cover all external territories. Both the Education and training and the Community services and health instruments include more than a dozen different series of delegated legislation made under a number of parent Acts.
The 881 instruments scrutinised by the Committee this sittings is the largest number of instruments ever scrutinised in a sittings.

Every instrument of disallowable delegated legislation is scrutinised by the Committee under its four principles, which may conveniently be called its terms of reference. These principles are now included in the Standing Orders. The Committee discusses each instrument which appears to be defective and writes to the Minister or other law-maker for advice about the apparent breach of its principles.

During these sittings the Committee detected prima facie defects in 171 out of the 881 instruments which it scrutinised. These defects are set out below under each of the four principles of the Committee.
(a) Is the delegated legislation in accordance with the statute?
This principle of the Committee is not interpreted narrowly to include mere technical legal validity. Rather it is interpreted widely to include all aspects of parliamentary propriety.

Naturally the Committee does scrutinise instruments for technical validity. During these sittings the Committee questioned instruments which purported to provide directly for the same matters dealt with a month earlier by a determination of a specialist tribunal. Other instruments purported to allocate identical sums of money for similar projects in a series of determinations without attempting to revoke, replace or remake the earlier instruments in the series.

In another case affecting validity a supposed revocation was ineffective as the instrument did not include any words of revocation. In another the stated purpose of the instrument was not effected due to the omission of appropriate words. Several instruments referred to Schedules which were not provided. In one case Schedule headings were transposed. On two occasions two separate instruments were given the same number in the series. In one case two separate and important provisions were given the same number. In two cases statutory authorities were referred to by incorrect titles. Finally, four fresh instruments were made which were evidently intended to replace four earlier ones. Some three weeks later two more instruments were made which purported to revoke two of the earlier instruments from that later date.

A number of instruments were felt by the Committee to breach parliamentary propriety even though validity was not in question. Some instruments had no system of numbering or citation, without which delegated legislation may be imprecise and confusing. Others either had no Explanatory Statement or explanatory material of poor quality. Several Explanatory Statements cited Acts incorrectly. One Explanatory Statement advised that the purpose of the instrument was to allocate a sum of money among several institutions. However, the sums actually allocated by the instrument did not add up to that sum. Parts of some instruments were so poorly reproduced that they could not be read. Others appeared to omit words and phrases.

Some instruments provided for further instruments which appeared to be legislative in nature, but which were not subject to tabling and possible disallowance in Parliament. One provision referred to the ``published policy of the Department'', with no provision for tabling or disallowance.

On several occasions the Committee queried the technical drafting of instruments. One single provision used four cumulative negatives. Another used archaic language such as ``Deck Boy''. A similar instrument referred separately to a ``kitchenman'' and a ``kitchenmaid'', although both of these categories have the same grades and salaries.

Many principal instruments of delegated legislation have been amended often, with large numbers of additional provisions inserted. Some of the more important of these principal instruments were amended by renumbering all provisions. This was done without any charts or tables comparing old provisions with new. In these cases the Committee believes that a reprint of the principal legislation should be produced at once. Without such reprints the legislation is extremely complicated. In several cases the renumbered provisions were themselves subsequently amended with no reprint produced at all.

It is common for delegated legislation to incorporate other material. This is generally valid only insofar as the incorporated material, apart from acts and regulations, is in existence and is not amended. However, in some cases it appeared that makers of delegated legislation were unaware of this requirement. In one case an instrument expressly incorporated future material.
(b) Does the delegated legislation trespass unduly upon personal rights and liberties?
The Committee closely scrutinies delegated legislation for possible breaches of personal liberties.

Strict liability offences are accepted by the Committee only in unusual circumstances. The Committee generally regards it as inappropriate for the executive to create offences where no intention to commit a crime is required. In one case during this sittings strict liability was provided for all of the officers of an organisation if the organisation itself breached a provision. The instrument which created this offence was not accompanied by an Explanatory Statement to explain the necessity for such a provision.

Another provision reversed the usual onus of proof in criminal cases, so that a person was presumed guilty unless that person could prove themselves innocent. Again the Committee insists on a full explanation before it will accept such an offence. Similarly, the Committee believes that there should be clear protection against persons being required to incriminate themselves. In one case, the person in charge of an establishment could refuse to answer questions on the grounds of self-incrimination. However, if that person waived this right then the right was waived for all persons present on the premises, who were then required to answer questions even if the replies incriminated them. In another case, it was an offence to refuse to answer a question without reasonable excuse. It was unclear whether self-incrimination was a reasonable excuse.

In a related type of case, public officials could demand personal information from any person at all. The Committee obtained an undertaking that such information could only be required from a narrow class for the purposes of the scheme.

In another offence provision, the owner of a motor vehicle was deemed guilty of certain offences even if the vehicle had been stolen or taken illegally at the time the offences were committed. At the other end of the scale, the Committee questioned mandatory provisions which did not include any sanctions.

The Committee examined a number of provisions which empowered officials to enter private premises. In such cases the Committee believes that warrants to enter, search and seize should be issued only by a judge or magistrate, should be in a mandatory form subject to tabling and disallowance in Parliament, and should be limited as to the hours, dates and places of entry. The Committee questioned one provision where it was unclear whether these safeguards existed. In another case a warrant was in a discretionary rather than a mandatory form.

The officials who actually execute a search warrant should be required to produce a photographic identity card on demand, or else leave the premises if requested. This safeguard was not provided in several instruments. Under one instrument photographic identity cards did not have to be produced in an emergency, although written identification did.

One instrument provided that a public official could remove persons from an area if they had contravened the regulations. The Committee pointed out that whether a person had contravened offence provisions was a matter for a properly constituted court, not for the opinion of an official.

It is not only offence provisions which may breach personal liberties. The Committee is vigilant to ensure that all procedures in delegated legislation are fair and equitable. One instrument provided that certain property dealt with by a statutory authority became the property of its new owner free of any charges and encumbrances. The Committee sought assurances that holders of a mortgage or charge over this property would not thereby lose their rights.

The Committee questioned what appeared to be harsh provisions in an area with important financial and livelihood implications. In one of these there was a time limit for the provision of information. Failure to meet the time limit would have severely adverse financial consequences, yet there was no discretion (subject to external merits review) to extend the limit. In another there was only a restricted right to apply for an extension of time. One provision queried by the Committee purported to operate notwithstanding certain other provisions. This procedure appeared to avoid a number of important safeguards.
In a related series of instruments some individuals were required to make an important decision within eight days while others were given thirty days to make the same decision.

A considerable proportion of delegated legislation imposes or changes the level of taxes, levies, fees and charges. The Committee always requires that the Explanatory Statement advise of the basis for the imposition or the change. This is often to effect a policy of cost recovery, or to reflect changes in the CPI. In any event, it should be notified.

Duties and rights imposed by delegated legislation should be clear and unambiguous. In one instrument there was no indication of who was to exercise a number of discretions. In another, obligations were ``subject to the conditions which the Department from time to time notifies.'' Other provisions were questioned by the Committee because they were vague, uncertain and subjective. Some rights were expressed to be subject to the ``national interest.'' Others were required to be ``consistent with the interests of Australia.''

(c) Does the delegated legislation unduly make the rights and liberties of citizens dependent upon administrative decisions which are not subject to review of their merits by a judicial or other independent tribunal?

The Committee examines all discretions which may affect individuals to ensure that external review of the merits of a decision is provided in appropriate cases. In the reporting period the Committee inquired about discretions granted to Ministers, to the Registrar of a Court, to secretaries of departments and to statutory officers. In many cases the power to exercise these discretions could be delegated to others. The Committee believes that the case for independent review is stronger where there is a wide power of delegation. Where delegation is to any person at all the case is overwhelming. In any event, the Committee also examines delegations to ensure that they are restricted to the narrowest possible class.

In one case, an instrument provided that only a restricted class of public officials could be authorised for certain purposes. However, the power to appoint individuals within this class could be delegated to any person at all.

The Committee examines the type of discretion to decide which review rights may be suitable. Some discretions are to exempt individuals completely from the operation of a scheme. Wide discretions like this should usually be subject to AAT review. Other discretions may have a commercial value or affect a person's livelihood. Here external review will also usually be essential. Other discretions may have a financial value. It is common for delegated legislation to provide that an official may refund fees already paid, or waive or remit in whole or part fees which are payable. Here also the case for external review is strong.

The Committee believes that discretions should not be open ended but rather limited and guided by objective criteria. In the absence of any criteria at all, or where criteria are subjective, vague or wide, then external review should be provided. In some instances an instrument may set out criteria but then provide that an official may make a decision regardless of the criteria.

Review rights should not only exist, but also be notified to the person affected by the adverse exercise of a discretion. The Committee believes that where such a decision is made, there should be an express requirement that any review rights be advised in writing at the same time as advice of the decision itself. If there are no review rights this should also be advised to the person affected. At present, many instruments of delegated legislation are unclear as to whether review is provided for discretions. This is particularly so in the large number of instruments which amend principal instruments. Such principal legislation, or the parent Act, may provide review rights. In such cases the Explanatory Statement, or Notes in the body of the instrument should indicate whether review exists for individual discretions. If review is not provided this also should be clearly advised in the Explanatory Statement. The Committee has scrutinised instruments which refer to reviewable decisions without any indication as to the decisions subject to review.

Some instruments provide for decisions to be reviewed by special bodies established for the purposes of the parent Act or delegated legislation made under it. The Committee generally prefers that decisions be reviewed by the AAT, which places itself in the position of the original decision maker and which may substitute its decision for the original decision. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975, which established the AAT, provides many safeguards for the appeals process. The Committee accepts specialist internal review procedures in place of the AAT only if they are genuinely independent of the original decision makers and of the executive generally, and include similar safeguards.
(d) Does the delegated legislation contain matter more appropriate for parliamentary enactment?

The Sex Discrimination (Operation of Legislation) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1990 No.244, prolonged for a further 12 months Commonwealth, State and Territory legislation which would otherwise be in breach of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984. The total period of such exemptions is now seven years. The Committee has indicated that any further exemptions should be by Act rather than regulations.

During this sittings the Committee made a submission to the Administrative Review Council's major project on Rule Making by Commonwealth Agencies. The ARC, the peak Commonwealth advisory body on administrative law, had expressly invited the Committee to make such a submission. The submission covered most areas of current concern to legislative scrutiny committees. In particular, it emphasised that the drafting and presentation of delegated legislation, including access by the public, should not be less than that of Acts of Parliament. To this end the present proliferation of types of instruments of executive law-making should be subsumed within a single delegated legislation series, preferably the Statutory Rules series, professionally drafted and made by the Governor-General, subject to the highest levels of safeguards expressed in the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 and the Statutory Rules Publication Act 1903.

The submission emphasised that consolidated reprints of delegated legislation should be available at least with the same frequency as those of Acts. The Committee also considered that automatic repeal provisions under which existing delegated legislation is repealed after a fixed number of years might be appropriate.

There might be merit in a single series of delegated legislation being presented and amended by the loose-leaf method which is, in effect, an instant consolidation. Agencies could also be required to produce convenient ADP access to a definitive consolidation each time the principal instrument is amended.

During the sittings the Committee initiated a project on quasi-legislation, which is one of the most important issues facing legislative scrutiny committees. Delegates to the Third Commonwealth Conference on Delegated Legislation, held in Westminster in November last year, including the Australian delegation, expressed concern at the increase in quasi-legislation. Quasi-legislation is difficult to define. At the conference Professor Gabriele Ganz said that quasi-legislation is not a term of art. It may include circulars and press releases or even oral directives from Ministers or others in the executive. Often it will include matter which is administrative in nature as well as legislative. However, any material which determines a general rule of conduct or declares a power, right or duty applying to broad classes, as opposed to applying the law in individual cases, is legislative. Insofar as this material is made by the executive, it is the duty of Parliament to supervise and control such legislation. I hope that the work of the Committee will advance this process. During these sittings Senator Bishop, the Deputy Chairman of the Committee, tabled on behalf of the Committee on 20 September 1990 the manuals used by officials in the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs to administer the Migration Act and Regulations. Senator Bishop pointed out that the 195 manuals were 3,300 pages long and cost 400 dollars. This is the type of quasi-legislation which the Committee will scrutinise.

In the initial stages of the project the Committee is examining the lists of procedural manuals produced by agencies under the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act. The Committee will examine all manuals from selected Departments or statutory authorities for legislative implications, particularly for control by Parliament and other safeguards. It will also examine all manuals relating to selected topics from across the range of Departments or agencies, with the same object.

The Committee has continued its practice of hearings with public officials to explain aspects of delegated legislation which it has raised. In a previous report Honourable Senators will recall that the Committee asked officials from two different Departments to brief the Committee on delays in implementing undertakings given to it to amend legislation to meet its concerns, and on delays in replying to correspondence. During this sittings, at the invitation of the Committee, a Minister nominated senior officials from the Department to attend the Committee to discuss progress on aspects of changes to delegated legislation and parent Acts. The Committee is grateful to the Minister for this cooperation.

On 29 November 1990 date I tabled the Eighty-seventh Report of the Committee, called ``Subdelegation of Powers''. This Report is a survey of the law and practice in this area, written by Emeritus Professor Douglas Whalan, the Legal Adviser of the Committee. Subdelegation of legislative or administrative powers is an important area of concern to the Committee. Many instruments of delegated legislation provide, for example, that the Minister may exempt classes of persons or individuals from paying fees or charges. Often this power may be delegated, sometimes to any person at all. The Committee insists that such delegation be restricted to appropriate levels of persons. Similarly, other subdelegations are, in some cases, to approve the spending of hundreds of millions of dollars of Commonwealth money. Here again, the Committee scrutinised carefully all aspects of such delegations.

One area of concern to the Committee is the existence of significant instruments, clearly legislative in character, which are subject neither to tabling nor disallowance. It is, of course, only by chance that the Committee becomes aware of these instruments. Since the establishment of our sister legislative scrutiny committee, the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, such instruments are picked up in the Bills stage. However, there are some legislative instruments for which provision was made before that Committee was established, which lack any parliamentary safeguards. Senator Kay Patterson drew the attention of the Committee to one such instrument, which appeared to contain defects which in a disallowable instrument would lead to a protective notice of motion of disallowance pending a reply from the Minister. The Committee scrutinised the instrument and wrote to the Minister, asking if the parent Act could be amended to provide for full parliamentary supervision. The Committee also asked if the present instrument could be amended.

The work of the Committee now includes scrutiny of instruments of a type possibly not seen before in Commonwealth delegated legislation. The Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Act (No.2) 1989, among other things amended two parent Acts to provide for the making of six new types of delegated legislation. This delegated legislation cannot be disallowed outright by either House of the Parliament. However, the Act provides for either House to approve amendments of the legislation, with the legislation only coming into effect if such amendments are approved by the other House. The Committee scrutinised a number of these types of instrument, and wrote to the Minister where it detected possible deficiencies. As usual, the Minister replied with a prompt and helpful explanation, including an undertaking to amend an instrument to meet the concerns of the Committee.

The Committee acknowledges the high level of commitment to its principles shown by Ministers. Recently the Committee advised a Minister that certain review provisions were a credit to the portfolio legislation.

It is not usual for the Committee to mention individual Ministers in these reports. However, there were two instances of major reforms by Ministers which the Committee felt should be drawn to the attention of the Senate. The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, Senator the Hon Bob Collins, a former Chairman of the Committee, has advised that the numerous and bulky Civil Aviation Orders will progressively be included in the Statutory Rules series. This series is better drafted and presented than the rest of the more than 100 other series of delegated legislation. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the Hon John Kerin MP and the Minister for Resources, the Hon Alan Griffiths MP, have made instruments in which each amendment is part of a complete reprint. This provides the best possible access to delegated legislation by the Parliament and by those members of the public whom it affects.

The Committee has been greatly assisted in its work by its Legal Adviser, Emeritus Professor Douglas Whalan of the Faculty of Law at the Australian National University. Douglas Whalan comments on every disallowable instrument of delegated legislation, attends Committee meetings when required, writes special reports and generally provides high level legal support.

Despite the good cooperation that the Committee receives from Ministers, the Committee sometimes receives letters drafted by officials who appear to lack a complete commitment to improve the quality of delegated legislation so that it meets the high standards of the Committee. For the information of Honourable Senators one such letter is included below.
The Committee thanks the Senate for continuing the strong support which the Committee has always received during its 58 years of existence.
LETTER
Minister for Small Business and Customs
The Hon. David Beddall, MP
Senator Colston...19 OCT 1990
Chairman
Standing Committee on
Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Colston

I refer to your letter dated 24 August 1990 seeking advice as to a possible duplication of time and resources involved in the processing of Statutory Rules 1990 Nos. 147 and 148 and Statutory Rules 1990 Nos. 217, 218, 220, 221, 222 and 223. I share your Committee's concern that the process of subsidiary law-making should be streamlined as much as possible to avoid unnecessary delay and duplication of scarce resources. I am advised the Legal Services Branch of the Australian Customs Service (ACS), which processes the documentation for regulations presented under my name to the Federal Executive Council, also makes every endeavour to assist in this regard.

As an explanation to what might appear in the instant case to constitute a breach of the above, I make the following general observations, followed by specific comments on the Statutory Rules your Committee has highlighted.

Regulations are drafted by the Attorney-General's Department upon formal instruction by the Legal Services Branch of the ACS, which processes instructions on behalf of the relevant policy area of the ACS or, in some cases, another Minister or Department. The time taken to draft the amendments varies according to the complexity of the request and the drafting priorities of the Attorney-General's Department. In addition, the urgency of each regulation varies as does the draftsperson in the Attorney-General's Department. When the first draft is complete the ACS ensures it is suitable in terms of the policy which it intends to achieve. If the draft is unsuitable then some liaising must occur between the ACS and the Attorney-General's Department to finalise the draft amendment. It is only when the draft is finalised that prints of the amendment can be submitted to the Federal Executive Council. These prints have to be accompanied by the various Executive Council Documents which are prepared by the Legal Services Branch of the ACS.

If a number of amendments need to be made to any of the regulations which I administer and those amendments are to be made under the same enabling provision, then appropriate instructions are sent to the Attorney-General's Department, either at first instance or when the various draft Regulations are scrutinised, for the consolidation of the proposed amendments under a single Executive Council Minute. Where, however, instructions have to be sent separately because the need for amendment arises at different times, oftentimes to attempt to consolidate these amendments at a later stage creates a substantial amount of duplication of time and resources, especially for the Attorney-General's Department. Different draftspersons are frequently involved in processing the various instructions, some of which might have a particular urgency. To consolidate in such circumstances may result in the delay of proposed regulations which would otherwise be ready to proceed to the Federal Executive Council.
With regard to the present request, the following observations on each of the abovementioned Statutory Rules are relevant:
SR 147 and SR 148 of 1990

The request initiating SR 148 was received in the Legal Services Branch on 16 February 1990, and the request initiating SR 147 was received over 2 months later on 27 April 1990. This resulted in drafts being prepared and finalised over a month apart. SR 147 was a matter of urgency (it prescribed new Warehouse Licence fees for 19901991) and so its preparation had priority over SR 148. In addition, the urgency prevented any attempt to consolidate at a later stage because of the delay that this may have caused to SR 147. The result was that they were both ready to proceed to the same Executive Council Meeting (18 June 1990).
SR 217, SR 220 and SR 222 of 1990

The request initiating SR 222 of 1990 was received in the Legal Services Branch on 31 October 1989. This amendment did consolidate a number of amendments to the Customs Regulations. This consolidation created some delay and the proposed regulation was not ready to be presented to the Executive Council until 26 June 1990.

It may have been possible to process SR 217 and SR 220 of 1990 together, as instructions were received only a fortnight apart. Both amendments, however, had corresponding amendments to the Excise Regulations (SR 218 of 1990 and SR 221 of 1990 respectively). The normal ACS practice in such situations is to process these ``twin'' amendments together to enable the amendments to be drafted and cleared at the same time. There is minimal delay in these cases because the reasons for amendment and the amendments themselves are similar, if not identical, for both the Customs Regulations and the Excise Regulations. This means that drafting instructions to the AttorneyGeneral's Department can be consolidated, liaising need only occur with one draftsperson as the one draftsperson is responsible for both amendments, and the amendments can be cleared as one.
SR 218, SR 221 and SR 223 of 1990

As outlined above, SR 218 and SR 221 of 1990 were processed with their corresponding Customs Regulations amendments. SR 223 amended several Excise Regulations. The requests for amendment were received by the Legal Services Branch at dates ranging from 31 August 1989 to 20 March 1990 and this led to its presentation to the Executive Council to be delayed until 21 June 1990.

I would like to reassure the Committee that, wherever practical, amendments to delegated legislation made under the same enabling provision will be consolidated to ensure there is no duplication of time and resources. If, however, such a consolidation would in fact duplicate such resources, or if it would be more efficient to process corresponding amendments made under different enabling provisions together, for the reasons noted above, then such consolidations will not be pursued.
I trust the above is of assistance to the Committee.
Yours sincerely
DAVID BEDDALL

DEBATE.TITLE: GUIDE TO THE ASSESSMENT OF RATES OF VETERANS' PENSIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That-
(a) the instrument dated 5 November 1990 revoking the previous Guide to the Assessment of Rates of Veterans' Pensions; and
(b) the Guide to the Assessment of Rates of Veterans' Pensions,
made under section 29 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, approved by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs on 6 November 1990, and laid before the Senate on 7 November 1990, be disallowed.

The decision to disallow any delegated legislation is not one to be taken lightly. In this instance the Opposition finds itself with no choice but to proceed with a disallowance motion first put before the Senate on 26 November. The role the Government and the Department of Veterans' Affairs have played in forcing this disallowance motion is quite shameful.

The second edition of the Guide to the Assessment of Rates of Veterans' Pensions, commonly referred to as GARP 2, assesses veterans on both their medical impairment and their lifestyle impairment in order to determine the rate of war disability pension they should be paid.

In measuring lifestyle impairment, a lifestyle report is used. It is widely agreed that this report is overly long, repetitious, intrusive and complex. Veterans' organisations have campaigned long and hard for the removal of this report. In tabling GARP 3 the Government has recognised the unsatisfactory nature of the lifestyle report and has, in fact, removed it.

However, the changes have gone much further than this with the complete removal of the individual consideration of lifestyle effects. In GARP 3 an imputation system is being adopted whereby a medical impairment rating, with an inconsequential lifestyle loading, is the sole basis upon which determination of disability pension rate is made. As a result of removing individual consideration of lifestyle impairment, there is no recognition of the fact that the same medical impairment may have quite different lifestyle consequences for individual veterans.

Another consequence of the changes introduced in GARP 3 would be that the only avenue of appeal against a particular assessment would be to challenge the medical impairment rating. In the past, nearly all successful appeals have been based on a challenge to the lifestyle rating assigned to a veteran.

Further, it would appear that GARP 3 is not consistent with the Veterans' Entitlements Act. The removal of the lifestyle rating component from the overall assessment of degree of incapacity appears to be contrary to the concept of incapacity in the Act and could well be challenged in the courts. Subsection 5(9) of the Act and, indeed, the definition of incapacity contained in the glossary of GARP 3, indicates that in assessing incapacity it is not just the medical impairment, but the sum of the effects of the disease or injury on the veteran, including lifestyle, that is to be assessed.

However, at the front of GARP 3, under the heading `Principles of Treatment', incapacity is defined solely in terms of medical impairment. It is stated that a lifestyle loading is added to the medical impairment rating in order to reflect the effect of an impairment on a person's capacity to function in society and enjoy life. The problem with this is that no matter what the medical impairment rating is, the same lifestyle loading is added. Anyone can see that the lifestyle loading is, therefore, irrelevant. No account is taken of the real effects of impairment on lifestyle. Essentially, the medical impairment alone would determine the rate at which a disability pension is payable.

The Government will argue in its defence that the Returned Services League (RSL) and other ex-service organisations have long sought the abolition of the lifestyle report, and that in tabling GARP 3 it is recognising such demands. This argument, however, fails to address the full extent of the changes made. That the Government has removed the lifestyle report is not a point of contention. Indeed, the Opposition has welcomed the removal of the lifestyle report. The point of contention is that no satisfactory arrangements have been put in place.

There seem to be a number of other options available; for instance, a shorter and simpler form. The Department's own determining officers have already indicated that sufficient information on lifestyle could be gained if the number of questions were reduced by 30 per cent.

Another possibility is that the veteran's doctor could provide both lifestyle and medical impairment assessments. This already occurs for those veterans who are assessed for an extreme disablement adjustment (EDA). Under GARP 3, a shortened version of the lifestyle report, completed by the consulting doctor, would be used in assessing EDA pensions. Alternatively, GARP 3 could possibly be acceptable if there were to be an additional provision which would entitle a veteran to have evidence taken into account where it was clear that there was an extreme lifestyle impairment.

In signalling its intention to disallow GARP 3 nearly a month ago, the Opposition was giving the Government as much time as possible to consult further with ex-service organisations in order to reach agreement on a more satisfactory arrangement which could be put in place. We in the Opposition find that it is extremely disappointing that there is still no agreement after this time between the Government and the ex-service community. The Opposition is forced to pursue this motion of disallowance due only to the Government's intransigence on the issue.

It is true that the Department of Veterans' Affairs proposed that GARP 3 be allowed but with a monitoring committee established to evaluate its operation and report back within 12 months. The Opposition could see some virtue in this proposal but the offer was so strongly rejected by the Returned Services League, the Australian Veterans and Defence Services Council, the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia and the Regular and Defence Force Welfare Association that such an arrangement was felt to be totally unsatisfactory by those organisations. They had two reasons for that: firstly, the inequitable provisions in GARP 3 would be allowed to take effect for a period of at least a year; and, secondly, at the end of 12 months the Government would still not be compelled to take any action at all on GARP 3.

It would appear that soon after the Department's proposal was rejected, it was decided to abandon serious efforts to provide a compromise agreement. In a briefing note, which was forwarded to me by the Department subsequent to the rejection of the monitoring committee proposal, it was stated that if disallowance were to occur it would have to inform veterans that GARP 2, and thus the lifestyle report, would be reactivated.

Further, it was asserted that, `All the odium will attach to the Opposition and the RSL'. This briefing note was prepared for the Australian Democrats by the Government. The Australian Democrats, I am glad to say, were not seduced by these blandishments and will be supporting today's motion. Without even waiting for the Senate to consider this disallowance motion, it seems that the Department has already sent a letter to current applicants for a war disability pension carrying a message to that effect. The letter completely fails to outline the valid concerns of ex-service organisations with regard to the removal of individual consideration of lifestyle effects in GARP 3, changes which will result in 23 per cent of applicants being worse off than would have been the case under GARP 2.

In distributing such a letter, the Department is resorting to shameless and quite unnecessary abuse of its role, which ought to be to keep its clients fairly and accurately informed on issues of relevance to them. If the lifestyle report is reinstated as a result of this disallowance motion, then it is the Government and not the Opposition which must be taken to task for allowing this situation to occur. The Opposition will not allow veterans to be deceived and misled by the Government on this issue.

I again repeat that the Government has given the Opposition no choice but to press for a disallowance of GARP 3. Ex-service organisations have indicated clearly that GARP 3, for the reasons I have outlined, is quite unsatisfactory. They are prepared to suffer under GARP 2 for a little longer in order that a satisfactory alternative can be found. If the Government cares about compensating those who fought for our country, then it must recognise that GARP 3 is seriously flawed and cannot be allowed to come into operation. It is up to the Government in consultation with the ex-service community to sit down and determine as quickly as possible an acceptable alternative to GARP 2 and the lifestyle report.

It is disgraceful that the Government has been so determined to have its own way in this matter that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Humphreys, is prepared to have his Department conduct a scare campaign to vilify the veterans' organisations and the Opposition-a campaign which will frighten elderly veterans. Unlike the Government, the Opposition does not have a hidden agenda. We are determined to fight for the best interests of the veterans and thus must take the action that we take today. The veterans' interests must come before administrative convenience or cost cutting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the Australian Democrats to support this disallowance motion. Senator Newman has very adequately traversed the ground which justifies the disallowance. I think honourable senators are aware of the fact that the veterans' community in this country is very suspicious of what is happening to its entitlements and that has created a very negative climate. That negative psyche and climate places specific focus on this instrument, GARP 2 and the proposed GARP 3.

SPEECH.PARA: I am grateful for the briefing notes that the Department of Veterans' Affairs has given to me on this issue over the last two weeks. They are comprehensive. I am not going to canvass all the points raised in them. I would simply like to cite the fact that the dissatisfaction has a very long history. Veterans in this country have resented the lifestyle questionnaire from the beginning. It is something on which they find it very difficult to compromise. It is an area of deep resentment and conjecture and the simple realities are that the processes of consultation between veterans' organisations, the Commission and the Department have not adequately resolved the odium and problems surrounding this instrument.

Veterans' disability is assessed in two ways. On the one hand, there is a medical judgment about where they are at in medical terms, and then there is the second dimension to the judgment and that is how they live their lives-in other words, their lifestyle. These two are merged together and it is the second aspect which is seen as being particularly unacceptable by veterans. On the one hand, they have gone before a medical assessment process which arrives at some assessment of disability; on the other hand, they are asked questions about how they live: do they garden, do they shop, do they drive cars, do they carry shopping bags? Frankly, they find it very difficult to bring the two together.

Veterans cite the fact that this intrusive questioning about how one lives one's life in terms of determining whether one is entitled to a benefit has been an extraordinary dimension of the process. This deep dissatisfaction expresses itself in their attitude towards the instruments that have been devised over a period of time. Naturally, the veterans' organisations have carried the flag and they have been doing that for a long time. The processes of consultation seem to be coming along, but they have been frustrated very much in the last week or so by what Senator Newman cites as being a very unfortunate letter which emanated from the Commission and which has muddied the water yet again.

The Democrats believe that the question has to be resolved as quickly as possible. The solution does not lie in the regulations in their present form. We believe that we need to disallow in order to allow a more constructive and positive resumption of the processes of consultation. That belief is based on a clear perception of the fact that the resentment within the veterans community is so profound. In the briefing note that was given to me-I am grateful for it-by the Department, the first point made is that veterans detest the lifestyle report and have protested vigorously about it. That is a strong acknowledgment of what is out there.

The second briefing point, and I do not have time to go into the details, was that the Returned Services League and other ex-service organisations have repeatedly called for the abolition of the lifestyle report and not for its modification. That is a statement of the entrenched position on the part of veterans' peak organisations.

The third heading in the briefing note says that the Repatriation Commission was initially opposed to the abolition of the lifestyle report. In other words, it took the opposite position. That is the entrenched problem which exists. It is the feeling of the Democrats, in support of the Opposition and specifically Senator Newman's motion, that what is presently proposed is still unacceptable. It needs more deliberation; it needs a spirit of cooperation which is not there now but which needs to be achieved as quickly as possible. Not only is there resentment but there is also confusion among veterans. They happen to be a group of people who, because of their circumstances and ages, are confused by complex things. As was mentioned in debate the other day, a person who is very expert in these matters says that Australian legislation affecting veterans is among the most complex in the world. That all gives rise to an attitude of suspicion in the veterans' community. When that attitude is reinforced by intrusive questionnaires about how one leads one's life in an attempt to determine or influence outcomes of entitlement, we are dealing with a vexed situation indeed.

The Democrats think it is appropriate to disallow at the moment, hopefully to achieve a period of intensive and more constructive consultation in order to arrive at something which is not only satisfactory to veterans but which also fulfils the acknowledged administrative needs of the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with a motion to disallow the third edition of the Guide to the Assessment of Rates of Veterans' Pensions (GARP), the main feature of which is the abolition of the lifestyle report. Senator Newman has indicated that the move is at the request of the Returned Services League (RSL). I understand that the Australian Veterans and Defence Services Council has supported that move.

SPEECH.PARA: The guide was introduced with the enactment of the Veterans' Entitlements Act in May 1986, the purpose of the document being to introduce equity and consistency into the assessment of veterans' disability pensions which was not present under the repealed Repatriation Act. The adverse effect of war-caused disablement on veterans' lifestyle is a component taken into account in assessing rates of pension under the guide. The lifestyle report is a questionnaire used to gather information about lifestyle effects for the purposes of pension assessment.

As I understand it, the RSL wanted to do away with the lifestyle report used to arrive at pension assessments. For some time the veteran community and the Opposition have berated the Repatriation Commission and the Government for using such a long, complex and intrusive form. The Commission was initially opposed to the abolition of the report and it was only after persistent pressure from the ex-service community and after being convinced that a fair system could be devised that it agreed to abolish the questionnaire.

In June this year the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) announced this decision to spontaneous applause from his RSL audience and, I understand, praise from the Opposition, including Senator Newman. This was the major change in the new guide. The report was done away with and replaced with a method which imputed a lifestyle rating to veterans seeking an increase in pension without any intrusion into their private lives and without any fuss. The system takes into account lifestyle effects as a result of medical impairment from war-caused disabilities. An automatically allocated lifestyle loading is added to the impairment level in order to assess the pension rate. The level of the loading increases as the level of impairment increases. Furthermore, the new process would have resulted in a greater number of veterans receiving an acceptable rate of pension in the first instance without having to go through lengthy and worrying appeal processes.

Now, it seems, the RSL is saying there was not adequate consultation and that what it really wanted was to replace the questionnaire nobody wanted with another questionnaire. The Senate might like to know that this would be the third attempt at such a questionnaire. The last attempt was the result of considerable effort by the Department of Veterans' Affairs, involving the RSL, other veterans' organisations and a professor from Griffith University who is an expert in form design. It worked well at getting the answers but everybody hated it. The RSL now wants to try again. Meanwhile, by disallowing the new guide, the RSL and the Opposition will once again try veterans' patience by imposing the present questionnaire on them.

The third edition of the guide we are discussing today stems from a review of the previous guide, which was carried out on the recommendations of the Veterans' Entitlements Act monitoring committee. It is not something which has been arrived at in a hurry. There has been consultation with the ex-service community in designing this third edition. Consul- tation began in 1989 when 20 ex-service organisations were invited to make written submissions. Nine organisations, including the RSL, responded and their comments were taken into account. The Services member of the Repatriation Commission attended a number of ex-service organisations meetings and conferences where he canvassed problems arising from the lifestyle report and reactions to the possible abolition of the report.

Once the review team had designed a proposed set of changes, including the abolition of the report, the RSL and other major ex-service organisations were provided with copies of the team's recommendations for comment. On 5 July this year the National Secretary of the RSL was given a briefing about the decision on the new method of imputing lifestyle in the assessment of pension. The President and the Secretary of the Australian Veterans and Defence Services Council were given a briefing by the leader of the team. A group of senior RSL Veterans' Review Board advocates was also briefed. The last meeting gave rise to a letter from the National Secretary of the RSL, which read in part:

Although I was not present when you attended our meeting last Friday which reviewed the Report on GARP II, I understand that your comments made the meeting all the more successful with a greater understanding resulting for all present.

It seems to me that the veteran community had a more than adequate opportunity to make its views known. In any case, of the hundreds of official and personal representations to the Minister and to the Repatriation Commission received before and after the abolition of the report was announced, there were no more than a handful which argued for its retention or for anything other than abolition.

Another concern raised is that many veterans would be disadvantaged by the report. Let me give the Senate the facts. Firstly, the new process would remove any intrusion into personal privacy. Secondly, it is estimated that by using the new system the great majority of veterans would automatically receive at least the same rate of pension as they would by using the present scheme. Statistical analysis of pension assessments by the Department of Veterans' Affairs indicates that 77 per cent would receive a higher or the same level of pension under the revised guide as they received by the completion of a lifestyle report under the present scheme. Those veterans who would receive a marginally lower pension would, in the main, be at the lower end of the impairment rating scale. There was no Government directive to cut costs or lessen compensation to veterans by introduction of the revised scheme.

Thirdly, removal of the report would enable the Department to process applications for increase more quickly. The only exception to the arrangements concerns the very small number of applications for the extreme disablement adjustment allowance, which is currently about 350 per year. The law requires an assessment of lifestyle before the allowance can be granted. Applicants will continue to be individually assessed by medical staff and reports on lifestyle submitted to determining officers. Savings provisions would protect those who currently have a higher pension rate than assessed under the new edition of the guide, unless their condition has improved significantly or the assessment was based on false or misleading information. This means that no veteran could have his or her existing pension reduced by application of the revised guide.

I emphasise again that abolishing the lifestyle report is in response to the veteran community's demand for years that this be done. The Government has received hundreds of representations asking for its removal and much praise for finally removing it. The media, the Opposition in this House and in the House of Representatives and the ex-service organisations have consistently argued that the lifestyle report is an invasion of privacy, a cumbersome imposition on ageing veterans and even a trick to reduce pensions. This is not true, yet the Government believed it should react positively to this process. That is why the report is being removed. It will be replaced with a more efficient system which is fair and equitable.

Alternatives were considered by the Repatriation Commission, including the possibility of making the report entirely optional. It did not take long to reject this option because it discriminates in favour of the better educated and the more articulate against the less educated and more reticent, of whom there are many in the veteran community. Simplifying the questionnaire was tried with the present form but has obviously failed to satisfy veterans. Designing a new form which would be short enough to please the veteran community would produce a document which has no place in a fair system for determining veterans' disability pensions. The only other option would be to have those same questions asked at an interview. This would obviously require an increase in public servants employed to process claims and therefore increase costs. More importantly, it would still be seen as an invasion of privacy.

There is one other point I must make: the Repatriation Commission, in the spirit of compromise, offered to set up a monitoring committee for the guide. The committee would have comprised the Services member of the Commission, a departmental representative and two nominees of the ex-service community. The committee would have monitored the implementation of the revised guide for the first 12 months. The Commission undertook to correct any demonstrable anomalies or faults in the new guide. The proposal was totally rejected on the day it was made by the RSL and the Veterans and Defence Services Council.

Veterans who have claims currently before the Department will now have to be issued with lifestyle reports to complete. Lifestyle reports were not issued in recent months in anticipation of the third edition of the guide becoming effective. These veterans are now being advised by letter of the uncertainty of the third edition becoming effective and, as a consequence, are being advised to complete lifestyle reports.

The RSL and the Opposition have issued media releases attempting to distance themselves from the results of their action by complaining that the Repatriation Commission is biased and is not giving veterans the full story in these letters to them. But the letters are intended to do nothing more than explain why veterans will have to complete lifestyle reports. This they do adequately.

Finally, I can only repeat that the purpose in abolishing the lifestyle report was to provide veterans with a fair and equitable compensation system without the need for intrusion into their personal lives. This represents a compassionate approach, responsive to the wishes of the veteran community, rather than any attempt to disadvantage them. For these reasons, the late objections to the revised guide appear misguided and out of touch with the wider veteran community. I ask senators to reject the motion of disallowance, as this would lead to a return to the questionnaire which veterans find so objectionable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: -in reply-The Government says that there has been more than adequate opportunity for the veterans to make their views known about the second Guide to the Assessment of Rates of Veterans' Pensions (GARP 2). There certainly was but the problem was that the veterans did not know what the Government was proposing to put in its place, and that is where adequate consultation did not take place. Obviously the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) was reading a brief and did not understand that. It is also clear, from the Parliamentary Secretary's response and from the briefings we have had, that efficiency has been the paramount consideration in this issue. The Government has not been concerned so much with justice. In fact, the information from the Department of Veterans' Affairs shows that 23 per cent of veterans will be losers under the new proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government seems to be saying to us, `If you don't have my solution, well then you can't have any solution', although the Government and everybody else have recognised that the previous solution was unsatisfactory. The Parliamentary Secretary said that this is the third attempt. Does that mean that it is the last attempt or is he not willing to try any harder for our veterans? We think he should try again.

The Parliamentary Secretary also says that it is the Returned Services League and the Opposition-he is repeating the furphy that has been put out to the veterans-that are forcing a lifestyle report back on veterans. In fact, it is the Government that is doing so by its intransigence. He also mentioned the fact that the lifestyle reports have not been used in the last few months. I ask how the Parliamentary Secretary can get by without the lifestyle reports in the last few months, yet he is not prepared to get by without them in the next few months while further negotiations take place. Quite clearly in the interests of justice and if he really cared about the veterans he would operate on that basis. If the Government insists on the lifestyle report, it is on the Government's head. I thank the Australian Democrats for their support because they obviously are more in touch with the problems being faced by the veterans than the Government is.

I support exactly what Senator McLean said, that is, that this is an issue which must be resolved as quickly as possible; that there must be constructive consultation; that this disallowance motion is simply designed to allow that to happen; and that the resentment in the veterans' community is profound. Senator McLean is absolutely accurate on those matters.

Summing up and putting it in a nutshell, these regulations would give no recognition to the differences of lifestyle impairment between a clerk who loses his thumb and a pianist who loses his thumb. Blind Freddy and surely any senator with any compassion or understanding and certainly with any intelligence would recognise that there is a good deal of difference in lifestyle impairment when a clerk loses a thumb and when a pianist loses a thumb.

I am astonished that the Government has refused to acknowledge that basic fact and also that the Government is having to be forced into reconsidering this whole matter. We are not taking this action lightly. We believe it is a serious matter when the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) have so little concern for the veterans' community that efficiency in administration has taken precedence over justice and compassion for our veterans' community. Therefore, we are forced by the Government to take this action to require proper, meaningful consultation and to find a proper solution.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
