DEBATE.TITLE: NORTHERN PRAWN FISHERY VOLUNTARY ADJUSTMENT SCHEME LOAN GUARANTEE AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 November, on motion by Senator Cook:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —A debate on the northern prawn fisheries voluntary adjustment scheme may not attract a lot of Australians to turn on their television or radio to listen, but it is important to the people who are involved in it. Australia is only small in the fishing business by world standards but, to the people who are involved, and in the areas in which it is involved, it is very important.

SPEECH.PARA: In this particular case the Opposition supports the legislation and the revised amendment to the northern prawn fishery management plan. Before I get under way I pay tribute to all sections of the industry for the constructive way that they approached the problems evident in the original plan and also thank the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) for his flexible attitude to the amendments and to the revised management plan. There were days and days and hours and hours of discussions, visits and calls to try to improve the original proposal that was put forward. This whole exercise demonstrates what can be achieved with a little bit of goodwill and a lot of commonsense. I am most grateful to the people who were involved in the way that the matter was discussed. I am not saying that everybody is satisfied because, of course, in a deal of this magnitude they cannot be.

I have been involved with the fishing industry ever since I came into the Senate 15 years ago. I am well aware of the problems and the difficulties. I also understand only too well the difficulties associated with fishery management, particularly in the overexploited areas. In the northern prawn fishery there is the classic situation of excess capacity with the resulting danger of overexploitation and economic ruin. The industry has had this problem for a number of years, and this is the first time that there is some real hope that the problem can be remedied.

All concerned-the Government, the Opposition and all sections of the industry-agree that there is a need for industry restructuring and also that, although there may be some reservations, the optimum size of the industry is somewhere near this 50,000 A-class units, based almost wholly on the economic evidence. The main argument, it seems, is how we are going to reduce the current fishing effort of 96,170 units to 50,000 or, to all intents and purposes, how we will half the present effort.

We all know that the enhanced buy-back scheme did not achieve the results that the industry had hoped for. A more drastic plan was needed to be worked up; hence the proposal tabled in this place on 9 November. It would have been an impossibility to devise a management plan to please everybody. When we take out half of the fleet, we must hurt somebody. Therefore, it is quite remarkable that a compromise solution was arrived at in a relatively short time to appease most of the people.

The amended plan overcomes to a considerable extent the main industry concerns, if not the individual concerns, which we cannot really expect ever to do. We are all concerned with the profitability of this most important fishery and the Opposition would want to see a healthy, profitable industry remaining. The best advice available to me indicates that the profitability in the fishery has declined to a very great extent. The prices for both banana and tiger prawns on overseas markets fell by about 40 per cent in 1989, and the low prices have extended well into 1990. This decline in price was a direct result of competition from other places and particularly from the farm-grown prawns.

I have read an article recently in a journal called INFOFISH International of May 1990 which makes reference to some of these things. We have only to look at the size of the industry to understand the concerns. Australia's industry amounts to an average of approximately 10,000 tonnes catch per year; whereas the world catch is 2.7 million tonnes. So what Australia does really does not make much difference, but what happens in the rest of the world makes a lot of difference to Australia's share of the market in other places. This journal goes on to say:

For example, in Taiwan alone, there are now about 2,000 shrimp hatcheries and 40 feed mill plants . . . Thailand with about 50,000 ha of shrimp farms now has 15 feed manufacturing plants and more than 1,500 family-owned and operated hatcheries . . . two of the largest hatcheries in Thailand have a combined monthly output of over 40 million postlarvae . . . In Thailand alone, more than 10,000 ha of new ponds were constructed in the last few years . . . Indonesia and the Philippines likewise added another 4,000 ha and 8,000 ha of new ponds respectively . . .
And so it goes on.

The real pressure on the world market for Australian prawns is going to come from the Eastern countries. For instance, in China in 1988 the output reached nearly 200,000 tonnes, and China is ranked as the top producer with more than 22 per cent of the world output. These are the sorts of figures that we need to take into account when we bear in mind that Australia produces 10,000 tonnes a year. Prices are coming down on an international basis and the costs are still going up, particularly for the wild prawns and the fuel costs that go with it. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics considers that prawn prices will continue to fall. It also considers that in the long run the optimal fleet size will be about 100 boats, about 80 of which could be less than 370 units. In the absence of better advice to the contrary and with the concurrence of every industry group, the Opposition is accepting this target as being where we have to head.

We also realise that, should this target not be achieved by 1 April 1993, a compulsory proportionate reduction must take effect. We all hope that the target can be reached without compulsion. Nobody on this side of the chamber wants to see compulsory acquisitions and compulsory wind-downs, but it happens with grocery stores, with dairy farms and all over the place. The economic circumstances are changing from day to day.

We just hope that the fishermen will be able to see that, although fishing may have been their way of life, circumstances may now well have passed them by and they may have to readjust, as it is euphemistically called. We know that we cannot satisfy everybody and that this is going create problems with the sale of large numbers of well-equipped boats in good condition. But we have to accept the position and the fishermen have to accept it also.

The scheme that we are now proposing must be made to work. In the past 10 years we have had many plans that have not produced the results that we hoped for. This is not the end of the industry. I hope that it is the beginning of a new, modernised, improved and more profitable industry. We just hope that everybody will be able to settle in and that the industry will be stronger and better than ever. We do not want to see it go to the compulsory closure and acquisition stage. We support the proposition before us because we believe that it is the best alternative for us at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats also will not be opposing the passage of the Northern Prawn Fishery Voluntary Adjustment Scheme Loan Guarantee Amendment Bill. However, I would just like to make a few comments about the management plan, together with its amendments, which is what this loan guarantee is all about. This debate finally comes down not so much to a debate about fishing but more to a debate about bureaucracy and the administration of the downsizing of the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: It has already been said that, in any rearrangement of any industry where something is wound down, somebody has to lose. I do not accept that. I think it is possible for the losses to be shared equitably amongst those who are presently participating in the industry. That is what the bureaucratic side is about: there is the capacity to ensure that any losses that occur are shared fairly and equitably across the industry.

It may also be said-and it has been said in another place already-that consultation has taken place. Superficially that is true. There has been a great amount of information-gathering taking place. There has been a great amount of representation to those who are formulating the management plan, but I suggest that what we see before us in the management plan and its amendments so far is evidence that the Government and those who have been negotiating have been incapable of synthesising into one concise plan the information that has been presented to bring about a resolution which is fair and equitable for all concerned. The ramifications of the implementation of the present management plan are that some will lose more and some will lose less. Those who will lose more are those that I am concerned about.

Before I detail my concerns, I would like to place it on record that we are in complete agreement with the sorts of things that were said in the other place in the passage of this loan guarantee amendment in November. For example, I will quote statements made by the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis), who said:
The policy statement-
which was originally issued by Minister Kerin-

placed particular emphasis on the need to ensure that fisheries resources are not over exploited and that any exploitation is at a level which can be sustained while maintaining the surrounding environment.
I will not take any issue whatsoever with that statement, and it gains the Democrats' complete support. Another statement which was made, which I was very pleased to see, reads:
These objectives are entirely consistent with the Government's policy of ecologically sustainable development.

That phrase is becoming much more common in claims that are made by the Government. Another thing which the honourable member for Gellibrand mentioned in his speech on this matter was that the community return legislation which would be subsequent to this was designed to return to the community some sort of recompense for the fact that its resource was being used. Further on there was this suggestion:
An industry-government committee has been established to ensure a continuing high degree of consultation.

These are fine sounding words, but I suggest that the trawlers who are involved in this industry are typically independent individuals and perhaps not easy to unite in support of what they see as outside interference in their industry. That has been the difficulty for the Government in formulating the management plan.

I have received about 200 letters on this matter. Although I am pleased to say that the latest proposal actually meets most of the concerns, as far as I can tell there are still some unresolved matters. In respect of the resolution of some of the concerns of those involved in the industry, I am pleased to see that the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) said in a speech in the lower House that the coalition parties are still considering the fairness of the plan. I am aware that Senator Boswell is also of the view that the problems that some people in the industry foresaw should be taken into account. The Democrats share those concerns.

I am very glad that Senator Macdonald is in the chamber at the moment. The Democrats are often accused of agreeing with the Government without giving consideration to legislation. For some reason the honourable senator fails to recognise the importance of the negotiation process which can take place and the occasions on which the coalition and the Democrats agree to carefully examine legislation. That negotiation will continue while ever we agree that there is a problem with legislation. Negotiation did continue in this case. The Democrats took seriously the threat of the disallowance of regulations.

I am disappointed to say that I do not believe all of the problems have been resolved. I am disappointed that an agreement was reached at such an early stage. As far as I can see, there is a problem with clause 3, which sets out the general outline. Under that amendment, the units which would be taken into account for cancellation will now become active class A units instead of all being class A units. I think the effect of that simple change may have been unforeseen by those who proposed it. The effect is that 19 out of 58 trawlers will be seen to be doing very well out of this rearrangement and 39 others will be seen to be doing not as well.

Let me be explicit. Operators who at the time of implementation had some suspense units-for example, 100 suspense units-which were originally intended to provide for the upgrading of trawlers and who had not used those suspense units over the six years to upgrade their trawlers, will now be in a very advantageous position compared with those operators who have efficient trawlers and who had taken advantage of their suspense units to upgrade. Most of the operators in the latter category have no debt. But they will have to go into debt in order to continue in the industry. I believe that that is inequitable. This inequity can be resolved by not implementing the amendment to apply active class A units. I hope that the Government will see that this would be a sensible course of action. I hope that this matter can be resolved.

We do not have the capacity in this legislation to change this arrangement because agreement has already been reached. In the reduction to 20,000 units, smaller boats will get 890 units and the remaining 70 boats will get only 300-odd. As far as I can see, the only other possible solution-and this has been raised in negotiations-would be the overall implementation of quotas. That is not really a satisfactory way of resolving this matter. The imposition of quotas has been raised and dismissed as a way of getting over this problem. This would not be the best way of proceeding. I do not think we should support quotas. However, the imposition of quotas would be fairer to those who have to carry the burden of this cost than what is proposed now.
I support the passage of the loan guarantee legislation. However, I do not think that the management plan, which is consequential upon the legislation, is as fair as it might be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to commence my remarks by responding to Senator Bell's acknowledgment of my presence. I want to refer to his comment that I should note that the Australian Democrats are taken seriously on occasions. They must be very rare occasions.
—This is one of them.

—I do not know about that. The Northern Prawn Fishery Voluntary Adjustment Scheme Loan Guarantee Amendment Bill 1990 is very complex legislation and is very difficult to understand. The honourable senator made some points which I would like to explore. Although the legislation is complex, after listening to the honourable senator it sounds much more complex. I wonder whether some of the comments that the honourable senator made are accurate or are relevant to the plan and the Bill which is before us. If the honourable senator wanted to be taken seriously, he probably would not have supported the Government's guillotine motion. This would have allowed us to discuss the Bill fully and properly. People do not take the Democrats seriously because they side with the lot on the other side of the chamber whenever serious matters come up.

SPEECH.PARA: I continually like to remind my southern colleagues-and I stress `southern' colleagues-that northern Australia, with around 5.6 per cent of the population, produces almost half of this country's export income. One industry which illustrates the export ethos of northern Australia best is the northern prawn fishery, which covers an area extending from the tip of Cape York across to Broome in Western Australia. Over 90 per cent of the annual catch is exported, almost exclusively to Japan. Between the present 215 boats which comprise the fishery, total production for 1990-91 is estimated at being worth about $170m. The industry is particularly important to north Queensland, which I principally represent in this place.

About 85 boats which are licensed to work in the northern prawn fishery are based in Cairns and Innisfail, on the east coast of far-north Queensland. In addition, a number of other boats are located at Karumba, in the north Queensland Gulf country. Behind sugar, fishing is the biggest primary producer in the Cairns region, earning around $200m a year.

Over the last 10 years there have been a number of developments which have put the future of the fishing industry in jeopardy. The main problem has been the size of the fleet, which has resulted in overfishing. There is evidence that the resource itself is being depleted. Every resource industry, such as the northern prawn fishery, has a finite capacity for exploitation. There are only a limited number of prawns which can be caught in each season. Eventually a point is reached where more fishermen does not mean a larger catch but instead means a slimmer profit margin for the operators.

All parties seem to agree that the present size of the fishery needs to be reduced from the present 215 boats or 96,000 units. As Senator Archer mentioned, perhaps the greatest competition has come from the aquaculture industry. This threat to the industry is set to increase. I am told that grown or farmed prawns have a noticeable difference in taste compared with the trawled product.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have no taste.

—That is probably right. Having lived in the north and experienced, as Senator Boswell has, this fresh product straight off the trawlers, I can certainly vouch for its quality. I am impressed that the free range producers-as one might call them-are looking towards marketing the fresh product as `wild seafresh prawns' as opposed to the farmed product.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill before us provides for an increase to the limit of commercial borrowings to fund the adjustment scheme for which the Commonwealth will provide with a government guarantee. The existing Act provides a government guarantee for loans of up to $5m. This amendment Bill will increase the limit to $40.9m. While it is not actually a part of this Bill, the Government has also approved a government grant of $5m over the next three years from the national fisheries adjustment program to help fund the adjustment scheme by providing an initial pool for payment of principal and interest on the borrowings.

As Senator Archer has mentioned, we support the Bill itself. We did have a number of grave concerns about the Government's amendment to the plan-which of course is not a part of this Bill but which was gazetted at the same time. As Senator Bell has acknowledged and as Senator Archer has mentioned, it is indeed pleasant that all parties were able to get together to look through the plan and, through very wide consultation with the industry, come up with a set of regulations which generally suit everyone.

At this stage I should make reference to Senator Archer and his office. They did an enormous amount of work in liaising with the industry and the Government and pointed out some rather glaring errors in the plan as it was proposed originally. Through this wide consultation process a plan has now been developed which has fairly widespread and general support.

I did intend to go through the provisions of the Bill at some length but, as our time has been restricted-a fact which has been made very clear in the case of a number of pieces of legislation-I will not be able to give the individual clauses and the details of the plan the attention that I would have liked to give them. But I can say that whilst we in the Liberal and National parties support the Bill and the northern prawn fishery plan in its amended form, I am concerned at the prospect of a resource rent tax being imposed on operators in the northern prawn fishery. It is implicit in the second reading speech of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) that, whilst there are no provisions in this Bill for a resource rent tax, it is in fact the Government's intention to bring in such a tax at some time in the future. The Minister mentioned in his speech that he was thinking about effecting this resource rent tax, possibly as soon as autumn 1991. In the closing lines of his second reading speech Mr Kerin said:
The Government has made no secret of the fact that it expects industry to share some of the new profits which result from this restructuring with the wider community.

The Government's view is that where genuine new profits are made arising from the exploitation of a community resource for private gain, the industry will share a portion of those profits with the wider community.

I was not aware that prawn fishermen were any different from other people who are trying to eke out a living during these difficult times. Prawn fishermen pay their income tax, capital gains tax, provisional tax, fuel tax-and what a lot of that they pay-and so on. Why should they have to pay another tax which is custom-made for them? Anyone can see that if they make some more money out of the industry-and I hope that will happen as a result of the restructuring-they will pay more income tax on that money. Why another tax should be foisted upon these people who are trying to make a living is beyond me and I condemn the Government for even thinking of it. On the one hand, the Government is trying to do something for the industry and the people who are working in it by making it more profitable through a voluntary buyback scheme and, on the other hand, it is going to take back any profits that might be made by way of a resource rent tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —The $40m is the bait.

—Senator Boswell is right. There is a bait there and regrettably it is leading to this resource rent tax. No doubt the Democrats will join us in opposing that when the time comes because it seems to me to be quite ridiculous. This is a renewable resource. The life of a prawn is about 18 months and the resource will renew itself if it is not overfished.

SPEECH.PARA: My restricted time is almost up, but I again ask Minister Kerin to look very seriously at this matter before he implements any resource tax. In fact, he told the industry some time ago that he did not think he would live long enough to see the day that the northern prawn fishery would be profitable enough to afford a resource rent tax. Not long after he had said that, he turned around and flagged that that tax will be coming.

I support the measures that this legislation will implement. I think the fisheries plan, owing to the good work that has been done by all parties, is as close as we will get to the right thing. We believe it is going in the right direction and we certainly support it. But I hope that the good work that has been done by this legislation and the plan is not spoiled when next autumn the Government's attention is again drawn to the northern prawn fishery when it is looking at implementing this resource rent tax. I urge support for this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Northern Prawn Fishery Voluntary Adjustment Scheme Loan Guarantee Amendment Bill 1990. The purpose of this Bill is to provide a government grant of $5m for a loan guarantee for commercial borrowings up to $40.9m over a number of years in an effort to reduce the number of units in what is generally accepted to be an overfished area. At the moment there are 96,000 units and there has been an agreement to bring that number down to 50,000. Some people say that 50,000 is too low and that 70,000 units would be a more realistic approach. Nevertheless, under the Northern Prawn Fishery Management Committee resolution 23 there was an agreement to reduce the number of units to 50,000.

SPEECH.PARA: At that time the Government brought in a plan that was going to be fair to some and unfair to many. The smaller one-and two-boat owners in particular-were going to be almost driven out of the fishery because of the Government's plan. I must pay tribute to Senator Archer today because he has borne the brunt of the difficulty in bringing all of the parties together to come up with a conclusion that is accepted by most of the industry. As a matter of fact, I have before me a number of telexes sent from all sections of the industry asking me to support the conclusion that Senator Archer has reached with the Government.

In 1987 the Government approached us with a similar buyback scheme which was unfair and which would have resulted in a number of people losing their livelihoods. We rejected that scheme in the Senate when we moved to oppose the regulation. As a result of that the fishermen decided that they would bring in their own voluntary adjustment scheme. They reduced the unit capacity from 133,274 to 96,400 and reduced the number of boats from 302 to 217.

There have been problems with that voluntary adjustment scheme. The scheme ran out of money when it needed it most-at the beginning of this year when the prawn catch was down. A number of boats would have been on sale. Unfortunately, at that time the voluntary adjustment scheme lacked money and therefore could not take the effort out when it was most needed. There are now 217 boats in the fishery.

Originally, everyone agreed with the proposal now before the Senate. After some investigation some came up with problems that would affect them. I say to those people: the Senate-I include the Australian Democrats, the Government and this side-has done its level best to accommodate all sections of the industry. I have had representations from the smaller fishermen, who told me that they would go bankrupt if we were to accept the Government's original plan, and from the very big fleet holders, who said that they would be in trouble if we were not to accept the Government's plan. My advice to them was, `There is not one section of the industry or the Parliament that doesn't agree that the effort has to be reduced in the fishery. Can't you go out there, talk to each other and come up with something that will be acceptable to the whole industry?'. That is exactly what happened. They went out and talked amongst themselves. After two or three days we received a proposal that had been put together by Senator Archer. It had the general acceptance of the industry. I think that about 17 or 18 boats are unhappy. I say to them: I am sorry that we cannot accommodate you but we have done our best to look after all sections of the industry.

In the new scheme there will be a buy-back price of $950 per unit up until April 1993. That should remove a great number of people from the industry. Fishermen will be able to sell their units for $500 for an A-class unit, and a further $450 as compensation to get that effort out of the fishery by April 1993. If, after the beginning of the season in April 1993, the effort has not been reduced to 50,000 units, all boat owners left in the fishery will have to surrender a proportion of their units so as to allow the fishery to come down to 50,000 units. The industry has two years to adjust. Hopefully, with this $950 incentive that applies before April 1991, a lot of effort will be removed from the industry.
I will now refer to the rent resource tax. In the second reading speech of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) he states:
. . . to ensure that fisheries resources are not over exploited and that any exploitation is at a level which can be sustained while maintaining the surrounding environment . . .

He said that, to maximise economic efficiencies in the exploitation of resources, the Government would collect an appropriate charge from the individual fishermen exploiting the community resource for private gain.

Only last week-or it may have been this week-we received a discussion paper on resource rent in fisheries. That discussion paper stated that it had been written for fishermen. But if fishermen cannot understand it they should not think that they are mentally retarded. Everyone down here is finding it very difficult to understand this Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Economics discussion paper on resource rent fisheries. I have given it to some of the best researchers in the Parliament and they are having difficulty. When people write such papers they should write them so that 99 per cent of the population can understand them. I make that plea on behalf of the normal people out there.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not meant to be understood.

—If that is the case, it has certainly achieved a 100 per cent result. Today we examined the Budget Papers and found that last year there were 288,000 fishing licences. It is estimated that the amount will increase to 733,000 in the coming year. That is a huge jump of 154 per cent in an item that usually goes up only marginally. Yet time and time again Mr Kerin has told us that in his lifetime-Senator Macdonald referred to this-there will not be a rent resource tax. There was then a recommendation in the Budget for a rent resource tax. I approached the Government and it denied that there would be a rent resource tax for two years. Yet here we find that there is an estimated increase of 733,000 in the coming year.

SPEECH.PARA: A rent resource tax seems to be socialism in its worst form. Fishermen pay their taxes and their sales taxes. They make tremendous inputs just so they can get out and fish. They will now be partners with the Government, which will take what it calls super profits. I do not know too many fishermen who have made super profits. In the last couple of years they have been battling just to hold on.

I am being told to finish my speech and I do so by asking this: where does a rent resource tax stop? Do we put it on beekeepers? Do we put it on kangaroo shooters? Where does it end? I should not have mentioned those as I have probably encouraged the Government to do some sums and place this charge on the other industries which are not paying it at the moment. My time is up. We have done the best we possibly could for the industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those honourable senators who have spoken, both for the Opposition and the Australian Democrats, in support of this particularly important Bill, the Northern Prawn Fishery Voluntary Adjustment Scheme Loan Guarantee Amendment Bill 1990, which relates to the government loan guarantee which will provide the funding to enable restructuring of the northern prawn fishery to be undertaken.

SPEECH.PARA: The restructuring arrangements are of course absolutely vital and have in fact been preceded by considerable discussion with northern prawn fishery industry organisations and members of the Opposition. Of course the individual fishermen concerned have also, in many instances, been consulted.

I believe that the single boat operators and those with smaller boats are treated equitably under the restructuring. That has been an important goal of the Government. That would explain why the constructive approach has borne the fruit that it has. It is also important to say that Senator Archer and his staff have been particularly helpful and constructive in bringing to these discussions their particular expertise and point of view.

It was as a result of all these discussions that further amendments to the management plan were introduced in both Houses on 4 December. That allowed industry groups to give their support in a way which they had not been able to give to the initial proposal. It is for that reason that this Senate chamber should support this legislation.

DEBATE.TITLE: EUROPEAN BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT BILL 1990INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT ASSOCIATION (FURTHER PAYMENT) BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 and 13 November, on motions by Senator Cook and Senator Tate:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The International Development Association (IDA), as the soft loan window of the World Bank, is one of the main contributors to development in the poorest developing countries. Between 1990 and 1993, the IDA plans to lend $9.3 billion in soft loans for its core poverty program. These loans are interest free, repayable over 35 to 40 years and have grace periods of 10 years. They are, therefore, practically no different from grants.

SPEECH.PARA: Without the contribution of the IDA, the problems of poverty in the poorer developing countries would be much worse than they are now. Though in many cases, particularly in subSaharan Africa, it is clear that the impact of the IDA and other international or bilateral aid agencies on the massive problems of poverty and population growth have often been disappointing.

Economic stagnation, rapid population growth and the vicious cycle of poverty in the world's poorest countries are problems of concern to all Australians. Starvation and the threat of starvation faced by poor people in the least developed countries are the most obvious manifestations of the problems facing these countries. I am sure of strong support through all sections of the Australian community for humanitarian assistance to those countries to provide food and shelter to people stricken by drought and other man-made or natural disasters, and facing starvation.

Assistance to develop the economies of the poorer countries in the longer term is urgently needed in order to prevent poverty and to obviate the need to rely on charity from wealthier countries. This will take time but action is urgently needed to prevent a looming disaster which also poses serious environmental dangers that should not be ignored. Alleviation of poverty and improvement of health and education services are essential prerequisites for the slowing of population increases which, if not slowed, would threaten the environment not only of the poor countries but of the whole world. Desertification and the loss of tropical rainforests are global problems that call for global solutions. The slash and burn agriculture and traditional livestock practices of the burgeoning poor are destroying forests at a faster rate than production for timber.

We should also not forget an economic motive. Economic growth in the poorer countries can fuel world trade and provide benefits to the donor countries as well as to the recipients. Until recently, when the combined effect of a slowdown in world trade and the rate of liberalisation of their economies slowed their growth, India and China were starting to have such an effect on world trade. Australia would also be a beneficiary to such growth in world trade, although we would be less likely to benefit if we failed to become more internationally competitive in a wide range of industries.

The IDA provides funds for much needed infrastructure in health, education and other essential services, without which the poorer developing countries would have little hope of ever escaping from the grip of poverty. The funds provided by IDA are seldom sufficient to meet the needs of these countries, for investment, domestic savings and investment are also critical, as is private overseas investment. Without funds from IDA the needs for investment in essential public infrastructure simply could not be met.

The case for assistance to the IDA by Australia is therefore clear. Like the World Bank in general, the IDA contributes more to development than funds at concessional rates. Its role in policy dialogue to ensure that economic policies are in place to maximise the benefits of IDA is just as important. The desperate need of the poorest countries for funds unfortunately does not mean that these funds cannot be wasted. Quite the contrary; it is often the case that the countries with people most in need of assistance have governments that are willing to waste scarce resources on military spending or other luxuries that they cannot afford or allow funds to be siphoned off into offshore bank accounts.

That is not an argument for not giving assistance to these countries. Rather it suggests that funds must only be given if strict conditions are attached together with the provision of a capacity to monitor performance in relation to those conditions. The World Bank does not always manage to enforce its conditions but it does manage to have successes in the longer term, which could not be achieved as easily through other channels. For example, bilateral aid is not usually on a scale sufficient to have the impact on government priorities that the large international banks can have.

Australian assistance to the IDA, as a proportion of the total aid budget, has risen steadily over recent years from 9.1 per cent in 1986-87 to 14.1 per cent in 1990-91. As the real level of the total aid budget has been whittled down, the decision to maintain contributions to the international development banks has meant that the proportion going to them has increased significantly. The effect of this has been to eat into the proportion of the budget available for the bilateral aid programs to the point where we spend almost as much on the banks as we do on the bilateral programs in South East Asia. This is something that the Opposition believes is undesirable as bilateral programs are able to give rise to benefits which are more tangible for the Australian community, being located in countries with which we have a wide range of ties.

It is important to note that the Government's allocation of the highest priority to maintaining its level of support to the development banks has been made at the same time that it has failed to set a multi-year commitment to the bilateral program in Indonesia, one of our closest neighbours with whom we have ties of political, defence and economic significance. Indonesia has an outstanding record in poverty reduction, but it still has many people living in poverty particularly in the eastern region closest to Australia. It is in the interests of both Indonesia and Australia that this poverty is eradicated. Similarly, priority has been given to the maintenance of support for the banks at a time when a commitment just entered into with the Papua New Guinea (PNG) Government had to be abrogated. Perhaps the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) could explain why this absolute priority was given to the international banks.

When this question was asked in the other place, the answer, which came interestingly from Mr Langmore, explained the level specified in the Bill as `the contribution we are asked to make in roughly proportional terms with previous contributions, less a little'. This simply begs the question of the level of priority. Apart from the cost in terms of squeezing the bilateral program, the apparent readiness of Australia to answer the call by the international development banks for further funds does nothing to increase Australia's voice in these institutions. One might ask whether Australia has a voice in them at all.

The Annual Report entitled Australia and the World Bank was presented by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and not by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade who has responsibility for the aid program. Exercising his responsibility as Australia's Governor on the World Bank, the Treasurer has presented a report setting out what the bank has done over the last financial year and providing assessments of the efficiency and effectiveness of its various arms. It includes some comment on the attempts that Australia has made to influence the World Bank in relation to allocation of IDA funds and a range of other matters.

It is interesting to note that Australia argued for greater allocation to Asia where there has generally been a better record in the efficient utilisation of funds and where the allocation per head has been lower than in other regions. There has been no indication that this pressure has been successful. Failure to achieve influence for Australian positions in relation to bank management issues are recorded in more detail.

Throughout the document there seems to be little indication of the exercise of Australian influence in relation to issues of specifically Australian interest. Perhaps the only exception to this is in relation to bank activities in the South Pacific. The bank seems to have reversed its previous unwillingness to modify its organisation or procedures to suit the unique requirements of the small Pacific states. There is nothing, however, to show that bank activities are related to other Australian development assistance or wider foreign policy objectives in the South Pacific.

Australian funding of the World Bank in general, including the IDA, has the appearance of a blank cheque issued without any particular regard for Australian objectives in donating such large sums. It is reminiscent of aid to Papua New Guinea, with the exception that in the case of the World Bank there is no indication that the amount will gradually decrease. It is as if there has been some assessment that the funds given to the international development banks are the best used of all the elements of the aid budget and should, therefore, be maintained at all costs. The Treasurer's report, however, contains no argument in support of such a conclusion. Not surprisingly, given that the document has originated from the Treasurer rather than from the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB), it contains very little on the rest of the aid program or wider foreign policy. The fact is that the international development banks or, more precisely, Australian representation at their headquarters in Washington and Manila, are treasury fiefdoms and are therefore protected from budget costs regardless of whether they are able to demonstrate any tangible benefits to Australian objectives in international development.

In conclusion in relation to the IDA, the case for Australian assistance is clear. For humanitarian, economic and environmental reasons it is important that Australia supports the activities of the IDA to provide assistance to poorer developing countries. The level of assistance that Australia should give is, however, a separate issue. The level as a proportion of the total Australian aid budget, as I said, has risen significantly, skewing priorities in such a way that bilateral aid options have been held back.

The Opposition therefore supports this Bill, which is based on a pledge already given, but records its concern that the effect of the present pledge is to continue support at levels which the Government has never properly justified and which, if projected into the future, would lock a future government into an aid budget which did not reflect its priorities. This Opposition would not permit itself to be so locked in in the future.

I will now make a few comments on the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development Bill 1990. The Opposition supports this Bill for Australian participation in the new bank which is being established to help fund the reconstruction of the economies of the former Eastern bloc countries as they undergo the transition from centrally planned economies to free market economies. The successful transition from totalitarian political systems to stable, liberal, democratic orders will depend in no small part on the ability of the economies to respond to the challenges they will face in the competitive world economy.

This will not be an easy process. The difference between a free market economy and a centrally planned economy is not simply one of emphasis. The transition will require nothing short of a revolution in institutions and the way of life. After many years of repression, expectations are bound to be high and the development of stability will require both the realistic political management of those expectations and the economic progress needed to provide improvements in living standards. The new development bank, as a region-wide institution, will play a crucial role in this process, engaging in policy dialogue and helping to shape and support workable economic policies that might not always be popular.

The proposed Australian role in the bank is modest, reflecting the limited role that Australia is likely to play in the reconstruction of eastern Europe. The sum of ECU30m has been provided, to be paid in annual instalments of approximately A$9m over five years. It is appropriate that we should support an institution which will play such an important role in the reconstruction of Europe, but it is also appropriate that our role should be relatively small.

In addition to the benefits for eastern Europe, Australian membership of the bank will provide some benefits to Australia. It will allow Australia a voice-perhaps a better voice than we get on the IDA-and it will allow us to provide some input to the economic reform process in eastern Europe. This will have some commercial and economic advantage for Australia. It will allow the Australian Government to formulate trade development strategies in response to the opening up of opportunities in eastern Europe. In conclusion on this particular Bill, we also offer our support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will also be supporting the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development Bill 1990 and the International Development Association (Further Payment) Bill 1990, although I will be moving a second reading amendment at the end of my speech.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats support the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development Bill because it offers Australia the chance to be part of the restructuring process now taking place in eastern and central Europe. The functions of the bank as set out in article 2 of the schedule are commendable because they encompass a strong emphasis on assisting recipient countries to become fully integrated into the international community.

Perhaps one of the biggest problems facing eastern and central Europe, however, is the environmental one. For years now these countries have claimed that they have had no environmental problems to deal with. We now know that the ecological destruction in these places is massive and quite possibly in many areas beyond restoration. I was pleased to read that the functions of the European Bank, as set out in article 2 of the Bill, include the following:
to promote in the full range of its activities environmentally sound and sustainable development;

It is appropriate that we congratulate those involved in setting up the bank for their prudence in including a statement concerning environmental considerations within the bank's functions. We trust that this will promote environmentally sound and sustainable development in the bank's activities and that it will also provide a lead to other international financial agencies to place an equally high priority on protecting the world environment. It is certainly a step forward when such considerations are adopted within the functions of newly set up financial development agencies such as this European Bank. We are pleased that Australia is involved in this enterprise.

I wish also to make a few brief comments in relation to the International Development Association (Further Payment) Bill, which also has the support of the Democrats. The one area of major concern in development is the reduction in the overseas aid budget. Australia has pledged $382.5m, or 1.99 per cent of our total Budget, for funding of development projects under this three-year round of the International Development Association. It is obvious that there has been a clear reduction in the volume of funds being provided for official development aid, and we agree with Senator Hill's comments on this matter.

In relation to this Bill we are especially pleased that women will finally be recognised in the design of development projects funded by the International Development Association. It is a long overdue reform, and we commend the officials involved for ensuring that this recognition was finally given by taking into account the importance of women as decision-makers and work force participants in all societies.

The Democrats would also like to place on record our support for the adoption of environmental considerations in all aspects of the International Development Association's future activities. This too represents quite a forward step in overseas aid development projects, and illustrates the point that the Democrats and non-government aid agencies have been making for some time-that there is a strong association between environmental destruction and Third World poverty in many developing countries.

Despite these reforms-and they certainly are of a positive nature-the Democrats would like to see the Australian Government use this opportunity to take a number of other steps in its power and make further reforms along this path. As Senator Hill has been telling us, Australia at the moment is represented on the Board of Governors of the World Bank by the Federal Treasurer, and Australia belongs to a group of countries which elect the Executive Director to the Board. Australia currently holds the position of Alternate Executive Director. I will be moving an amendment to the second reading of this Bill requesting that the Government take action to assist the World Bank's policy process by broadening the selection process for Australia's position on the World Bank so as to make it as wide as is practicable, given the Public Service requirements of such positions.

In the past, Australia's Executive Director has been chosen from Treasury. I believe that the Government has decided that in the future, when the position of Executive Director becomes vacant, Treasury will call for applications from three government agencies: the Treasury itself, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau. While this is an improvement, we believe that it does not go far enough.

The Democrats have proposed an amendment with the knowledge that in a recent parliamentary report the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade recommended precisely this idea of broadening the selection process. Headed by former Queensland senator John Black, this Committee reported on Australia's overseas aid programs and, among other things, assessed the adequacy and effectiveness of this country's participation in the decision-making processes of the international development agencies to which Australia contributes, such as the World Bank.

The Committee also received evidence from numerous organisations in the aid field which pointed to environmentally damaging activities resulting from insensitive and badly managed aid projects financed by multilateral development banks such as the World Bank. In submissions and evidence to the Joint Parliamentary Committee, the World Bank's performance in terms of environmental considerations also received some criticism.

On page 74 of the report, the Committee expressed the need for the bank to become more sensitive in the strategies which it adopts and pointed out that there is a greater need for the executive to broaden its understanding of what is required in developing countries. According to evidence presented during the Committee's hearings, the World Bank often funds poorly thought out development projects which subsequently cause massive dislocations of indigenous people with the benefits of projects going, in many cases, only to the privileged classes.

The poor in these developing countries are not involved in the design or implementation of development projects and the Committee discovered that the lending policies of the World Bank often lead to massive indebtedness on the part of the developing country. One way in which the Committee suggested that these problems could be overcome was for some appointees to the World Bank executive to have a greater awareness of development issues. This could happen by broadening the selection process for Australia's appointment to the executive so that a greater range of people in the community and from the aid agencies have the opportunity to serve in that sort of capacity.
In the chapter in which it dealt with the international financial and development agencies, the Committee made the following recommendation:

Australia's executive director and alternate director positions should be filled on the basis of expertise in development and development finance issues. Therefore they should be openly advertised inside and outside the Public Service, and filled on merit. The Committee regards continued membership of the World Bank as an essential aspect of the aid program. However effective membership requires greater participation and awareness of development issues in policy formulation.
In responding to these recommendations, the Government accepted the general thrust of them and committed itself to advertising the position widely in the future.

We too believe that this sort of reform is essential if the bank is to continue its new found balanced approach to the challenges of development and see it as more than just an accounting transaction. Essentially, this reform recognises that the World Bank is a development agency and that the person who fills Australia's position of executive director should at least have some experience in the fields of development and development finance. It is to Australia's shame, of course, that we remain the only country that does not require its bank executive director to have that development experience. I move:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate:

(a) condemns the Government for its failure to implement its own response to the recommendations of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade report of December 1989, in relation to filling of Australian positions at the multi-lateral development banks; and
(b) calls on the Government and in particular the Treasurer, in consultation with the Minister for Foreign Affairs, to ensure that in future:
(i) such positions are openly advertised both inside and outside the public service
(ii) candidates are selected on the basis of merit and
(iii) selection criteria shall include the desirability of demonstrating an experience in development and development finance issues''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: -I rise to follow, from the Opposition, the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Hill, and to support some of the comments he made in respect of Australia's foreign aid commitments. I am concerned that this country is giving as much money as it is in foreign aid when, as Senator Hill said, in many cases it could be seen as a blank cheque. Whilst I support the general principle behind the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development Bill 1990, I have some concerns.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe it is important for us to assist those countries that have been recently freed from the shackles of communism. It is important for us to help them rebuild their shattered economies, but it is also important that the aid that we supply overseas is properly directed and is not abused. I seek leave to table a deed of a grant of land for a cattle property called Kulai outside of Goondiwindi in Queensland.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The deed of grant of land shows that the cattle property Kulai was purchased late last year by the China National Foreign Trade Transportation Corporation, Shenyang branch. This organisation is an arm of the Chinese Government. It has purchased this cattle property which, I understand, has an area of 2,137 hectares just outside of the Queensland town, Goondiwindi. It has attached to it a feedlot licence for 16,400 head of cattle. I ask: how can the Chinese Government afford to pay over $1.2m to purchase this cattle property at a time when Queensland farmers are finding it difficult enough to hold on to their own farms?

SPEECH.PARA: Also of concern to me is that it appears from the title deed that the Chinese Government was able to buy this cattle property; but not at the exorbitant interest rates that Australian farmers have to pay-16, 17, 18 or 20 per cent overdraft rates. No, the Chinese Government was able to purchase this cattle property for cash. The deed of grant of land shows that there is no encumbrance over the land. It walked in with its cheque book and it signed away. It purchased a cattle property in Queensland at a time when, according to Australia's overseas aid program pamphlet circulated by authority of Senator Evans this year, the total Australian aid flow to China in the financial year 1989-90 was $42.7m. Is it not a bit absurd that we should be providing $42.7m in aid to the People's Republic of China and yet it should be able to come here and buy a Queensland cattle property for over $1.2m in cash?

I am not foolish enough to suggest that there might not be a legitimate reason why the Chinese Government should have purchased this cattle property. It may have purchased the cattle property for the purpose of increasing the trade to China in Australian beef. But I hasten to add that at the time the Chinese Government purchased this cattle property there was already approval for a feedlot licence. Nothing has been done about that feedlot licence in the last 12 months. In fact, the Chinese Government had been so tardy in taking up the opportunity to install the feedlot that it has had to apply for an extension of the period of time in which to complete the feedlot. I am told that extension of time has now been given to the Chinese Government and it has until 9 November 1991 to comply with the terms of the Act.

If this feedlot is so important to the Chinese Government, if it needs it so much for trade between Australia and China, why has it not done anything about it? Why does it have to apply for a 12-month extension in which to do the work? These are the questions which need to be answered. These are some of the problems with Australia's foreign aid budget at the moment. It seems that we are giving money to governments and yet those same governments are purchasing property and commercial investments in Australia.

There seems to be some contradiction. I am also not foolish enough to suggest that $42.7m in aid to China was all cash because, of course, it was not. Some of the aid was important because it assisted Australian companies in getting a foot in the door in China. But, on the face of it, we have to ask whether this purchase of a cattle property in Queensland can be justified when we are giving so much money to China. Maybe we should put it the other way around. Can we justify giving $42.7m to a repressive communist government whose human rights record is well known and has been repeatedly criticised by Amnesty International? Can we afford to give this much money to the Chinese Government at a time when it can afford to come here and buy farms that Australian farmers cannot afford to own themselves?

This highlights the quandary in the policy decisions behind Australia's foreign aid budget. I believe it highlights some of the potential traps into which we could fall if we are not very careful about the manner in which we allocate overseas assistance. I hope there is some very good explanation for what has happened in Goondiwindi. I hope that we will look closely at the sort of foreign aid we give in future and that we take the time to check our priorities and ask whether we should give money to governments that seem to be able to fend quite well for themselves, thank you very much.

I believe that charity starts at home. At a time when our rural sector is in a dreadful recession and Australian farmers in their thousands are being forced off the land-pushed off the land-because of a combination of factors, including this Government's failed economic policies, I do not believe it is appropriate for us to write a blank cheque to every government that holds out its hand for a grant. These problems are of great concern to me and, I believe, to many Australians and we must turn our attention to these problems in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is unfortunate that the guillotine is operating because it would be important at some stage to have a rather lengthy debate on the operations of the World Bank. I feel that is long overdue in this Parliament. It is very heartening to see that more members of this chamber are becoming interested in the operations of international financial institutions. That was not always so 10 or 15 years ago, but over the past five, six or seven years more honourable senators have expressed interest in what is happening in these international institutions and the focus of their policies.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of that has been the result of the interests of environmental groups and their concern-indeed the concern of quite a number of people-about the policy of the World Bank to come to arrangements with the elite in various countries and engage in quite suspect, in many cases, development projects. This is not to say that the operations of the World Bank are not beneficial in many circumstances. Quite clearly they are, but there are areas to which attention needs to be paid. These areas should have the microscope put on them.

One of those areas has been subjected to public debate and pressure. At last the World Bank has responded to this public pressure and debate. I refer to environmental concerns which have arisen. However, we have to take a lesson from that. Year after year the World Bank said it was doing the right thing and was taking these things into consideration. In 1987, after years of denial, World Bank President Barber Conable delivered a speech in Washington in which he publicly acknowledged that, as far as environmental destruction was concerned, the bank:

had been ``part of the problem in the past,'' and announced that the Bank would mend its ways by greatly increasing its environmental staff and by increasing lending for environmentally beneficial projects.

Later it was proved that this speech contained a degree of rhetoric. According to a number of people in the environmental movement, there is still a long way to go in this respect. The spring issue of World Policy Journal contained an article written by the director of the United States Environmental Defense Fund's international program, which referred to congressional hearings held in October 1989-2 1/2 years after Conable had committed the bank to sweeping environmental reforms-and which slammed the bank for the continuing and systematic violation of its own environmental and social policies. The hearing had before it information that the bank was continuing to finance a dam project in northern central India, despite the fact that, among other things, no resettlement plan had been formulated for the 90,000 rural poor that the dam's 120-mile reservoir would displace.

I cannot vouch for the accuracy of the comment made in the World Policy Journal, but two points need to be made. It has taken many years for the bank to admit its failings in respect of the environment and it admitted to them only after substantial intense pressure from environmental and community groups. Once it had admitted its failures, it is alleged that it continued to hide behind rhetoric. Measures have been taken by the World Bank-I know that-in respect of the environmental issue now, but we have to learn a lesson from that: despite the rhetoric some problems may still occur. Indeed I was disappointed to hear someone say in debate that the poor were doing damage to the environment. Again I quote from that article in the World Policy Journal:

Third World NGOs were particularly outraged because the plan seemed to blame the poor for the destruction of tropical forests while promoting investments to open up large areas of pristine forest for exploitation . . .

As honourable senators realise, I have expressed concern in this chamber in the past about another aspect of the World Bank's focus, and that is population control. It is very important that we do not allow the World Bank to make assumptions which are not well founded. Its assumption that the fertility of poor women in poor countries is to blame for a range of problems-from environmental damage to war-is plainly ludicrous. I do not intend to make a speech today about that, but I would quote from a document authored by someone who would not share many of my views. The article, which was written by one Betsy Hartmann, appears in the journal Progressive of 18 September 1990. It is headed `Bankers, Babies and Bangladesh'. It deals with the World Bank involvement in Bangladesh. It must be remembered that Australia is also involved in this area. The article reads:

. . . at the 1988 annual meeting of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, Bank President Barber Conable pledged that his institution is ``dedicated to attacking poverty and beating it back.'' A vital part of his battle plan is ``curbing excessive population growth.''
It goes on:

``The societies in which population is growing very fast must accept that many-perhaps most-of these new lives will be miserable, malnourished, and brief,'' he said. There was no mention of the misery that population control has brought to poor people like Osman Ali.
Osman Ali is a Bangladeshi typical of the people whose human rights have been violated. The story of Osman Ali began this article. It continues:

Conable's pronouncement was nothing new. For more than 20 years, the World Bank has played a strategic role in pressuring Third World governments to implement population-control programs. It can do this by virtue of its leverage over other forms of development aid.

By procreating too often, the logic goes, the poor help to create and perpetuate their own poverty. Their numbers spread scarce agricultural and environmental resources too thin, keep wages low and cost governments too much money in social services. Forcing down birth rates through population-control programs will thus help the poor help themselves.

There are two main problems with this analysis. First, it obscures the real cause of poverty in the Third World: the unequal distribution of resources and power within individual countries and between the developed and underdeveloped worlds. The Bank has always turned a blind eye to inequality; moreover, it actively allies itself with the same Third World elites who monopolize resources within their countries and thus prevent real development.

The article goes on to cover a number of other situations. The point that is being made, of course, is that the real cause of poverty is not the fertility of poor women in poor countries, but is made up of a number of other factors, which are addressed by a number of people in the World Bank. But so far as the bank's population control measures are concerned, what is happening is quite a disgrace. Turning to Bangladesh, this article reads:

In financial terms alone, population control now absorbs a full third of the government's health budget. Mother and Child Health, supposedly a cornerstone of Bangladesh's population policy, has consistently taken a back seat to sterilization, with tragic consequences.

According to World Bank figures, only 2 per cent of children in Bangladesh had been immunized by 1987 against the common infectious diseases. Almost half of infant deaths and one-third of childhood deaths are caused by illnesses which could be prevented or readily cured.

The articles goes on further but time is running away under the guillotine and I do not intend to continue. I just raise these issues because regard must be had to them by the international institutions themselves.

There is a whole range of information now as to what is the bottom line of such population control measures. The bottom line is a violation of human rights. I would like to see the World Bank and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development have, somewhere within their charter, a principle to ensure that those measures adopted coincide with and respect the culture of the developing countries and the individual human rights of the people in those countries.

Finally, the India project of the World Bank, about which I asked questions in the Estimates committee hearings, will be found to be wanting. I would like to know why the United States of America opposed the project which I referred to in the Estimates committee, because that has not yet come out and I have not yet received an answer as to the full issue of the India matter.

I say again that the decision-making process has to be taken from the bureaucrats and put back into the hands of the couples-and that is not being done because, for example, the Billings method is being ignored, even though the Indian Council of Medical Research has done a study on that method and found it to be most effective. That method puts the power back into the hands of the people, away from the bureaucrats. This is one of the reasons why some of the international bureaucrats do not want it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development Bill and the International Development Association (Further Payment) Bill, I particularly want to concentrate on the first Bill. In doing so, I want to contrast what Australia is doing with what has occurred in eastern Europe in recent times, and consider our trading role with those countries in recent years.

SPEECH.PARA: First, I would like to acknowledge the fact that in eastern Europe we are seeing the whole structure change into market orientated economies. This was the fundamental reason for the establishment of the European Bank. I want to contrast Australia's input into this with our trading situation. It is worth noting that in recent years we have had an export trade worth something like $1.5 billion per annum with eastern Europe. In return, our contribution to this particular bank is going to be $9m per year. I believe it essential that this bank be established, but I am concerned, in terms of the value of the trade that we extract out of those countries, that our contribution will be seen as very miserly.

My concern is that as a result of the list of shareholders-the United States has 100,000 shares, Japan 85,000, France 85,000, Germany 85,000, Italy 85,000 and the United Kingdom 85,000-Australia has the potential to lose a significant amount of our trading clout in terms of the redevelopment of eastern Europe and its movement towards a market oriented economy.

While I certainly support our involvement in the redevelopment of eastern Europe, I think that our contribution should and could have been significantly greater and much more positive. It is going to be very important in the next year or two, in terms of the situation in eastern Europe, that we work very hard to maintain our market share of exports into those countries, because there is no doubt that those countries that I have mentioned, and others that are making a significantly greater share in terms of the European Bank, will use that as a lever to try to extract more trade from those countries at the expense of Australia. This is particularly important at the present time with the breakdown of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade talks and what is occurring there.

I believe this situation has the potential, because of our small contribution, to put Australia at a trading disadvantage. I want to contrast this, in the few minutes that I have, with some expenditure that is here. I think that Senator O'Chee raised a very valid point in terms of where Australia places finance and how we handle ourselves. Let me give the Senate one internal example. Let me compare this $45m over the five years-approximately $9m per annum-with the $69m spent last year in the advertising and promotion budget of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. In the previous year the amount spent was $54m, so we were able to find an additional $15m to go into that particular activity, which, I believe one can argue very strongly, will have a minimal impact in many areas in terms of improving our position. Yet we can see here the magnitude of our contribution in an area which is absolutely crucial in terms of our current account and in getting on top of our debt problem.

I summarise by saying that it is absolutely crucial, now that this bank has been structured, that Australia maximise its promotion overseas in order to maintain our market share in these countries which have become very important to Australia. Otherwise, I believe, the countries that I have mentioned-Europe, America and Japan-will walk all over the top of us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we move into the final stages of the debate on the second reading of this Bill the guillotine is ticking away and, as each of us is given a limited time, we have to curtail our remarks much more than we would wish. The last 18 months will go down as the most momentous period in the history of eastern Europe and, indeed, of the world. We have seen the death of socialism. We have seen the end of the Cold War and the political liberation of millions of people. For those who truly believe in the value of freedom and the strength of the human spirit, these will be great triumphs. Many people like to disparage the remarks of Ronald Reagan but I am not one of them. He was quite right when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: You cannot massacre an idea. You cannot run tanks over hope. You cannot riddle a people's yearnings with bullets.

Yet the challenge is now with us because the world is a less stable place than it was previously. Unless we see dramatic changes take place which will enable that political freedom to be backed up with economic freedom, we can say that there has ultimately been no conquest of the individual over the state. What we need to see is the complete transformation of command economies into vibrant market economies. Indeed, it is in this context that my remarks are directed to the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development Bill 1990.

In July and August of this year, I spent some four weeks in Europe looking at the European single market in 1992, the developments in eastern Europe and the implications that they have for Australia and Australian trade. These four weeks followed on a meeting with Carla Hills in Washington just prior to the G7 summit in Houston and after delivering two papers on trade in Canada. The four weeks in Europe were broken up between two weeks in the United Kingdom as a guest of the British Government, a week in each of Brussels and West Germany and a week in Czechoslovakia.

It was in those periods of investigation that I gained an insight into the enormous problems that are facing eastern Europe and, therefore, the rest of the world in coming to terms with providing free economies. Fairly recently as a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I had the opportunity of meeting with Mr Gerasimov, a spokesman for the Soviet foreign ministry. In that discussion he illustrated three points which I think are quite significant in the mistakes that the Gorbachev administration had already made.

The first mistake was the attempt to implement a prohibition on alcohol, which simply resulted in enormous forgone revenues from the production of alcohol, together with an increased demand for sugar because, quite simply, people were making alcohol at home. Secondly, too many roubles were printed. Thirdly, the Gorbachev administration made a mistake in not producing consumer goods but in attempting to pick winners and produce manufacturers who were tool makers. Quite frankly, to bring about an equilibrium between demand and supply in the Soviets would require price rises of over 50 per cent. One sees enormous distortions in the Soviet economy with massive subsidies being paid still for food and shelter, and also this enormous demand question. A rapid rise in the monetary supply has fuelled inflation with wages rising something like 1.4 times faster than productivity gains.

In one of the papers that I gave in Canada, I dealt with questions dealing with recent developments in eastern Europe for specific trade and investment and the implications for Australia in particular. Some of the issues that I raised in that paper are relevant to look at today. I looked at the impediments to trade and investment in eastern Europe. The first is the conflict of objectives. When western companies are looking to establish joint ventures, they are looking at doing so with an aim to looking for markets in eastern Europe.

On the other hand, when we look at the aims of the Eastern bloc countries, they are looking to increase their exports. This thus means that joint ventures will have to be self-supportive in currency terms.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Mr Deputy President, I seek leave for the continuation of this debate until the natural expiry of it at 12.51.

—Thank you very much. A major problem, of course, is that of the willingness and commitment to establish the concept and reality of private property. This is still a debate going on in Soviet Russia; this is a debate which, in countries such as Czechoslovakia, has been placed up to and decided upon, and they indeed will create private property and allow markets to work. In East Germany the 8,000 enterprises which the West German Government identified are proceeding to move into private hands.

SPEECH.PARA: But there will be enormous problems in negotiating with lethargic bureaucracies which remain. One of the fundamental problems is that those people who presently control property and enterprises are the very people who are ideologically opposed to them being privatised. So there are long term problems to be negotiated.

To look at the bank itself: the bank will take over some of the World Bank's responsibilities for eastern Europe, even though the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund will continue programs of structural adjustment lending. It will have an initial capitalisation of $US13 billion. The European Community's 12-member states and its institutions will hold a 51 per cent share; the United States, 10 per cent; Japan, 8 per cent; and the Soviet Union, 6 per cent. Australia's contribution is $45m over the next five years and is, indeed, to be part of the underwriting of the activities of the bank.

The establishment of the bank represents a compromise between the United States and Great Britain on the one hand and the French on the other. This compromise means that 60 per cent of the bank's activities are to be directed to the private sector and to assist with the privatisation of state owned enterprises, while up to 40 per cent will be allocated to the state sector in each country assisted. That which is allocated to the state sector is intended to assist industries deemed to be moving towards denationalisation and demonopolisation.
