I think it is interesting to compare the degree of national private investment which is going on in Europe now. Of all the private investment going into Poland, 60 per cent is German; into Russia, 50 per cent is German; and into East Germany, 97 per cent is German. After that comes the United States, Switzerland and the United Kingdom, with Japan just moving. Much of that investment is also being done through German subsidiaries.

The proposed privatisation role of the bank to be established is, in fact, to have little precedent but I think it is important that we do not see a repetition of the errors that were made with regard to World Bank allocation of funds, particularly in the Latin American markets.

The Hungarian economist James Kornoi says that there needs to be developed a new middle class in eastern Europe, composed of industrious, thrifty entrepreneurs. Only with such individuals can there emerge genuine private stocks, authentic stock companies and a real stock exchange. I close with a quote from the CATO Institute based in the United States:

The message is quite simple: there is no capitalism without capitalists. And capitalists (domestic and foreign) are something the east European nations will have to cultivate on their own-through constitutionally guaranteed and fully functional property rights systems, viable legal accounting system, modest levels of taxation and regulation, and a functioning convertible currency.
I trust this bank will enhance those prospects.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for its support of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development Bill and the International Development Association (Further Payment) Bill. In the less than two minutes available to me, I regret that I am unable to give any kind of reasonable reply to a number of the points that have been raised during the debate. But let me just say two things. First of all, as to the validity or legitimacy of Australia spending such a significant proportion of the aid budget on the World Bank, I believe there is ample justification for that.

SPEECH.PARA: The International Development Association is an efficient and effective vehicle for developing development assistance to the poorest developing countries and in this way-by contributing money to the World Bank development agency-we are usefully supplementing the regional focus of our bilateral aid program in a way that is entirely consistent with our obligations of good international citizenship to help the poorest and most deserving countries.

There are some returns for Australia in this in a number of respects, not least reputational but also in terms of the procurement that is possible through World Bank programs by virtue of being a credible paid-up member of it. Generally I think we can amply justify the payments that we do make.

As to the second reading amendment that has been moved by the Australian Democrats, there is quite a lot to be said about the appropriate nature of the qualifications for executive directors of the bank. I simply say that it is important not only that there be expertise within our representatives on development and technical assistance issues of a familiar kind as Senator Bourne emphasised but also that there be a capacity to play a professional role in equity investment issues, borrowing issues and the kind of policy decisions that the bank constantly has to make on loans and guarantees and, in effect, investment appraisal.

For those reasons it has been somewhat traditional for the market from which executive directors have been drawn to be a fairly limited one. I believe we have acted consistently with our response to the Senate committee report by widely notifying, as we promised to do, the availability of this position coming up. It was not wide outside the public sector agencies immediately involved, but it was nonetheless not unreasonable.
With those very few remarks I commend the Bills to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The time for the consideration of the Bills has expired.

—by leave-We will support the amendment because we believe it is important that these positions be advertised outside the Public Service. Those outside as well as inside should have the opportunity to apply, but I do not want my remarks to be interpreted as a criticism of any particular appointment or a suggestion that a particular appointee was not properly qualified. But because recent appointments, notwithstanding the advice of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, were not publicly advertised we have indicated to the Australian Democrats that we will support their amendment.
—The question is that the amendment be agreed to.
—The question now is that the remaining stages of the Bills be agreed to and that the Bills be now passed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will be aware that during the recent debate on the industrial relations legislation I drew the attention of the Senate to the plight of Mr John Ellenbogen in New South Wales, who was attempting to pursue before the courts of that State a matter in relation to his professional standing in a clash that he has had in an industrial dispute with the Blue Mountains City Council.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to speak briefly to the plight of Mr John Ellenbogen because it goes to the very heart of human rights in Australia. I have had quite a number of conversations with John Ellenbogen and, in fact, I have asked questions in this place of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans). Those questions and the answers are on the record.

Much is said in this place about human rights, and so it should be. Human rights are very close to the hearts of all Australians. I think it can be truly said that Australians are fully committed to human rights in this country, but there will always be aberrations and those aberrations must be seriously and consciously addressed by us as legislators.

I am very disturbed by the circumstances in which Mr Ellenbogen finds himself and I would like to provide some details of those circumstances to honourable senators. Ten years ago the Hon. Andrew Peacock, then Minister for Foreign Affairs, signed the ratification instrument for the International Covenant for Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR). He signed this on behalf of Australia but in doing so Australia filed a number of reservations about that covenant. Four years later Senator the Hon. Gareth Evans, in his capacity as Foreign Minister, advised the Secretary-General of the United Nations of Australia's withdrawal of most of those reservations. In a press release on Human Rights Day in 1984 Senator Evans stressed:
The ICCPR provides a charter of the civil and political rights of individuals within a country and places an obligation on the country to ensure the protection of those rights.
He went on to say:

Civil and political rights are those rights which we enjoy as citizens of a country in our dealings with government and include such matters as the right not to be subject to arbitrary arrest, the right to a fair trial, to freedom of speech, freedom of movement, freedom of religion and the right to equal protection of the law.
This, of course, includes equality before the law.

In a number of subsequent statements Australia has quite emphatically endorsed the principles of that covenant. Unfortunately, it is a sad situation that Mr John Ellenbogen does not enjoy such rights before a tribunal in New South Wales. The realities are that, in fact, he as an Australian is not equal before the law in the circumstances in which he finds himself.

The situation is that Mr Ellenbogen fell into dispute with the Blue Mountains City Council. He attempted to carry his case before the Industrial Relations Commission in New South Wales and the only way of doing that is to get a special writ of the Minister. Because of my own intervention and the intervention of Mr John Howard, who is his local member, after some 20 months Mr Ellenbogen got a special writ and found himself before the Industrial Relations Commission.

He is a highly qualified person. He has a bachelor of commerce and a masters degree in business administration. He is a very competent, articulate man; but still he finds himself in the most extraordinary situation. Even after getting that special writ-that was actually the beginning of a nightmare in attempting to pursue his case supposedly equally before the courts and equally before the law-he had to get two references to the tribunal, which he succeeded in doing.

The Blue Mountains City Council-that is, his former employer-is represented before the tribunal by its own solicitor and by a barrister. The Crown appears in the court as well and is represented by the Crown Solicitor and by a barrister. But right up to the present time Mr Ellenbogen has had to appear for himself without any legal or financial support. After 4 1/2 years of delays and intentional blockage by government authorities, he has managed his entire living expenses and he brings his case before the court daily on a budget of $19.18, which he receives from the Department of Social Security in a form of benefits. He has lost, in this process of four years, all other financial resources. As I say, he has himself before this tribunal by a special writ of the Minister.

New South Wales legal aid does not cover industrial matters; indeed, it specifically excludes them. As the law stands at present, normally only unions and employers are able to appear before this jurisdiction and Mr Ellenbogen is there by special writ of the Minister.

It is apparent that he is a very determined individual. Between 3 January and 5 December this year he has on 29 occasions travelled from the Blue Mountains into the city and he has had to represent himself in court for a period of 23 full days without any financial support whatsoever. He is appearing in his own right, as I said, against solicitors and barristers representing the Blue Mountains City Council and the Crown Solicitor and barristers representing the Crown, and he is standing there without legal aid, supposedly equal before the court, representing himself.

I put a case to Mr Fahey, the State Minister for Industrial Relations and Employment, to the State Attorney-General, Mr Dowd, and in fact to the State Premier that his circumstances be acknowledged as being quite extraordinary by virtue of the writ having been granted to him. We asked for special financial assistance, which has not been forthcoming. Instead, the New South Wales Government actually claims a copyright over Mr Ellenbogen's own words spoken in open court in his own defence. It will not hand over the transcript without some considerable payment from the person that they know is simply not able to pay for that transcript. Up to now Mr Ellenbogen is about 1,000 pages of transcript behind in his own proceedings. His application to the Premier, as I said, for tangible support has so far received nothing but resounding neglect.

In 1988 Australia claimed on page 136 of its second report of the ICCPR to the United Nations Human Rights Committee that `in all Australian jurisdictions all persons are of equal standing before the courts and tribunals'. Quite clearly that is not the case in relation to Mr Ellenbogen's circumstances before this jurisdiction in New South Wales.

I know that the Ellenbogen circumstances are a matter of some considerable controversy between the former Federal Liberal shadow Attorney-General, the Hon. Neil Brown, and the Greiner Government. I have been privy to some of the correspondence over the situation in which Mr Ellenbogen finds himself.

If we look at the realities, the fact is that the State Government and the Minister have issued a writ to allow him to appear before the court but there is no attempt to follow through with the necessary provisions to allow the gentleman to have equal standing before the court. He is clearly disadvantaged in terms of his representation; he is clearly disadvantaged in terms of his access to resources-even the resources of the printed transcripts of his own words are not made available to him. Indeed, almost three days of the court proceedings have been taken up by cross-examinations and the case being presented to the tribunal justifying the fact that Mr Ellenbogen should not be entitled to transcripts. The cost of those three days of proceedings, of course, would vastly outweigh the limited cost of providing the man with photocopies of the proceedings recording his own statements before the court.

Surely no person in Australia should be forced to reduce his food intake-and this is what this gentleman has had to do. He has had to so trim his budget that he is barely able to feed himself or to pay his fares from the Blue Mountains to appear and represent himself before this tribunal.

What I am saying is that for Foreign Ministers, Federal Attorneys-General and others to assure the United Nations that all Australians have equality before all courts in this land is clearly not a statement of what the realities are. We have in New South Wales this very day clear proof positive of the fact that we cannot claim such things for Australian citizens.

I have on a number of occasions placed this matter before the Senate in the form of questions and statements. All I can do is to call upon the Government and, in fact, all members of parliament, and particularly all New South Wales members and New South Wales senators, to carry this case to the Foreign Minister seeking his intervention in the implementation of the international covenant to which we are a signatory. I can only seek their intervention in appealing to the New South Wales Government, to the New South Wales Industrial Relations Minister and to the Premier to make a special grant available to Mr Ellenbogen so that he at least is able to present himself and feels that there is genuine sincerity intended in the granting of that writ and not just the continuation of a nightmare in which he finds himself in an attempt to pursue his case before one of the courts of the land which we as a government have assured to the United Nations and the people of the world provides equality for all Australian citizens.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take this opportunity to say a few words about the problems that are besetting the Horn of Africa and in particular the famine victims of Eritrea and Tigre. I do that not simply in my capacity as one of the two parliamentary sponsors of the Eritrean Relief Association. I say in that context that both I and Senator Schacht are indeed honoured to be in that position. I speak because it is a matter which I think ought to concern all Australians and the Federal Government in particular.

SPEECH.PARA: I also speak in the context of a further Food For Life campaign which was launched by the Melbourne Age on 14 December last. As I understand it, even the bankrupt Victorian Government has managed to give $25,000 to the campaign but I am not aware of the Federal Government having yet made any commitment and I wish to take this opportunity to urge it to do so. The Age campaign is a relaunch and it is fair to say that the previous campaigns that have been run in the previous two years have been remarkably successful in raising in excess of $1m which has gone through Community Aid Abroad to help famine victims in those two areas.

Certainly the dimensions of the current famine would seem to be even greater than in previous years. The latest estimate suggests that something like 10 million people are now facing starvation in the region. For the first time even drinking wells are drying up or turning saline. The United Nations, through the world food program, has predicted very dire consequences, forecasting that something like 4.28 million would require food, almost half of them in Eritrea, and a further 20 per cent in neighbouring Tigre. It has appealed for almost 850,000 tonnes of food to be donated. That figure is the assessment of the Ethiopian Relief and Rehabilitation Commission and is less than the figure of the World Food program, which has put the food requirement at 941,000 tonnes. I hasten to say that the Eritrean Relief and Rehabilitation Commission, which I think has probably in general done a very good job in trying to deliver aid to the people in its own areas, is for obvious reasons unable to ensure that aid flows through to Eritrea. From my own experiences in dealing with the Commission in the early 1980s I thought that it was then-and I presume now-a very appropriate vehicle for the distribution of aid throughout Ethiopia. But that of course does not cope with the problems of Eritrea. Those problems are part and parcel of the ongoing war of liberation that is being fought there and is now in almost its twenty-ninth year.

I think it is fair to say that the Eritrean People's Liberation Front (EPLF) has by far the upper hand and it is only a matter of time before it will finally succeed in liberating Asmara, the traditional capital of Eritrea. When that occurs then I think we will be entitled to feel that the end is nigh, but that point has not arrived. It has been a protracted siege of Asmara and the latest reports suggest that the fighting is at a standstill. If that is the case, then it looks as though we will have to be even more patient.

I want to refer briefly to some remarks contained in an interview with the EPLF secretary-general, Mr Afewerki, as recorded in the October edition of the Adulis, which is published monthly by the Foreign Relations Bureau of the EPLF. I found the remarks of the leader very encouraging in the sense that they seem to constitute a recognition of the mammoth post-independent problems that have not always been faced up to by emerging nations. He does, I think, have an acute awareness of the potential for corruption in Third World countries and the abuse of power that often follows from independence. He shows a very clear determination to ensure that that does not happen in this instance. Indeed, he does not even aspire to political office once the war of independence has been concluded. He says that the role of the EPLF will come to a halt at that time.

Quite clearly the EPLF has been addressing a number of the post-independence problems that will arise-such as devising Eritrea's own currency. At the moment the Ethiopian birr, the Sudanese pound and to a lesser extent the Saudi riyal are simultaneously used as optional currencies throughout Eritrea, and the United States dollar is also used. It is probably an indication of the magnitude of the difficulties faced that Eritrea does not yet have an independent, convertible currency.

The EPLF also shows an acute awareness of the need to achieve international legitimacy, and therefore its call for the United Nations to organise a referendum in Eritrea is one that ought to be supported by the UN itself and certainly by the Australian Government. It has given a commitment to create a multi-party system in Eritrea, and again I think we would all welcome that. It is clear that it sees the pitfalls of one-party systems. Indeed, even those who have tried them, such as Mr Mugabe in Zimbabwe, would ultimately have to acknowledge that their advantages are far outweighed by their shortcomings in the democratic process. Again, that is an enlightened acknowledgment.

It is also interesting that it has decided to place a ban on religious political parties and it says that the same rule would apply to regional and ethnic movements. Again, I think that is probably a sensible commitment to give in the circumstances. Eritrea being a heterogeneous society with diverse, linguistic and religious constituencies, the last thing it would really want is to foment tensions and difficulties along racial or ethnic lines. I think broadbased political movements are certainly what is desirable in that context.

The United States shows a recognition of the merits of the argument. Presidents Bush and Gorbachev both discussed the issue in their recent summit and I think the US has now finally come to a stage where it regards the Eritrean cause as legitimate and would therefore, I think, welcome the end of the struggle on the basis of an independent nation. That I think is something that the Australian Government will do in due course as well.

It is not altogether clear to me why the EPLF has refused to resume the talks and the peace process. I did not find the argumentation particularly convincing on that point but no doubt there are military and strategic reasons for that although it was originally proposed by the EPLF itself. It has probably got a bit to do with the capture of Masawa in February this year. It is interesting to note that agreement has now been reached following negotiations coordinated by the world food program which will allow Masawa to serve as a channel for food shipments into Eritrea. I think we should welcome that announcement made only in the last few days.

That now being the case, there is the prospect of alleviating to at least some extent the horrific drought and famine problems. That is why I take this opportunity to say that it would be very welcome indeed for the Australian Government to show some Christmas generosity, despite the fact that we have inordinate problems of our own, by contributing to the Age appeal, and I urge it to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak today on the duplication which occurs between the land care program and the National Soil Conservation Committee. I think it is appropriate at this time when we have discussions going on regarding rationalisation of the roles of the Commonwealth and the States that we should also look at duplication which exists in Commonwealth functions. I suggest that now that the political glamour of the land care program has disappeared somewhat-and there is no doubt that it was used as a political tool-Commonwealth functions should be looked at very closely and coordinated into one function to stop the current duplication.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure honourable senators would be aware that I have been a great supporter of the soil conservation program and the change of attitude in Australia towards land care which really started in a big way in the mid-1970s and has gradually improved. Today soil conservation is a State and national effort. When we examine the reports on both programs we see that fundamentally there is a transfer from one to the other. The land care program transferred some $23.4m to the national soil conservation program during the year.

There are land care reports for the various States. In Western Australia, my State, the number of land care districts has increased from 109 to 120. Between two committees, 26 people in total are responsible for the management of them. There are 12 people on one body and 14 on the other. The inherent costs involved in what is fundamentally a duplication of two functions need addressing. The emphasis should be on maximising the dollars and cents in programs, not on duplication of functions of people.

Time is limited so I will not try to track on all this now, but the reports show that some 200 land care groups have been established in Australia. Some 120-odd of them are in Western Australia, which signifies very clearly that the real push and the drive for land care or the national soil conservation program started off in Western Australia.

It is a matter of concern that, with the duplication, the amount of money allocated this particular year has not been sufficient for a land care coordinator in Western Australia, despite the position that we find ourselves in. I would certainly urge the Government and those responsible for these two programs to have a careful look at them and see how they can be coordinated into one program so that we do not have the duplication.

Of course, the duplication is not confined to the people on the committees. Two separate sets of accounts have to be kept. There is duplication of auditors and the people who perform the various administrative functions associated with the running of these committees. I mentioned that we cannot find enough money in Western Australia for a land care coordinator, yet we can find enough for duplicated functions. Something like 80 per cent of the State is now covered by land care districts. Some 50 catchment groups have been established in catchment areas to deal with salinity problems.

We are now looking in a much broader way at soil degradation problems. Water erosion, wind erosion and soil salinisation have always attracted the headlines. We can see these problems very clearly. But with the transfer of responsibilities, particularly from the land care program to the national soil conservation program, attention is now being given to soil structure decline, invasion of production land by native woody shrubs, and water repellency.

These things are not obvious to the eye. But soil structure decline and water repellency are two factors which in fact lead to the other problems. Water repellency prevents proper plant structure that will hold the ground together and keep it healthy. It therefore leads to soil structure decline. It is very pleasing to learn from the reports that those particular aspects-I believe for the first time-are being seriously looked at as part of the broad picture encompassed by the programs.

I come back to the prime purpose in raising this matter of public interest today. I think there is an opportunity to coordinate the two programs, get them under the auspices of one active committee, and maximise the dollars and cents that are currently being put into programs so that they are much more effective. I believe the whole issue of soil conservation or land care, whichever one wants to call it-they are really one and the same thing-is above party politics at this time. If the Government is serious about cutting out duplication, this is a wonderful opportunity for it to do so.

I raise another point very briefly. I am bitterly disappointed that today Mr Justice Maddern of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission refused to hear the SPC Ltd case even though there is an agreement between employers and employees about the direction to take. The people involved are going to have a very sad Christmas and my sympathy goes out to them.

I believe the handling of this situation shows the inadequacy of the current Industrial Relations Act. Certainly I do not accept Senator Cook's explanation that it can be handled under section 115 because that spells out quite clearly that there has to be a dispute before a matter can be heard. Obviously in this case, because there is agreement, there is no dispute.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 November in the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) I raised a series of questions with the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) concerning allegations of fraud on the construction of Royal Australian Air Force base Tindal in the Northern Territory and concerning the redeployment of Tindal staff of Australian Construction Services. On that date the Minister was not able to provide me with answers and he subsequently wrote to me in a letter that I received on 6 December providing certain information.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not surprised that the Minister did not choose to table that information in the Senate and make it publicly available in the Hansard. So I intend to read the two answers into the record and then to comment on them. With regard to Tindal fraud Senator Bolkus replied to me in the following terms:
Details relating to allegations of fraud at Tindal RAAF base were requested and I have answered the questions as adequately as possible given the stage that proceedings are at.
Based on advice, the thrust of my answer was:
Allegations of fraudulent practice by both contractors and ACS employees have been made over a period of time and have been given quite a deal of publicity.
Every allegation has been thoroughly investigated by either or a combination of:
- internal departmental inquiry
- DAS fraud control unit
- Australian Federal Police
- State police
The upshot is that charges have been laid against one contractor and one ex-ACS employee and the matter is currently before the courts.
A committal hearing for the contractor has been set for 6-7 December 1990 and for the ACS employee for 26-27 January 1991.
Further discussion may be sub judice and, as I have said before, investigations are continuing and the possibility of further charges cannot be ruled out.
Once the investigation is fully resolved I will provide the specific details requested such as:
- how many officers were involved
- how many contractors were investigated, and
- how many employees were counselled or disciplined
When court proceedings are finalised further details may be provided.
In connection with the redeployment of Australian Construction Services Tindal staff, Senator Bolkus replied in the following terms:
A number of questions about the redeployment of ACS staff previously associated with the Tindal project were raised.

I am advised that there is no connection between the redeployment of staff from the Tindal project and any allegations of fraudulent activities there. Staff located on the Tindal project site peaked at 60. Of course more than 60 people were employed on site over the project's full duration but some of these were contract staff and others were Auslig employees.
It should be noted that the numbers of people engaged on a project such as this build up and taper off over a period of time. In fact there is still one officer engaged on site.
Having carried out some research into the questions my Department now advises that to the present date of those staff engaged on the project at Tindal:
- 11 have voluntarily resigned
- 22 transferred to positions in the Public Service in other locations as follows:
- 7 to Adelaide
- 8 to Darwin
- 1 to Alice Springs
- 1 to New South Wales
- 1 to Victoria
- 1 to Tasmania
- 3 to Katherine
- 4 returned to Adelaide after term transfer to Tindal
- 1 has been promoted to a position in the Public Service in another location (Canberra)
- 5 accepted voluntary retrenchment packages in 1989.
In addition one officer was offered a transfer to a position in Adelaide but refused. He is now the subject of action under the Redeployment and Retirement (Redundancy) Award 1987.
In addition to staff located on site at Tindal a number of staff located in the Adelaide office were engaged on the Tindal project. Of these there have been:
- 19 voluntary resignations
- 5 age retirees
- 1 invalidity retiree
- 50 remaining in Adelaide
In addition to the foregoing some Darwin based staff also worked on the project. Of these:
- 1 transferred to Canberra
- 1 transferred to Tasmania
- 2 voluntarily resigned

The number of Australian Construction Services employees therefore identified in the Minister's answer is 123, and I appreciate that the Minister indicated that the general workload peaked at 60. However, in linking the issue of fraud and the matters that needed to be investigated, I am concerned to note from the information provided that of the 123 identified employees 33 have since resigned, five have been retrenched and one is subject to redundancy.

So if I add together the resignations and the retrenchments they are of the order of 30 per cent-27 per cent have resigned and 3 per cent have been retrenched at this stage only one employee has been charged with regard to the allegations of fraud. It causes one to wonder about the 33 who have since resigned. We need to know: were they forced to resign in lieu of being prosecuted for serious offences? The fact that 23 other employees transferred interstate should not be overlooked either. Next year during the Estimates I will be pursuing the large number of employees over whom there now hangs a cloud with regard to their bona fides in the conduct of this major Australian Construction Services project.

In addition, I am informed that a number of service personnel employed in the Department of Defence are also under investigation with regard to fraud allegations and that either Defence or public prosecutions could also be laid. It is a serious matter when such a high proportion of employees have obviously been subjected to questioning. It will be interesting to note Senator Bolkus's subsequent replies with regard to investigations as to how many departmental and service officers were involved, how many contractors were investigated and how many employees were counselled or disciplined.

In recent days a number of other issues relating to the Australian Construction Services have been raised in this chamber by my colleagues Senator Parer and Senator Newman in particular. Obviously, Australian Construction Services has not operated as an efficient organisation. The fact that it has had the carriage of large contracts and large sums of taxpayers' funds is something that the Senate needs to keep under close scrutiny and it needs to ensure total accountability.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: -You looked a little surprised, Mr Acting Deputy President, when I rose for the call. I am not on the list of speakers, but I did not have an opportunity to raise a matter last night so I am taking the opportunity now.

SPEECH.PARA: During the last two to three weeks the Government has been attempting to convince us of the seriousness of its fight against welfare fraud as it has been pushing the data matching legislation through this chamber. It was rushed through the House of Representatives and then rushed in here. It has had scrutiny but was passed last night with, I believe, the minimum of attention. During that time, the Government was telling us that it was serious about its fight against welfare fraud.

It was timely that during this week the Auditor-General's report on the operation of the Department of Social Security's telephone rental concession scheme was tabled in the Senate. The reason I want to speak on it here is that rather than just having that document as a tabled document there should be on the public record an analysis and a description of the sorts of things that the Auditor-General was highlighting.

This report is very scathing of the lack of accountability and monitoring that occurs during the administration of this scheme. The Auditor-General found that neither DSS nor Telecom Australia was willing to accept primary ownership of the scheme and that there was no clear designation of responsibilities between the two organisations. It was found that the scheme fails to ensure that the concession is paid only to eligible pensioners and beneficiaries.

In this day and age when we are trying to direct benefits and target them it seems odd that there is such sloppiness in the administration of this benefit. The major problem seems to be that the present system does not prevent vouchers from being used for the payment of telephone accounts which are not in the name of the eligible beneficiary. The Auditor-General's testing of a sample of Victorian vouchers found that 20 per cent of those vouchers had been credited to telephone accounts that did not relate to the eligible beneficiary. He noted that if his sample results were extended nationally it would mean that $8m of the scheme's $40m annual expenditure is being illegitimately claimed. As annual expenditure on the scheme is now over $46m a national extension of the Auditor-General's findings would actually mean that over $9m is being misappropriated annually.

The cause of the problem is a lack of sufficient checking of an applicant's eligibility for the concession. If applicants put a contact phone number on their benefit application they are automatically considered eligible for the telephone rental concession if there is no known evidence to the contrary. There is no requirement to provide a recent telephone account as evidence that the phone number which has been furnished relates to a service that is held in the name of the applicant.

The inability of the Department of Social Security to check applicants' eligibility for the concession is heightened by the fact that its household income test is, in the words of the Auditor-General, not capable of effective implementation. In other words, it is impossible for DSS to check if the income of the household where the concession is being claimed is below the $215 per week threshold.

The Auditor-General also found that the present system is incapable of ensuring that those people who are eligible for the concession receive and make use of the correct concession. Generally only one voucher should be accepted for credit against any one telephone account. The Auditor-General found cases of six vouchers being credited against the account of a non-DSS client and three vouchers being credited to a company telephone account. Although the DSS manual does not permit the use of prior year's vouchers, the Auditor-General found that payments of over $1m were made against prior year's vouchers in 1989.

The Auditor-General also found numerous examples of where multiple vouchers were tendered with the payment of a single account. He also found many cases where vouchers were accepted for credit against accounts where the details of the voucher did not accord with the details of the account. The problem of vetting the use of vouchers has been exacerbated by an inadequate control and monitoring of the custody and issue of the replacement vouchers.

Examples of inadequate control and monitoring include failure to record the number of vouchers issued, failure to stamp replacement vouchers, failure to check an applicant's eligibility for replacement vouchers on the DSS on-line inquiry facility, failure to include the issue of replacement vouchers on updated computer records and failure to include the person's pensioner or beneficiary number on the register of manual issues-a litany of failures.

The Government might have some excuse if these accusations were being made for the first time. But as far back as 1976-77 the Auditor-General found that ineligible people were receiving the concession and that DSS could not verify that Telecom's claims for reimbursement included only eligible recipients. A working party considered the matter between September 1983 and January 1985 but could not agree on how it should be changed.

After the Joint Committee of Public Accounts expressed concern about these unresolved matters Cabinet convened a second working party and a revised scheme began in January 1988. I would hate to work out how much all these reviews and committees cost. Then in April 1988 DSS's own audit branch found that vouchers were being issued to people who were not entitled to them and that DSS staff were not adequately briefed on eligibility criteria. The report of this latest audit says:

The matters now raised . . . indicate that deficiencies still exist in the Telephone Rental Concession voucher system and that the new system has not overcome the principal deficiencies in the old system.

One of the particular concerns for me as a member of the Senate in reading this report, and particularly for those of us who support the law making role of the Parliament, is the fact that since the introduction of the new Telecommunications Corporation Act last year the telephone rental concession has had no legislative basis.

In his report the Auditor expresses concern that there is no overriding legislation despite the amount of expenditure involved and the fact that both Telecom and DSS have shown a lack of willingness to redress deficiencies. As the Auditor has stated:
DSS believes that the key responsibility for ensuring the integrity of the voucher system rests with Telecom.

On the other hand, Telecom `is willing to accept responsibility only where the voucher indicates clearly the telephone account for which it was issued'. This week I gave notice of a motion to urge the Government to take immediate action to rectify the ongoing but fundamental problems entailed in the administration of this scheme. Because of the embarrassment it would cause the Government, this motion obviously will not ever see the light of day except on the Notice Paper.

The Government cannot fob off this report. It must set up an inquiry to ascertain the amount that has been lost and what, if anything, can be done to recoup this money. The telephone rental concession scheme should be enshrined in legislation. The responsibilities of DSS and Telecom must be clearly specified in a formal agreement between them, and the Auditor-General has made a number of pertinent recommendations which have the potential to improve drastically the efficiency of the scheme without imposing an exorbitant financial or human resource burden on either DSS or Telecom. These recommendations should be examined forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the Government's response to the report of the National Committee on Violence and seek leave to incorporate a statement in Hansard and move to take note of the documents.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The National Committee on Violence was established as a result of an agreement between the Commonwealth, State and Northern Territory Governments at the Premiers' meeting on gun control held in December 1987. The catalyst for the establishment of the Committee was the tragic mass shootings which had occurred in Queen and Hoddle Streets in Melbourne.

The Committee presented its report to Governments at the end of January this year, and I released it publicly on behalf of the Commonwealth on 9 February. The report is the result of a year of intensive and productive work by the Committee. Its work program included community forums and committee meetings in all States and Territories, the analysis of hundreds of submissions and responses, a series of discussion papers covering different aspects of violence in Australia and, finally, the preparation of a wide-ranging report.

Before turning to the contents of that report I would like to take this opportunity to thank Professor Chappell, who chaired the Committee, the Committee members and the members of the Australian Institute of Criminology who provided the secretariat to the Committee. Without the dedicated work of all of these people we would not now have before us what I consider to be a blueprint for a less violent society. I thank and commend them all for their efforts.

The report is a comprehensive and detailed document which comprises some 138 recommendations. These cover a wide range of matters from long term initiatives to overcome the root causes of violence, such as employment and training initiatives, to support for victims of violence. It is made abundantly clear that just as there is no simple, single explanation for the causes of violence so there are no easy panaceas.

Implementation of the report will require a long term commitment, over several decades, by all levels of governments as well as by individuals and community organisations. For, the report stresses that the problem of violence cannot be left to governments acting alone. Rather, if we are to change community attitudes and create a less violent society, then the role of individuals and community organisations will also be central to the task.

This tabling statement then, and the Government response to the report which I will also be tabling, should not be seen as the end of the Government's response but as the beginning. The report provides us with recommendations and principles which will need to become, or remain as the case may be, important considerations in ongoing Government decision making. Of the Committee's recommendations, fewer than a quarter are specifically for Commonwealth consideration, although others will involve Commonwealth participation through, for example, Ministerial councils and, where the Commonwealth sees a national interest, it will encourage all jurisdictions to adopt a uniform approach through appropriate Ministerial councils.

The remainder of the recommendations deal with matters for consideration by State and Territory governments, local governments and by non-government organisations. State and Territory governments have each received a copy of the report and will be making their own assessments of relevant recommendations. The monitoring unit which I will be announcing later in this statement will have responsibility for ensuring that all nongovernment institutions are aware of those recommendations which are of relevance to themselves and, where appropriate, will seek to assist them in their task by providing a clearing house for information and by providing training seminars.
I now turn to those matters which are particularly for Commonwealth consideration.

I would like to start by noting how pleased I am to see that the Government is already on the right track in fulfilling many of the Committee's recommendations designed to correct the root causes of violence. Particularly in the areas of income support, education, training and the provision of opportunities for women, young people and Aboriginals we already have in place the types of measures which the Committee sees as central to reducing the incidence of violence in our society.
The report rates poverty as one of the more important causes of violence and notes at page 142:

``. . Most violent offenders, and victims of violence, are drawn from the disadvantaged strata of Australian society. The image which many people who are on low incomes have of themselves is one of worthlessness, expendability, or at best irrelevance. This self-image is reinforced if the person of economic disadvantage belongs to a minority group. Respectable paths to status or prestige are seen as barred too often. This translates into a search for dominance or anger, often expressed in self-destructive or outwardly aggressive behaviour.''; and

``The Committee considers that governments and oppositions should avoid the kind of political point-scoring which labels poor people as worthless bludgers. The Committee considers it a responsibility of the Federal Government to provide adequate income support for the most disadvantaged members of society . . . Evidence for the importance of adequate income support comes from countries which lack income support programs and where the level of violence is much higher.

This Government has given social justice enormous priority. That priority has been backed by action rather than words alone. In this respect much has already been done to curb the problems of violence and it is crucial that those policies are preserved in the future if Australia is to reduce the divisive and destructive results of the type of society which treats its disadvantaged people as worthless.

This year the Government took further steps to expand on its good record in relation to social justice issues. In particular it has introduced the active employment strategy. Job search allowance and Newstart provide financial assistance for the unemployed-while also providing them with the opportunity to retrain and acquire skills so that they are better equipped to compete in the job market.
These programs combined with the JET scheme, which assists sole parents to re-enter the work force, help people to live their lives with dignity, independence and most importantly, with self esteem.

The Government has also addressed poverty by increasing the opportunities for people to obtain a better education. It has developed a system of student allowances which has a genuine and achievable objective of promoting equality of educational opportunity.

In addition, the Government is promoting a better standard of living and financial independence for the disadvantaged through the social work service of the Department of Social Security; increases in the family allowance; the creation of a successful child support scheme which is helping to alleviate poverty amongst custodial parents and income related fee relief to ensure that low and middle income working families are not denied access to child care because of prohibitive fees.
These are but a few of the initiatives which the Government has taken in addressing the social injustices which the Committee has identified as important underlying causes of violence.
It is clear however that there is still much to be done and that there can be no grounds for complacency.
To me perhaps the most horrifying findings of the Committee were the vulnerability to children to violence, with infants up to one-year-old being the age group at greatest risk of homicide.

While child abuse is an issue which is the responsibility of the States and Territories, the Government believes that this is such an important issue that it is appropriate to complement their efforts.
The Government has decided to tackle the issue of violence against children as the corner-piece of its initial response to the report.
I am thus pleased to announce that Cabinet has given in-principle approval to the development over the next 3 financial years of a national campaign against child abuse.

The campaign will build on the Government's social justice initiatives which have already done so much to alleviate child poverty through income support measures and will reinforce the Government's efforts to improve opportunities for children. It will also be extremely timely in view of Australia's ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child.

As well as tackling the problem of violence in society such a campaign will contribute towards alleviating problems which can lead to youth homelessness and will thus further the Government's commitment to tackling the problems identified in the Burdekin Report, ``Our Homeless Children''.

The campaign, details of which are still being developed, will concentrate on a primary child abuse message emphasising positive parenting and the unacceptability of violence. It will combine a vigorous education campaign which will reach a broad cross-section of the community with direct service delivery, through an expanded network of family skills centres, to targeted families. This later aspect of the campaign will build upon the Government's current family skills program which is designed to provide direct assistance and education to families suffering from problems such as sexual and physical abuse. The campaign, with its emphasis on parenting skills, is consistent with the approach put forward by the Council of Social Welfare Ministers, though it covers service delivery in addition to a media campaign. The Government supports the involvement of a joint Federal/State/Territory task force in the development of strategies for the campaign to ensure that it will not duplicate child abuse campaigns currently run by the States and Territories.

The additional funding will be directed towards increasing the number of family skills training centres, so that centres will exist in all jurisdictions, and developing a basic training package relating to positive parenting and non-violent problem solving which can be used directly with vulnerable families. Add on components to the training package will be developed for professionals and community workers and for use with schools, health services, community organisations and self-help groups. In addition, a vigorous education campaign using selective print media, video tapes and workshops will also be developed.

The actual services will be located within established Government-funded family organisations which have public acceptance and can provide back-up services. The entire package will have the advantage of enhancing the autonomy and resources of the family to deal with tensions in a constructive non-violent way while respecting and promoting its integrity and survival as a social unit.

I am sure that honourable senators will agree with me that, in providing as many families as possible with these basic skills in positive parenting and non-violent conflict resolution, we can make a significant contribution to breaking the cycles of violence which currently cause so much misery and emotional and physical damage to the children who are the potential of this country. For, it is quite clear that improving family skills is regarded as critical in arresting the inter-generational cycle of emotional deprivation, violence and abuse.

As I indicated earlier, the Committee's recommendations cover a wide range of topics and are addressed to numerous organisations and bodies. Because of the number of bodies involved and the complex interaction of the numerous recommendations the Commonwealth will be establishing a monitoring unit within the Australian Institute of Criminology from 1 January 1991 for a two year period.

Amongst other things the unit will organise seminars and act as a clearing house in relation to material relevant to the implementation of the report. This will ensure that both government and non-government bodies can learn from the initiatives of others and will help avoid needless duplication of research and activities.
At the same time the unit will have the effect of maintaining low-key pressure on the various bodies to persevere with the issues covered in the report.
The unit demonstrates the Commonwealth's long-term commitment to the implementation of the recommendations of the report.

In preparing its report the National Committee on Violence divided its recommendation into areas of government and non-government responsibility. The Commonwealth's full response to all recommendations is included in its response which I am tabling in conjunction with this statement. I would like now, however, to comment briefly on the Commonwealth's response to some of those recommendations which touch upon its areas of responsibility.

I noted at the beginning of this statement that the Committee arose out of the Premiers' meeting on gun control. In the section of the report which puts forward recommendations for public sector agencies involved with criminal law the Committee has made a number of important recommendations relating to gun control. It sees these recommendations as central to its strategy for a less violent Australia. The Commonwealth has urged effective uniform national gun control laws on the States and Territories both at the Premiers' meeting, which led to the establishment of the Committee, and through the Australian Police Ministers' Council, and will continue to do so. It must be recognised though that the Commonwealth does not have the Constitutional power to impose its preferred position. Nevertheless, it has implemented strict controls on the disposal of surplus military weapons and a ban on sales of semi-automatic firearms to members of the public from the small arms factory at Lithgow (Recommendation 55.1) and, under the auspices of the Police Minister's Council, has developed a generic statement of firearms approved for importation (Recommendation 55.2).

I consulted widely on the development of this generic statement over the past year and, in November, Australian Police Ministers (apart from the New South Wales Minister) unanimously adopted the statement as a national policy relating to the importation of firearms. Apart from clearly setting out allowable imports, the statement is significant in that it prohibits the importation of all military firearms, such as Chinese military rifles, other than for official purposes. The statement of permitted firearms imports will be incorporated into the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations in the near future.

The National Committee on Violence has recommended (Recommendation 55.3) that rifle clubs established under the Defence Act be placed within the ambit of State Licensing and Registration requirements. Honourable senators will recall that legislation to remove the special status of defence rifle clubs, and place them under the jurisdiction of State gun laws, was disallowed by this chamber. However, it remains the Government's view that the legislation governing defence rifle clubs is an anachronistic and unnecessary use of defence powers.

Another important aspect of the Committee's work is its identification of the complex relationship between the consumption of alcohol and violence. In the section of the report directed at health and welfare authorities there are several recommendations aimed at reducing the consumption of alcohol, including by an increase in the excise differential between high and low alcohol beer. The Commonwealth has already taken action in this regard. The Government's reforms to the taxation structure of beer announced in the 1988-89 Budget significantly widened the excise differential between low and high alcohol beer with excise now based on alcoholic content. There is now little scope to influence the relative price of low and high alcohol beer by further reducing the excise payable on low alcohol beer since to reduce it further would make low alcohol beer comparable in price to soft-drinks and could encourage the use of alcohol.

The Commonwealth has also taken steps to ensure that marketing and advertising of alcohol encourages responsible use. The Commonwealth will be taking up with industry, in the context of the national health policy on alcohol, the Committee's recommendation that health warnings should be placed on alcoholic beverage containers. Advertising is regulated by a voluntary code, which was recently reviewed in the context of the national policy on alcohol to incorporate community concerns. The revised code prohibits the advertising of alcohol in a way that strongly appeals to young people, promotes excessive drinking or associates alcohol with hazardous activities. The Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy, comprising Commonwealth, State and Territory Ministers responsible for health and law enforcement issues, has set up a committee to monitor the effectiveness of the revised code. Should the Committee find that voluntary regulation is unsatisfactory, consideration may need to be given to some form of mandatory control.

The Commonwealth appreciates the special problems the report raises about substance abuse within the Aboriginal community, and its association with violence. The report provides a package of recommendations designed to restore the pride of all Australians in the extraordinary richness of Aboriginal social and cultural traditions, and seeks to find solutions to substance abuse and the other diverse problems which lead to violence among Aboriginals. Some of these matters are currently under consideration by joint Commonwealth and State Aboriginal health bodies, and are also expected to be addressed in the context of the forthcoming report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. The new Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission will continue to fund public awareness and public information campaigns which reflect the objective of raising awareness of indigenous issues and society among all Australians.

In this regard, the Committee recommends the expansion of the Community Development Employment Program, under which Aboriginal communities may choose to forgo individual unemployment benefits in order to receive funds equivalent to the community's unemployment benefits plus an additional grant of 20 per cent of this amount. This fund then supplies wages to provide ongoing employment on community development projects for members of the community who would otherwise be unemployed. I am pleased to advise that the Government expanded the program in 1989-90. There are currently over 30,000 participants in the 130 community development programs operating in communities located from traditional lands in central Australia to the urban centres of coastal New South Wales.

In analysing who are the victims of violence the Committee found that they most commonly fall into two broad categories: ``men who engaged in altercations with other men and women and children who suffer at the hands of men with whom they have been living.''

The Commonwealth Government is continuing to intensively tackle the problem of domestic violence. It has allocated $2.1 million to community education on domestic violence through the National Domestic Violence Education Program and a further $1.35 million has been allocated for the next 3 years to continue work on violence against women.

Consistent with recommendation 45 of the report, the Commonwealth has undertaken a number of initiatives to assist people who are homeless as a result of domestic violence. The most recent is the extension of the supported accommodation assistance program (SAAP) to at least 1993-94, with a guaranteed level of Commonwealth and state funding. It is estimated that, as a result of the new SAAP agreements an additional $20 million will be spent from 1989-90 to 1991-92 by the Commonwealth and State/Territory governments for assistance for women who are homeless as a result of domestic violence. The Commonwealth also supports the recommendation (recommendation 46) that victims of domestic violence should be given priority in the allocation of emergency and low-cost accommodation.

The actions just outlined which the Commonwealth Government has taken in support of the Committee's recommendations are but a small percentage of our initiatives. The Government's response details other initiatives which have been taken in respect of recommendations covering such diverse topics as police and court procedures, violence in sport, violence and the media, environmental planning and victim toys.

There is a great deal more work to do to implement the recommendations of the report and achieve the type of non-violent society which I am sure all honourable senators would like to see in Australia in the 21st century. I believe, however, that the Commonwealth has made an excellent start and expect further results to flow from the work of the violence monitoring unit and from the consideration of these matters by Ministerial councils and by all levels of government.
The Committee has provided all Australians with a blueprint for a less violent society. It is now up to all of us to implement that blueprint.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the documents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a preliminary response to the Government's response to the report of the National Committee on Violence.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Almost two years ago, in February 1989, I addressed the National Committee on Violence in my then capacity as Shadow Minister for Justice.
On that occasion, I voiced the Opposition's concern about the level of violent crime in Australia and what seems to us to be an inadequate response by Governments.

Examples of the poor response by Governments include the decreasing real level of funding of the Institute of Criminology and the Criminology Research Council. I also noted that the apparent lack of adequate funding had imposed substantial restrictions on the capability of the Australian Federal Police to combat crime.

At the same time, there was no doubt that the rate of violent crime was on the increase. For example, in my home state of South Australia, since 1982 the rate of violent crime had increased by 102%, robberies were up 65%, serious assaults had increased by 151% and rapes and attempted rapes 109%.
I noted again that the police force was starved of funds.

The Federal Opposition does not regard the deterrent of likely apprehension and severe penalties as the total answer to criminal violence but we do regard it as a significant area which has been neglected.
I voiced the Opposition's hope that the Committee will report on deterrents-in terms of police resources, apprehension rates and penalties.

Another area in which the Opposition was particularly interested to learn the Committee's conclusions was that of domestic violence. In particular, we wished to learn the relationship between domestic violence and economic stress within a family as standards of living fall and government family support decreases; and we would be looking to the report to assist policy makers and legislators in that regard.

We were also particularly interested in the relationship between violent crime and alcohol. It was the Opposition's view that in the Government's ``Drug Offensive'' there had been insufficient emphasis upon alcohol abuse. My personal point of view was that I would like to see more of the enormous revenue gained by Government in alcohol taxes re-invested in sensible drinking education programs, detoxification and other treatment centres, in encouraging low alcohol products, and in protection of those abused.
Courts imposing lower sentences because offenders were intoxicated sends a totally wrong message, and I called for this practice to be remedied, by legislation if necessary.

I further noted the Government's neglect of the issue of illegal drugs and violent crime. It seems to the Opposition that the Government has totally underestimated the extent of importation of narcotics and is expecting the impossible from such bodies as Customs, the NCA and the AFP and State police forces. We need to place greater emphasis on policies to influence both supply and demand. On the one hand, we need education and rehabilitation programs to reduce demand, and on the other hand we need law enforcement and penalties to interrupt and deter supply.
This was another area in which the Opposition would be looking to the conclusions and recommendations of the Committee with particular interest.

In the context of these comments, the Opposition welcomed the commendably detailed report of the Committee, ``Violence: Directions for Australia'', which was tabled in May this year. One of the aspects of the report which is most laudable is that it is implementation-oriented; its 138 recommendations and conclusions are phrased in terms of the agencies which have responsibility for the various actions required.
The Government has, in the intervening seven months, come up with an exceptionally detailed 52-page response to the report and the Committee's recommendations.

The Opposition has not yet had the time to examine this response in the detail which it deserves. However, I would like to make some brief comments on the recommendations relating to some of the issues I have just mentioned and the Government's response to them.

The Opposition commends the Government's move in the 1988-89 budget to widen the excise differential between low and high alcohol beer. However, it should be noted that it was actually after this that the Committee recommended that the excise differential be increased so that low alcohol beer is significantly cheaper than high alcohol beer. The Committee would obviously not be satisfied with the Government's answer that the excise on low alcohol beer cannot be further reduced without making it comparable in price to soft drinks. I would call on the Government to exercise more ingenuity than is demonstrated here in its efforts to respond to the Committee's recommendations.

I think all Australians would share the Committee's horror that infants up to one year old are the group in our community at the greatest risk of homicide. The Committee has made a detailed examination of this type of violent crime, and has produced a number of recommendations which are aimed at decreasing the incidence of violence in families. Although these recommendations are principally the responsibility of State governments rather than the Commonwealth, we welcome the establishment of a national campaign for the prevention of child abuse.

The Opposition commends such moves by the Federal Government as the introduction of the National Domestic Violence Education Program, and the 40% increase in funding for the family services programs run by the Office of Legal Aid and Family Services.

However, we are disappointed that the Committee did not examine in greater detail the relationship between domestic violence and economic stress in the family, although the recommendations about the availability of respite child care for low income families, and a 008 hotline for advice for parents are peripherally related.

Another Committee recommendation is that the Commonwealth should sign and ratify the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. This Convention has in fact just been ratified, with the support of the Opposition. However, I must voice the Coalition's disappointment that the Government failed to make reservations about the need to respect the rights and responsibilities of parents towards their children in key areas. The Minister, Senator Tate, told the Senate on November 7 that he expected that Australia-like the Vatican-would make reservations about the need for the Convention to properly recognise the pre-eminent role of the family. The Convention's articles fail to accord parents the right and duty to provide guidance to children on the information they receive in their formative years and the associations they keep. It further fails to properly recognise the rights and responsibilities of parents regarding their children's educational, physical, social and moral development. We had called on the Government to lodge reservations safeguarding ``the inalienable rights of parents'' in regard to privacy, freedom of association, religion, education and freedom of expression, and we are extremely disappointed that the Government has chosen not to do so.

The Opposition had hoped that the Committee's report would focus to some extent on deterrents in relation to criminal violence, in terms of police resources, apprehension rates and penalties. We believe that increased penalties and increased likelihood of apprehension would have a significant effect on rates of criminal violence, and we are disappointed that the Committee has not made recommendations with respect to these matters.

I would also draw the Senate's attention to the Committee's recommendation that Governments should increase their contributions to the Criminology Research Council. The Government's response claims that the CRC's funding is now indexed to the cost of living, and is therefore maintained in real terms, but that the level of contributions is an issue to be decided each year in the Budget process. I would point out that the level of the Commonwealth's contribution in 1989 was a pitiful $125,000. The Opposition calls on the Government to do as the Committee recommends and actually increase this amount.

I note in passing that, in relation to the Committee's recommendations about legislation on firearms control, the Opposition agrees with the Government's response to recommendation 54.1 that the responsibility for such legislation should remain with the States.

The National Committee on Violence has produced a report which merits the detailed consideration of governments at the Federal, State and local levels, as well as many other bodies, agencies and individuals in the Australian community. The Opposition supports the Government in its recognition that the implementation of the report requires a long term commitment, of which this debate is just the very beginning. There is, as the Minister says, still much to be done. We share the hope that all responsible Australians will co-operate in facing the enormous challenge ahead of us to bring about a less violent society.
Debate (on motion by Senator Hill) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition basically supports the introduction of the Australian Sports Drug Agency Bill for one very sound reason and that is that the Opposition joins with the Government in opposing the use of performance enhancing drugs in sport. In other words, we oppose cheating-cheating on one's fellow athletes, cheating on one's nation, cheating on one's supporters.

SPEECH.PARA: We also oppose performance enhancing drugs because in fact they are instruments of death. As the reports of the Senate committee on drugs in sports clearly indicated, the massive development of drugs in sport-in an organised way in some countries, particularly in the former eastern bloc in Europe-has led to disastrous, horrific consequences among those athletes who take them.

So this Bill seeks to establish as a statutory authority the Australian Sports Drug Agency, which in effect has been operating for some time, as a response to the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts drugs in sport inquiry which was headed by former Labor Senator John Black. Other members of the Committee were yourself, Mr Acting Deputy President, Senator John Coates, Senator Bob Collins, Senator John Coulter, Senator Julian McGauran, Senator John Panizza and Senator Olive Zakharov. The reports of that committee were issued last year. When issued, the reports generated a very large amount of controversy and there has been much debate in this chamber about the subject.

The question facing us is whether this Bill is entirely the right way to go about resolving the problem that both the Government and the Opposition recognise exists and that we both agree calls for action. In the main, the Opposition agrees with the Government. We do have, however, a couple of specific problems and one of them is this: the Sports Drug Agency is yet another governmental statutory authority being set up, but in this case it is being set up because self-regulation, particularly by amateur sporting bodies, has failed to prevent the widespread use of performance enhancing drugs. On the contrary, there was plenty of evidence before the Senate drugs in sport inquiry that some officials in amateur sports were actively encouraging the use of performance enhancing drugs, in many instances, it seemed, because of the level of funding.

Particularly while the Government uses an elite funding approach whereby funding depends heavily on performance or the prospect of performance, the use of these drugs certainly appears to have been encouraged or at least a blind eye was turned. Some of the evidence in that drugs in sport inquiry, particularly that about some of the power lifting and weightlifting, was quite dreadful.

It is unacceptable that amateur sporting bodies have not demonstrated in so many instances-I am not saying universally-the willingness, the determination, to stamp out the killer drugs that are used to enhance performance or in fact any performance enhancing drugs. That is one of the reasons we strongly take the view that this organisation should exist as a governmental body only so long as the sporting associations continue to be incapable of policing their own activities. This function could and should properly be performed by a non-governmental body. That is if, of course, the sporting community overall were prepared to face up to its full responsibilities.

If that were to take place, if the sporting community itself would do it, who would cover the cost? I would suggest that in that situation any responsible government would ensure that the costs of testing were made available to the sporting bodies so that they would be properly covered. But it is the Government itself that will be running an organisation which has the capacity to earn money by testing for professional sports like rugby league and so on where in fact it has been with great success conducting revenue raising activities. In this context it seems curious that this body should be seen to be, in perpetuity, a governmental body.

For that reason we take the view that there should be a three-year sunset clause in this legislation and not because we want to see the body wiped out. On the contrary, we want to see the body run by the people who ought to be running it and that is the purpose of the sunset clause. In fact, we are proposing a sunset clause so that the matter can be reviewed on our coming to office after the next election.

That is the purpose of the sunset clause-not to do away with the organisation but to ensure that the organisation is run by the most appropriate people to run it, and that is not the Government. The less the Government has its clammy fingers in things the better as far as the Opposition is concerned, particularly in an area where there is every prospect of an efficient, well-run organisation-as this is, I might say, at the moment-being able to raise revenue in large amounts from a whole range of bodies requiring testing.

In fact, because the local organisation, the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories, has International Olympic Committee accreditation-as I understand it, it is the only organisation in our region to have that accreditation-it then has the opportunity of earning revenue from drug testing in the whole of our region. It may well be a useful earner of foreign exchange.

The fact-and I must stress this because there has been some misunderstanding among some people in the sporting community-is that the purpose of our sunset clause is not to wipe out the body but so that when we come into government after the next election we can review whether or not the sporting community has developed the determination to face up to its proper responsibilities to ensure that its own house is in order. I regret that at this stage we simply cannot say that its house is in order, and the Senate committee demonstrated that to be so.

We also have a bit of a problem about privacy. I will not go into that at great length other than to say that the present arrangements are rather curious in that if someone has shown a positive result to a test his or her name will not be made available. So if a football team was tested and half the team was found to be positive, the following week half of that football team would not be on the paddock-with no explanation.

The problem that stems from that is that at any time some highly performed athlete, whether it is a footballer or anyone else, does not turn up to participate or is left out of a team, there will be the inference, unfortunately because of this legislation and this privacy requirement, that he or she has failed a drug test. I think that is a most unfortunate consequence of the privacy aspect of this legislation. While I understand that there are benefits in privacy, there are also disadvantages.

I also have a little bit of a problem about the fact that Senator Richardson at one stage suggested that the reason this Bill was not coming forward was some sort of hesitancy or reluctance on the part of the Opposition to have it come forward. On 13 November Senator Richardson made that suggestion in an Appropriation debate and it is utter bunkum. At least he did have the courtesy to say that if that suggestion was wrong he would apologise. I am waiting for him to apologise.

The facts are that this Bill was so delayed by an incompetent Government opposite that it came to this chamber after the cut-off date for legislation to come to this chamber.
