In fact, we had to pass a special enabling motion this morning to enable this very important piece of legislation to come in. Mr Acting Deputy President, you and I took the strong position at the time when Senator Richardson made those remarks that we wanted this legislation in before we got up, despite the heavy program, because we wanted to send the right signal to the sporting community and to young athletes that both the Government and the Opposition were very serious about stamping out drugs in sport. I am glad that the Government has brought this legislation forward even though it is at a very rushed time in the lunch hour when we cannot have divisions.

Another point I wish to make is that we want to move amendments in the committee stage-and I regret to say that the committee stage may now have to be deferred until tomorrow-removing the restriction on people over 65 being on the agency. This is the usual amendment we move. We are opposed to age discrimination. I hope that the Australian Democrats, who recently put out a press release supporting the removal of the age discrimination clause from the pharmacy legislation, will join us in this matter.

In conclusion, I repeat that the coalition strongly supports the thrust of this legislation and supports the creation of the Sports Drug Testing Agency. Our only reservation is about the manner in which it should conduct itself if and when the amateur athletics organisations demonstrate that they are capable of looking after their own shop and making certain that their own sports are clean.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to state from the beginning that the Australian Democrats unequivocally support the Australian Sports Drug Agency Bill and the motives behind it. We congratulate the Government on its actions in establishing the Australian Sports Drug Agency and we fully support the efforts being put into the testing for all forms of performance enhancing drugs. We therefore hope that we will be able to see its passage through some time today.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to spend a bit of time now on the foreshadowed Liberal amendments, of which there are a number, beginning with the proposed sunset clause that Senator Michael Baume has just been dealing with. My reading of this clause and my understanding of this issue, coming into this place after 20 years of physical education teaching, is that it would effectively wipe out the effect of this whole Bill. While I understand that it may not totally destroy it, we believe that it would severely reduce the effectiveness of the body. It really puts us back to square one.

I cannot see how the amateur sports would be able either to raise sufficient funds or to organise the administration of the testing themselves through this body if government support was effectively withdrawn. We understand that the Opposition has philosophical problems with the establishment of another government instrumentality but in this particular case we have no such problems and therefore will be opposing this amendment.

I would like to move on to two other amendments. Unfortunately Senator Crichton-Browne was not able to speak before I spoke, but I understand that he is going to be proposing the other two amendments that have been circulated. These are about the disclosure of confidential information. There are quite persuasive arguments both ways regarding the disclosure of names of athletes whose names have been placed on the register of positive tests.

There would probably be a deterrent effect if athletes were certain that their names would be splashed about in the media. However, the Democrats believe that a carrot rather than a stick approach should be considered and believe that the education functions of the agency, particularly in schools, will go a long way to changing our future athletes' perceptions regarding drug use.

There is also a concern for athletes who test positive after unintentional or inadvertent use of legal substances, such as medicines-or indeed coffee, as we saw not so long ago-that contain some level of substances which are in fact on the banned list.

On balance, the Democrats believe that protection of privacy of the athlete, and particularly of the athlete's family members, in general overrides other considerations. There should be no public crucifixion of athletes, especially before they are dealt with by the ruling bodies of their own sports. The intent of the legislation is quite rightly to solve the problems of cheating by the use of performance enhancing substances.

But we note that there is already in the legislation the possibility for the Minister to obtain information and, if it is appropriate, for her or him to release information about substance abuse by any particular athlete. This means could be used to cause speculation about particular athletes or teams and we would hope that the Minister would handle this with the utmost discretion. The Democrats therefore believe this matter has been dealt with with a sensitive and fair balance and will be opposing the Opposition amendments on this issue.

Senator Baume foreshadowed an amendment regarding the exclusion, as it stands now, of people over the age of 65. Our concern has been, and continues to be, that these people are not covered under the Comcare legislation. We had thought that the whole problem regarding Comcare had been overcome when Senator Tate agreed to an amendment similar to this in previous legislation in the community services and health portfolio last week. However, it seems that now the Government has indicated it will not be supporting the amendment and has indeed changed its mind.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! To mark the retirement from the Senate of Senator Peter Baume, who has been a distinguished Temporary Chairman of Committees in addition to his other contributions to the Senate, I propose, with the concurrence of the Senate, that he take the chair at the beginning of tomorrow's sitting. This was a privilege that I extended to Senator Hamer upon his retirement. Is leave granted for this proposal?

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to yesterday's Cabinet decision not to make a decision on the proposed resource security legislation. I ask the Minister: why was a decision not made? To provide all participants in the resources area with some certainty, when will a decision be made? Does the Minister still support the proposed resource security legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposals which have been discussed in Cabinet thoughtfully and intelligently were discussed in a rather ill-conceived and misinformed way in the press. Senator Baume, not being a fly on the wall in Cabinet, presumably relies on the press. Those matters will be dealt with by Cabinet in the new year.

ANSWER.PARA: I just want to make the point that if a proposal for a specific resource development project is brought forward by a State government seeking Commonwealth action to assist security of wood resource for that project, it will be given prompt consideration. Senator Baume would well know that the Government has the Resource Assessment Commission and ecologically sustainable development processes looking at the longer term context of these issues but these processes do not prevent the Government dealing with individual resource development proposals, if brought forward.

I certainly embrace the importance of resource security for forest-based companies. The methodology of obtaining that resource security will be announced by the Government at the appropriate time early in the new year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for letting us have the benefit of the thoughtful discussions that led to no decision. I ask the Minister, in view of his response about the prompt consideration that would be given to any individual recommendation: when does Cabinet next intend to sit to deal with such individual matters? Will the Minister indicate whether the inability to make a decision is leaving uncertainty hanging over the industry? Is the lack of a decision simply a further indication that the Government is bereft of strong and stable leadership?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —One surviving element of Senator Baume's intellectual capacity is to conclude anything that he wants on the basis of any piece of--
—Come on, it's Christmas time.

—Well, it is Christmas time and the Opposition is going to bring forward a nasty matter of public importance today. Fancy that-fancy criticising stability in the leadership of the Government at Christmas time! What a dreadful, miserable lot honourable senators opposite are. This is the main item on the agenda when we have little time in which to deal with the legislative program. Honourable senators opposite are alleging instability when there is none and when that is what they have themselves.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Baume asked about individual matters which I referred to in my original answer. There is no proposal currently for an investment in this industry in respect of which--

TALK.START.PARA: —You're not going to make one. You don't know what the rules are.
—Order! The honourable senator has asked a supplementary question.

— Senator Baume says that I do not know what the rules are. There is no proposal at the current time before this Government which relates to the issue of resource security. They are the individual matters. As I said in my original answer to Senator Baume, the Government recognises the importance of this and will deal with it at the appropriate time. I was saying to the honourable senator that it was not the appropriate time.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator then asked me when Cabinet will sit. I do not have my diary with me. But, with the greatest respect, I am not sure that that is anything terribly to do with the honourable senator. I think Cabinet will sit--

TALK.START.PARA: —It has to do with people who have applications.

—No applications, Senator. I do not know when Cabinet will sit. I think the next meeting of Cabinet will be in about the middle of January. There will be further meetings in late January and February.
—Did you get rolled by Richo?

— No, nobody got rolled by anybody yesterday. We had a very thoughtful discussion about it all. Senator Richardson, I might say, was in full flight in the course of the discussion. In fact, I think we agreed to have a cup of coffee to talk about it. The real question is: who will pay?

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Baume alleges indecision as a result of all this. I referred to a thoughtful process of discussion and decision making. That is what we have. It is no good making from the hip decisions about many of these difficult issues. That has never been the style of this Government and it will not be now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Defence advise the Senate whether the Government has made a decision concerning the Jindalee over-the-horizon radar network.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Jindalee project is the final major capital item arising out of the Government's adoption of the defence strategy contained in the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities and the White Paper in 1987. Along with the Anzac frigates, the FA Hornets and the Collins class submarines, the Jindalee over-the-horizon radar network project will substantially enhance our defence self-reliance. The project will cost over $900m and includes the prime contract, four years maintenance, support and other assorted costs.

ANSWER.PARA: After carefully considering the competitive tenders in the extensive selection process, the Government has chosen Telecom Australia as the preferred tenderer. We will now negotiate with Telecom on the details of the innovative risk sharing contract which will provide incentives for cost minimisation and high performance.

The Jindalee project has a local content of 70 per cent, which the addition of the defence offsets will provide Australian industry involvement of around 80 per cent. The completion of this project in the mid-1990s will give Australia a state-of-the-art radar surveillance system, enabling us to detect air and sea targets up to 2,000 kilometres from our shore.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to the Treasurer's rejection of calls from those of his ministerial colleagues he terms the `new interventionists' for new industry assistance measures. I ask the Minister: does he concur with the views of the Treasurer or does he agree with the reported statements of his colleague the Minister for Community Services and Health supporting an increased emphasis on export assistance schemes, which Mr Howe described as the most important issue in the life of the Parliament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the honourable senator say Mr Howe or Mr Howard?
—Mr Howe.

—Mr Howard has also described it as very important. People sometimes have discussions about these issues in Cabinet, shadow Cabinet or in public. About a month ago Mr Howard made a point in a press release, which I do not have with me at the moment, about the importance of exports and the means of export assistance for major exporting firms.
—Not enhancement programs.

—Well, I am talking about what he said. The honourable senator can find out. Honourable senators opposite talk about leadership. They do not even know what their former Leader is saying. I suppose that is no longer relevant. They do not even know what their present Leader is saying.
—Are you in favour of enhancement programs?

—This question is in the same category as most questions that we get from this Opposition-it is singularly simplistic. To my mind this is what fits honourable senators opposite for being in opposition forever.
—Are you a new interventionist?
—Senator Hill wants to say that a person either is a new interventionist or is not a new interventionist.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Hill interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that, but the simplicity of the question is mind-boggling. The point is that I am not going to be fixed with labels of that kind by anybody. Senator Alston has already drawn a conclusion from what I said and Senator Baume has drawn another one. I reckon Opposition senators ought to have a party meeting to talk about it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence. I refer to an answer the Minister gave to a question from Senator Loosley on 12 December in which, in part, the Minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . Mr Uren regularly briefed former Prime Minister Fraser on internal divisions within the Labor Party.
In view of Mr Uren's refutation of this most serious charge, will the Minister now substantiate his charge or withdraw this slur on Mr Uren's reputation and apologise?
Opposition senators interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Some of us want to hear the answer.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is typical of the Opposition to react like this to what I think is a quite legitimate question from Senator Childs. I read the Senate Standing Committee of Privileges report yesterday. I have also read the comments of Mr Fraser, and even he would refute what was contained in the Privileges Committee report. I still regard the matter as not fully clarified in my own mind on the evidence available to me. Naturally, when this matter comes up for debate during the discussion of Committee reports in the first week of the new sitting session, I will be commenting on Mr Uren's remarks and stating my views.

ANSWER.PARA: I conclude by saying that I find it amazing that Mr Uren's remarks could be so contrasted in two Melbourne newspapers this morning. One newspaper gave one account and another newspaper gave a totally different account. The distortion which has occurred, even in relation to my remarks in the Senate about Mr Uren-which I do not withdraw-and the selective publicity that was given to that, is a very poor reflection on the reporting of that matter at the time.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under standing order 72(2) I seek leave to ask Senator Cooney a question in his capacity as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills.

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I ask Senator Cooney what the Committee has achieved in the recent parliamentary session in terms of improving the legislation which it has considered.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This answer begins with a phrase that is new to the Senate- I thank Senator Bourne for her question. I give this answer on behalf of the Committee, the members of which include Senator Vanstone--
—Some distinguished former members.

—It had some distinguished former members, who are no longer there, unfortunately. Also on the Committee are Senator Sherry, Senator Macdonald, may I say the formidable Senator Crowley, and Senator Bourne herself. So, although I appear as Senator Cooney, I am really the Committee heavily disguised as Senator Cooney. On that basis, I thank Senator Bourne again for her question, to which I can provide only a rough and general answer, though I do have some facts and figures to back me up.

ANSWER.PARA: In the course of the current parliament, the Committee has examined some 213 Bills both from the Government and from private members and senators. Of those Bills the Committee has commented on just under one-half-100 of them to be exact; we made a century. The Committee's comments on these Bills have ranged across the whole spectrum of its terms of reference. I believe that the success or otherwise of the Committee is evident in several ways. Firstly, the most tangible measure of the Committee's success is the number of amendments--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I think the honourable senator is debating the matter and I ask you to call him to order.
—In view of the fact that it was a Christmas question I will allow him to continue.

—Mr President, it is not a debate; I am just laying the foundations for the answer. I was told by the person who prepared this answer that it would not take long. The first and most tangible measure of the Committee's success is the number of amendments moved and passed as a result of the concerns expressed by the Committee. In the short time available to me I can only draw attention to the ones which have actually been passed. If Senator Ray had given me more time I could have given further examples. In this regard I refer to the States Grants (Higher Education Funding) Bill 1990, which was amended on the motion of the Government; the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill 1990 and the Livestock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill 1990, which similarly were amended on a motion of the Government to require the tabling of certain guidelines; the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories (Conversion into Public Company) Bill 1990, a very important Bill which was amended on a motion of the Government to require that the annual report of CSL be tabled in the Parliament; the Australian Maritime Safety Authority Bill 1990, which was amended by the Senate; and the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1990, which was amended by the Senate to remove some retrospectivity to which the Committee had drawn attention. In this context I also note that the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1990 was referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs explicitly on the basis of comments made by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee.

ANSWER.PARA: The second way in which the Committee has been successful is in the sense that matters raised by the Committee as possible problems in Bills are not necessarily problems. In many cases, Ministers have responded to the Committee in terms which have allayed the Committee's concerns. Ministers have also assisted the Committee, and ultimately the Senate, by providing clarification or further information on matters raised by the Committee. In this sense, I draw attention to the assistance which has been recently forthcoming in relation--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Cooney, it is becoming a very long answer.

—Mr President, I have to put in this part: since Senator McMullan has come onto the scene we are getting perhaps a better response from Treasury than was formerly the case. In any event, I conclude by saying that this Committee has been most successful in scrutinising Bills for the Senate and giving a report on them.

ANSWER.PARA: This is not part of the answer, but I will conclude on this basis: I congratulate Senator Bourne on the question because it is one example of where the legislature, which we all purport to be, at Question Time does in fact have the ability to express its point of view, in contrast to what is normally the case where it is the Executive that is questioned and gives the answers. Although we accept the toing and froing which goes on across the chamber, this is one occasion where the legislature-Senator Lewis would agree with this-has its say.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that Senator Cooney table the papers from which he was quoting.
—by leave-I table the papers.

—Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware that the main opposition parties supporting democracy in Burma have formed a provisional government, known as the National Coalition Government of the Union of Burma, with the aim of removing the Burmese military regime and eventually handing over power to a national assembly? What is the Australian Government's attitude to the establishment of the provisional government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was announced a couple of days ago, on 18 December, that the National League for Democracy (NLD) and the Democratic Alliance of Burma have formed a provisional government, known as the National Coalition Government of the Union of Burma, based at Maneplaw in Burma. The provisional government is headed by Dr Sein Win, who was elected as an NLD candidate in the May national elections and is a cousin of the leader of the NLD, Aung San Suu Kyi, who has been under house arrest since July 1989.

ANSWER.PARA: Reports of the number of elected NLD representatives who have associated themselves with the provisional government vary from 10 to 50. Altogether, the NLD won 396 of the 485 seats contested in the May elections. Other members of the provisional government are associated with the Democratic Alliance of Burma, which comprises about 22 different ethnic, student and expatriate organisations. The Karen and Kachin independence movements are prominent members of the Democratic Alliance. The provisional government's claim to popular acceptance in Burma must depend largely on the number of representatives elected at the May elections who are prepared to support it.

On 7 December, the Secretary of the ruling SLORC-State Law and Order Restoration Council-accused sections of the NLD of planning to set up a parallel government on the border. By imprisoning most of the NLD's leadership and arresting at least 40 elected members, the military regime seems intent on bringing about the situation it most wants to avoid by giving the elected representatives of the NLD, who are not prepared to accept the regime's conditions, little alternative but to make their way to the border and declare themselves for the provisional government. In these circumstances, I am sure it is the case that the sympathies of the international community will remain with the elected representatives who have been so vigorously persecuted by their military rulers and denied their rightful place in a democratic government.

As to the specific Australian policy in relation to all of this, while the Australian Government has made known our concern over the repression of democracy in Burma, which has led to the announcement of this provisional government, the question of Australian recognition and support for the provisional government does not arise as, of course, it is now the case that Australia recognises states and not governments. We do consider that the establishment of a provisional government reflects the failure of the Burmese regime to honour the results of the May elections and the severe repression and intimidation that has been directed at the NLD, many of whose leaders have been arrested in recent months. We consider that the political crisis in Burma cannot be resolved without genuine democratic change. We call on the military regime in Burma to accede to the widespread popular desire for representative government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Resources to a farcical survey released by the Resource Assessment Commission claiming that Australians would be prepared to pay an average-and we all know how averages are calculated-amount of $52.80 to avoid mining in the Kakadu conservation zone. Does the Minister endorse the survey and its findings? Can he inform the Senate how much it cost and what contribution it will make to the economic development of this country?
—I find this a peculiar question. As the Minister representing the Minister for Resources I am invited to comment on an activity by the Resource Assessment Commission.
—It is out of order.
—I would be advised if it was out of order, but I can proceed to answer part of the question.
—A good try if you don't want to answer.

—I was about to answer the question. But if it is out of order that is a matter of importance. The Resource Assessment Commission is a body which is judicially separate from the affairs of government. Therefore, it operates according to its own charter as it perceives fairness, equity and justice in the particular matters it deals with. It has before it a reference concerning Coronation Hill and the conservation zone in the Northern Territory. It determines how it best proceeds to gather evidence and obtain opinion in order to make a judgment and offer advice to the Government. It is not appropriate for me to say any more than that. I, like many other Australians, certainly wait with interest to see what the outcome of the Resource Assessment Commission's deliberations might be. But the procedures that it follows and the way in which it gathers evidence and opinion are matters for that body.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In light of the Minister's response, does he believe the survey is an attempt to mould public opinion ahead of the Commission's final report or the public release of Labor's long overdue consideration of the three-mine uranium policy, which also affects development in Kakadu?

—This is quite extraordinary. Here we have a quasi-judicial body independent of government trying to inform itself on a very complex and controversial issue. It is trying to inform itself by obtaining evidence and submissions from the various parties that appear before it, all of whom have distinct interests. It tries to inform itself of its own motion as well. I am now being asked whether it is trying to mould public opinion. That is a slur on the activities of the Resource Assessment Commission and Senator Tambling should withdraw it. I say that because it is seeking to inform itself in order to offer advice to the Government. When it offers the advice to the Government we will be able to judge the quality of that advice. It is not an organisation that in any way participates in political debate. It does not seek to form opinions. Senator Tambling has stepped over the limits of what is reasonable in dealing with a body such as the Resource Assessment Commission, and he should retract accordingly.

—Can the Minister representing the Attorney-General inform the Senate of the latest developments in relation to the blocking of the national companies scheme by the Liberal-National Opposition in the Western Australian Legislative Council?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very important matter. That is why it has led to much consultation and discussion in Western Australia over the last few hours. As recently as an hour before Question Time there had been no resolution favourable to the passage of the Corporations Bill by the Opposition parties in the upper House in Western Australia. There seems to be some suggestion that perhaps a deal can be done between the Western Australian Opposition parties and the Federal Attorney-General in this matter; that cannot be the case. This is a project of all the jurisdictions around Australia, all the elected governments of all political persuasions-State, Territory and Federal-in the Commonwealth of Australia. This project is absolutely essential. That is why it has the support of all those governments responsible to the residents of their particular jurisdictions-States, Territories or, as I say, the Federation as a whole. This legislation, which will allow for political responsibility in the area of companies and securities, and for regional responsiveness in the way in which services are delivered in the various States and Territories of Australia, is extremely important.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Beahan alludes to some very serious consequences that could flow from the failure of the Western Australian upper House to pass this legislation. Indeed, there is, for example, a very serious possibility that Western Australian stockbrokers will have to shift their operations interstate in order to continue business because, unless the corporations legislation is passed in Western Australia, the Stock Exchange's national guarantee fund may not continue to cover stockbroking operations in Western Australia. As I understand it, there are some eight stockbroking firms operating in Perth. It would be an absolute paradox if, as a result of the Western Australian Opposition in the upper House failing to pass this legislation, those stockbrokers had to set up really active business offices, say in Adelaide or Melbourne, in order to get the protection of the guarantee fund for their clients. It would be a paradox because it would be sending business to the eastern States, whereas the claim of the Opposition parties in the Western Australian upper House has been that they are trying to protect business in Western Australia.

We know already from previous answers that Western Australian companies wishing to raise funds outside Western Australia will have to comply with consequent additional fees and costs. But of course the most striking paradox and contradiction is that the Western Australian Opposition parties in the upper House may well bring about a situation where the Bond Corporation investigation, amongst others, will be severely restricted by the actions of the Western Australian Opposition. In particular, the Australian Securities Commission will not legally be able to take over this investigation and any Western Australian investigation will not be able to exercise powers of investigation outside Western Australia. I think that all honourable senators could understand the very grave seriousness of that situation developing. As I say, it would be a political contradiction to what has been claimed to be the concerns of the Western Australian Opposition parties in matters relating to these particular activities either being dealt with fairly before judicial tribunals or by other established procedures.

To have a situation where that investigation could be put in such severe jeopardy would be a total contradiction of the proclaimed stance of the Western Australian Opposition, and indeed calls it into question. I hope that over the next few hours-it is only late morning in Western Australia-there will still be an opportunity for the Western Australian Opposition parties to come to an understanding of the import and the consequences, perhaps unintended, of their stance, which I hope has been well motivated on behalf of the business community in Western Australia. As that community reels under the impact of the decisions being taken by the Western Australian Opposition, I hope that a more sensible accommodation to the need for an Australia--

TALK.START.PARA: —There's a lot more reeling under Brian Burke.

—Senator Bishop is interjecting. Of course, if she is hostile to the plea I am making, she is totally at variance with the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Nick Greiner, who has given his full support to this legislation because he has such a firm grasp of the desirability of this legislation, both domestically and in respect of the international aspects of fundraising for Australia-wide business and commerce.

—I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to evidence given to a Western Australian parliamentary select committee by Brian Burke's former driver and personal assistant that Mr Burke had instructed him to tell gaoled phone tapper Robert Smith to `get something' on Liberal members of parliament Ross Lightfoot and Ian Laurance, and that subsequently Smith had dropped off at Brian Burke's home a package labelled `BB' which could have contained a tape recording. In the interest of Australia's international reputation, will the Minister investigate this matter and assure the Senate that Burke is a fit and proper person to hold the high office of ambassador?

—Once again I have nothing to add to my previous answers on this particular subject. Once again, may I say, it is becoming extremely tiresome to have this constantly repeated exercise, under a very thin veneer of parliamentary privilege, putting prejudicial material onto the public record in circumstances which simply do not deserve or demand any response from the Government.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I ask you to direct that the Minister is out of order in reflecting, as he has, on a parliamentary committee of the Western Australian Parliament. He is clearly casting aspersions on evidence provided to the committee. I ask you to rule that he is not entitled to do that.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—There is a long history of exercises of this kind of prejudicial smearing by the Opposition. There are many such instances that I recall very well from my days in this Parliament in relation to Lionel Murphy, whom members of the Opposition had no difficulty in trammelling and assuming guilt for in circumstances which were wholly unconscionable. I remember the way in which Opposition senators treated our colleague Senator Loosley on so many occasions in this Parliament, accusing the Australian Electoral Commission of not properly investigating a matter when it was properly investigated, accusing the Government of gagging the Director of Public Prosecutions when it was not the case that the DPP was gagged, and accusing us of interfering in the judicial process when there was no shred of justification for that.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister is clearly debating the question. I ask him to answer the question, or ask you to ask him to sit down.
—Order! The Minister is in order.

— Throughout this whole process, those opposite have assumed and presumed guilt and have used every available opportunity to advance smears without a shred or a shadow of justification. When that very same judicial process absolves people, as it did in the case of my colleague Senator Loosley, was there one word of apology or one word of contrition? I shall just say this about honour, decency and dignity in the political process. On our side of politics, we have never had to confront the prospect of holding our shadow Cabinet meetings in Boggo Road gaol.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TASMANIAN FIRE SERVICE: MAINTENANCE OF EQUIPMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Administrative Services to the decision by the Australian Construction Services (ACS) to cancel the agreement with the Tasmanian Fire Service for the servicing and maintenance of fire equipment in establishments of a range of government departments and statutory authorities and the awarding of agreements by ACS to the multinational company Chubb. Is it not a fact that the price list for servicing of fire equipment submitted to ACS by the Tasmanian Fire Service was at least as competitive and in some cases cheaper than that submitted by Chubb? Is the Minister aware of the widespread satisfaction expressed by government departments and instrumentalities in Tasmania with the service provided by the Tasmanian Fire Service, which is of course wholly Tasmanian? Would the Minister advise the Senate as to why the decision was taken and whether something can be done to restore the agreement wholly to the Tasmanian Fire Service?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter has been raised with me by Senator Harradine by way of correspondence. I also note that Senator Walters was in contact with my office yesterday on precisely the same matter, having followed up some correspondence as well. This matter is one that is under active consideration by me at the moment. Through one of my staff, I have indicated to Senator Walters the process involved in issues such as this. In recent days we have had the case of the Australian Furniture Research and Development Institute in Tasmania also being aggrieved by a decision of Australian Construction Services. We took a very close interest in the matter and at the end of the day we made a decision which all Tasmanians applauded as it was the best decision in the circumstances.

ANSWER.PARA: Since it has been raised with me by a number of senators and members, in this particular case I will take the same wholesale, detached approach to assessing the case that has been put up by the people in this place and in the other place, as well as the case that has been put to me by my Department. That is under consideration at the moment. As soon as I have had a chance to deliberate on it fully, I will be in contact with those who have raised the matter and I will also come back to the Senate with an answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. It relates to the Burkegate cover-up, which seems to get deeper and deeper every day. Is the Minister aware that on 18 November 1987 the then Premier of Western Australia, Brian Burke, informed the Parliament of Western Australia that he had not given approval to the board of the State Government Insurance Commission (SGIC) of Western Australia to borrow $160m to purchase St Georges Terrace properties from the Bell Group Ltd? Is the Minister also aware that the minutes of an SGIC board meeting on 19 November showed that the Premier had approved those loan raisings? Does the Minister agree that the Premier clearly and grossly misled the Parliament of Western Australia? Does the Minister consider this action improper? Does the Minister believe that it is appropriate that his Ambassador to Ireland remain in that post while these matters of propriety are before the Minister?
—I am aware of only one thing of relevance to this answer: that is, the grubby sanctimony with which the Opposition continues to pursue this matter. I have nothing further to add.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. The Minister has now refused to answer about eight or nine questions on this matter. He talks about presuming innocence instead of guilt. I seek an answer to the question: when, and under what circumstances, will he investigate these matters, which are clearly on the public record-and not allegations-and which are contained in public documents, one of which is the Hansard from the Western Australia Parliament and the other being an extract from the minutes from an SGIC board meeting, which I seek leave to table.

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rest my case.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Can the Minister inform the Senate as to whether the Australian Industrial Relations Commission has handed down a decision in respect of the SPC matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning the President of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, Mr Justice Barry Maddern, handed down a decision under sections 107 and 108 of the Industrial Relations Act. In that decision he said:

ANSWER.PARA: I am not satisfied that conciliation has been completed and, in the circumstances, I am not of the opinion that the matters, at this stage, should be referred to a Full Bench in the public interest. Conciliation proceedings will be conducted by Commissioner Donaldson as soon as practicable. If agreement is not reached as a result of those proceedings I would be prepared to consider a renewed application pursuant to Section 107 of the Act.

My understanding, as a consequence of that decision today, is that Commissioner Donaldson has listed a proceeding for Monday, at which the parties can attend. I am not at this stage advised whether it is a hearing or a conciliation conference but I believe it to be a conciliation conference. If I am right in presuming it is a conference then I believe that does offer an opportunity for the parties-the unions, workers and employers in this particular case-to thrash out the various issues that have featured in the SPC case and resolve them. I wish the parties well, and trust that they can negotiate a satisfactory outcome. I acknowledge that this proceeding is going on in the Commission, a forum in which the award can be varied if there is an agreement or arbitrated decision in the end to vary, and that should speed the process considerably.

I should also say that this morning, on entry to Parliament House, I was asked by a reporter whether I knew that a New South Wales county council was doing an SPC deal and bypassing the unions. I said, in that particular case, that if anyone is doing deals of that nature they are ill advised or foolish to bypass the union movement because an award will need to be varied in the end, otherwise a breach of an award would occur. The union is an applicant or a respondent to such an award and it will be heard in those proceedings. It is advisable and prudent to involve all parties in a consideration of a particular issue.

I have now been advised that on Radio 2GB it was reported that the Federal Government is going to step in and stop a pay deal. It quoted me as allegedly saying that, and Mr Peter Reith and the New South Wales Government have described this as the Government being clearly worried. Can I say that in this case it refers to a pay arrangement being heard before the New South Wales Commission concerning the Prospect County Council. I was not responding to the question, which was a question at large, not in particular, with any knowledge of the Prospect County Council.

I am not proposing to step in. This is an excitable report by a radio journalist and it is only matched in its excitement by the meddling interference in industrial relations by Peter Reith and the Opposition. They would be best advised to keep out. Their presence may well promote their policies, but it does not in any way help the parties, the workers, the unions and the companies. The Prospect County Council issue is before the New South Wales Commission. It is being dealt with there. That is the right way to proceed and I commend the parties and hope the matter is resolved as soon as possible.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: QUEENSLAND CATTLE PROPERTY: PURCHASE BY CHINESE GOVERNMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is the Minister aware of the purchase by the Chinese Government of a Queensland cattle property for over $1.2m in cash when Australian aid to China in the previous financial year was $42.7m? Does the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade examine such matters when deciding to give aid to foreign governments? Further, how can the Government justify this sort of situation when Australian farmers are being driven off the land in their thousands by this Government's deliberately engineered recession?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My only awareness of this particular matter came from Senator O'Chee's speech in the debate just before the suspension of the sitting today. His speech was as irrelevant to the subject of the debate as his question is to the condition of the economy or anything else this afternoon.

ANSWER.PARA: The circumstances of a sale and purchase of this kind do not in any way relate to the conduct of my portfolio. It is conceivable that the Foreign Investment Review Board and the Treasury may have had something to do with looking at it, depending on the nature of the transaction, the details of which I am not aware of. If Senator O'Chee wants to find out anything more about it he can put a question on notice to the relevant Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. The matter quite clearly is within the ambit of the Minister's Department. We are talking about Australian aid to overseas governments. Therefore, I ask the Minister whether he believes his Department should examine investment by overseas governments in Australia when we give foreign aid to them?
—No, I do not.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. I draw the Minister's attention to an article in the Australian Financial Review dated 19 December 1990 which states that potential bidders for Aussat Pty Ltd are being asked how much they think they should pay to interconnect to Telecom Australia's network and how they would like Australia's telecommunications industry to look after 1997. I ask the Minister: is this Government so desperate to dump Aussat that it is prepared to do it on the terms and conditions of the bidders rather than on the basis of a fair return for Aussat's current owners, the Australian public? Does this not indicate that the Government has no long term strategy for this industry and is undertaking its current reforms for purely short term political purposes?

—No, it does not. I must say that, although I have not read the article in the Financial Review, I will certainly do so today. If Senator Kernot has accurately reported it, I have to say that I see absolutely nothing remarkable if that sort of dialogue has, in fact, occurred between people who may potentially be interested in investing in the organisation and the people who are responsible for selling it. It would seem to me to be a fairly reasonable basis to proceed on, to talk to people who are interested. Of course, anyone would be interested in talking to people who are potentially interested in putting money in about the terms and conditions under which they are prepared to do so. Having said that, I am not familiar with the article, I will read it and ask the responsible Minister, Mr Beazley, for a response which I will provide the Senate with tomorrow.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I ask the Minister: who, then, is going to make the final decision on the sale terms of Aussat, and is it true that there is some action being taken to eliminate the debt at this stage to make its price more acceptable?

—The answer to the first part of the question is the Government. The answer to the second part of the question is that I will get a response from Mr Beazley and provide it to the Senate tomorrow with the rest of the answer that I have already given a commitment to provide.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services. The Minister will be aware that on 1 December the Government introduced generic drug prescribing under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Is he aware that the generic equivalent of some commonly prescribed drugs are unavailable? In particular, I refer to Amoxil, which has a generic equivalent manufactured in Italy and which, according to the wholesaler, will not be available until February. Did the Department refuse to substitute Moxacin-incidentally, manufactured by the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories-for Amoxil when this deficiency was pointed out? Will pensioners have to pay $27 for a course of Amoxil if it is prescribed? Finally, was the Minister asked by the Pharmacy Guild of Australia to defer the introduction of the scheme until January because of similar foreseen difficulties?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware, in general terms, of the program for making available generic drugs in order to reduce the cost to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme-which means the cost to taxpayers-for the provision of suitable medication for those who suffer from a particular disease or illness. Of course, generic drugs are of the same type in their medical and pharmaceutical impact on human beings as those which bear a more generally known label or heavily advertised name. In relation to any particular generic drug's availability, I have no information in the brief. I will certainly bring it to the attention of the Minister.

ANSWER.PARA: As to whether the Guild itself asked for a delay in the implementation of this particular scheme-if Senator Herron says that it did make that request I have no doubt that it was made-I am sure that the Minister had good reason, on balance, for deciding that the scheme should be implemented. If the early implementation of that scheme has led to the situation where some generic drugs are not available as might have been anticipated, I feel confident that Mr Staples will take that into account in any relevant decision as to the cost to those who might be required to pay full cost for a labelled drug. I will seek further information from the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Social Security seen reports of a proposal by Alice Springs magistrate Mr Dennis Barritt for a system of vouchers for food and essential services for Aboriginal people with alcohol problems? What is the Minister's response to such a suggestion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen that suggestion from the magistrate, Mr Barritt. There have been a number of suggestions emanating from the Northern Territory in the last six months because of problems with alcohol and, obviously, there are considerable problems. When one focuses on the difficulties of the excessive use of alcohol, one quickly comes to the conclusion that the solutions do not lie totally within the social security system. In fact, the majority of them are outside it.

ANSWER.PARA: A number of departments, since an incident in Alice Springs with a march of Aboriginal women some time back, have been meeting to bring to bear a range of possible solutions. However, I would not have thought that food vouchers would be one of them for a number of reasons. Firstly, in response to some suggestions made by Mr Perron some time ago that social security should be paid only to Aboriginals who went back to their stations, we said that we would never support systems of A-grade and B-grade citizenship. I think the same would apply to a suggestion about food vouchers. The second reason would be that if one looks at their use in countries like the United States, then one will always see the creation very quickly of an illegal market in the trade in them. By its very nature, that ensures that if one is trying to deliver to those in need, those who seek to make a quick buck will never have that as their priority. So on those grounds the proposal ought to be rejected.

It should be remembered that already more than 95 per cent of payments of benefits made from the Alice Springs office of social security are actually split between husband and wife and children. That means that wives are receiving their half of the married rate of benefit plus whatever amounts have accrued for their children. That means that at least some of those problems ought to be addressed. The difficulty is that in remote Australia the problems are not simply about access to social security payments, but about access to better health facilities, better education and training and, of course, employment. It is in all those areas that the Government will be seeking to address the problems.

We would hope that the working group that has been established can report on this early in the new year and we can take some real steps to improve the situation. But food vouchers will not be the way to go and the Government will not be considering that suggestion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for Defence to comments he made on the 1990-91 Budget and the 1991-94 Forward Estimates when he said that reductions in defence force capabilities were required so that funds could be made available for higher priority requirements, including the capital equipment program. In that the Army has been required to find over $16m in savings this year, thus requiring the disestablishment of 22 Construction Squadron and the headquarters of the 3rd Division, and also requiring reservists attending their annual 14-day training camp to be paid for only nine days, can the Minister indicate what other reductions in Defence Force capabilities he is planning and which capabilities he was referring to in his Budget and Forward Estimates comments.

—Senator Newman has been helpful inasmuch as she has answered part of her own question. I was referring to some of those elements. I cannot add anything usefully at the moment because the big announcement on this matter will be in terms of my response to the full structure review. That will be put down in the Parliament in May. I expect to receive the full structure review at the end of March, as I will the interdepartmental committee on the Wrigley report on the Australian Defence Force and the community plus a number of other reports. I will go through government processes in April and I hope to make a parliamentary statement in May which encompasses some of the questions Senator Newman has asked.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article in the Australian of 19 December in which it is stated that nursing students have complained that their courses have become too academic and that they are failing their subjects following the switch of nursing training from the hospital system to universities? Is the Government concerned about this report, including claims that failure rates in some subjects are as high as 50 per cent? Is there any action the Government can take to determine whether there are serious faults with the system of nursing training and, if there are, whether they can be redressed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The complaint in the article in the Australian arises from the decision to transfer nurse education from hospital based courses to higher education. It is a decision which was strongly influenced by changes that have occurred in nursing practice in recent years. The change recognised that nurses are part of a team involved in the delivery of health care services. As such, they need a broad understanding of the principles that underlie the work they do. In turn, health care has become much more complex in recent years, particularly as procedures based on sophisticated technology have become much more common.

ANSWER.PARA: It should be recognised that a large proportion of the nursing work force is employed in acute care hospitals where the average length of stay for patients has decreased and where patients who are in hospital are more seriously ill. In summary, the level of expertise and responsibility required of nurses is higher than it has ever been. The Government recognised that and recognises that while the humanities base of nursing practice will always be very important registered nurses must also have a thorough grounding in the basic sciences in order to understand the illnesses and medical procedures affecting their patients. As this need has become more obvious in recent years, prospective students may still not realise that science is an important prerequisite for success in nursing.

In response to Senator Colston's second question, the Government recognises that clearly each institution must look carefully at the course content of its nursing program and the assessment procedures. Standards for entry into nursing must also be examined and, where appropriate, bridging courses developed and offered for students who lack the appropriate entry qualifications. In response to the third question, the most important contribution the Government can make is to support the nurse education programs, recognising that nursing is now a profession requiring strong academic training. Nursing as a career should be promoted in schools with emphasis on the challenge and opportunities it provides. We should also be attempting to attract stronger students into nursing, not compromising the standards of existing courses because of a perception of nursing in the community that has not caught up with the reality of nursing in practice.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. On Monday he boasted that under the accord policies to 1988 the Government had provided `low wage outcomes and a distribution in factor shares away from wages to profits'. Now the Treasurer's contractionary policies have engineered a depression, destroying many small businesses, contracting most of the larger businesses and producing massive unemployment. Can the Minister tell us how his current industrial relations policies-by that I mean another accord and larger unions, with those unions involved in all negotiations over wages and those negotiations strictly controlled by the umpire-will help Australia to develop wage costs more closely related to productivity which economic recovery in Australia so desperately needs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —All I can say, with the red light flashing, is that sometimes I am accused of taking a long time to answer a question, but now I am asked to give a whole policy speech. I do not think I can fit it into the remaining 45 seconds of Question Time.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me, however, answer the question by citing two outstanding examples of how we are managing in the current economic circumstances. The first example is an example of something that was possible to achieve only because of the accord. About three or four weeks ago we brought out the September wage round with a tax cut. We therefore in one fell swoop lowered the rate of inflation in this country without imposing wages costs on employers but at the same time maintaining the purchasing power of wages. We did that in one swoop. The only way in which we could manage to do that in Australia was with an accord. Many of the economic commentators hailed that as a significant policy breakthrough at the time, recognising that, in a completely decentralised system such as the Opposition preaches, that type of management is not possible.

Secondly, the changes in union rationalisation are aimed at creating one bargaining unit in the workplace. In Australia there are up to nine unions in medium-sized companies; management deals with nine separate bargaining arrangements. By creating one bargaining unit we simplify the bargaining process, remove the old demarcation barriers and create multi-skilling, career path possibilities and training and accreditation for advancement. We do all that in a way which generates higher productivity per head of employed worker in the work force. It is clear from our record that productivity per head has increased.

Finally-this has not been an exhaustive answer-the Government is managing a wages system which has some centralised increases but is now shifting the focus to enterprise. The national wage case currently sitting is about, in part, determining the guidelines for enterprise level bargaining under a managed, decentralised system and doing it in a way that will ensure that productivity is generated properly and that the benefits of that productivity are shared for the economy and for the workers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you read it in the Hansard and see how silly you are?
—Why don't you pull your head in?

—On a point of order, Mr President, I would ask you to rule as to whether the language which came from the Government front bench, which was that an Opposition senator should pull her head in, is indeed parliamentary.
—Order! I will ask the Minister to withdraw, but I have ignored consistently today interjections from my left at least as bad as that.
—Mr President, I withdraw, but I ask that Senator Walters observe the proper decorum of this chamber and cease interjecting when she is out of order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday at question time Senator Olsen asked me a question as Minister representing the Minister for Finance regarding the Australian National Audit Office. In providing an answer I point out the terms of the question:

ANSWER.PARA: It has now been nine months since the Government received the Sheridan report-an independent review of the Australian National Audit Office. Can the Minister explain why, despite repeated calls for its release, we have not seen this report?

Senator Collins released this report on 6 December this year and tabled it in the Parliament, together with the Government's supplementary response to the report. The full text of the response is recorded at page 5213 of the Senate Hansard. I seek leave to incorporate the remainder of the answer in Hansard. It is a bit esoteric for honourable senators.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

Briefly, in response to the JCPA report the Government has decided that the Auditor-General should be the sole external auditor for Commonwealth-owned or controlled entities, but did not accept that the ANAO should be established as a statutory authority. With regard to the release of 60 full-time staff for efficiency audits referred to by Senator Olsen, the report concluded that initiatives already undertaken by the Auditor-General, or suggested in the review and properly matters for decision by the Auditor-General, could lead to additional resources, broadly equivalent to some 60 full-time staff, becoming available for efficiency auditing over the next two years or so. These resources, in the order of $3m per annum, together with the $2m per annum increase in funding for efficiency audits announced in the Government's earlier response to the JCPA report, represent a very substantial increase in resources above the level allocated to such tasks at the time of the report, then estimated at $1m.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 November 1990 Senator Crichton-Browne asked a question without notice regarding the interception of telephone calls. I answered that question and Senator Crichton-Browne then asked a supplementary question. He again referred to the matter in the Senate adjournment debate of 29 November, referring in particular to a radio interview with Mr John Lewis of Telecom Protective Services, Western Australia. I have some additional information for Senator Crichton-Browne in respect of those matters. Telecom has now identified a case to which Senator Crichton-Browne may have been referring in his question without notice of 27 November 1990 and in his follow-up comments in the adjournment debate on 29 November 1990.

ANSWER.PARA: The case involved Telecom staff in a Perth district where technical staff responding to a complaint regarding the status of a previously reported customer fault conducted tests and intercepted a conversation between the customer-that is, the complainant-and a Telecom technician. The incident has been investigated by Telecom Protective Services, which is currently preparing a brief of evidence to be forwarded to the Director of Public Prosecutions for consideration. Telecom views any breaches of the Telecommunications (Interceptions) Act most seriously and has assured the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Beazley, that the remarks made by Mr John Lewis in the radio interview were in no way meant to reflect at all on comments made earlier by Senator Crichton-Browne.

DEBATE.TITLE: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICETELEPHONE CALLS: INTERCEPTION AND MONITORING

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Crichton-Browne on 27 November 1990, relating to interception and monitoring of telephone calls by Telecom.

I should not want it thought that my question was stimulated by one particular complaint, as there have been a number. It would be evident to all of us that when a matter of this nature is raised in a public forum almost half the community suddenly imagines that it is having its telephone calls monitored and one receives a flood of complaints.

There are some very disturbing features running through the thread of complaints that have come to me. In my view the intrusion into privacy is a breach of the most fundamental kind and it is grossly offensive to all Australians. There is, and there always will be, a great temptation for Telecom or any other organisation which has at its disposal access to tap in immediately to somebody's telephone calls for whatever purpose, whether it be for workers compensation purposes or for other equally unsavoury reasons. It is a matter of sadness to all of us that probably a considerable majority of the Australian people, rightly or wrongly, now suspect from time to time that their telephone calls are no longer private. I suspect that there is not a senator in this chamber who does not work under the premise that any conversation he has on the telephone is not being intercepted by somebody else. I am not necessarily suggesting that this is done by Telecom, but this is the state of mind and perception which, sadly, is permeating the community. I am careful when I say that not to suggest that there is something terribly wrong with Telecom and the vigilant way in which it deals with these matters at an official level when they come to the notice of management.

However, recent events in Western Australia give rise to concern. I have had my own telephone monitored by Telecom for three months because of my belief and Telecom's belief that my telephone calls were being intercepted and my conversations recorded. Frankly, with the events unravelling in Western Australia at present, my concern and that of Telecom has had very good cause. When asking questions of the Minister in respect of this matter, I have been very careful not to be inflammatory because I think it would do little to unsettle the vast majority of decent Australians by raising spectres of this nature. I hope that whenever these matters are brought to my notice-whether they be from the management of Telecom or from Telecom employees-those people will not as a result of that be vilified, intimidated, threatened or compromised in their future careers or promotions.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented and I wish to make a personal explanation. Yesterday Mr Courtice on the Bundaberg commercial radio station 4BU misrepresented me in drawing differences between me, Senator O'Chee and the Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Tim Fischer, when he said, in effect, as it was reported to me, that Senator O'Chee and I supported tariffs and Mr Fischer supported free trade and that we would all have to get our acts together. I challenge Mr Courtice to find anywhere where Mr Fischer and I have differed-we both support fair trade, and I include Senator O'Chee in that-or where I have ever called for tariffs in this place or any other place.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been successful in moving for Senate inquiries into the dumping of sugar when the embargo was lifted. I have made strenuous representations to Senator Tate on labelling. I have moved in this place for an inquiry into the anti-dumping legislation to see whether it is adequate in terms of Australia's current needs. To conclude that Mr Fischer and I have ever had a difference is scurrilous and untrue, and is again an example of how carelessly the honourable member for Hinkler handles the truth.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented. Mr President, I too have been the victim of a similar shabby and grubby remark by Mr Courtice on Bundaberg radio. The fact is that Senator Boswell, Mr Fischer and I all believe in fair trade within the terms of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. This obviously includes the right for Australia to utilise means such as protection against countervailing and dumping when Australian primary producers have been the victims of subsidies and dumping from overseas. This is a matter on which Senator Button concurred yesterday in Question Time. I do not intend to sink to the grubby personal level of attack that Mr Courtice has brought upon those on this side of the chamber and in the other place. I merely remind him of the proverb `physician heal thyself', because it was not long after Mr Courtice said there was no rural crisis that his own Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) contradicted him.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Hill proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The incapacity of the Government to address Australia's real economic and social problems compounded by a lack of leadership and a debilitating succession of squabbles.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Hill, is it the wish of the Senate that the clock be set at the agreed times for this debate? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this time of the year it is not unusual to reflect on the events of the past 12 months. This was a year in which the Australian people narrowly, and clearly with hesitation, entrusted the reins of government to the Australian Labor Party for a fourth successive term. I use the word `entrusted' advisedly because government is a privilege. It was not an election in which the people voted confidently. It was fought against the background of a massive balance of payments deficit; the background of a foreign debt that had trebled under previous Labor administrations; and the background of people struggling under record high interest rates-interest rates which were not only having the claimed effect of dampening demand but also were crushing Australian business, crushing the capacity of Australia to produce competitively. Therefore, instead of getting the country out of the economic decline into which it had entered, the Government was, in fact, contributing to its further decline.

SPEECH.PARA: In that election we set out an alternative-a major program of reform: reform of the labour market; reform of national infrastructure-roads, transport, the waterfront; privatisation of government enterprise and simplification of regulatory reform. But a clearly nervous and hesitant community was not quite ready for change. Instead it accepted what was put to it by an arrogant Treasurer (Mr Keating), the mastermind of the growing economic catastrophe who pledged that everything was on track, that the most worrying figures were beautiful figures and that the public need not be concerned because there would be a soft landing.

When the community hesitated, Mr Hawke intervened and talked of his special relationship. He claimed his much flaunted special relationship and asked that the public again trust him. In fact, he said, `Trust the team. Trust the Treasurer and me. If you are concerned by the Treasurer, don't be, because I am alongside him. We won't let you down'. The Government offered no new policy direction at the election, just a call for trust and, of course, a very negative campaign on the Opposition about which it boasted after the election.

What we have witnessed since the election is an amazing betrayal of that trust. Those are not just my words. I do not often quote editorials, but I refer the Senate to last Saturday's Adelaide Advertiser editorial, which is normally regarded as a sensible, moderate editorial. The writer headed that editorial `Labor has betrayed our trust' and wrote:
The people . . . are no longer prepared to accept the insensitive arrogance of a Government which has lost credibility and direction. They no longer trust federal Labor.

There are fears among decent hardworking people that their jobs and consequently their personal and domestic security are under threat. People are despairing for their future and the future of their children and grandchildren.
Who can blame people for being frightened when the Labor leadership plainly has no idea where the economy is going?

A Government which refuses to accept what the people already knew about the parlous state of the economy and the desperate plight of working Australia can no longer command confidence, attention or respect. Federal Labor has betrayed Australia.

I suspect that those are the sentiments of many Australians at the moment. Australians have been appalled at the obscene spectacle of Messrs Hawke and Keating brawling over the spoils of office, power and influence whilst the community suffers. What I think the community is so upset about is the timing of this leadership brawl. When Australians are suffering, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer seem more concerned about who will maintain power.

Australians are also appalled about Mr Keating's J-curve which, in effect, became a U-turn. Australians remember when the Treasurer said so little time ago that hell would freeze over before his policies would lead the country into a recession. Now he boasts that it is his engineered recession; it is being managed; it is the recession that the community had to have.

Senator Short will have an opportunity to contribute briefly to this debate and will look at the economic mismanagement which has led to this crisis. I hope that he will have a chance to touch upon the confusion now evident in industry policy. Not only are we witnessing a leadership contest but also we are witnessing a clear split within Cabinet as to the way out of that economic crisis.

Mr Dawkins is calling for a change of policy-a more interventionist approach. He is described in the last edition of the Bulletin as `the Left's new ministerial visionary'. The Treasurer is calling Dawkins's approach `a grave mistake'. Senator Button, it seems, is calling for a more interventionist approach in the export economy but not the domestic economy. So it is not surprising that the community is confused and has lost confidence. Where is the Prime Minister whilst this debate is raging? The Prime Minister is sitting firmly on the fence. No-one regards him as a leader any longer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Old Jellyback.

—He is someone who has a capacity to pull votes. At a time when Australia so desperately needs leadership, it is not getting it from Mr Hawke. As one interjector reminded me, it was the Treasurer, Mr Keating, who referred to the Prime Minister as Old Jellyback, a weak leader. We have a clearly ambiguous industry policy coming from the Government which I hope Senator Short will have a chance to enlarge upon. Senator Alston will look at the social cost of this economic mismanagement, the human suffering--
—You've already read that.

—We will be interested in Senator Faulkner's contribution. I think it will be his first in this place. Senator Alston will look at the thousands of people who are becoming unemployed every week as a result of this Government's economic mismanagement and the human suffering from the Government's engineered recession. And Senator Faulkner calls himself a socialist. I refer the Senate again to the article in the Advertiser:

SPEECH.PARA: Across Australia there are now 698,000 people officially looking for work. In South Australia alone 62,000 people are out of work.
Across Australia 42,000 jobs were lost in November, 7,700 of them in South Australia.

These sterile figures, while totally unacceptable in themselves, must not be allowed to disguise the true picture of human misery and suffering. Labor has said, `If you can't govern the party, you can't govern the country'. What a boomerang.

Let me dwell for a moment on the litany of divisions that currently exist in the Government Party and within the Government. The Gulf crisis, probably even beyond the economy, is the most critical matter facing Australia at the moment. We have the Left putting down in writing the conditions on which the Prime Minister could and could not act. Then the Centre Left, fearing that it would be left out, had to do the same thing and leak to the press its own letter to the Prime Minister. All that does is compromise the Prime Minister's capacity to indicate even a unity within the governing Party.

On privatisation we saw a dispute raging for months. It finally had to end when the special conference to achieve compromise was held, while the economy continued to deteriorate. On telecommunications reform, there was the Keating position, and then the Beazley position, both made publicly. There was a campaign of leaks by Mr Keating, the whole of Mr Beazley's Cabinet submission appeared in the paper, and then there was a Treasury minute criticising the Beazley submission and introducing a new option. Senator Button argued against the Beazley option and, we understand, informed the Centre Left that telecommunications reform was not important anyway. On the environment there was public debate between Ministers Kerin and Griffiths; Kerin and Griffiths attacked the conservationists; Griffiths attacked Kerin's sustainable development process. On infrastructure, Mr Howe of the Left called for a massive increase in spending, not the tokenistic gimmick advocated by Senator Richardson. And so one could go on.

Perhaps the most unedifying of all was the insight we have had into the internal workings of the faction system. We got that insight from John Gayler, who, speaking of the Right, said, `I'm not interested in their particular form of thuggery'. He told us that incompetent Ministers are in the ministry simply because of their factional allegiance. So it is not surprising that the Australian people are so disillusioned and so disappointed. It is not surprising that, in terms of the editorial to which I referred a moment ago, they are feeling betrayed by Labor. It is a sorry record since Labor's re-election. It is a record of which Labor members should not be proud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
