TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that this matter of public importance at this stage of the year is a very churlish sort of thing. I would have thought that the Opposition would have sent members of the Government flowers or chocolates or something rather than move a matter of public importance such as this, because the Government has taken on the role, which has been confirmed by the Australian people, of being in government in a very difficult period of time.
—You make it difficult. It is all your own work. It's all self-inflicted.

—We have seen eight years of change, after more than nearly 30 years of neglect, largely presided over by the National Party, which dominated the coalition for so many years and which prevented real changes in this country. We now find Senator Boswell being very vocal about it.

SPEECH.PARA: Mao Zedong once said that all power comes out of the barrel of a gun. Well, in this matter of public importance all intellectual power comes out of the columns of the Adelaide Advertiser, it seems. That is the basis on which Senator Hill wrote and read his speech-an editorial in that newspaper. The whole story that Senator Hill tells, when strung together, is a series of unsubstantiated allegations from various snippets in the press. I find it extraordinary that Senator Hill made some of the allegations he did in his speech today, particularly when they concern me or my position on a certain matter.

The first part of Senator Hill's speech was devoted to telling us why his side lost the last election. As he put it, there was a very nervous community. It was a very nervous community when it examined Senator Hill's leader in the last election, and indeed it was entitled to be. Mr Peacock had been leader for a relatively short time in this incarnation. This matter of public importance seeks to relate the questions of economic stability with stability in the leadership of the Government. The people opposite are experts on the question of leadership stability. If one looks up any dictionary on leadership-

TALK.START.PARA: —You wouldn't find Hawke or Keating in it.

— No, but we will find, for example, Snedden in it: `If I ask them to walk through the valley of death on hot coals, they would do it-that is why I am leader of the Liberal Party'. That is next to Robert Southey, the great poet, and among people like that the leader of those opposite manages to get into the international dictionary of quotations because he represents what has been happening in the Liberal Party over many years: constant changes of leadership, stabbings in the back, and finally a sigh of relief because the Liberals found Dr Hewson as a sort of compromise candidate, representing, as he does, the quintessence of Liberal Party leadership-the intellectual capacity of Andrew Peacock and the style of John Howard. That is the compromise which has been arrived at in terms of the present Liberal leader. As I said the other day, somebody really has to drive a Ferrari to distinguish him from the very ordinary.
—Have you looked at the polls recently?

—I study polls from time to time, but I also study other things; and I think that is advice that the honourable senator should take as well. Senator Hill, in the speech which he wrote and read, referred to the spectacle of brawling in the Government and the economy in the last 12 months. As he put it, he gave an end of term review of the economic situation in the past year. I must explain to Senator Hill yet again that we do not pretend that it is easy to manage an economy like the Australian economy with a commodity-led dollar and a great degree of dependence on commodity exports. Those things are very difficult and were handled in times gone by by tinkering with exchange rates by various conservative governments which ignored the entire issues of Australian competitiveness-the competitiveness of the financial sector and of Australian industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Hill talked a little about industry. In the seven years of the Fraser Government, during which time Senator Hill was here, there was not one change of any significance to tariff policy. Of the 65 per cent reduction in tariffs which has taken place since the early 1970s not one percentage point took place under a Liberal government. Senator Hill was here, as was Senator Short. Senator Alston was here as an office boy, where he still ought to be. I repeat: not one percentage point of change took place in that time.

Senator Hill speculated on changes in industry policy. There was no change in those last seven years that the Liberals were in government. There have been enormous changes in the time that we have been here, and change is difficult to manage. These people would not know about that because they never tried it. With their new-found, born-again enthusiasm for alleged radical change, which Senator Hill listed, including the labour market, roads, privatisation, and all those things--

TALK.START.PARA: —All the things that you know are right but do nothing about.

—I would make the point that those sorts of things were never thought about by the previous Government. I would say to Senator Alston that when Opposition senators talk about leadership they all hark back to the days of Robert Menzies, when it seemed that they had some good leadership, stability and all those things. Those were the years when opportunities were lost.
—We are looking forward.

—I know that Opposition senators are looking forward to being in government, but that is something they have been looking forward to for eight years now, and we intend to keep them doing that. They are not looking forward in terms of any policy prescriptions which have emerged in the past 12 months-the horror stretches, as Senator Hill would describe them perhaps. In the past 12 months where are the differences on fundamental economic policy between the Government and the Opposition?

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Alston interjecting -

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston can tell me when he has the opportunity to make a speech. What the Opposition has done is sit there revelling in the plight of the unemployed and revelling in the plight of the disaffected in the community.
—Appalling.

—`Appalling', says Senator Alston cynically. The Opposition sees the plight of the unemployed as its launching pad into government but, as an ex-Treasury official pointed out in an article in the Canberra Times the other day, there is no fundamental difference between the economic policies espoused by Dr Hewson and the economic policies espoused by Mr Keating as Treasurer-no fundamental difference. Where the differences arise is the Opposition's new-found machismo to tinkle at the edges with talk about micro-economic reform and all those sorts of things. I am saying that the Opposition's track record on any of those issues is not very good. We have attempted those things. Some of them have been occasioned with difficulty, others have not.

SPEECH.PARA: I find this matter of public importance, accompanied by a tale full of sound and fury from Senator Hill, as somewhat disappointing at this time of the year. Of course there are important issues for the Government to address, and some of them have been mentioned by Senator Hill. But it is a little early to be talking about an ambiguous industry policy when nothing has been announced and it is a little early to talk about the state of the economy next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —When might you announce it?
—No, Senator Hill did that in the context of talking about scuttlebutt in the press about differences between--
—You got thrashed by Richardson and you know it.
—I did not get thrashed by anybody yesterday. I am not in the habit of doing that. All I meant was vocal.
—Shouting you down.

—No, not at all. Senator Alston has a fertile mind and sadly not a very good one. He can imagine all sorts of things because he does not understand the realities of economic management. I reject the assumptions underlying this matter of public importance, as it is called. There are matters of economic difficulty at present- we recognise that-but they are not anything to do with the Labor Party leadership. The Labor Party leadership is much more stable than anything the Liberals have ever provided and the economic management is much better.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are here, on the second last day of sitting, with still dozens of Bills before this chamber, spending an hour on a matter of public importance raised by the Leader of the Opposition in this place, Senator Hill. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The incapacity of the Government to address Australia's real economic and social problems compounded by a lack of leadership and debilitating succession squabble.

The Australian Democrats do not disagree with the earlier proposition that this Government has demonstrated an incapacity to address Australia's real economic and social problems but we would say that that incapacity is shared by the Opposition. Senator Button a minute ago asked the question, `What are the differences between the economic policies of the Government and the Opposition?' and I interjected at the time that they are minuscule and very hard to find.

Only last week in this place, again in a debate raised by the Opposition, I very briefly put down our views about the economic policies of both the Government and the Opposition and I will do that again. The policies are both based on an ideological commitment to deregulation and privatisation leading to private sector irresponsibility which we have seen and for which ordinary Australians are now paying, and leading also to unrestrained borrowing overseas which has, of course, been a major factor in blowing out our foreign debt. The Government has failed to reduce the current account deficit and, as we know, the Budget this year predicts a deficit of about $18 billion.

It is important that we look at the second plank of the Government's strategy, that is, the high interest rates, which were designed to choke off demand for imports. This is a very single-stranded strategy, a blunt instrument and one that has been very counterproductive. In the process a recession has been induced, and this is being felt especially in my home State of Victoria. The Government's national unemployment target has already been exceeded and worse is yet to come. We are staring down the barrel of one million Australians being unemployed. The cost is being felt in human terms. The Smith Family has reported, as I said last week, that in the last four months there has been a 40 per cent increase in emergency relief requests. The Brotherhood of St Laurence has documented that currently we still have over 300,000 children living in absolute poverty. We only have to read the newspapers daily to see these problems generated by the Government's economic policy.

The Opposition's policies of privatisation and deregulation do not give us any more comfort. Full privatisation is what it is after and the faster the better. The Opposition proposes a consumption tax which will hit the poor and low income families simply because it is not prepared to chase the real tax cheats and avoiders, any more than the Government has been. It offers at least another $2 billion cuts in Government spending and social infrastructure and privatisation of the social security system. As I say, the Opposition's policies do not give us any comfort of any great competence on its behalf to address the major economic concerns before this country.

In terms of the second plank-the social problems which the proposition before us suggests have not been dealt with by the Government-the records of both the Opposition and the Government are equally abysmal. Social justice is the trendy term that is bandied about by the Government, which even put out glossy little brochures bragging about how much social justice it is spreading around. Let us have a little look at how it is going. As I say, I am taking the Opposition up on its record at the same time because it has not been prepared to go out on a limb to support ordinary Australians, and it is about time the community took a long, hard look at how the Opposition's record stands up on these principles as well.

Time and time again we sit here and see the Opposition supporting Government measures designed to hit easy targets, that is, the people in this country who do not have the power, the money or the influence to take on the Government. It seems a pretty fair assessment of the Opposition to say that it is really full of sound and fury, such as we are hearing and seeing today, signifying nothing. It does lots of posturing, lots of huff and puff but, when it comes to the crunch, it does nothing.

TALK.START.PARA: —A bit hard when you are not in Government.

—Let us look at the Opposition's recent record, because Senator Alston is going to get up in a minute, so I am told by his leader, and tell us all about the social justice and community service records of propositions put forward by the Opposition and how it will demonstrate its capacity. Let us see what the Opposition has been up to.

SPEECH.PARA: The liquid assets test has been introduced for unemployment and sickness beneficiaries That is a patently unfair measure that further penalises people for being unemployed or sick. The Democrats voted to remove that altogether. Where was the Opposition? Voting with the Government, of course! On rural policy, after all the lip-service paid to rural Australia by both the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia, it took a virtual revolt from rural backbenchers-to their credit-to get the Opposition to support our proposal to remove the assets test on family allowance. Then, just two days ago in this chamber, rural families witnessed the spectacle of the Opposition parties voting against our amendment to exempt the family farm from the assets test on family allowance supplement. The Democrats know, and rural Australia certainly knows, that the Opposition's excuse, that the family allowance supplement is a welfare payment, is pretty weak.

Many farming families now need this welfare payment just to keep their heads above water and would not meet the income test. In opposing the Democrats' amendment at the time, the Opposition was consigning these families into further poverty. As my colleague Senator Meg Lees has commented in a subsequent press release, `You can't eat dirt'. That is clearly what the Opposition and the Government expect farming families who are not getting an income to do.

Pensioners have not been exempt from these attacks either. We have seen a wave of attacks in recent months. The $2.50 charge for pharmaceuticals is one that has caused us, and many others, great concern and expects those elderly who are using pharmaceuticals-and obviously the ill elderly as well-to make decisions that should be medical decisions made by the prescribers of those pharmaceuticals and not by the pensioners themselves.

The Government, as usual, has ignored much evidence which has indicated that this is a wrong, potentially dangerous and unnecessary measure. It has steamrolled ahead, once again with the support of the Opposition, despite stirring speeches by Opposition senators in this chamber. But when it comes to the crunch, they vote with the Government-a scene to which we have become accustomed.

The deeming of the rate of return on loans and accounts held by pensioners has clearly caused, and is causing, the pensioners of this country more concern than almost any other measure in recent memory because of its poor execution and its lack of consideration of the fact that it affects old frail people who may have difficulty managing their affairs. It unjustly penalises all the elderly in these circumstances. Again, the Opposition had a chance actually to oppose something. If it had joined with the Democrats in just one or two areas, we could have made this measure much fairer for pensioners.

Young people have not been exempt either. We had the wonderful scenario earlier this year of the Opposition joining with the Government to reduce support payments to young people. How this is supposed to benefit the community is well and truly beyond me, to say nothing of the terrible effect it has had on thousands of already disadvantaged young Australians. It is no wonder that the youth of this country are so cynical about politicians when this is the sort of treatment they get at the hands of the Government and the Opposition alike.

The list goes on. I must say that many of the Government measures are particularly mean and are targeted at precisely those Australians who bear the brunt of Mr Keating's engineered recession. Those of us who have been reading the financial papers in recent weeks and who listened to the AM program this morning know that Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation is getting along very nicely, thank you very much. By taking advantage of tax rates in this country of around 2 per cent, he has been shoring up his international operation. Yet, young people, pensioners, the sick and the elderly are paying under this Government, with the support of the Opposition.

Nothing that the Government or the Opposition have done this year indicates that either of them has the capacity to come to grips with, or is interested in, seriously coming to grips with the social problems affecting this country. Of course, this is because they both follow the same ideological economic rationalism based on deregulation and privatisation.

The second part of the matter of public importance that is before us today talks about the compounding of the Government's incapacity by a lack of leadership and a debilitating succession squabble. This is really the nub of the proposition that has been put to us today. The Opposition has raised this matter for the purpose of political point scoring. It wants to engage in a little bit of personality politics. It wants to see some blood on the floor. After all, the House of Representatives has come back to sit today. The Opposition in the Senate is desperate to get a bit of media coverage. Most of the members of the media are over on the other side of the House watching the A-team. I must say that, in the face of a legislative program which is still packed and in the face of major issues that ought to be before the Parliament, the media and the general public, this is the sort of thing that brings into ill repute the actions and work of politicians and political parties.

I would like to say that the media colludes with the Opposition in this sort of practice. Last weekend's newspapers demonstrate what I am talking about. With all of the challenges and despair that exists, the major issues dealt with in virtually every weekend paper by key journalists, most of whom work upstairs in the Press Gallery, was the succession squabble that has been raised today by the Opposition.

In the Weekend Australian Paul Kelly wrote a full page feature article under the heading `Labor's love lost'. He said nothing about the fact that in that very same week this Government, which claims not to be doing so, actually passed legislation which will allow it or a conservative government not only to sell off 100 per cent of the Commonwealth Bank but also, if it wants to, to sell it off to foreign interests. Mr Kelly was more interested in writing about blood on the floor between Keating and Hawke.

Michelle Grattan wrote an article in the Age under the heading `Awaiting more thrills in the leadership cliffhanger'. I do not think Michelle will find too many thrills in what the Opposition has to say in the debate this afternoon. The Sunday Sun carried an article by Peter Logue under the heading `Hawke and Keating can't last' and an article by Richard Farmer under the heading `Doubts on leadership still linger on'. There was nothing from them, or any of the others, about the fact that under the Opposition's privatisation plan for Telecom and the Government's plans for deregulation Australian women are going to be seriously disadvantaged. This was pointed out by Ann Moyal in a paper entitled `Women and the Telephone in Australia'. I consider that to be a major issue worthy of the attention of journalists of the capacity of those I have named.

Alan Ramsey wrote an article in the Sydney Morning Herald which was headed `Keating slips into bleak recession'. This was not an economic piece. The article contains a cartoon which shows Mr Keating and Mr Hawke engaging in a very active wrestle at the edge of a waterfall. This very good cartoon has nice squiggles which demonstrate a great deal of movement. Yet, the Sunday Age contains a photograph of Mr Hawke and Mr Keating with their arms around each other. Underneath the photograph is an article by Michael Gordon headed `Death of a double act?'. The same paper contains an editorial on this subject.

The Canberra Times of last Saturday contained an article by Tony Wright headed `Keating's speech and a breach of confidence'. I can understand the basis for Senator Hill's remarks about the Adelaide Advertiser. I should add that the television people conducted doorstop interviews on the Senate side door on only two days last week although there have been four weeks of sittings. The only question that was asked was about the squabble between Mr Keating and Mr Hawke.

What are the issues that the journalists and the Opposition could be looking at? Let us join together and put pressure on the Government, as the very responsible Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Tickner, is doing in order to get big funding for Aboriginal health. We could use a little bit of help on those sorts of issues.

It would be nice to see the media pay some attention to the fact that after years of work by senators from these cross benches, the Government has finally agreed to reduce the duty on wheelchairs, pacemakers and defibrillators for disabled and ill people in this country. But it appears that this is not a major news item. It is much more important that Mr Keating and Mr Hawke should shed blood on the floor in the ministerial area.

The whole range of major key issues that are before this country are being neglected by the Opposition. We need only look at the number of futile questions that have been asked this week to see where the Opposition's priorities are. We only have to look at the important legislation that has yet to be passed, amended or dealt with in some way or other. Yet we are spending time on this sort of exercise. This demonstrates what the Opposition's priorities are. It is particularly ironical because its capacity to solve the real problems is no better than that of the Government's.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Accustomed as I am to the ramblings of the Australian Democrats in this place, I am nevertheless amazed that Senator Powell and the Democrats find the most serious economic crisis since the 1930s not to be a matter requiring debate in this chamber. This matter of public importance brought to the Senate today by Senator Hill goes to the heart of the problems and hardships facing all Australians. There is no need for Australians to be suffering these problems and hardships. They are not imposed on us by an act of God or by circumstances beyond our control. Rather, they are the deliberate, inevitable, engineered result of the subject of the matter of public importance which we are dealing with at the moment, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The incapacity of the Government to address Australia's real economic and social problems compounded by a lack of leadership and a debilitating succession squabble.

Let there be no doubt about it: our problems are home grown. They have been planted, nurtured and brought to full bloom by an incompetent government which not only fails to address our real economic and social problems but also fails to recognise what those problems are-a government which chooses to put petty personal ambitions and super egos above the national interest and the common good.

Senator Hill has dealt with the leadership issue in his remarks and Senator Alston will cover the social consequences of the Government's failure when he speaks later in the debate. My main purpose today is to highlight the evidence and the extent of the Government's incapacity and incompetence in its economic management.

The evidence of the Government's incapacity to provide effective economic management abounds. The main cruel evidence, of course, lies in the deep recession Australia is now experiencing. This is a recession that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said on 22 March of this year-two days before the Federal election-that the Government would not let happen. This is a recession which he now says we had to have. What nonsense, what arrogance and what economic blindness. The only reason that Australia has had to have this recession is the Government's gross criminal negligence and incapacity to provide effective economic management. The result is for most Australians the greatest hardship in living memory.

At the business level, particularly in small business, bankruptcies have soared to record levels. Unemployment is, to use the words of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson), rocketing up, and he admits that it will go much higher in 1991, despite the cloud-nine assertion by our discredited Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that it will not reach double figures. Indeed, Mr Hawke put forward this assertion as a truth only two weeks ago. But we all know what the word `truth' means to this Prime Minister and this Government: it means the exact opposite to how all other Australians define it. This is the same Prime Minister who said again just two weeks ago, `The Australian people should not fear the recession'.

I have news for our Alice in Wonderland Prime Minister: Australians do fear this recession, and well they might as the dole queues grow by more than 1,000 people a day, as more and more businesses go under and as more of those children that the Prime Minister said would not be living in poverty by 1990 go into poverty. This recession, to quote both the Treasurer and the former Finance Minister, has been deliberately engineered? What gain has Australia derived from it? Absolutely none. We have had all of the pain of a recession and none of the potential gain. We have had none of the potential gain for several reasons, which are all directly attributable to the Government.

We have had none of the potential gain because the Government has, firstly, failed to recognise that the number one problem that must be attacked is inflation. Secondly, it has failed to produce an appropriately tight fiscal policy and, indeed, is now presiding over a massive blow-out of the Budget, with the surplus for the year now certain to be much lower than the $2 billion less than was forecast in August. Thirdly, the Government has failed to take appropriate offsetting measures to accompany its progressive easing of monetary policy and is therefore storing up potentially more difficult long term consequences. Fourthly, because its industrial relations decisions are dictated by the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Government has failed either to encourage or to permit employers and employees to negotiate directly on wages and other conditions of employment without interference by unions, governments or commissions. Indeed, we have a Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) who vehemently denies that such negotiations are in the interests of workers, even if the alternative is for those same workers to lose their jobs as their employers are forced to close their doors.

Fifthly, the Government has failed comprehensively on micro-economic reform, again largely because it is the captive of powerful unions. There has been virtually no progress on waterfront or coastal shipping reform. The Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport third runway has not progressed and the proposal to merge Telecom Australia and OTC Ltd is the antithesis of desirable reform. Sixthly, this Government has failed to address the urgent need for fundamental tax reform and, particularly, the need to abandon our archaic and unfair wholesale sales tax system and replace it with a modern indirect tax system embracing a broadly-based consumption tax which would provide scope for significant personal tax relief and increased saving and investment.

The seventh reason-as Senator Hill said in his remarks-is that the Government has again comprehensively failed to give industry any certainty on which to base its future planning and investment decisions. On the contrary, the Government gives increasingly confused and confusing signals. The Treasurer says one thing and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) says another, only to be then mercilessly-or perhaps mercifully-publicly humiliated by the Treasurer for his trouble. Ministers Dawkins, Kerin and Howe have all made separate and conflicting statements. The Cabinet cannot come up with any environmental guidelines. Last night we had the damaging farce of Cabinet's inability to make any decision on the timber industry's access to resources. The Industry Minister is obviously having great difficulty in getting an industry policy paper together. Eighthly, by concentrating entirely on bludgeoning the economy into submission in order to suppress demand, the Government has failed to address the only long term path to increased productivity, competitiveness and real incomes-namely, the supply side of the economy.

I believe that the Government stands condemned in the eyes of all Australians for these failures. No other government in Australia's history has so betrayed the trust of the electorate; no government has so deliberately engineered-to use its own word-such a brutal and unnecessary recession; no government has so squandered the great opportunities with which it was presented; and no government has deserved more to be thrown out of office for incompetence, and that, inevitably, is what will happen at the next election. The only question is whether our nation can afford to wait that long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I was asked to speak in this debate I thought we would be in for some fireworks from the Opposition, judging from the terms of the matter of public importance that was put before us. But I have to say that, waiting for my turn to speak, I nearly went to sleep listening to the contribution from the Opposition. I know it was once said of Geoffrey Howe, the former Deputy Prime Minister of the Conservative Party in Great Britain, that being attacked by him was like being savaged by a dead sheep. After hearing the contributions of Opposition senators here today I think we could say that being attacked by the present Opposition is like being savaged by a dead mouse. It has absolutely no impact and no credibility and is of total non-interest. I would have thought that if this were going to be the big fiery debate to end this long parliamentary session in the Senate a few backbenchers and a few other shadow front- benchers would be in the chamber cheering the speakers on. But there are not because most members of the Liberal Party know that this is just a last gasping shot at the Government on the second last day of this long sitting.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard Opposition senators go on at length about the Government's mismanagement of the economy. They have made assertion after assertion but, in the two speeches that I have heard today, they have not given any outline of what they would do to change anything in Australia. That is the fundamental problem with this Opposition; it can nitpick and have a go at the Government in a number of areas-like any government we will make mistakes from time to time; no one denies that-but there is no comprehensive plan coming from the Opposition. It has said that it will probably introduce a consumption tax, but there is no detail about it. It has said that it will reduce tariffs to nothing by the year 2000, but there is no detail about how that target will be reached. At the first chance honourable senators opposite get to be hairy chested about cutting government expenditure, they funk it in the party room, and as a result we have seen in the last few days Opposition senators in this chamber voting against cutbacks in government expenditure in the assets test to the tune of some $55m. They could not even take the decision to cut expenditure by $55m.

We have heard Opposition senators going on about their wonderful privatisation program, yet when the Pipeline Authority Bill came through the Senate yesterday they voted against it. They took a decision not to allow the privatisation of the Moomba-Sydney gas pipeline to take place. When put to the acid test they have failed. They have failed for seven years. They are now working themselves into a lather because they believe that they have a great opportunity to win the next election because of the present standing of the Government in the opinion polls. I remember them saying the same things during the last term. At times they were well ahead of the Government in the polls, but when it came to the crunch the people would not trust them, because they are not credible. That is the problem that the Opposition has.

When we look back over the record of government since the Second World War-the Opposition was in government for 30 of the last 40 years-we see that the present Opposition parties have basically been asleep. They did nothing in those long years. All the things that the Opposition is shouting about today and saying the Government has not done could have been done when the Opposition was in government for 30 years. When it had an opportunity to do those things it did nothing.

Those opposite criticise us for not going fast enough on shipping reform, waterfront reform, telecommunications reform, tax reform, rail changes and so on. But they had 30 years and they did nothing. Despite the current economic difficulties, we are proceeding with major reform in those areas. We have the national rail freight initiative. We are getting the manning rates down in shipping to the levels of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries. There have already been 20 to 30 per cent productivity increases on the waterfront. We have seen the biggest change in telecommunications in our history. We are creating a major national carrier that can not only do the job in Australia but also compete worldwide.

The one thing that those opposite have not mentioned is the success of the accord in getting a wages outcome over the last seven years that has reduced our inflation rate to substantially less than it was in the Fraser years. The last inflation figure, which was for the September quarter, was 0.7 per cent. As a result, the accord is now being adjusted to lock in that lower inflation rate as a basis for sustained growth in the next couple of years. These are things that those opposite have not been able to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is rather extraordinary to listen to people such as Senator Schacht and Senator Button. The way they talk one would think that there was nothing wrong with the state of the economy and that somehow all we need to have is more of the same over the next couple of years and we will be right as rain. Senator Schacht, who fancies himself as an expert in interpreting polls, surely does not believe that more of the same will rescue the Government from its current predicament. I would have thought that these polls were enough to terrorise anyone, even the nervous nellies in the Party who do not believe in the whole range of economic measures that Senator Short and Senator Hill have outlined today. For Senator Powell to somehow pretend that there are no differences between the major parties in policy terms is fatuous nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: The tragedy is that not only could we have a more efficient economy but also we would not have to have the magnitude of human suffering that we are seeing at present. That is probably the saddest part of this whole exercise. The recession that we had to have has now led to the alleged jewel in the Labor crown of 1.6 million jobs having been created since 1983 looking as though it might as well never have happened. We now find that unemployment has reached 700,000 and that unemployment beneficiaries total about 500,000-up 30 per cent for Australia and, in my State of Victoria, up 72 per cent over the last 12 months. People are going out the job doors backwards. Even though the bulk of those jobs were full time, it is not much consolation to those thousands a day who are now finding themselves in the unemployment queues. The problem will be compounded by school leavers in the new year.

We are clearly looking at the worst recession since the Second World War. This of course makes a cruel joke of all the promises that we would have a soft landing and there was no need to fear recessions-generally the sorts of things that a Prime Minister without principle would say in the run-up to an election. Just as he used to say that interest rates would come down and then revised his promises, so Australians were fooled into thinking that somehow the economy would turn around magically of its own accord. We now find people of the calibre of Bruce Chapman, a recognised authority on employment trends, predicting that long term unemployment is likely to be almost 50 per cent higher by the middle of next year. Apart from what that does to the Budget surplus, we should all be able to appreciate the measure of human tragedy.

That is why we are seeing this desperate U-turn promoted by people such as Messrs Dawkins and Howe. Even Mr Dawkins had to concede that the latest unemployment figures showing 8.2 per cent of the work force out of work were grim. He described it as a very rapid decline in the number of jobs and a very rapid increase in the number of people unemployed-although of course he did not think that Australia was facing a recession of 1982-83 proportions. But, again, he made those predictions with some caution and some trepidation. Of course, that is precisely correct because we will see a recession of at least that magnitude.

The social tragedy is that at a time when we need some innovative and imaginative welfare policies and a recognition that we need an active employment strategy, we have a Minister for Social Security presiding over these rocketing figures who has absolutely no interest in the portfolio. I do not need to catalogue the number of areas in which Senator Richardson has poked his nose and which he has no business getting into simply to demonstrate that the last thing on his mind is trying to tackle the social and human problems in Australia. He is interested in the numbers, power, resolving leadership issues and getting his head on the box. But in recent times there is not much about social security that he has been promoting other than trying to sabotage the Expenditure Review Committee. Indeed, at one stage Mr Willis complained that Senator Richardson had tried to oust him from the Ministry. We know that Senator Button has much to fear in that regard as well. Senator Richardson was quite happy to announce that if he had been as disloyal as Senator Button, he would not still be in the Ministry-a clear call for Senator Button's head.

Senator Richardson is happy to be involved in issues such as the Commonwealth Bank, to pontificate about the Party reaction, to promote mickey mouse schemes, to establish special trusts for the proceeds of privatisation and to predict that there will not be any change in the Labor Party's ridiculous three mines uranium policy-not because of the merits of the argument, but because there is not enough support for change in the Party branches. All those sorts of interventions are simply a recognition of the fact that he is not prepared to face up to what is desperately needed, and that is an active employment strategy that will provide some alternative to people remaining on welfare indefinitely.

The Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research said today that economic growth was unlikely to be sufficient to absorb the increase in the Australian labour force. We know that the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development has not been very comforting in terms of jobs. That is the Achilles heel of any government, but a government that pretends to believe in social justice and one that claims to be concerned about the workers is in the process of delivering perhaps the greatest tragedy of all. Rather than suggesting that we revel in the plight of the unemployed, as Senator Button's disgraceful canard implied earlier this afternoon, the Government ought to be taking a lead in demonstrating how it will solve some of these social problems. Instead, all Senator Richardson has done is try to back away from a number of Budget commitments and cost the Treasury about $150m in the process. It is a tragically inept and inadequate response to a very serious social problem. I do not think that any Australian expects it to improve while this Government remains in office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It really is the second last day of the session, is it not. Quite clearly, the Opposition's heart is not in this matter of public importance. Senator Hill came in here under duress from his party room and stumbled his way through a written speech. Senator Short and Senator Alston really do not believe what they have told us today; their hearts were not in it. They have come in here with the most hypocritical matter of public importance imaginable; they are talking about supposed leadership problems in the Government. This comes from an opposition whose leadership record since 1983 is unparalleled in Australian political history. It has had more leaders, more division, than any other political party at any time in Australian history.

SPEECH.PARA: We just have to look at the record of the Liberal Party when its members talk about division. They studiously avoided mentioning Mr Howard's name. They studiously avoided mentioning Mr Peacock's name, not to mention the National Party. I do not really want to bring up the issue of Mr Sinclair and the way in which he was removed by Mr Blunt in a palace coup. Opposition senators should remember Mr Blunt-the world's greatest letter writer-when they talk about leadership. I remember Mr Blunt. He was so unpopular and so desperate that he wrote in excess of a quarter of a million letters to Australian electors to gain the National Party a few votes in the last election. It was not very successful. In fact, Mr Blunt was such a failure that he lost his own seat-one of the safest conservative constituencies in this country.

Of course, we can always mention the Senate leadership. I am not churlish enough to talk about Senator Hill and the way in which he just scraped in as Leader of the Liberal Party in the Senate and that group of backbenchers who plot against him every Question Time as he fouls things up for the Opposition. Because it is Christmas, I do not want to talk about the leadership of the National Party in the Senate, either. Again, Senator Boswell has made political history in this country. He is the only leader of a Party in Australian political history not to hold a shadow portfolio.

We have heard from the Opposition that this is the most important matter that has faced our community. For the last four weeks we have heard that the Government is allegedly paralysed by leadership problems. It has taken the Opposition four weeks to propose a matter of public importance before the Senate. With just two days to go before the end of this sitting, the Opposition has managed to come in here and to propose a matter of public importance on the leadership of the Government. If this matter were such a crucial issue, I am sure that the Opposition would accept that it would have been canvassed more often.

We have heard yet again Senator Alston's obsession with published opinion polls. I do not have time to quote from the Australian Financial Review on that issue, but it is clear that Dr Hewson is starting to have the same party room pressures that destroyed Mr Howard, destroyed Mr Peacock, destroyed Mr Blunt and destroyed Mr Sinclair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired. The debate on the matter of public importance is now concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.
The Tax Expenditures Statement tabled today, which is a document from the Treasury, is to be welcomed. The introduction to the document states:

The Tax Expenditures Statement was first published in 1986 and has been published in every year since then . . . Tax expenditures are those provisions of the Australian taxation law which tax certain classes of taxpayers or particular types of activity differently from the chosen benchmark structure. These provision may take the form of tax exemptions, deductions, deferrals, rebates or special rate relief.

It is a very important document as it is essential that information on tax expenditures be given equal weight to the direct outlays of government because in many respects they have a similar effect. The scrutiny of government spending should require that all forms of spending be reviewed.

The figures are not small by any means. In 1989-90, the total costed tax expenditures amounted to $9.4 billion, that is, 11 per cent of direct outlays by government. In the case of the social security and welfare expenditure, the tax expenditures of $5.67 billion are the equivalent of 21.5 per cent of direct outlays for that portfolio of $26.3 billion. In the case of industry assistance and development, the tax expenditures of $3.45 billion are 50 per cent higher than the direct outlays by government of $2.26 billion.

These figures are very significant. The ones that I have mentioned relate only to the items that are actually costed. Regrettably-and this is a criticism of the document-many tax expenditures are not able to be costed and so they have the words `not available' beside them in the tables. That certainly detracts from the value of the statement. Nevertheless, despite that, it is a very important statement.

I note the new method of valuing tax expenditures adopted in this report. Tax expenditures are now costed according to the year in which there is an impact on the revenue rather than in the year in which use of the provision is made. This allows more meaningful comparison with direct outlays and is to be welcomed.

I am also pleased to see that the timeliness of the data provided in the statement has been improved. Whilst last year's statement included data only until 1987-88, this year's publication includes data to 1989-90, although additional caveats apply to the accuracy of costings provided for the most recent year. I do have a criticism of this and previous tax expenditures reports. It relates to the caveats which apply to comparisons of costs of direct outlays and tax expenditures, which are listed in Attachment C to the report. That issue deserves more explicit recognition in this report, particularly because many readers of the report may go to tabulated information and, therefore, be unaware of the caveats which are outlined in the attachment. Whilst the Australian Taxation Office and the Treasury are to be congratulated on improving the number and timeliness of the costings since the last report, as I have already intimated, we are a long way from an exhaustive list. For example, none of the fringe benefits tax concessions have been costed.

In a perfect world, I would go so far as to suggest, the full benefit of the information in the statement will materialise only when it takes its rightful place alongside the information in the Budget Papers. In my book, this information rates in importance next to the Budget documentation, which ordinarily receives so much attention. Such a move would go a long way to breaking the common perception that expenditures through the tax system are somehow intrinsically different from direct outlays and, therefore, do not need to be reviewed in the same way. As I said earlier, that is a point with which I would not agree. In the meantime, I hope that this statement continues to occupy an important place in the valuable information produced by the Treasury. It is a document that warrants much closer attention by the Parliament than we have given it in the past. I hope that we will have the opportunity to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: At the same time, I call upon the Government, as part of this self-assessment process, not to extend the statistical information on the back of the return purely for the purpose of producing reports such as this. Mr Acting Deputy President, I could not let this opportunity go by, particularly with you in the chair, to commend this report. The Australian Institute of Health is an independent statistics and research agency within the Federal Community Service and Health portfolio. It comprises three major research divisions: Health Services, Health Technology and Health Monitoring. I draw attention to page 57 which states:

Cancer remains the second most common cause of death in Australia, accounting for 25 per cent of all deaths in 1988 . . . . There has been a very large increase in cancer death rates in males since the 1940s, mainly due to smoking related cancers . . . . The higher incidence and mortality for males is largely due to their greater use of tobacco. About one-third of cancer deaths can be ascribed to tobacco--

On page 99 of the same report there is a list of the major risk factors for preventable cancers. At the top, under the heading `Lung cancer', is tobacco smoking. It then states that the aim for the next few years is to set a program of health for all Australians in relation to five lung cancer related goals as follows:
* To reduce the incidence of death from lung cancer.
* To prevent the onset of smoking in non-smokers, especially children.
* To reduce the number of smokers.
* To reduce the exposure of smokers to tobacco derived carcinogens.
* To reduce involuntary exposure to tobacco smoke.
Among other targets are the following:
To reduce the prevalence of smokers from 33 per cent (1983) to 28 per cent or less by the year 1990 and to 15 per cent or less by the year 2000.
To reduce the difference in prevalence of smoking between males and females from 23 per cent to 10 per cent or less by the year 1990 and to a negligible figure by the year 2000.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I am sure you will agree with me that these are admirable aims. My reason for standing today in response to this report is to plead with the Government to take notice of it and, perhaps, to act on the aims. I refer, particularly, to where an opportunity has arisen, namely, to ban the incidental advertising of cigarettes on television. The Government did not take action in that regard when it had the opportunity. I think the time has come when this action is urgent. A small step, perhaps, but one that should be taken urgently. If the Government is to take any notice of this report it should take action in that regard.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Recently, I had the opportunity of saying a few words on the report of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC). But there is another matter that I want to raise in regard to that report; that is, a program cut by the ABC of the very popular program, Countrywide. I could find no mention in the report of the axing of such a popular program, only the boast that it covered rural issues, bringing viewers in the cities dramatic accounts of the loss and devastation caused by the May floods. It also said:

SPEECH.PARA: From its new base in Brisbane, the program emphasised more detailed analysis and reported on a wide range of topics.
I feel that there has to be a program like Countrywide which captures the colour of the bush and the things which happen outside the cities.

The charter under which the Australian Broadcasting Corporation operates calls for the national broadcaster to provide adequate and comprehensive programs. By any standards, that must include television aimed at the generally ignored minority of Australians who live outside the big cities and provincial centres. For the rural audience, ABC television supplies only 30 minutes of programming a week in the form of Countrywide-a catch-all of news, current affairs and magazine stories that might appeal to people with interests outside suburbia.

According to a memo from the controller of news and country affairs, Countrywide was axed, `because ratings in the city are falling'. This, I believe, was the result of changing the timeslot for the program from 9.30 on Wednesday night to early Sunday, when most farmers would still be in the paddocks. It then moved to 8.00 p.m. on Friday, the traditional time for most country folk to have their night in town. So it is no wonder to me that the ratings were falling.

The change in format of the program from rural issues to a gentrification of the program so as to appeal to many of the greenies in the cities, would have had another effect on its ratings. Instead of reporting on newsworthy items for farmers and bushies, the report boasts that Countrywide:
. . . has reported on a range of topics including abuses in drought payment schemes, controversial use of chemicals to clear land and the death of 5,000 cattle from botulism in Queensland feedlots.

That is not to say that there have not also been some issues that it has dealt with intelligently in the year, such as the serious issues of wool marketing, soil degradation and salinity and the importing of questionable pig meat.

If there are complaints about the program, a better solution is to restore it to a more sensible timeslot and more tightly focus its rural brief. The Corporation's preferred solution-to increase the rural content of programs such as the 7.30 Report-might only succeed in producing segments aimed at the ABC's environmentally conscious city based audience rather than real producers.

When I saw Doug Murray say goodbye to everybody on his last night on the Countrywide show, I felt very sorry about it. But I would like to congratulate the ABC on its annual report. In doing so, I remind it that it should examine honestly whether it is really achieving one of its stated goals, which is to be an effective and distinctive alternative to other broadcasters through a wide range of high quality and innovative services to rural and remote Australia-I emphasise that-to the cities and to specialist and minority audiences, and not just chasing a ratings war with the other commercial channels.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to talk on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) annual report 1989-90, there are a number of matters that I would like to raise in terms of the operations of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation which have been raised with me by constituents in Western Australia. Senator Bjelke-Petersen, I believe, raised a very important point when she made reference to the charter of the ABC and the fact that it is not a ratings operation. In fact, it is quite different and its responsibility is quite different from commercial radio. Part of its charter is to ensure that people who live in remote areas or people who live in relatively small inner communities have access to information and data that would not be otherwise available to them.

SPEECH.PARA: Three matters have been brought to my attention which I want to raise in the time available to me. The first one concerns the operations of Country Hour and regional radio in Western Australia and also some television broadcasting; that is, the networking of programs out of Sydney, in particular, and Melbourne to a lesser extent. One must make the point that while these programs may be of a lot of interest to people in Sydney, to people in other parts of Australia they do not have as much attraction.

The particular point I raise is the situation, for example, of the tomato growers at Geraldton who have been accustomed for a number of years-ever since Country Hour has been operating-to getting market reports through Country Hour. That service has now been discontinued and this has put them in a difficult position in terms of having knowledge of what is occurring in the marketplace in Perth. That is one of the functions that consistently has been part of the operations of the Country Hour.

The other two points I raise also relate to people in remote areas, and not so remote areas, who are being disadvantaged. For example, in the Christmas holiday period the broadcasting of the trotting to country areas has been stopped. It is very easy if one happens to live in metropolitan Perth or any of the metropolitan cities to hop in one's motor car and drive down to the trots. But if people are 200, 300, 400 or 500 miles away and trotting happens to be their interest, they cannot get there. Likewise, a complaint that continually comes up is the discontinuation of the broadcasting of the cricket into country areas. Once again, this is the only opportunity that people have to participate in this recreation unlike people who live in metropolitan areas. The total expenditure of the ABC is $510,343m. In the structuring of its programs sufficient funds should be made available to cater for that part of its charter and for people who live in country areas.

One must also emphasise that in metropolitan areas there are groups of people who have particular interests, groups that are very small in number and cannot have an impact on the ratings as far as the type of broadcasting is concerned. If there is to be this sort of contribution from the public purse, I think it is beholden on the ABC to meet that part of its charter.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
