SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity, Senator Peter Baume, as it is the second last day of your appearance before the Senate, to congratulate you on a job well done and to wish you all the best in your new career.

SPEECH.PARA: The Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1990 will amend both the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1935 and the sales tax regulations. While the coalition supports this Bill, it contains a number of anomalies and shortcomings which I wish to draw to the Government's attention.

The Bill has been introduced to give effect to the announcement made by the Government in its August Budget to provide relief from sales tax on computers used by manufacturers and persons who process goods on behalf of manufacturers. The comment from industry in response to this announcement was, `About time'. In legislating to exempt computers from sales tax in the manufacturing industry, the Government is finally recognising the technological advances which have been made over the years and which have led to the computerisation of a number of functions not previously considered within the realms of computer technology.

The move towards the use of computer technology in many manufacturing processes has been tax-exempt because the functions the computers perform have fallen within the `aids to manufacturing' provisions of sales tax law. Under these provisions computer hardware qualifies as an aid to manufacture when it is used directly in the physical manufacturing process. There is also a number of supporting income tax rulings in the area of aids to manufacturing. The sales tax exemptions announced in this year's Budget will apply where 50 per cent or more of the individual items of computer equipment are used, firstly, in the engineering or technical design of goods for manufacture and of machines, tooling and production processes needed to make goods for manufacture performed using CAD, CAM and CAE equipment. Non-manufacturing activities specifically excluded under the Bill are audio-visual production, architectural-structural design, certain computer software and the work of certain authors and secretaries.

The second criterion covers production related computers, which includes scheduling, sequencing, monitoring, controlling and costing of the processes of manufacture. It will also extend to the ordering, handling and controlling of new materials to be used in the manufacture of goods, such as just-in-time material control systems. Broad exclusions under this category include marketing, sales, management and accounting activities. That is in accordance with normal precedent.

The third area is that of print related computer equipment. This will cover equipment used for the finalisation of text or artwork for printing, including, for example, the final layout of text by a typesetter, the production of forms by a commercial printer, the recording of newspaper advertisements, the subediting of newspaper articles and the production of technical manuals and other manufacturing documentation. It is in this area that I believe the great problems arise under this legislation, particularly for the newspaper industry. I thought this legislation was essentially designed to assist the newspaper industry. Under this category, exemption will not be available for an author such as a general journalist who finalises the format or typesetting of his or her original works. The exemption will also not be available for the activities of an office secretary. The latter is not surprising.

Provision is also made in the Bill to exempt sales tax on computer equipment in cases where a combination of the three new eligible exemption areas, which I have listed earlier, are employed such that the total use on all of the exempt activities is 50 per cent or more. I concur with that sort of approach. In addition, the exemption will cover combinations of previously exempt criteria and new exempt uses. So for manufacturers who use a computer for 20 per cent of the time as an aid to manufacturing activity and 40 per cent for technical design work, the exemption will apply because the total exempt usage of the computer exceeds 50 per cent.

There are broadly four groups of people who will be eligible for these exemptions: manufacturers registered under sales tax law; unregistered manufacturers other than those who operate in a small way, where their average turnover is less than $50,000 per annum; persons carrying out processes or treatment to goods on behalf of manufacturers, whether or not they are registered; and subcontractors engaged by manufacturers to carry out the exempt activities on their behalf.

A registered manufacturer will be able to purchase eligible computer equipment free of sales tax by quoting a sales tax certificate to the supplier-a normal procedure-and sales tax regulations will be aimed to require quotation of a certificate in these circumstances. An unregistered person who is entitled to exemption will be able to claim exemption by providing to the supplier a written certification claiming exemption. This is the same procedure that presently applies to persons who are entitled to an exemption from sales tax but who are not registered. No amendments to the law are required, naturally, for this procedure.

These new exemptions will apply from 19 October 1990. I have a problem with this date, except for paragraph 7 (a) which refers to regulation 12 and which will commence on the day that the Act receives royal assent. To qualify for sales tax exemption, each individual piece of computer equipment will need to satisfy the definition of eligible computer equipment. The definition, while not exhaustive, primarily includes hardware and excludes accessories such as computer furniture and consumable items. So the exclusion also extends to telecommunication equipment such as satellite dishes and private automatic branch exchange systems.

The Government's estimate of the cost of providing exemption for this computer equipment is $44m in 1990-91 and $70m in 1991-92. In his second reading speech on the Bill, the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) made the comment that the Bill will assist Australian manufacturers to become more competitive in the international environment.

I would hate to shatter any illusions of those on the front bench, the Minister or the Government he represents, by suggesting that any manufacturer who has been waiting for a government to change its sales tax laws before updating its equipment to the latest computer technology will have already missed the international market competitive boat. I think this is a reflection on the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce as well as tax and other areas. I think it is most important that our laws, particularly our taxation laws, keep up with advances in technology to ensure that the manufacturing sector of the community remains internationally competitive. It cannot do this unless our laws keep abreast and provide the right sorts of deductions in terms of changing technology. So rather than being a piece of legislation which provides the impetus for manufacturers to move into the latest technology, it is what I would term catch-up legislation.

The Australian Taxation Office has been dealing with an increasing number of cases where manufacturers have not paid sales tax on computer equipment purchases. Manufacturers have not paid the tax, believing that the equipment was purchased to be an aid to manufacture and thus was exempt. Regrettably, we have a difficulty with the Taxation Office because it is now arguing that sales tax is owed. This is very much a backward-looking piece of legislation. It shows neither foresight nor vision about where the manufacturing industry may be heading. It also lacks any understanding of the impact of modern technology through computerisation on job structures.

By way of illustration on this point, I refer to the case of the computers used in manufacturing printed matter, particularly newspapers and magazines. The Australian Taxation Office has on its books at least 12 cases of newspapers that have not paid sales tax on updated computer equipment. The bone of contention has been computer equipment used by general journalists. The problem is the lack of proper definition of and extension to `general journalists'. Approximately 15 to 20 years ago, for most newspapers, the process of producing general journalist input into the final newspaper went something like this: the general journalist or a local reporter would come into the office and bash out the story on a typewriter. He would not include a heading, an introductory paragraph or any font information. When the story was passed to the subeditor, this information would subsequently be added. Having been edited by the subeditor, this piece of paper with all the necessary markings would then go on to the production department. In this department the story would have to pass through three different machines-one for the heading, one for the introductory paragraph and, finally, one for the body of the story.

This typesetting has gone through a number of different technological developments but typically it was done on a linotype or tape perforator machine. The next stage was for the original copy and the proof from the typesetting process to be compared by proofreaders. Any difference, where marked, was taken back for correction. Once corrected, printing could commence. Under this system, the aids to manufacture sales tax exemption applied from the production department step in the process onwards. This is the point that I wish to make.

Using this technology it is evident that the keystrokes which were used for printing the final product were formed at the production stage where rekeying of the general journalist's story occurred. I think that fellow senators will agree that this process was riddled with inefficiencies, particularly the duplication of keying in the story first by the journalists, then by the subeditor, and finally by the production department.

Typically, I believe that the way technology now enables the system to work is as follows-and the reporters upstairs might like to correct me-the reporter enters his story, including the heading, introductory paragraph and fonts into the computer system. The subeditor is then able to call up the story on his screen and do any editing which may be required. Using the latest technology it is possible for a general journalist to view, on his computer monitor, the page on which the story is to appear and to type the story straight into the space specified for it. Once the article is typed in, the general journalist is able to give the necessary commands, from the computer terminal, to have the story or the whole page printed out on bromide paper ready for the printing plate to be made. There is no need for the story to pass through a subeditor before it becomes the final product.

The other aspect about a newspaper industry's technology is that all functions to produce a newspaper can be done on the same computer terminal. This is the difference nowadays with modern technology. Individual computer terminals and keyboards are not job-specific. I think that this is the problem with the legislation: the terminals and keyboards are not job-specific but the legislation tries to relate them to particular types of personnel. Telephone advertisements, Australian Associated Press information, sports results and subediting can all be done on any one of the machines installed as part of the total system.

So with the changing technology, brought about to remove inefficiencies and keep the industry commercially viable, there came a change in job specification. Virtually the whole production department became redundant. A reskilling of the work force was required along with a reassignment of roles which were negotiated with the unions and the Australian Journalists Association.

In the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), which is before us today, the clauses dealing with the exemption of computers used in the finalising of text or artwork to be printed are as follows: the equipment which is to be used mainly by a subeditor will qualify for exemption-I have no problem with that; equipment which is to be used by a person who is designated as a journalist but who performs predominantly an editing role on the third party source material will also qualify; and equipment which is used to set, display or classify will also qualify.

The definition inserted in subclause 1(1) of the first schedule to the principal Act by paragraph 4 (b) of the Bill excludes equipment which is going to be used by a general journalist from the sales tax exemption. I am concerned at the non-exclusion of computer equipment used by general journalists employed by newspapers and magazine manufacturers. My reasons are as follows: firstly, the definition of the term `general journalist' focuses on the designation of the individual rather than on the type of work performed. Without the input of the general journalist, the final product is not the same.

For example, I now indicate the way the Australian which was produced on 18 October would appear. I must say that page one of the Australian on that date was not particularly interesting. The front page would be very boring without the input of the general journalist, but at least we would have the photograph of Archbishop Hollingworth to look at. To reiterate the point that I made earlier concerning the technology and induced job structure changes in the case of general journalists, they now perform the majority of the functions previously performed by the typesetter for the articles which appear in the end product.

The manufacturing process which results in the newspaper as the end product begins with the general journalist sitting down at the keyboard to key in his or her story. Technology has changed, job descriptions have changed, and the Government's thinking on this point needs to change so that it reflects the practice of today and not the practice of 20 years ago. I think that this paper illustrates my point.

Another flaw in the Government's thinking on this Bill which I mentioned earlier but will reiterate because it illustrates my point is the implication that equipment used by general journalists is somehow different from that which other contributors to the newspaper's manufacture use. This is certainly not the case. Computer equipment is not job specific; that is the problem. The only reason terminals are assigned either to advertising classifications or to the journalist section and so on is for job flow efficiency and for supervisory reasons. Small newspapers, which typically provide a valuable community service, could well be discriminated against by this Bill; and that is one of my major objections. In the small newspaper area, for example, the general journalist is more than likely also to be the subeditor. Thus, there is uncertainty as to whether this equipment would be sales tax exempt under this Bill or not. I believe that some clarification is required on the role performed by the general journalist vis-a-vis subeditors, in particular where the roles are merged, if the coalition's point of view is not accepted. Certainly there is need for an income tax ruling.

The loss of sales tax income as a result of extending this exemption to also include terminals used by general journalists is estimated by the industry to be no more than $2m. Given the number of other budgetary changes which the Government has made since August, particularly in social security and other areas, it is not a large figure, but the Government has to focus on improving industry efficiencies. This is one area on which it could well focus some attention.

On the subject of definitions, the definition of `finalisation' appears far too restrictive and requires relatively detailed knowledge of what constitutes editing and subediting in the context of a newspaper or magazine. This definition should at least be cross-referenced with the definition of `general journalist' and the reference to `subeditor' for purposes of clarification.

Another area which the Government needs to tidy up is that which covers equipment used by a journalist mainly in an editing role on externally sourced material. While under the explanatory memorandum's definition of `general journalist' it is stated that `the term will not include a journalist who performs predominantly an editing role on third party sourced material such as international news which comes into a publishing house via a wire service', this is not stated in the Bill as such.

While tidying up the legislation for the Government, I should also like to mention the reference to `manufacturer' in paragraph (4) (a) of the schedule which, if it is intended to include a deemed manufacturer of printed matter, needs clarification. This needs to be stated, and is another deficiency in the legislation. The definition of `architectural/structural design computer equipment' might also need to be reworded if it is not to operate, in conjunction with paragraph (2) (f), to exclude the designs of major items of plant which become structures. Last year, at roughly the same stage in the Senate sitting program, the Senate had before it a sales tax Bill, over which the Government had some difficulty in telling the difference between a microchip and other forms of firmware. Once this problem was brought to its attention, the Government, to its credit, did make the necessary alterations to sort it out. I am hoping that the same will apply again today.

The exclusion for software generation computer equipment and specifically paragraph (b), which reads, `the goods are not mainly for use in connection with the embodying of the program concerned in a microchip', should be reconsidered for the following reasons. First, often it would not be known at the time software is developed whether it would be embodied in a microchip. Secondly, the software design might be embodied in something other than a microchip but still be firmware. Thirdly, the use of the phrase `for use in connection with' might not necessarily create the linkage which is sought.

Another issue is whether computer equipment used to produce designs and plans, where the design process involves a degree of programming, is excluded from the design engineering computer equipment exemption because it could fall within subparagraph (a) of the definition of `software generation computer equipment' and is not excluded by subparagraphs (b) and (c) of that definition. Computer equipment used to produce designs and plans could well fall within the design engineering computer equipment exemption, notwithstanding that the design process involves a degree of programming. It would therefore be desirable if the Minister were to clarify that such computer equipment does in fact constitute `eligible computer equipment' for the purposes of proposed clause (2) (1) of the first schedule.

On the topic of manufacturing equipment, there is no specific reference to specification testing, scientific research and maintenance equipment. I believe a specific reference is necessary, particularly in the case of scientific research and maintenance equipment. Many large scale manufacturers use computer systems extensively to control and schedule plant maintenance.

There are also a couple of vagaries with regard to items of computer equipment. First, there is no reference to typesetting equipment or to pagefax equipment. Secondly, paragraph (m) of the definition excludes a device that forms part of the infrastructure of a telecommunications network. However, it would appear, in theory at least, that where the telecommunication network is installed solely to facilitate manufacturing activities this definition might operate to exclude equipment which is intended to be covered-for example, analogue-to-digital converters, modems and cables which might all form part of a specific telecommunications infrastructure.

Creativity also receives a rap across the knuckles from the Government in this legislation. I have already mentioned the case of computer equipment used by general journalists not being exempt. This non-exemption also stretches to authors and specifically mentions original literary, dramatic, musical or artistic work. There is no incentive to encourage creativity at all in this Bill, and this is a further indictment. If the Government wins the day on this Bill-and surely it will because of the guillotine process-then the only incentive it has given the newspaper and magazine industry is to use imported material or second-hand articles. The reporter covering local events and issues is being given the thumbs down treatment and is discriminated against.

Although I have not heard from any groups representing the authors of literary, dramatic, musical or artistic work in this country, if I were one of them I would not be pleased with this Bill. The main problem that I see for authors in this Bill comes under the definition of `eligible print finalisation activities', where the computer equipment used to create text or images that embody an eligible original literary, dramatic, musical or artistic work is sales tax exempt where the finalisation is not carried out by the author, or any of the authors, of the work. Again, they are discriminated against.

I am sure that the Senate will appreciate that more often than not the author is the person best placed to do the finalisation of his or her piece of literature or music, particularly on the modern day technological scene. No-one else can know what they are wanting to portray by the words and notes they have used. Thus, the Government has made a very definite move by including this paragraph in the definition to exclude the `creative' sector of our society, including authors and the other people I have mentioned.
In concluding, I wish to draw to the Senate's attention the Minister's comments in his second reading speech:
The Government intends to examine further options to relieve the impact of sales tax on business inputs in the sales tax simplification review announced by the Treasurer in this year's Budget.

Why did he not do that job in this Bill for this particular purpose if he had that in mind? We in this place have heard the Government regularly mention the phrases `tax simplification' and `micro-economic reform'. Along with the rest of the nation, we look forward to some action. We have been promised some action, but we need such action now on this front. This Bill, given the state in which the country now finds itself, only adds further to the sales tax confusion. It is additional proof of the need to convert to a goods and services tax, as proposed by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1990, as well as the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990. I shall address my remarks first to the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill and then proceed to the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill. My colleague Senator Coulter will later offer some remarks on amendments that he is moving to the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The main purpose of the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) is to amend the Bounty (Computers) Act 1984 to allow the extension of the scheme from 6 July 1990 to 31 December 1995. The Bill provides for the rate of bounty to be phased down from 20 per cent to 9 per cent of factory costs. The Australian Democrats, after due consideration, do not oppose the phasing down of this bounty. We have had extensive consultation with industry bodies in this particular industry and we believe that the phasing down is being carried out at that level with the full agreement and support of the industry. So, it is for that reason that we are pleased to support it.

The Democrats believe that the phasing down will act to restore the relationship between the effective rates of assistance for the information technology sector and will align it with the rest of the manufacturing sector. It is interesting to examine and compare the performance of Australian indigenous companies and foreign companies that receive the bounty in the industry technology sector. Australia is the only market in the world where most of the United States, European, Japanese, Asian and indigenous companies operate. These companies use Australia as a testing ground, in many cases, for new products and new strategies. The top three ranking companies in terms of sales revenue are: IBM Australia Ltd, Telecom Australia and Alcatel STC Australia. The top three Australian-owned companies last year were: Telecom Australia, Computer Power Group Ltd and Imagineering Technology Ltd.

Only 11 of the top 20 bounty recipients, and three of the top five bounty recipients are Australian indigenous companies. Of course, this means that nearly half of the recipients are non-Australian; a bleak and typical snapshot of Australian high-tech industry. Most disturbing is the fact that export performance is highest in non-Australian companies. Fewer than half of the top 50 Australian information technology companies export technology. However, the sector has a number of strong export performers resulting in an export propensity-that is, exports as a percentage of total sales-of between 39 and 51 per cent. The strongest performers are foreign transnationals who use Australia as a centre for sourcing the regional inputs for particular products. Nevertheless, if we look at Australian exporters alone, they have an export propensity of 40 per cent and are performing reasonably well. Let us hope that this trend can be improved over time. In this context, I draw the attention of the Senate to claims made by the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent), in the other place, that these transnationals often rig transfer pricing mechanisms in order to qualify for bounty assistance. I express concern at these remarks and would ask the Minister to comment on this allegation and certainly to investigate them as quickly and as effectively as possible.

Notwithstanding the nationality of the recipients of the bounty, it is accepted that the bounty has assisted in increasing exports. This is confirmed in the recent Bureau of Industry Economics Program Evaluation report No. 8-the Computer Bounty Scheme. Let us hope the reduction in the bounty does not have an unfavourable effect on our export performance. The Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray), in his speech, emphasised the continuation of the bounty to encourage research and development. The Australian Democrats certainly support this objective and agree that targeted government assistance is crucial in this area. The Bureau of Industry Economics report states that the sector is a strong research and development performer with an average research and development intensity-in other words, the ratio of research and development expenditure to turnover-of 9 per cent, well and truly above the manufacturing average of one per cent.

The Minister states that the bounty has been instrumental in the development of a number of industry sectors, in particular growth of 25 per cent in the sector in this industry which produces bountiable equipment. However, the Bureau of Industry Economics in its report on the computer bounty scheme states:
This suggests that the bounty has been influential in encouraging industry growth. The significance of this growth is more difficult to ascertain.

It is, in fact, difficult to determine the actual contribution of the bounty to the growth of the information industry for a number of reasons-firstly, the prevailing economic circumstances, notably the movements in the Australian dollar resulting in increased export market activity in 1985-86 and a decrease in 1988-89. Furthermore, the firms that receive the bounty may also be recipients of other government assistance as part of the Government's information industry strategy such as the export market development grants scheme, the 150 per cent tax concession for research and development and the partnerships for development scheme.

In closing my remarks on this Bill, I want to make it clear that the Australian Democrats believe in government intervention in the marketplace and, in particular, in overseas trade. This involves consumer protection but it also involves assistance to industry where such assistance leads to improved outcomes. In supporting this Bill, we are in no way embracing the free market deregulation mania to which the old parties are increasingly drawn. Experience in other Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development nations shows that proper government policies yield economic and societal benefits. In this context, I eagerly await Senator Button's forthcoming industry policy statement. Certainly, it is clear that our export industries deserve a concerted and well thought through program of government assistance and encouragement.

I now turn to the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1990. The Bill implements a Budget commitment of the Government to exempt from sales tax computers used by manufacturers and people who process goods on behalf of manufacturers where they are acquired from 19 October 1990 onwards. There are four basic situations where exemption will be granted. Firstly, computers used by manufacturers to design goods for manufacture; secondly, computers used by manufacturers to schedule, monitor and control the production of goods; thirdly, computers used in the finalisation of text or graphics in the printing industry, including those used by typesetters and subeditors in producing newspapers; and fourthly, computers used in a combination of the previously mentioned functions. The exemptions also apply to subcontractors who carry out the relevant functions on behalf of manufacturers. The estimated cost of these measures is $44m this year and $70m next year.

The Australian Democrats support this legislation. However, we do not understand the rather arbitrary treatment which is being imposed upon the newspaper industry under the Bill, so I join Senator Watson in his criticisms of the Government in this area. I understand that negotiations have been conducted between some members of the industry and the Government concerning the problems in the legislation, and I hope this will be resolved in a satisfactory manner.

The proposals appear particularly disadvantageous for smaller newspapers such as country or regional publications and do not appear to have any rationale. Whether or not a particular story ends up in a particular newspaper is irrelevant. The fact that the story was prepared for inclusion in a newspaper is surely enough to qualify as part of the manufacturing process of the newspaper. The subediting and editing functions are akin to a quality control process, yet the stories which are discarded are still part of the production process and the equipment used predominantly by journalists to produce these stories should also qualify for sales tax exemption.

I certainly believe that the Government should immediately look at this particular situation and the series of anomalies which affect the production of newspapers. I urge the Government, as Senator Watson has, to take urgent action in this particular area. The Australian Democrats will certainly be pressing the Minister to introduce satisfactory amendments early in the new year. Although aids to manufacture and auxiliaries to aids are exempt from sales tax, one of the major problems of the wholesale tax is that it does tax some business inputs. This Bill eliminates some of these extra costs but only in the areas which have been specifically mentioned.

I welcome the Budget announcement of the complete review of the wholesale sales tax. Hopefully, the review will lead to the total elimination of the liability to sales tax on business inputs. This, in turn, will assist the competitiveness of Australian industry. However, the current situation is not a major impediment to our exporters in the terms that the Opposition claims. The total effect is less than 2 per cent of our exports and this should be noted.

Another furphy being run by the Opposition to justify its proposed broad-based consumption tax is that exported goods are taxed under the wholesale sales tax. Except in the very limited case of business inputs, goods for export are exempt from wholesale sales tax and always have been. The zero rating of exports under the Opposition's consumption tax proposal can be achieved by exempting all business inputs from sales tax in the first place. We look forward to the Government taking this action as a result of its forthcoming review. In fact, we much prefer this method of assisting our exporters, thus eliminating the need to tax every good and service.

Some examples of what the Opposition proposes to tax under its broad-based consumption tax are foods for human consumption; agricultural machinery, implements, equipment and materials-it wants to do so at a time when our rural industries are going to the wall; spectacles and eye glasses; and wallpaper paints, putties and wood filler. Talking about taxing the dead, the Opposition also proposes to tax coffins, cremation caskets, urns as well as wreath and floral tributes.

Not only does the Opposition propose to take from the dead, it also proposes to take from the young. Prams, strollers and pushers, which are at present exempt, would be taxed at 15 per cent under the Opposition's proposals. So too would sanitary napkins, pads and towels and wedding rings. People concerned about the environment will be unhappy to learn that goods for collecting solar rays will also be taxed.

My colleague Senator Coulter and I will be moving some amendments. My amendments seek to remove recycled plastic products from the imposition of sales tax. Products that are totally or in part made of recycled plastic would be affected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is that?

—I advise Senator Watson that I am re-running the amendments which the Opposition refused to support last time. These amendments relate to recycled plastic, recycled paper, aids for disabled people and certain computer equipment which assists disabled people. These amendments have been on the table for some three months and they are simply being re-run today. I would have hoped that, as sufficient notice has been given, these amendments would have received the support of the Opposition. Unfortunately, I have been advised that this is not going to be the case. The Opposition believes that it should wait until the Government assesses its own position in terms of the report of the Industry Commission which covers these proposals.

SPEECH.PARA: I find the Opposition's position extremely disappointing. The Government's position is also disappointing. But at least there is some rationale in what it is doing, even though I regret the delay which will result in suffering by handicapped people and further environmental damage. But I fail to understand why the Opposition, once again, has adopted the position that it should not interfere with Government policy, that it should wait until the Government makes up its mind.

Why on earth does Senator Watson take his place in the Senate when he is not prepared to move amendments to the Government's legislation-amendments which, I believe, by far the greater majority of his constituents would support? Since the Opposition last neglected to support these amendments, I have received literally hundreds of letters asking why on earth we have not been able to get the amendments through the Senate. My answer was that the Opposition felt that it should not help disabled people; that it should not exempt from sales tax products that advance environmental protection and conservation. Once again, I will have to tell people that the Opposition has adopted a similar position.
Half way through today I thought there was a glimmer of hope that Senator Watson would be able to talk his colleagues into supporting at least some of these amendments. But that was not to be.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can we talk about something we don't have before us?

—The amendments which are currently being circulated in the chamber have been in Senator Watson's possession for three months. I have advised Senator Watson that I will be putting those amendments again. I do not know how much notification Senator Watson requires. Maybe I should make it six months next time. I now advise Senator Watson that if the Opposition knocks back the amendments again, I will move them again as soon as a sales tax Bill comes before the House. I trust that that will be enough notice for Senator Watson.

SPEECH.PARA: Very little remains to be said, except to repeat that I am extremely disappointed that when we have such clear cut issues such as conservation measures that benefit our environment and assistance to disabled people, we cannot gain support from the old parties. This once again shows that they have had their day. Members of those parties should leave this place. The running of this country should be left to people who want to turn it into a forward looking nation-a nation that cares for its people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1990 and the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990. I propose to direct my remarks to the bounty legislation. Debate on this Bill has been curtailed because of the guillotine motion moved by the Government and supported by the Australian Democrats. Nonetheless, I will endeavour in the time available to make the points that need to be made.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worthwhile exploring the question of why this Bill is part of the guillotine program. The Bill ought to have been introduced in the last session before the winter recess. The Government simply forgot that the bounty scheme ran out on 5 July 1990 and, therefore, properly ought to have been replaced in the last session. Despite the retrospective nature of this Bill-and this Government is becoming progressively adept at introducing retrospective legislation-there are still serious legal questions that arise as to the legality of the bounty payments which have been made subsequent to the expiry of the old scheme and the introduction of this one.

We said very strongly in the debate that ensued after the Government moved the guillotine motion-and I spoke in this debate-that the result of having to deal with 52 Bills in such a short time as a week and a bit would be poor legislation. We have seen plenty of examples of poor legislation coming before this chamber. One of this morning's newspapers carried a story that the Australian Securities Commission had discovered a serious flaw in the new corporation legislation which was guillotined through the Parliament. The Government had failed to include the legal requirement for managers and trustees to comply with the covenants of trust deeds, which was the law under the old scheme. This was simply left out of the current legislation.

As well as that, my colleague Senator Watson, in dealing with the sales tax Bill now before us, gave examples of how the legislation is both poorly drafted and fails to take into account the way in which technology has advanced. Having seen the way in which the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce (DITC) has failed in its duty to introduce bounty legislation within an adequate time, it is not surprising that this morning we saw that the recently appointed head of the Department, Dr Malcolm McIntosh, is resigning after being in the job for only six months.

This follows the report last week that the Managing Director of Austrade, Mr Lindsay MacAlister, has resigned. What other resignations are in the pipeline for DITAC? Dare I suggest that it might be the Minister himself? This Department has failed to deliver any coherent, sensible or, indeed, successful industry policy. People are bailing out of it like rats from a sinking ship.

I now turn to the Bill itself. The Bill extends the computer bounty scheme until 30 December 1995 and, furthermore, makes some amendments to the textile yarns legislation-another piece of legislation that was introduced hurriedly at the end of last year. In our debate on that Bill we outlined problems that we foresaw occurring and, indeed, they have now been seen by the Government to occur, so in this Bill the opportunity is taken to amend part of that legislation as well. Basically, we support the extension of the computer bounty scheme, firstly, because it provides for predictability and certainty within the computer sector; secondly, because it reduces the overall rate of assistance; and, thirdly, because we acknowledge that bounties are less distortional than tariffs or quotas. However, our support for the Bill should not be seen as an endorsement of the strategic trade approach of the Australian Manufacturing Council, because we simply do not uphold that attitude.

In discussing this legislation, it is important to look at the review that the Bureau of Industry Economics (BIE) conducted in July last year when it was requested to undertake an evaluation of the bounty scheme. The Bureau invited written submissions from bounty recipients and conducted a postal survey to which 72 recipients of the bounty responded. Of the respondents to the survey, 24 per cent indicated that they were not satisfied with the administration of the bounty scheme by the Australian Customs Service-which is quite interesting in light of the other criticisms that have been levelled against the Australian Customs Service. This is one more aspect that obviously needs attention. The dissatisfaction interacts with various anomalies which are noted within the scheme. These anomalies arise because goods which are similar in character to bountiable items are assisted by tariffs rather than by bounties and disputes have arisen within the Customs Service as to which items are eligible for a bounty and which are not.

In addition, on the import side, components of some items which might be covered by the bounty and therefore enter duty free have had tariff duties imposed. This is particularly the case with communications-related equipment where products intended to be covered by the bounty are closely related in function and manufacturing technology to tariff-protected goods. Further findings of that survey show that the number of claimants increased from 11 in 1984-85 to 179 in 1988-89, that payments under the scheme similarly rose from $1m to $35m and that the average bounty paid last year was $174,000.

It would seem that the bounty played a relatively minor role in the performance of the sector overall. The report acknowledged that changes in the value of the Australian dollar, rather than the scheme itself, had a marked influence on the performance of the industry. To back up that point, 26 per cent of survey respondents stated that their level of production would not be affected at all if the bounty scheme was removed altogether, and 44 per cent of respondents stated that their level of export activity would not be affected if the scheme was removed altogether.

The review was also particularly useful in that it criticised the strategic trade theory which is currently gaining some headway with some members of the Government and some people within the bureaucracy. Of course, it must always be identified as just another version of the argument for targeting assistance and it suffers the same pitfalls as does the practice of picking winners generally. As I said earlier, we in the Liberal and National parties prefer the use of bounties rather than tariffs and quotas because we see two benefits which are quite important. The first is that the value added bounty is a way of supporting domestic producers while enabling consumers to obtain products at world prices, and the second is that bounties provide a more visible form of assistance.

The BIE found that the assistance afforded through the computer bounty is closely in line with that for the rest of manufacturing, with the exception of the passenger motor vehicle and, of course, the textile, clothing and footwear industries. What the report did not do-and it would have been useful if it had-was assess how many firms had fallen by the wayside in spite of receiving bounties, because respondents to the survey about the scheme were those who were in receipt of the bounty and who were now exercising a 150 per cent research and development tax concession or partnership in development programs to augment the computer bounty. Further, the Bureau did not identify what proportion of the expansion of the industry over the life of the bounty was attributable to the bounty itself and not to other forms of Government assistance and the increased demand for products or the fluctuations, particularly of the exchange rate.

A couple of other points are also important. These relate to the differences between what the Bill does and what the BIE report in fact found and would have recommended. There is a discrepancy between the financial impact statement of the Bill and the forecast level of bounty predicted by the BIE. On the one hand, the explanatory memorandum to the Bill estimates that the cost of extending the computer scheme will be as follows: in 1990-91, $37.6m; in the following year, 1991-92, $38m; in 1992-93, $36m; in 1993-94, $34m; in 1994-95, $32m; and, in 1995-96, $25m. On the other hand, the BIE predicted that until 1992-93, with the same rates as were adopted by the Government, bounty payments would level off from July 1990 at about $33m per year. It will be interesting to see which prediction is in fact accurate.

The coalition has an alternative for industry. The coalition offers certainty by informing industry now of our goal to reduce industry protection to negligible levels by the year 2000. We offer complementary measures of structural reform, such as an industrial relations system featuring voluntary enterprise-based agreements and guaranteed voluntary unionism; the injection of competition into telecommunications; waterfront reform which will take away cabotage from Australian waters; and, most importantly, reform of the unsatisfactory regime of taxation, including wholesale sales taxes and the introduction of a goods and services tax.

As I have said, in supporting this piece of legislation the Opposition in no way wishes to signal that it supports the strategic trade theory, which is only another way of expressing the picking of winners. As I also said, this legislation is another example of the fact that the Government is incapable of managing its own business. Its Department failed to introduce the legislation prior to the expiry of the previous scheme and thus we are again indulging in retrospectivity, with a question mark hanging over payments made between the expiry of the last scheme and the introduction of this scheme. This Bill is serving a dual purpose in fixing up problems that have resulted from the textile yarns legislation introduced in the last session-problems which were foreshadowed by the Opposition, both in the House of Representatives and by myself in the Senate. The Bill is part of the overall guillotine program which has seen other pieces of legislation forced through without adequate debate and with subsequent errors showing up in that legislation. It is a sad way to go into Christmas- to see a Government racing through 52 pieces of legislation simply because it is not able to manage its own program and handle its own departments in a competent way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We differ very much from the Opposition in what Senator Bishop has just enunciated. It is very appropriate that the setting of appropriate tax rates, the payment of bounties and various other monetary measures should be used to move the society quite deliberately in the direction in which we wish it to move. Moreover, we believe that the Government should be taking a much more far-sighted view of where it wishes society to go and using those tax measures quite deliberately to encourage certain industries, to discourage other industries, to encourage certain practices, to discourage other practices and, quite deliberately, to move society in the direction in which it quite clearly needs to go.

SPEECH.PARA: It is in that context that I wish to speak to the amendments tabled in my name and which will be moved by my colleague Senator Spindler as a block. These are amendments to the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). In each case they relate to industries which very much need to be encouraged because of the direction in which we are now moving. I refer specifically to the increase in concentration of greenhouse gases in the global atmosphere and the consequences which will flow from those, one of which will be that in the very near future we will need to use industries which are much less polluting.

On previous occasions I have put before the Senate the figures which indicate that, as a country, Australia is very profligate in its use of fossil fuels. It uses roughly 4.5 tonnes per person per year of carbon-based fuels. According to the scientific report of the IPCC-the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change-which, interestingly, Senator Michael Baume quoted yesterday in his rather disparaging remarks about greenhouse, we need to reduce our carbon dioxide emissions down to 0.35 tonnes per person per year as rapidly as possible; in other words, Australia needs to achieve about a 92 per cent reduction in per capita release of carbon-based gases, principally carbon dioxide.

Australia has removed the sales tax from photovoltaic cells and the array of equipment that goes with them. I do not know whether it is as a consequence of that, but it does so happen that per head Australia produces more photovoltaic cells than any other country. As I think other honourable senators would know, we are the world's leading manufacturer of photovoltaic cells in terms of the efficiency achieved. Professor Martin Green of the University of New South Wales has achieved 24 per cent efficiency, which is the highest efficiency ever achieved. Professor Green's production line has been bought by BP Solar and has been put into production.

In the amendments which I am putting we are seeking to move into other areas of electricity generation with technologies which are established, technologies which can produce electricity at a competitive rate with fossil fuel-based electricity, and in which we already have, as it were, a nascent industry in this country. We are seeking the removal of sales tax from devices which would be used to convert wind energy into electricity and, as with the solar cells, the ancillary equipment which would go with those.

We are also seeking to remove the sales tax from electrically-powered vehicles. Of course, the second of those would involve no cost to the Government at all because currently we do not produce electrically-powered vehicles. But we do have, in the case of the University of Sydney, a very interesting experiment going on in which vehicles are being developed which will have solar panels on the roof. They will generate about 30 per cent of the energy that will be used during that vehicle's use and, at the same time, the carport roof will be covered with photovoltaic cells which will charge batteries. That electricity will then be transferred into the batteries in the vehicle overnight. One could have a totally solar-powered car.

We do not have the whole technology together but this amendment seeks to encourage the development of that sort of industry. Certainly, we already have the makings of a comprehensive technology which would allow second vehicles-commuter-type vehicles-to be totally run on solar energy. We believe that this development is absolutely necessary. It is a development that needs to be put in place over the next 10 to 15 years. It would be encouraged if the sales tax were removed from electrically-powered vehicles, as with the other amendment removing the sales tax from the goods and other bits and pieces and services which would go along with that.

I turn briefly to one part of the amendment which will be moved by Senator Spindler and which has been moved before. It relates to the recycled paper component of goods containing recycled paper. I remind the Senate that originally it was a motion of mine which sought to remove the sales tax from recycled paper. It was voted down by the combined vote of the Government and the Opposition. Shortly thereafter the Government introduced its own piece of legislation to do that. Unfortunately, it has made a very bad error; that is, in the case of paper bought by, say, a printer who then prints on that paper and charges the ultimate consumer for the manufactured goods, the portion of the cost paid by the ultimate consumer which relates to the recycled paper is taxed, so there is indeed a tax on recycled paper in that area.

It is unfortunate that the Government has not seen fit to remove this anomaly. It can be got around by people purchasing the paper, taking it to the printer and then simply paying for the printing separately. But that is a rather unsatisfactory arrangement. I simply run that analysis past the Government again because it is an anomaly which the Government did not intend to put into its legislation when it removed the sales tax from recycled paper. It has put it in there and it needs to be removed. Senator Spindler's amendment seeks to do just that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1990 and the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990, which have the common thread of encouraging the development and utilisation of computer-based technologies.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish to take up too much of the time available in response, although there are a number of things I would otherwise wish to say, but I will respond to some of the major issues raised in the course of this debate and some of those raised by honourable senators. Some of the positive things about the computer bounty scheme need to be mentioned. Debates tend to focus on the things with which we disagree rather than the things which have been successful. That is inevitably the case because people do not want to spend a lot of time debating agreed things; they emphasise the differences because that is the nature of the forum. But one thing that is important and underemphasised in the computer bounties area, and which the Bureau of Industry Economics brought out, is the extent to which there is a thriving area of research and development in the industry benefiting from the bounty. This will make a very major contribution to the development of Australian industry.

The Bill will maintain the relationship between the assistance for this industry and manufacturing generally. That is appropriate and has been acknowledged by all honourable senators. It is a very important part of the continuing Government commitment to the industries in question.

I want to take the opportunity to respond to two points which Senator Bishop made. In one she wandered off into an attack on strategic trade theory. I think that she actually wished that somebody had advocated it so that she could criticise it; but nobody did, so she pretended that they had and somehow or other linked such things so that she could criticise strategic trade theory and recount a series of Opposition industry policy initiatives.

As an academic concept, strategic trade theory is quite distinct from anything that is currently in the public debate in Australia. But let us not pursue that tangent, except to say that it is quite possible for a government which does not believe in picking winners or in using the taxpayers' money to take entrepreneurial risks that ought not to be taken with taxpayers' money-it is not the government's money; it belongs to other people-to still be effective in the areas of export and industry assistance. Those two things are in no way mutually exclusive. It is proper that a sensible government continues to look at those issues. We do, we have and we will.

The other question that Senator Bishop raised related in two ways to the timetable for this legislation. She questioned the legality of payments made since 5 July 1990, when the current bounty Act expires. We have to distinguish between payments in two different circumstances under the existing legislation since that time; that is, payments that would have been owing, had the scheme been operating, for products manufactured outside the bounty period. That would not be eligible for payment under the expired scheme and no such payments have been made.

Payments have been made since 5 July on bounty for equipment completed prior to the expiry of the bounty period; that is, prior to 5 July. Even though the scheme had expired, the Act still exists and they were payments for production completed during the period set down in the Act. Therefore, payments were made during that period but for production that took place in the period covered by the then existing Act. Payments since 6 July have been made only in respect of bountiable production completed prior to 6 July, which is within the law. The Act has not expired; only the current bounty period has. This Act comes in to pick up the payments that might otherwise have been made for the period since 6 July.

As honourable senators may not know, as soon as the decision to continue the bounty was announced, which was on 12 June, the Minister for Small Business and Customs, Mr Beddall, wrote to all 250 bounty recipients advising them of the decision and to continue to lodge claims with the Australian Customs Service for processing pending enactment of the new legislation to enable payments to be made quickly should the Parliament pass the legislation. Customs advises that almost 200 claims have now been processed, worth about $5m. Payments can be made to eligible bounty recipients as soon as the Bill receives royal assent. A number of other claimants have chosen to delay lodging claims until the new legislation comes into force. We expect, with the support which I welcome from honourable senators for the legislation, that the recipients will be making those claims expeditiously. I would be very surprised if they did not.

I shall say a couple of things in conclusion about the sales tax legislation. I would love to have had the opportunity to debate a little more the goods and services tax issue which Senator Bishop raised. It is a bit of a tangent but not one I initiated. I will simply say that it is another example of proposing to fight inflation by putting up prices and I remain unimpressed by it. It is interesting that people argue for a broadly based consumption tax at the same time as they are talking about increasing the exemptions within the sales tax system.

I welcome the support for the legislation and the debate around it. I indicate to Senator Watson that I note the questions that he will put on notice. Although I will not be able to fulfil the timetable on these matters as I have with other matters-because these questions only came in late on Thursday-I will get him prompt answers although not by tomorrow, I would have thought. I will respond very briefly to the Australian Democrats' amendments in the committee stage. Once again, I indicate in regard to the amendments moved by Senator Spindler that I am no more disposed to support them this time than I was last time and that we will not be supporting the amendment proposed by Senator Coulter. However, we can discuss those in the committee stage. I thank honourable senators for their support for the Bills.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: SALES TAX AMENDMENT BILL
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek the leave of the Committee, because of the operation of the guillotining process, to incorporate in Hansard 12 questions that relate to the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill No. 3. I seek responses by Senator McMullan at a later time, preferably this session, but I understand that some of the questions might be technical and that it might not be possible to have answers before the Senate rises.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The questions read as follows-
QUESTIONS FOR COMMITTEE STAGE OF SALES TAX BILL NO. 3
Part 1-Clause 2

1. Date of operation. I am aware that the Tax office has before it a number of cases where manufacturers have claimed exemption based on the premise that the equipment is an aid to manufacture but the ATO is claiming sales tax is owing. If this Bill is passed what is the situation for those companies whose equipment was bought before l9th October?
Part 2-Section 4 (B)

2. Concerned about the changed focus on people rather than their roles at work performed. Departure from the norm of sales tax references. Does the Minister agree that the definition of the term ``general journalist'' focuses on the designation of the individual rather than the type of work performed.

3. Does the Minister also concede that this Bill discriminates against small newspapers because the general journalist is more than likely to also be the sub-editor thereby denying sales tax exemption?

4. Given that the role of ``general journalist'' and sub-editor is often merged, does the Minister agree that this situation requires clarification within the Bill in order not to discriminate against efficient small papers?

5. The definition of finalisation appears too restrictive or alternatively requires relatively detailed knowledge of what constitutes editing/subediting in the context of a newspaper or magazine. Should not the definition of ``finalisation'' should be amended to read:

``In relation to text or images includes inputting, editing, formatting, typesetting and similar activities where carried out in connection with a publication or printed matter which will be manufactured.''

6. While it is the intent of the Bill, as explained in the explanatory memorandum ``the term (general journalist) will not include a journalist who performs predominantly an editing role on third party sourced material such as international news which comes into a publishing house via a wire service,'' the wording does not achieve this. Should not the wording be amended such that the intent is obvious from the Bill, rather than the reader having to rely on the explanatory memo.

7. I draw the Minister's attention to the definition of architectural/structural design computer equipment which might need to be reworded if it is not to operate, in conjunction with paragraph (2) (F) of Clause 2, to exclude the designs of major items of plant which often becomes structures.

8. I suggest to the Minister that the exclusion for ``software generation computer equipment'' and specifically paragraph (B) which reads, ``The goods are not mainly for use in connection with the embodying of the program concerned in a microchip'' should be reconsidered. The reasons for this are:
(a) It would not be known at the time software is developed whether it would be embodied in a microchip.

(b) The software design might be embodied in something other than a microchip but still be `firmware'; and thirdly, the use of the phrase ``for use in connection with'' might not necessarily create the linkage which is sought.
9. Pursuant to sub-paragraph (D) of Sub-clause 2 (2), goods which constitute ``software-generation computer equipment'' are excluded from the design/engineering computer equipment exemption.

An issue arises as to whether computer equipment used to produce designs and plans, where the design process involves a degree of programming, is excluded from the design/engineering computer equipment exemption because it falls within sub-paragraph (a) of the definition of ``software-generation computer equipment'' and is not excluded by sub-paragraphs (B) and (C).

It would be desirable if the Minister were to clarify that such computer equipment constitutes ``eligible computer equipment'', for the purposes of proposed Sub-clause 2 (1) of the first schedule to the Act, by making an appropriate statement during the course of the debate in relation to the Bill.

10. With regards to items of computer equipment, I wonder if the Minister could confirm whether eligible equipment includes typesetting equipment or pagefax equipment as neither are mentioned specifically?

11. Paragraph (M) of the definition of `items of computer equipment' excludes from exemption a device that forms part of the infrastructure of a telecommunications network. However, it would appear that where the telecommunication network is installed solely to facilitate manufacturing activities, this definition might operate to exclude equipment which is intended to cover. For example, analogue digital converters, modems and cables which might all form part of a specific telecommunications infrastructure.

12. There is no specific reference to specification testing, scientific research and maintenance equipment in the Bill. I believe a specific reference is necessary particularly in the case of scientific research and maintenance equipment as many large scale manufacturers use computer systems extensively to control and schedule plant maintenance.
I would welcome the Minister's comments on this.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Committee. I also seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the partly blanked out front page of the Australian newspaper, indicating the effect of the problems of the limited exemptions in the sales tax legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Clause 2, page 1, subclause (2), line 10, omit ``Paragraph 7 (a) commences'', insert ``Paragraphs 4 (da), (db), (dc), (dd), (de) and (df) and 7 (a) commence.''.
2. Clause 4, page 10, after paragraph 4 insert the following paragraphs:

`(1a) The recycled paper component of goods containing recycled paper'; Nos 1 to 9
(db) by inserting after item 60 the following new item:

(dc) by omitting sub-item (1) from item 123 and substituting the following sub-item:

(dd) by inserting in item 123A, after paragraph (d), the Nos 1 to 9 following new paragraph:

(de) by omitting from item 135a `in the transportation to and from gainful employment';'
(df) by inserting after item 153 the following items:

` 153a (2) Parts for goods covered by sub-item (1)
`153b (1) Electrically-powered motor vehicles Nos 1 to 9
` 153b (2) Parts for goods covered by sub-item (1)'.''.

To a large extent these amendments have been placed before the Senate on a previous occasion. They refer to the exemption from sales tax of recycled plastic products where such products are entirely, or partly, composed of recycled plastic. In addition, the amendment seeks to rectify a previous mistake where legislation was passed to exempt recycled paper from sales tax, but omitted to exempt that part of a product composed of recycled paper from sales tax.

There are a number of amendments which seek to eliminate sales tax from communication aids for disabled people and seek to widen the clause by which sales tax is to be removed from cars which are used for the transportation of disabled people. We seek to widen that from the limitation that it only happens in a case where a car is being used to and from gainful employment. As I have said, these amendments have been moved previously. They also include a widening of the clause which, in general terms, allows goods designed and manufactured especially for the use of disabled people to be exempt from sales tax.

It is with regret that I note that neither the Opposition nor the Government sees fit to accept these amendments which are modelled on the recommendations of the Industry Commission report put down earlier this year. The Government says it needs further time to assess these recommendations and the Opposition says it needs further time to assess the Government's assessments. Here we have bureaucratic procrastination while people who could benefit-those who are least well off in our community-are once again sentenced to wait.

The same sorts of arguments apply to proposals to remove sales tax from re- cycled paper and plastic products. We are exhorted to recycle and we are exhorted to conserve our environment and energy. Here is a perfect opportunity to follow through with action, where people have used glowing words, but they renege.

Senator Coulter has described in some detail the amendments that he is seeking to move. They also cover extremely important conservation measures. Once again, one must express regret that, while members of the old parties profess to be concerned about our environment, they are not prepared to follow through with action. Nevertheless, I press these amendments and commend them to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Spindler has indulged in a great deal of debating licence in the manner in which he has put the Opposition's views. I would like to remind the Senate that the Opposition did not receive the final draft, which included some additional items-1 and 2 (da) to (de)-until well into the second reading debate. They do appear to be somewhat similar to items put previously. Given the importance of these items we are not prepared to take them on the run. The Liberal-National coalition believes that items under 2 (df), which it did have adequate time to address, appear to be too loosely drawn, and `vehicles' could perhaps be extended to include golf buggies and electrically driven vehicular toys.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that when amendments of this nature are drawn, it is responsible for a party to cost them. The Senate has been presented with a raft of amendments which have not been costed. The Senate does not know the cost to the revenue. I believe that when amendments are drawn consideration should be given to ensure that they are tightly drawn. For those reasons, the Opposition will not be able to support the Democrat amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must correct one statement that Senator Watson made. My amendments are not similar to amendments previously moved; they are identical. Senator Watson had three months notice. He had verbal notice from me a week ago that I would repeat those amendments. All that he has not seen is the printed word which arrived on his desk this afternoon. He has known all along that these amendments were to be moved this afternoon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take long on these matters because it is a discussion we have had before. We will continue to resist what I call the bowerbird theory of sales tax amendment, that is, flitting around finding all the shiny-looking bits and trying to stick them in a heap. It does not constitute rational tax policy or rational policy development at all.

SPEECH.PARA: In the case of people with disabilities I understand the attraction of the recommendations, but it appears-and I am going from recollection-that this is only picking and choosing from among the recommendations of the Industry Commission, those with which people feel comfortable. In the end, we may all want to look at the Industry Commission report and say we do not agree with it all, but I do not find it terribly persuasive that we have to agree because it is modelled on what the Industry Commission recommended, because it does not incorporate all its recommendations. Therefore, we think it is perfectly proper that those recommendations ought to be considered in conjunction with all the others.

As I said during the last debate on this matter, I am also extremely dubious that the use of the sales tax to achieve this objective is the most cost effective way of providing assistance to people with disabilities. It is often the case that the people in greatest need are those not in a position to benefit from assistance such as this. There are people with disabilities who cannot afford vehicles at all. It may well be that if we were talking about targeting our assistance, we would be giving an entirely different sort of priority to the expenditure of taxpayers' money to assist people with disabilities.

We dealt with the conservation amendment with regard to paper and plastic on a previous occasion. I think it is part of an uncoordinated grab bag, and there would be substantial administrative problems with it. It is not the way in which we think, at the moment, that we should proceed to deal with the environmental issues that are raised in the amendments which originated from Senator Spindler concerning recycled paper and plastic.

I have not had the opportunity to give detailed consideration to those issues raised by Senator Coulter. They fall into the same category. Not having had the opportunity to consider them in the context of all the other issues we are looking at, I am not prepared to support them at this stage. What I will be looking for is the outcome of the considerations of the sustainable development committees, many of which will deal with the issue of tax. That will put us in a position to come up with a coordinated response.

I think what distinguishes the Government and, perhaps the Opposition, from the Australian Democrats in this matter is not this buzz phrase that Senator Spindler would love people to adopt about old and new parties, or old and new senators, as the case may be, but the fact that some people have to deal with policy on the basis that either they have, or aspire to have, responsibility to actually implement the policies and some people do not. That is a distinction that I will continue to emphasise.

As I said at the start, we do not intend to enhance or pursue the bowerbird theory of sales tax policy development. We will try to do it in a consolidated and consistent manner as we have done over the last seven years.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Spindler's) be agreed to.
