DEBATE.TITLE: STEVEDORING INDUSTRY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990STEVEDORING INDUSTRY LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 October, on motion by Senator Cook:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over a month ago we were dealing with the Stevedoring Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 and the Stevedoring Industry Levy Amendment Bill 1990. I preface my remarks by saying that it seems silly that after waiting for over a month to finish this debate, we now have to finish it in a rush because the Government has guillotined this and many other Bills. It seems, again, a classic example of the Government's mismanagement of its own agenda--
—And the Democrats.

—And the Democrats. The mismanagement of the agenda by the Government and the Democrats means that we have to guillotine things and have this measure through when it has been sitting on the Notice Paper, half-heard, for over a month.

SPEECH.PARA: The Stevedoring Industry Levy Amendment Bill 1990 is intended to assist in phasing out the statutory general levy. It also provides for an adjustment of the statutory levies, whether general or special, to ensure that the reform program hoped to be achieved by the Government is met and to provide for adjustments of the levy rates by regulation rather than through legislation. We do not oppose this Bill but we suggest that a sunset clause needs to be incorporated in the legislation to ensure that the reform processes proceed with the urgency they deserve. We will move amendments to that effect later.

The second piece of legislation is the Stevedoring Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1990, which alters the constitution and functions of the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee, which authorises payments in respect of employers meeting obligations under the award. The principal Act will be amended to allow the Committee to make payments in respect of the new redundancy packages included in the agreement. When this matter was last adjourned, I was referring in particular to the situation in the Port of Cairns, which is of more general significance because it is the first of the regional ports in which the Government is attempting to implement its reform process. It is essential for all the regional ports in Australia that it be done correctly at Cairns. I am sad to say that the reform process in relation to the Cairns port, and therefore other regional ports in Australia, is not moving as well as it should.

Yesterday during Question Time I highlighted the scandalous situation that currently exists at the Cairns port. There has been meeting after meeting for over six months now, trying to get some resolution, when all along what was really needed was some leadership from the Government on this issue. The Government, in spite of its rhetoric and, I think, its genuine attempt to implement some reform on the waterfront, has not been game to take on the unions which control the Australian Labor Party to get reform where it should be.

Yesterday I gave the example of the situation in Cairns. After months of meetings, a little over a month ago the Water Industry Reform Authority (WIRA) said to the parties, `Go away. Come back with an agreement in a month's time. If you don't, we will do something about it and we will get the Minister to do something about it'. Practically nothing has happened. Because no agreements could be reached with the stevedoring companies, the Association of Employers of Waterfront Labour (AEWL), which I do not think represents the people it is supposed to represent, went away with three of the maritime unions and came up with a memorandum of agreement for Cairns. This agreement has not been referred to the users of the port, the port authority or the stevedoring company which operates out of this port.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have an interest.

—Well, indeed. It says in its terms of agreement, inter alia, that there should be nine workers at the port whereas the stevedoring company believes that four are sufficient, although it is prepared to concede an extra one. The stevedoring company says that only five workers are needed to work the Cairns port for the two companies there. Those two companies are Freeport Indonesia and Incitech. They need four or five people, but the agreement which the three waterfront unions and the AEWL are attempting to thrust on the Cairns port is that there should be nine employees out of the current 23 plus, on top of the nine, any of the other 23 who do not feel like retiring and taking the redundancy package now. It is anticipated from inquiries around the Cairns port that this will be another seven or eight, bringing the figure up to 16, 17 or 18 workers in a port that needs only four or five. That is a classic example of why our port situation is the way it is and why it is impossible to export through our ports at any competitive rate.

SPEECH.PARA: I am informed, and I accept, that if this proposal is implemented in the Cairns port the charges at today's rate would treble for the two companies using the port. One does not have to be anything of an economist to work out that trebling the charges to use the Cairns port for the two companies that use it will mean that those two companies will no longer be able to afford to work out of that port. That will have severe and dangerous repercussions for the Cairns port. It means that Freeport Indonesia will not be able to use that port. If it does not use the port, the other major user, Incitech, will not be able to use it either.

Freeport Indonesia has spent $34m in the Cairns community so far this financial year. It does that through its stevedores in getting stevedoring provisions for its ships going to the equatorial parts of the world. It also ships vehicles, food, tractors, goods, greases and oils and all those sorts of things-$34m worth-out of the Cairns port. In a community as small as Cairns, that is an enormous amount of money. If Freeport and Incitech have to leave the Cairns port because of the charges, that $34m, which multiples many times over in a small place like Cairns, will simply be lost to the community. I am advised on all the best estimations and research that that will mean the direct loss of some 300 jobs in the Cairns area. That will have a multiplier effect and will lead to a lot of other employment losses in these very difficult times for employment.

Already the Cairns community has suffered enormously from the pilots strike. It was just getting out of that when the recession-the recession we had to have-hit Cairns. That has led to the collapse of a number of major building companies and general trading companies in Cairns. They have then left their suppliers without payment and that is having a flow-on effect. It is a very difficult time and, because the Government cannot get its reform program in place, it looks very much as though the Cairns community will lose another $34m with the resulting loss of jobs and the flow-on effect.

It only needs the Government and the people it appoints to take a firm hand to make that port operate as it should; that is, with four or five workers rather than the 16 or 17 which the Waterside Workers Federation and its mates are trying to impose on Cairns port. It is a very serious thing; it is not just a matter such as one talks about in industrial relations in Sydney or Melbourne. This will have immediate and noticeable effects in the Cairns area simply because the Government cannot get its reform program up and running as it should.

It is a pity Senator Collins is not here because I genuinely believe that he recognises the problem and wants to do something about it. In fact, he has put his job on the line. On 7 May this year he said that he would resign after one year if there had not been a significant improvement in the process of reforming the waterfront. I am sorry to say to Senator Collins, because he tries hard and tries to do the right things, that he has only five months to live in his job. There is no way in the world that the Government will get the Cairns situation sorted out in five months, let alone the situation in the rest of Australia. It is a case where the Government should forget about its union bosses and move on and get the job done. As I mentioned, Cairns is the first regional port to be subject to this reform process and it will be used as a precedent. The sort of things I have just been talking about in relation to Cairns makes one realise the difficulties in working on the waterfront throughout Australia. I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later hour this day.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move the notice of motion standing in my name relating to the Therapeutic Goods Regulations, and to move a motion to provide a time limit for the debate on the notice of motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:

That if the debate on the motion for approval of the Therapeutic Goods Regulations is not concluded at the expiration of 75 minutes after the moving of the motion, the President shall then put the question on the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That in accordance with section 2 of the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989, the Senate approves the Therapeutic Goods Regulations as contained in Statutory Rules 1990 No. 394, made under the Act and tabled in the Senate on 11 December 1990.

I have pleasure in presenting regulations to the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989. This Act was passed by the Parliament in December 1989, a mere 12 months ago. At that time the Senate amended the Therapeutic Goods Bill 1989 to provide that the Act will commence on the day after regulations made pursuant to the Act have been approved in the same form by both Houses of Parliament-a most unusual provision. I think that former Senators Macklin and Puplick, amongst others, bequeathed this as a memorial to themselves. The Senate considered that any regulations may be so substantial that they should not commence until positive approval of Parliament was obtained for the regulations.

In May this year the Senate disallowed previous Therapeutic Goods Regulations to provide the opportunity for further public consultation. As many honourable senators will be aware, the intervening period has seen much public debate and extensive consultation with interested parties. I believe it is quite obvious that the revised regulations reflect this activity over those many months. It is certainly a matter of regret that in this hiatus many people have been frightened into believing that the intent of the legislation is to somehow deprive them of access to the alternative therapies from which they clearly derive considerable comfort and support. I have had several letters to that effect. Even when visiting schools, quite senior students have approached me and brought this matter to my attention. Clearly they have been upset and have had their misgivings aroused by this particular propaganda campaign.

Patients have been encouraged to believe such bizarre interpretations of the purpose of the legislation as: natural remedies will be available from doctors only on prescription, all herbal products are to be irradiated, and practitioners will not be able to tell their patients what a product is for. It is a sad commentary that some practitioners-one hopes a small minority-have misled the people for whom they profess concern in such a cynical fashion, often to further personal motives.

Clearly there are some people out there, be they manufacturers, practitioners or distributors, who feel so insecure in their practices that they eschew all thought of their behaviour coming under the simplest scrutiny. These people simply emphasise the need for such scrutiny. In the meantime, their more proficient colleagues, who acknowledge that the standing of the alternative therapies is at least partly dependent on the standard of the products they use and recommend, have been constructively involved in assisting to identify and resolve genuine concerns about the regulations.

The public debate has introduced many extraneous issues. It has proved necessary to continually remind people that the purpose of the legislation is simply to establish one national system to ensure that the public is protected from substandard, unsafe or ineffective therapeutic goods which are supplied commercially to practitioners or consumers; that is, simply to provide a level of protection which is taken for granted in many other countries. Therapeutic goods, although used to improve people's health, involve an element of risk because they are intended to manipulate or augment normal body processes.

I advise the Senate of some pertinent and relevant factors: in Australia at the present time over 100 therapeutic goods are recalled from the market each year because of hazards to consumers; many manufacturers do not operate at internationally accepted standards of manufacture; the suppliers of some products make extravagant or inappropriate claims to the public; some suppliers promote products to inappropriately trained practitioners, thus encouraging these people to treat serious medical conditions; and independent analysis of products demonstrates many products do not reach appropriate standards of quality.

At a time when there are moves towards international cooperation in the regulation of therapeutic goods, Australia is being hindered in its participation in these developments because of the lack of a national system of regulation. For instance, our membership of an international group which deals with manufacturing standards for therapeutic goods has been deferred until the Therapeutic Goods Act commences.

It is now 10 years since the State and Commonwealth health Ministers, in conference, agreed that Australia needed to bring together into a single national regulatory system the various regulatory aspects for therapeutic goods currently resting with different levels of government and characterised by their many inconsistencies and gaps. It still comes as a surprise to some-though, of course, not to the honourable senators in the chamber who follow this matter with such avid interest-to learn that the new Act and its regulations do not introduce any regulatory requirements which are not already in existence in at least some part of Australia.

The development of the Act has given the opportunity to review the level of regulation of therapeutic goods, and indeed there will be a lessening of current requirements in some areas where this is not detrimental to the public interest. There is, of course, one aspect which might be deemed new. While some States have been charging registration and licensing fees, these have not been of the scope currently proposed. Nevertheless, such action is in line with efforts to better target the source of government costs and is consistent with international trends in this regard.

Many correspondents have made the point that the more potent drugs represent a higher risk than do the many products which may be purchased over the counter at the local pharmacy or health food shop. This is readily acknowledged and specifically reflected in the legislation which provides the ability to require different levels of pre-market assessment. The level of scrutiny applied to a new orthodox drug and to a new herbal product are very different. For example, most therapeutic devices and many alternative medicines are listed rather than registered in the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods. This means that they are subjected to a lower degree of scrutiny, such as checking for compliance with standards for quality prior to marketing.

However, certain factors can predicate the need for a higher level of scrutiny. For example, where an alternative medicine contains a substance which has been scheduled by the National Health and Medical Research Council because of its toxicity, or where an alternative medicine is intended to be used to treat a serious medical condition, it is necessary to establish the product's safety and effectiveness, hence registration involving a more detailed scrutiny is appropriate. Similarly, a product may contain substances which by themselves do not represent a risk but because of poor manufacture may have wide variations in the amounts of the active ingredients or may be adulterated or contaminated with other substances. The manufacturing controls are designed to ensure therapeutic goods are manufactured in a reliable and reproducible manner. The regulations also contain restrictions on the promotion of products to the public to not only ensure that the advertising of products is truthful but, equally importantly, that promotion does not encourage inappropriate self-diagnosis and treatment where the input of a trained health care practitioner is necessary.

Promotion of goods to trained health care workers is exempted from these requirements. Included in the exemption are alternative therapy practitioners registered under State or Territory legislation. However, it is recognised that few alternative therapy practitioners are registered at the present time. Until registration is more generally available, it is proposed to allow the alternative therapy industry to self-regulate advertising of products to practitioners on the understanding that the practitioner community identifies an appropriate level of accreditation and that the manufacturers will put a code of advertising conduct into place.

Provision has been made for two bodies, the National Conference of Natural Therapies and the Australian Homeopathic Registration Board, to fulfil the first function by providing a list of associations for inclusion in the regulations, with the Nutritional Foods Association having responsibility for the second.

I have mentioned the extensive consultation that has taken place, and I am pleased to report that the discussions with industry and practitioner groups have resulted in a number of amendments to the regulations. These amendments include, first, as already mentioned, extension of the professional advertising exemption to members of identified homeopathic and natural therapy associations; secondly, provision for homeopathic products provided to practitioners to be treated as listable rather than registrable products, together with complete exemption from product certification and licensing requirements for many of the more dilute homeopathic products; thirdly, acceptance of various additional nutritional substances for listing rather than registration; fourthly, provision for representation by manufacturers of alternative medicines on the Therapeutic Goods Committee; and, fifthly, various adjustments to the scale of fees and charges, including reduced licensing charges, for manufacturers of herbal and homeopathic products and waiving of the annual registration or listing charge where this charge would constitute 2 per cent or more of the value of the annual wholesale turnover of the product.

In addition to the amendments, it has been agreed that, first, codes of good manufacturing practice will not be applied to production and processing of herbal raw materials supplied to licensed manufacturers. Extended time will be allowed for manufacturers of dried herbal consumer goods to achieve good manufacturing practice standards. Secondly, a separate committee, the Traditional Medicines Evaluation Committee, has been established to evaluate traditional medicines for registration. The membership of the Committee would include representatives of the manufacturers and practitioners, and it will shoulder the heavy responsibility of consumer protection by reviewing primarily new herbal products. The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) will personally appoint the members of that Committee.

Following discussion with the Australian Democrats, the Government has undertaken to amend the regulations during the autumn sitting to reduce the annual licence charge for a manufacturer with an annual turnover of $50,000 or less to half that which would apply otherwise; and to exempt from licensing manufacturers of components for therapeutic devices where these components come into direct contact with body tissue or body fluid.

As Sir Humphrey Appleby would point out, the first line of defence against any proposition is to claim that there has not been adequate consultation. Despite a history of consultation extending over a number of years, such a claim might have been arguable with regard to the earlier regulations. However, it would certainly have no legitimacy in relation to the current regulations. We have all been flooded with comment on the legislation, albeit a lot of it based on misinformation. There have literally been hundreds of meetings and conversations centred on issues of concern and exploring solutions thereto. Such dialogue will of course be an ongoing process after the legislation becomes operative.

Let us consider the positions of the groups affected by the legislation. First, the manufacturers and sponsors of therapeutic goods, who have always supported the purpose and need of the legislation; who have been rightly critical of the frustrating and often expensive differences between State, Territory and Commonwealth requirements; who will be contributing 50 per cent of the costs of the program, but who have had direct input into the distribution of the impact of fees and charges through the Industry Government Consultative Committee; who have been provided with representation on most statutory committees and, in the case of non-prescription medicines, on the evaluation committees; and whose exports will be more readily accepted on overseas markets because of the Australian controls.

We then might consider the practitioners, who will have protection from unsatisfactory commercial products; who will receive product information safeguarded by industry self-regulation; whose services will be sought for the treatment of appropriate medical conditions because the public will not be encouraged by product promotion to self-treat serious conditions; and who will participate in the statutory and evaluation committees.

Then there are the consumers, who at times are almost forgotten by many but who are the focus of this legislation; who will have protection from unsafe, poor quality and ineffective therapeutic goods; who are not adequately protected by current controls; who will be protected from false or inappropriate product promotion; and who, despite some outrageous claims to the contrary, will not be inflicted with large price increases of products. The fees and charges should be reflected by only a few cents per product, and we will certainly be watching to see that this is not used as an opportunity by sponsors to extend profits while blaming the Government.

Let me reiterate the purpose of the legislation, which often becomes forgotten in the public debate. It is simply to regulate, in the interests of the consumer, the quality, safety and efficacy of commercially supplied therapeutic goods. As mentioned earlier, it is remarkable that distortions of this purpose have sometimes occurred. This legislation does not have any cynical hidden agendas. It is simply consumer protection legislation that is necessary to afford the Australian public a level of protection taken for granted in most of our industrialised partners. After years of deliberation and with 12 months having elapsed since the enabling legislation was passed, it is now time to move to a more efficient and effective way of regulating therapeutic goods in this country.

I would like to take the opportunity of acknowledging the high level of cooperation between all States and Territories in developing this truly national system to replace the current largely uncoordinated systems of State, Territory and Commonwealth controls. I commend the regulations to the Senate for its approval.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call the next speaker, I advise the Senate that the clock is being set on the agreed speaking times. I presume that the Senate approves that course.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not often feel sorry for people on the other side of the chamber, but I feel sorry for the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) tonight. I feel that they must dislike the Minister so much to have him represent in the Senate the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples). The Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs has had to defend that Minister this year when that Minister has disenchanted the pharmaceutical industry, disenchanted the nursing homes sector and the hostel aged care sector and disenchanted the therapeutic goods sector. He always leaves the Minister in this place, Senator Tate, with a mess and Senator Tate is the one who carries the can. If I were Senator Tate, my new year's resolution would be not to represent Mr Staples in this place. Give the task to Senator Richardson or Senator Cook, who are so good at speaking. I would opt out of the operation if I were Senator Tate, or at the end of next year he will not be looking as well as he does now. The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has made an absolute mess of everything he touches. If the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had any sense, he would get rid of Mr Staples from his present portfolio. Everything he touches is a disaster.

SPEECH.PARA: We are dealing with the Therapeutic Goods Regulations, and the Opposition does not oppose having regulations in this industry. We know that there have been some charlatans and that some people have brought disrepute to the industry, just as we know that there are some pharmacists and some people in the aged care sector who have brought disrepute--

TALK.START.PARA: —And some politicians.

—And some politicians, as Senator Walters reminds me, have brought disrepute on their profession. If the Minister's first attempt at the regulations had been better, Senator Tate and I could have had a holiday, we could have had a very easy session, if it had not been-
—Do not talk about going on holidays.

—Do not tell me how to make my speech. I have listened to the Minister without interrupting him. As I was saying, the Minister's first attempt to bring regulations into this place was a dismal failure. That occurred in May of this year when they were disallowed. The Government knew that the Opposition would not support the regulations in their current form or in their amended form.
—Or in any form.

—No, not necessarily in any form. But the Government made no attempt to negotiate with the Opposition, and suggested no remedies to address the concerns of the Opposition. Clearly, the Government intends to amend the regulations, as the Minister said tonight, but this is the first time that we have heard about it. The Government says, `We have had negotiations with the Australian Democrats'. It would have been nice if Mr Staples had been able to tell us so that I could have consulted with the shadow Minister as to whether we accepted the proposed amendments to the regulations, but this is the first time I have heard about them.
—I am sure he spoke to Dr Woods.

—He has not spoken to Dr Woods. I have spoken to Dr Woods in the last hour and a half, and Mr Staples has not spoken to Dr Woods. We have heard nothing about them. We did not know that the debate would be brought on tonight. The first the Whips knew about it, despite what everyone else might say, was this morning when Senator Tate or Senator McMullan gave notice that the matter was to be brought on.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has given the Democrats assurances that the regulations will be amended in the new year. But if the Democrats believe the Government's assurances, they are more stupid than I thought they were-in fact I think some of the people over here have become unreasonable-but if they believe that things are going to change they are deluded. What I think should happen is that we should see those amendments and then vote on them when we have seen them. We should not vote on some pie in the sky hope that the Minister is going to change them.

The Opposition has a number of fundamental objections to the original regulations. Firstly, they take away the consumer's right to choose the method of health care treatment, the preferred practitioner and the product used. They impose severe restrictions on the availability of remedies. They prohibit the sale of some homoeopathic remedies and many herbal substances and increase the cost of all natural therapeutic substances by imposing an annual registration fee. I believe from what has been said that that fee is going to be reduced but I have not had time to assess the impact of that. But it will not necessarily result in a national system offering uniformity and increased efficiency in the manufacture and sale of therapeutic goods.

There is also some confusion as to the operation of the grandfather clause to the Act that these regulations give effect to. All existing products that are listed or registered after six months of the operation of the Act will have to comply with the regulations. Existing products on the market will therefore not be protected from the heavy costs imposed by these regulations.

We also have serious concerns about the set-up of a number of committees. The Proprietary Medicines Advisory Council (PMAC) is constituted by incorporating the current Victorian PMAC and renaming it. The PMAC will evaluate nutritional and vitamin products. The committee's expertise lies in evaluating proprietary medicines, that is, those that are patented. It may have been better to look at a much broader scope and a much better representation on these committees with a wider range of people with expertise and interests in the alternative medicine industry. This seems a reasonable request but, for some reason, the Government seems to have been unwilling to accept this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Set up another committee.

—Let me say to Senator Coulter that the Government is prepared to do it for the general practitioners and for other industries. Another concern with the PMAC is that a body contracted for the purpose of evaluating over the counter products on a national basis should be set up under the relevant national legislation. It is inappropriate for a body with a national brief to operate within an existing State legislative framework.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has agreed to set up a Traditional Medicines Evaluation Committee (TMEC) which will evaluate traditional medicines, primarily herbal products, which require registration. However, each formulation will be evaluated by the PMAC as well as the TMEC. It is possible that the TMEC may give clearance to a formulation but it could be knocked back by PMAC.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's not the way we work.

—Senator McLean will have his chance in the moment. No reference to the TMEC has been included in the regulations. The composition of the TMEC, as announced by the Minister, places heavy emphasis on people from outside the natural therapy area on a committee. There should be more time to clarify the terms of reference for this committee. If there is debate in this chamber at the moment about this, it is because the issues have not been clarified.

SPEECH.PARA: The regulations attempt to ensure that an appropriate manufacturing code of practice is followed in the production of therapeutic goods and devices. This code of practice is significantly tighter than that which is currently enforced in most overseas countries. This means that Australian standards of manufacturing practice must be complied with for products which are produced solely for an export market. An exporting manufacturer may have to comply with two completely different sets of regulations, one overseas and one in Australia. The stringent requirements of good manufacturing practice (GMP) may make Australian production unviable. This is contrary to overall Government policy that seeks to encourage the manufacture of pharmaceuticals and therapeutics in Australia, their export from Australia and the development of new and improved therapeutic products.

Given our fragile trade situation-and not one of us here needs to be reminded of that-we should be encouraging our export industries, not crippling them. Imported products will not be subject to the code of good manufacturing practice that Australian companies are. What an advantage this gives to importers. The GMP is an important principle that ought to be adhered to, particularly in the case of large manufacturers. But to insist that a cottage type industry installs high tech industrial equipment so as to be able to comply with GMP will lead to the destruction of that part of the industry.

The code of good manufacturing practice imposes many unnecessary requirements on small herbal, vitamin and mineral supplement manufacturers where there is presently no obvious cause for concern over their manufacturing standards. What we are saying is that maybe with some more lateral thinking, some of these questions could have been answered and some of these smaller industries considered more fully in these regulations.

The estimated cost of the Therapeutic Goods Act is $30m. Fees and charges are expected to recoup $15m of this cost. One of our major concerns is the extra costs to be imposed on the industry. As I have said before, the first time I have had any indication from the Government about the costs is tonight. So, my estimates will most probably change slightly given the fact that some of those costs will be reduced. But again, what I find absolutely appalling is that I am the person who is responsible on this side of the chamber for taking health legislation through this place and I have had no communication at all about when these regulations will be brought on or any suggested amendments.

Schedule 9 of the regulations lists the fees that will be imposed and many of these fees are prohibitive. The regulations include charges for the checking of methods of manufacture, quality control, evaluation, et cetera. One company estimated that complying with the regulations could cost it anywhere between $1m and $3m a year. Again, I heard on the grapevine, but only heard officially tonight, that the Government promises to amend the regulations to allow small manufacturers to have their charges decreased by up to 50 per cent and that there will be an increased number of nutritional experts on PMAC.
The Government has told the Democrats about this and Senator Coulter might say that he negotiated with the Government about it, but I think it would have been a reasonable--

TALK.START.PARA: —Courtesy.

—It would have been just plain courtesy-at least this morning when this motion was moved-for me to have had a communication from either Minister Tate, or from Minister Staples. Although these amendments should be applauded, they do not go far enough. There are too many unanswered questions. The consumer's choice of therapeutics is too restricted. The fees and charges are prohibitive and will send many manufacturers to the wall.

SPEECH.PARA: The form of the relationship about PMAC and TMEC is far from resolved. The lack of national representation on PMAC will not instil confidence in the minds of manufacturers from outside Victoria. As I said, at a time when our current account deficit is out of control, the standards of good manufacturing practice in the regulations have the potential to shut down therapeutic exporters, thus forcing the industry to become reliant on imports.

If the Government had shown any interest in attempting to solve these problems, and had I known beforehand, I might have done what I did with the nursing home legislation. I might have come to Minister Tate and I believe that I would have had the same courteous response as I had on that issue. But I did not know, so I could not come to him and say, `How are we going to resolve this? How can we ensure that we have good legislation?'.

The Opposition does not want to just get up and oppose this for the sake of opposing legislation. We want to try to cooperate but it is very difficult to cooperate when in fact we are not consulted. When Mr Staples does not behave in a courteous and appropriate way, it makes it impossible for the Opposition to attempt to work with the Government to assist small businesses, which are not just facing these regulations but are also facing all the other things, such as high interest rates and inflation which affect businesses in this country, that are under threat. Here are small business people in the therapeutics industry facing all those plus the uncertainty that these regulations have brought about.

We do not want to continue to add to that uncertainty. We do not want to be part of that. But tonight we have to oppose these regulations because we do not believe that they are correct. We believe they still need amending. We do not think that we should approve them in the hope that the Minister will amend them in the future. We should have those amendments.

When my office rang last week to ask when these therapeutic regulations would be brought on, what was the flippant reply from Minister Staples's office? `We will bring them on when you decide to agree with them. That is when we will bring them on. Most probably that could be next year. They most probably will not be brought on until next year'. So the information that we were operating on was that the Therapeutic Goods Regulations would not be brought on until next year.

This morning we had indecent rush and haste. I hope that the therapeutics industry will realise from this experience-as the pharmacists and the people in the aged care sector have come to realise, not just the Catholic bishops-that despite the fact that this Government believes it has a monopoly on care, consultation and consensus, this is not the case. We would have cooperated had we had the opportunity to do so.

I condemn Minister Staples for the way he has handled this matter and the whole allied health care sector. I hope that those people will remember that when the Government next faces the polls. The Opposition and I do not believe that the appropriate remedies have been implemented to make these regulations meet the needs of the therapeutics industry. On that basis, we will oppose them tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say at the outset that there is a great deal wrong with the information that was contained in Senator Patterson's speech. I hope to correct that as we go along. Senator Patterson said in her opening remarks that the Opposition favoured the broad thrust of this legislation. Yet, we find that as early as 4 December, the shadow Minister, Dr Woods, was writing to constituents saying that he and the Opposition would oppose these regulations. On the basis of the grounds on which he made that remark, we negotiated with the Government because we also supported these regulations. We believe that we have regulations which now more fully meet the legitimate requirements of the Therapeutic Goods Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The Therapeutic Goods Act was passed late in 1989 with the Australian Democrats supporting its broad thrust. An amendment to the legislation ensures that the Act cannot become law until the regulations have been passed by both Houses. The purpose of this legislation is to establish and maintain a national system of controls relating to the quality, efficacy and safety of therapeutic goods that are used in Australia, whether produced here or elsewhere, as well as those exported from Australia. The present system is one of inadequate state by state registration and regulation. The Federal Act and these regulations will join reciprocal arrangements in a growing number of other countries which will facilitate import and export between these countries while ensuring quality.

Therapeutic goods cover a wide range of products from medical devices and pharmaceuticals to natural therapies, including herbs. The register of therapeutic goods will contain two classes-those to be registered and those to be listed. Registered goods-the small class-will require evaluation with regard to their quality, safety and effectiveness before being approved. Listed goods-the larger class-are of less hazardous nature and may require assessment with regard to quality and their compliance with appropriate standards.

Basically, the Act and these regulations are about public health and safety and consumer protection. The Australian Consumers Association (ACA) is very supportive of it and anxious that its implementation not be unduly delayed. Indeed, the ACA was disappointed when I successfully moved for the disallowance of the regulations in May.

Recent official reports of bacterial contamination in both orthodox and alternative medicines for oral and topical application show that 30 per cent of such preparations from both sources have unacceptably high levels of contamination.

It is manufacturers, not therapists and not individual users, of therapeutic goods for human use who must be licensed and comply with the regulations. They must allow their premises to be inspected to ascertain compliance with codes of good manufacturing practice. Various committees will provide advice to the Minister or Secretary on determination of standards, manufacturing principles and the approval of goods for supply. Decisions may be reviewed by the Therapeutic Goods Administration or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

When the regulations to the Act were first tabled in May this year there were sufficient anomalies for me to move for disallowance. This motion was supported by the Opposition. The concerns mainly cover the areas of advertising, advisory committees and the level of fees and charges. I believe that in addressing these and several other more recently raised concerns, the Government has gone as far as it can go in changing the regulations without transgressing the spirit of the Act. Further weakening of the regulations would totally emasculate and destroy the legitimate purposes of the legislation. The remaining concerns with the new regulations have been addressed by way of ministerial assurances in a letter of 12 December, which I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard.

I understand that the Democrats will support the Therapeutic Goods Regulations, subject to my providing an assurance that the Regulations will be amended to address concerns which you have raised. Your undertaking to support the Regulations is appreciated and it is clear that the period of negotiation following the disallowance in May 1990 has led to the development of Regulations which provide a more appropriate balance between the interests of the affected groups and the need to provide protection for the consumers.
I have agreed that the Regulations will be amended at the first opportunity during the Autumn sittings to-

(a) provide that the annual charge for a licence to manufacture therapeutic goods may be reduced to 50 percent of the amount prescribed in the Regulations to the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Act where the value of annual wholesale turnover is less that $50,000;

Due to the critical nature of these components, the principal manufacture will be responsible for the manufacturing standard of the component manufacturers and Commonwealth inspectors will retain the right to inspect (without charge) the component manufacturers.

I have communicated with Ms Hogg, Victorian Minister for Health regarding the need for adequate representation for nutritional products on the Victorian evaluation committee. I have strongly encouraged the appointment of either an expert in nutrition or a representative of the manufacturers of nutritional products.

I have also attached to this letter a draft document concerning minimum microbial levels in dried herb products. This document deals with the microbial limits in foods and the rationale and interpretation of the guideline limit for herbal preparations.

The frequency of testing batches of dried herbs for microbial contamination is at the discretion of the manufacturer and depends upon the confidence that the manufacturer has in the cleanliness of his procedures and the source of the materials used in the product.

You also discussed the need to monitor the performance of the Therapeutic Goods Administration and the effects of the legislation on the Industry, particularly the effects of fees and charges. The performance of the Therapeutic Goods Administration following the commencement of the legislation, will be closely monitored by members of the Industry Government Consultative Committee (IGCC) and the Senate Estimates Committee.

The IGCC will also have a continuing role in advising on the fees and charges particularly in response to experience with the effect of the costs on Industry. While I have little doubt that the activities and performance of the Therapeutic Goods Administration will be subject to scrutiny by various other bodies in the future, I suggest it would be appropriate to ask the IGCC to provide an evaluation of the impact of fees and charges on exports within 2 years from the legislation having passed both Houses.
Please do not hesitate to contact me if further information is required.
Yours sincerely
Peter Staples

TALK.START.PARA: —In the regulations there is a list of proscribed claims.
—It would be nice if we had had it beforehand.

—They were supplied to the honourable senator. In the first set of regulations, proscribed claims about therapeutic goods could only be advertised to medical practitioners, pharmacists and other members of the orthodox medical profession, but not to practitioners of alternative medicines such as herbalists, homoeopathic practitioners, nutritionists, osteopaths, et cetera. This was offensive to the latter. In the present regulations, advertising proscribed claims has been extended to this latter group.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an exact reciprocal of the arrangement under which orthodox medicine operates. Claims included on this proscribed list made with respect to drugs used in orthodox medicine can only be advertised in professional journals to doctors, nurses and people in the orthodox professions. These professionals have the presumed competence to assess the veracity of the advertised claims. In an exactly similar way, the manufacturers of traditional or alternative medicines may advertise proscribed claims to professionals in alternative medicine who are competent to assess these claims.

Claims from this proscribed list may not be advertised directly to the public. This is an important aspect of public protection. For example, all honourable senators will have seen exposure, through newspapers and such programs as The Investigators, of `manufacturers' of `lolly water' being sold as `a cure for cancer'.

I welcome the extension to alternative medicine practitioners but do not believe that it should be extended further. The responsibility must lie with the professional to weigh up the claims as to the efficacy of various products and then pass on his or her professional judgment to the patient or client. The doctor does this with proprietary drugs through information conveyed in medical journals. Natural therapists will now be able to do so through information conveyed in their professional journals.

An implicit assumption that all `natural' things are safe and require no regulation, and that all man-made chemicals are unsafe, are made by crooks, and need very close control lies behind much of the dissension over these regulations. This assumption is not based on fact and is irrational.

For example, approximately 25 per cent of all people in Australia, as in most industrialised countries, will get cancer at some stage in their lives. Comparative epidemiological studies indicate quite clearly that the bulk- that is, about 80 per cent-of these cancers are caused by factors in the environment and most of these are naturally occurring. Most of these factors have not been identified. This relates very much to the assertion that `no-one has been harmed by natural products'. Very often, no-one has looked and even if they have, there are enormous problems in identifying and isolating one factor from amongst the many others to which we are all exposed.

I would remind the Senate that tobacco is a natural product. It is a herb. It has been used as a therapeutic and cultural substance for thousands of years. It was not definitively established as a potent carcinogen until the early 1960s. Long tradition does not establish safety. We are all aware of the implicit therapeutic claims made by the advertisers of tobacco and the Democrats have sought rigid controls over the advertising of these claims to the general public.

Let me give a second example. Nothing could be more `natural' than honey. Claims as to the therapeutic value of honey for the treatment of a wide range of illnesses can be seen in a number of books on `natural health'. Of course, honey contains substances derived from the flowers from which the nectar was collected. Salvation Jane, which is also called Patterson's Curse, is much valued by apiarists as a good source of honey. Patterson's Curse contains pyrollizidine alkaloids which are potent liver toxins and carcinogens. Honey collected from salvation Jane contains significant levels of these alkaloids.

Apiarists fought successfully for several years to prevent the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation introducing biological control against this weed. Information-and this is the important point-that the honey from this source was a significant danger to health was assiduously suppressed during this debate.

There are many, many herbs which are used in both culinary and therapeutic ways which contain known carcinogens-pepper, tarragon, comfrey, mushrooms to mention just a few. If extracts from any of this host of `natural'- and I stress `natural'-plant material is marketed with claims of therapeutic efficacy, it is reasonable that the public have some assurance that the extraction process has not concentrated these carcinogens or converted them to even more potent genetic toxins. It is not a defence that these are `natural' and to claim, as some have attempted to do, that therefore they should not attract regulatory oversight.

These regulations and the legislation of which they are the principal instrument of implementation are completely silent on what people may believe about the effectiveness of any therapy, whether physical or chemical and whether `natural' or chemically synthesised. They are silent on what one person may tell another about those beliefs. They are silent on what or how a person may treat himself with therapeutic goods.

These regulations are about the appropriate regulation of manufacturers of therapeutic goods-that is, those who make and market therapeutic goods. They are about the protection of the potential and actual consumers of the products of these manufacturers. They are about ensuring that products are made in clean and hygienic premises to an acceptable standard, that the efficacy and safety of the product can be relied upon, and that the claims made by the manufacturer reflect these qualities. There is no interference with the rights of the individual to take what he or she likes and no interference with freedom of choice.

Considerable fear has been expressed by the alternative medicine school that the committee named in the earlier regulations to evaluate its pharmaceutical goods was biased and that alternative medicine industry would not be treated fairly. In the earlier regulations it was determined that all natural therapies would be assessed by the Proprietary Medicines Advisory Committee (PMAC)-a Victorian-based Committee which has traditionally evaluated orthodox proprietary medicines and which has generated a great deal of hostility from the alternative medicine industry because of past decisions on its products and the known attitudes of its members. I have successfully negotiated a change in this arrangement.

In the regulations as they now are, a new and separate committee is created to assess natural therapies. This is known as the Traditional Medicine Evaluation Committee (TMEC). It has qualified members, including three herbalists-a lecturer in herbal medicine and adviser to a herbal manufacturer, a practitioner in traditional Chinese medicine and a practising herbalist with expertise in herbal toxicology-and a pharmacist with strong associations with the Nutritional Food Association. The Committee is to be chaired by the Chairman of the Australian College of Natural Medicine. There are still some people who want a multitude of committees, one for each of their special interests. I consider this to be totally unreasonable.

All synthetic drugs would continue to be assessed by PMAC. The new regulations require that vitamins, minerals and amino acids would be assessed by PMAC rather than TMEC. This continued to cause unhappiness in the natural therapy industry, so I sought and gained an assurance from the Minister, contained in the letter that I have just incorporated, that he would ask the Victorian Minister for Health-I note that PMAC is an instrument of the Victorian legislation-to recommend that a representative of the nutritional food industry, as recommended by the Nutritional Foods Association, be added to the membership of PMAC. PMAC has now agreed to increase its committee from six to eight members and has agreed that one of the new members be a nutritional food teacher from the Deakin University nutritional school and the other a person who has specific expertise in the manufacture of vitamin, mineral and herbal therapeutic goods-that is, someone who directly represents the alternative medicine manufacturers.

Some lobbyists from the natural therapies industry have argued for 50 per cent representation on PMAC, but I believe that that is unreasonable. Vitamins, minerals and amino acids are not the sole preserve of the natural therapies industry but are of equal interest to orthodox medicine. There has to be some dividing line between what PMAC and TMEC assess. It is reasonable that that line be whether the items being assessed are synthetic or natural products. No specific examples of PMAC's alleged past bias have been supplied. However, even accepting that such bias against traditional medicine has existed-it is certainly quite believable-under the new arrangements in which two separate committees, presumably with competing biases, will each report, both committees will be extremely careful to see that any judgment they pass is fully justified and justifiable. Moreover, both are advisory committees to the Secretary of the Department, who makes the final decision.

Initially, the fee structure was based on total cost recovery from manufacturers. The philosophy underlying this was that the manufacturers were the ones generating the need for placing products on the market and that they would benefit from the imprimatur of registration. In the first concession the Government agreed that the industry would carry only 50 per cent of the costs, the other 50 per cent coming from general revenue. Half of the total cost is expected to be $15m. The most substantial fees will be for evaluation of products for registration and the inspection and licensing of manufacturers. It is anticipated that, of the $15m, the natural therapies industry will carry about $800,000 of the costs. The pharmaceutical companies will bear the brunt of this cost because most of their new products will require registration rather than listing. Those products already on the market will be grandfathered-that is an important point-and will be exempt from registration fees.

A successful Democrat amendment to the Act was to make low value, low volume goods exempt from fees and charges. This was done in order to address the genuine concerns of herb growers and small companies making medical appliances whose turnover on a number of product lines might be only a few hundred or a few thousand dollars. This amendment has been given effect in the present regulations by waiving the fees if the fee for registration or listing exceeds 2 per cent of the gross turnover on a particular good. Thus for a listed good if the annual turnover is less than $3,000, the manufacturer, such as a grower or marketer of herbs, does not need to pay the $60 fee to have that product listed.

The Industry Government Consultative Committee (IGCC) met in July with the Australian Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association and a general reduction in fees was recommended. Exemptions from annual listing or registration charges were made where the charge would represent more than 2 per cent of annual wholesale turnover rather than the 5 per cent proposed in the first regulations. Thus, if the turnover is less than $3,000 for a listed good, the manufacturer does not pay the $60 listing fee, and if the turnover for a registered product is less than $8,750, the manufacturer does not have to pay the $175 registration fee. The cost of an export certificate was reduced from $300 to $50, and it should be noted that an exporter will have to provide one only if the importing country requires one for that product. Some fees appear quite high, such as the fee for human clinical studies in evaluating therapeutic devices. I gained a ministerial assurance that, where a number of component parts were made on different premises for a device such as artificial joints, the manufacturers of these component parts would be exempt from inspection fees.

Some Western Australian medical device manufacturers have argued that the fees and charges will knock out research and development for small manufacturers and they cite the United Kingdom precedent where fees were introduced and exports fell. The United States, on the other hand, does not expect manufacturers to pick up the expenses for licensing and inspection and has maintained its exports. This situation may change, as this matter is reviewed each year. As far as I can ascertain, the United Kingdom charges appear to be higher than those which would apply in Australia, but I have not been able to get details of specific charges from the people most concerned about the United Kingdom situation.

We have gained a ministerial assurance, however, that the IGCC will monitor the TGA and provide an evaluation of the effects of the fees and charges on the industry within two years. This is contained in the ministerial letter which has already been incorporated. The period of two years has been chosen as it is expected that it will take some six to nine months to get this legislation into full operation. In all cases-except in the case of herb growers-where claims have been made that a business will go to the wall or will stop exporting because of the charges, further investigation has revealed that they are not significant in terms of annual turnover-for example, $20,000 for a turnover of $2m, or one per cent. Complaints have been made that manufacturers get nothing in return, but in fact they get the stamp of good manufacturing practice (GMP) approval, which enhances credibility in the domestic and international market. Totally outrageous claims have been made, including one from a manufacturer who maintained that he needed to spend $8m on upgrading his premises to comply with GMP. One might ask rhetorically what his premises are like if he needs to spend that amount on the necessary upgrading. It is indicative of the general lack of understanding of the new regulations and the misinformation which is spread, mischievously or otherwise.

In the case of herb growers, many of whom have annual turnovers of less than $70,000 and some of whom have annual turnovers as low as $15,000, the annual license fee of $1,000 and the inspection fee-not necessarily annual-of $1,200 was obviously a hardship. I therefore negotiated successfully for another ministerial assurance that license fees for those with a turnover of less than $50,000 would be reduced from $1,000 to $500. In these cases most, if not all, of their products will be listable and not registrable. For products already on the market, listing will be grandfathered and no fee will be payable. For new products a listing fee of $60 per product will be charged only when the gross turnover for that product exceeds $3,000.

There have been lobbyists who have been very tough but fair-minded in support of their industry. Anthony Morgan of the Nutritional Foods Association has put his industry's case extremely forcefully, as have David Marks and Rob Carolane on behalf of the herb growers. Unfortunately, some who have lobbied have made totally exaggerated claims. It is significant to note in passing that several manufacturers who are members of the Nutritional Foods Association do not submit some 40 per cent of their products to the NFA's own internal review process. These people are among the lobbyists making these exaggerated claims. Is it any wonder that such people do not want this Parliament to pass these regulations? Some herb growers, many of them biodynamic and organic farmers, have argued that the microbial limit for therapeutic goods was tighter than that for food and they object, quite legitimately, to treating their herbs with ethylene oxide or radiation to sterilise them.

The Therapeutic Goods Administration Laboratories (TGAL) replied in response to this claim that the National Health and Medical Research Council food standards code 1990 included microbial limits for some foods but there was no general limit for all foods. There was also a requirement that the foods mentioned be completely free of certain pathogens such as salmonella and E. coli. The TGAL is in fact flexible in interpreting results of its testing and may recall above or below the 10 colony forming units per gram, or per mil, microbial limit depending on the nature of the organisms found.

Some growers expressed concern at the cost of testing-that is, around $75 per batch-and the possible need to test every batch. I have obtained ministerial assurance that the frequency of testing will be at the discretion of the manufacturer. Frequency of testing will depend on the confidence that the manufacturer has in the cleanliness of his or her procedures and source of her or his materials. In other words, having established that the manufacturing practice is up to standard through the testing of several batches, no further testing will be required for that product as long as the manufacturing process remains the same. The question of whether a dried herb is a therapeutic or a food has also been addressed. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a schema supplied to me.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Dried herbs will be divided into two categories: appendix A being those herbs which automatically come under the Therapeutic Goods Act and appendix B being those which have both therapeutic and non-therapeutic uses. The onus is on the grower to decide whether to market her appendix B herbs as therapeutic goods or as a food; that is, as herbal tea. Whichever she chooses, she will label her products appropriately. If the product is marketed as a food it does not come under these regulations. After direct negotiations between growers and the Department, and via my office, some herbs, especially those used in making herbal teas, have been shifted from one appendix to the other. Further shifts can be negotiated and the Department has shown itself quite willing to review the classification of a herb on the basis of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Some companies, such as R.P. Scherer Pty Ltd, have argued that they will not be able to compete with imports from countries where manufacturers do not have the expense of compliance with strict GMP standards. Australian therapeutic goods manufacturers will be able to appeal against any imports which they believe do not comply with GMP, and the onus is then on the importer to prove that they do, and carry the expense of inspection of premises overseas if necessary.

It is important that these regulations be passed now. This will put certainty into this complex matter and allow a start to be made on dispelling the myths and misinformation which are now circulating. Any changes by those who are dissatisfied can then be proposed against a known and certain background, not against the mischievous rumour. There will be an amendment to the regulations in those areas indicated in the Minister's letter. Those amendments will be put in the next session. Passing these regulations now allows the important process of regulating the therapeutic goods industry, in the interests of consumer protection, to begin. Accordingly, the Democrats support these regulations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Therapeutic Goods Regulations. Sadly, this has come up very suddenly. Once again a deal that has been done by the Government and the Australian Democrats has made sure that this matter will not be debated to the degree that it should be. I want to make one point very clear and put it on the record right now: Dr Woods, the shadow Minister for health, has still, as of 15 minutes ago, not been spoken to by the Government or the Democrats about any of these proposals or amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation is quite clear, quite categorical and unequivocal. The real sadness about all of this is that the letter from Minister Staples to Senator Coulter is dated 12 December; today is 20 December. Senator Coulter did not have the courage of his convictions to go to Senator Patterson or to Dr Woods-no, no, no-the fairies at the bottom of the garden party strike again.

Only this afternoon, the Democrats' State President's husband in Western Australia-former Senator Jenkins' husband-Brian Jenkins, told an interested party in Western Australia, `No, it is the Opposition which is agreeing to these regulations and the Democrats are opposing them'. But then again, that could be true because those Democrats who had the courage of their convictions to oppose these regulations-and I hope there will still be some in the fairies at the bottom of the garden party that will have the courage of their convictions and oppose these regulations-have had to be screwed down by this non-existent leader, Senator Powell, who wants to go home to play tiddly-winks. She said to the Senate last Thursday morning, `I want to go home', as Senator Walters quite clearly said. I wish she would do herself a favour and go home but, more importantly, do us a favour and go home. At least we would get some legislation passed in this place without any of the nonsense that the Democrats are going on with.

Senator Powell has said that any regulation and any additional restriction against the private sector should be supported. The Democrats' record in this Parliament stands checked by that. If they can screw down the private sector, they will, and if they can put more people out of employment, they will. Sadly, this Government has facilitated that move. I hope that there are those in the Democrats who are prepared to have the courage of their convictions. I know that some of them are very personally concerned about representing their constituents. I know that some of them are very concerned about the implications of this. Unfortunately, their Leader and Deputy Leader have this great ability to change their minds five times in five minutes. It is probably being generous to say that they have minds. But let us be factual and say that only in the last few days the Democrats supported legislation to give the--

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about the regulations; you know nothing about them.

—Listen to old knowledge box back here, who would not even know what a chemist shop or therapeutic goods looked like. I go back to the point that patients are being offered a choice by the position that the coalition is taking tonight. SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately they have even bluffed some of the people from the Nutritional Foods Association of Australia, who sent in information to say that it had spoken to Jenny Macleod of Senator John Coulter's office in the last hour. The letter states:
I understand that the letter to be incorporated in Hansard, which will flag an Amendment Bill being proposed for the Autumn session is as follows.

She encloses the infamous letter that only appeared tonight on my desk just after 8 o'clock. The fact is that even the Nutritional Foods Association has been bluffed into believing that the Government and the Democrats will do what they say. We know that that is very unlikely.

Let us look at the Government's position on this. The other day, Senator West sent back all the information that the therapeutic goods people had sent her. In a most abusive letter she said that she had `flushed their products down the toilet where they deserved to be put'. If that is the Government's attitude, that is very sad. Many of us are given a contrary point of view to the position that we take but we do not have to abuse constituents the way that Senator West has obviously done.

This situation is a prime example of rapacious regulatory government at work. This Government is so determined to shackle the therapeutic goods industry that in the dying stages of this parliamentary session it is trying to force through these regulations with less debate than they deserve. This is just another addition to the business regulations that have been estimated to cost Australia between $34m and $46m a year. Do the Democrats bother about that? No, they do not. Do the Democrats bother about the 150 jobs in one company that will be done away with because of their support of these regulations? No, they could not care less. Once again, this is an effective denial of consumer freedom of choice when products become more expensive or simply unavailable when it is no longer profitable to manufacture them.

Labor governments do not pay much heed to the old saying, `If it ain't broke, don't fix it'. Oh no, they want to fix everything, regardless of whether it is needed. Of course, that is also the case unless they are defending their own vested interests. Such vested interests do not extend to the field of private enterprise, where the possibility of any type of marginal abuse always becomes the excuse for blanket regulation that restricts business or professions.

Apart from the lack of availability of these products in the future because of the restrictions that will be placed on them, what really concerns me are the number of enterprises that will go out of business and the number of employees who will lose their jobs. Neither the Government nor the Australian Democrats-and Senator Powell in particular-seem to care about that. Senator Coulter did not even make any reference to the number of jobs that will be done away with, nor did the Minister.

Unfortunately, that is a fact of life. Only last week 10,000 people went onto the unemployment queues. Does that matter? No, it does not matter in the slightest. The mere fact is that more people will go onto unemployment queues because of these regulations which will be carried tonight. In selling this regulatory proposal, the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) has admitted, under his list of the 10 common questions, that it will make alternative health products more expensive. Does he care that they will be more expensive? No, he does not. He glibly tells consumers that a major manufacturer has estimated that prices would not increase by more than 4c per item. Pull the other leg, because it defies commonsense to suggest that the fees being proposed will raise prices by only a couple of per cent. The Minister tries to reassure consumers that it will not make alternative health products harder to get. He states:
. . . some manufacturers who are making poor quality products may pull out of the market.

What a convenient excuse! It is simply an excuse, one that Senator Powell wants to go along with. I cannot understand why Senator Powell is so silly-mind you, I can and I should; I have known her long enough-to be able to accept that. The fact of the matter is that the Democrats are making sure that these regulations will force exporters to satisfy not only overseas codes of practice but also the draconian Australian code. Is that not a real boost to exports? Manufacturing for the home market, the local industry, must still compete against imported products that are exempt from compliance with the Australian manufacturing practice. No wonder a major Australian manufacturing company, R.P. Scherer Pty Ltd, has decided that these regulations will make a proposed $25m factory uncompetitive and, therefore, it has cancelled its plans with 150 jobs and $10m in exports, as I mentioned before.

Honourable senators should consider that this new regulatory monster will simply duplicate State legislation. I am very sorry that the time for this debate has been restricted so severely and that we have not had an opportunity to debate the matter thoroughly. I certainly hope and pray that there will be those senators in the Australian Democrats who are prepared to exercise a conscience vote and to make sure that these regulations are defeated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.
