DEBATE.TITLE: STEVEDORING INDUSTRY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990STEVEDORING INDUSTRY LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had almost concluded my speech. I am glad that the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) is now here to take part in this debate. I had been explaining the amendments we were looking at. I have been told in the break that I am naive, too trusting and I do not quite understand how things work. I was giving the Minister credit for, in my opinion, trying to do something about waterfront reform. I had said that he had failed miserably whilst I thought that he had tried to do the right thing. I stand to be corrected on that. I invite the Minister to do something about the very serious problem that exists in Cairns at the moment-a problem which can have enormous and devastating repercussions for the people of the Cairns area. With that, I conclude my remarks on the Stevedoring Industry Legislation Amendment Bill and the Stevedoring Industry Levy Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight two significant Bills, both vital to the waterfront industry and to our export industry, have come back to the chamber. Honourable members and senators on all sides of politics agree that a flourishing export trade would solve many of the economic ills besetting Australia today. The parlous state of the waterfront has long caused our manufacturers to avoid exporting their products and has jeopardised growth and employment prospects elsewhere in the economy. The Government's proposed waterfront reforms will hopefully lead to increased overseas trade and therefore increased prosperity for all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats unequivocally support waterfront reform and the fundamental recommendations and plans of the Inter-State Commission, but we do not agree these should be embraced at breakneck speed. Everyone agrees that the waterfront has been inefficient, with delays and questionable work practices by some employees for decades-decades, I might point out, under a Liberal Government which did nothing whatsoever to rectify the situation. To attempt to rush headlong into reform is dangerous. It is too easy to make mistakes which could be both damaging and difficult to redress. Bringing change to work practices that have been entrenched for 100 years poses great challenges, not the least of which is the avoidance of serious disruption to the nation's trade.

It is not that the Australian Democrats do not see waterfront reform as a matter of urgency or importance. We do, but we differ about the method and strategy. We are against confrontation and aggression and firmly for consultation and agreement. The report issued by the Inter-State Commission in March 1989 concentrated on a strategy to improve the industry rather than to examine its deficiencies in depth-a wise move, as we could still be back at square one. In its response on 1 June 1989 the Government accepted the majority of the Inter-State Commission's recommendations in its waterfront industry plan and emphasised three main recommendations. The first was a change in employment from a pooled arrangement to enterprise-based employment. Surely that is acceptable to the Opposition? Secondly, it recommended measures to improve the efficiency of port authorities. I would imagine that is acceptable to all Australians. Thirdly, it recommended measures to create a more competitive waterfront environment-once again, surely acceptable to all sides of this chamber. The Australian Democrats fully support these three recommendations.

In September last year the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority (WIRA) was set up to implement the Government's reform agenda, and recently Senator Collins announced that the first in-principle agreement had been agreed to. Although progress to date has been slow, things are starting to happen. One of the fundamental structural problems cited by the Commission is that of an ageing work force. Tas Bull, the leader of the Waterside Workers Federation, admits that at least 33 per cent of his members are over 55 and that there has been no recruitment in Sydney or Melbourne since 1975, no recruitment in Adelaide for 22 years and only 10 recruitments in Hobart since 1956. In other words, it is an ageing, entrenched and inherently inflexible work force.

To address this problem, the Government has put in place a generous redundancy plan, which I believe is in the vicinity of 70 per cent of an employee's base rate earnings from the time of retrenchment to retirement at 65. Employers and the Government will each contribute $154m each to finance this plan. By this plan the Government hopes to reduce the numbers by 3,000 employees in the upper age bracket and to replace them with 1,000 younger people who will be unfamiliar with the old questionable ways and hopefully more flexible and willing to accept new approaches. To date approximately 277 gangway watchmen have been paid out under the Government's special retirement and redundancy plan but, until enterprise agreements have been implemented, no waterfront workers have been able to receive their redundancy payment. It is no use the Opposition thumping the drum about delays. If the infrastructures were not in place, nothing could happen. However, now things are beginning to move. To blame stevedoring labour entirely for the woes that beset our waterfront is simply wrong. The attitudes and work practices of the waterfront in the past also reflect the attitude of waterfront management. This fact has been acknowledged in some of the contributions made to the Commission prior to its bringing down its excellent report.

The Australian Democrats argue that to confront the problems of labour without also addressing the problems of management is to deal with only half the problem. The Inter-State Commission found that only four companies performed almost all stevedoring work. There were strong barriers of costs and arrangements to any expansion or competition and there were strong links between shippers and stevedoring companies to prevent new companies entering the market. The main cost barriers included high relative labour costs, relative levies and current labour practices.

Much has been said about the need for genuine competition in the workplace. Indeed Mr Sharp, the honourable member for Gilmore, recently said in the other place that genuine competition on the Australian waterfront is the `first and foremost requirement'. They are excellent sentiments, but he was referring to waterfront workers. There was never a mention about waterfront management, nor did he say a word about competition across the board-that is, both workers and waterfront enterprises. The honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) spoke of waterfront bans on ships. The banned ships were rust buckets, unfit to take to sea, yet employers expected their workers to sail in them. There have been many faults on both sides but it is no use attending to only half the problem.

Before closing I would like to comment on the amendment moved by the Opposition in the other place. It concerns clause 7 of the Bill to insert a new section 9a into the Stevedoring Industry Levy Act 1977. The proposed section allows the Minister to give notification in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette that the levy ceases to be payable in respect of waterside workers who are not employed on a weekly hiring basis. Incidentally, after this cross-subsidy ends the permanent ports will no longer subsidise the non-permanent ports, which are currently in deficit to the tune of $6.4m. A finishing date is not to be notified in respect of a port unless all employers at the port have changed their employment arrangements in accordance with the reform agreement. In other words, the date cannot be notified in the Gazette until all arrangements have been finalised. If a finishing date were specified, there would be the inherent danger that all arrangements may not be completed by that date, necessitating mistake-fraught haste or costly changes in legislation to redress these. The in-principle agreement has specific dates and the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority has a finite life, which should be sufficient to ensure that adequate progress is made. The Australian Democrats therefore do not support the Opposition's amendment.

With these two amendment Bills the Government is addressing the problem of labour, but it has yet to address the problems of management. Management has been able to escape the effects of the general inefficiencies and increased costs inherent in the waterfront industry because of its monopoly powers and the general lack of potential competitors, and has been able to pass its costs on to those using the ports and ultimately the consumers of imports and exports. The Australian Democrats will never advocate rampant competition as the answer to economic ills, but we also do not advocate complete monopolies. We look forward to further legislation which will lead to more effective management by stevedoring companies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Stevedoring Industry Legislation Amendment Bill and the Stevedoring Industry Levy Amendment Bill are part of the reform process of the various waterside ports in Australia. That reform process is going on apace and I think there is much to be said for the way in which the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, Senator Collins, has gone about his work. But he has had much help in that. To use the Port of Melbourne as an example, the Minister would agree that the President of the Victorian branch of the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia, Mr Jim Beggs, the Secretary, Mr Claude Cumberlidge and other officers such as Archie Arceri have contributed much to the reform process which is progressing rapidly under the present Ministry.
—Have you ever worked on the wharves yourself?

— I have never worked on the wharves, but I have acted for people injured on the wharves. Had Senator MacGibbon ever been injured on the wharves, I would have been more than pleased to act for him. Had it been a matter of damage to the mouth, I would have called you as an expert witness.
—Senator Cooney, I would not want to interrupt a very stimulated exchange, but would you please convey your comments through the Chair?

—I certainly shall, and with no disrespect to you, Mr Acting Deputy President. What has happened under this Minister and those people in the Melbourne wharf is that they are about to establish four enterprise-based agreements with the stevedoring companies in that port. There are five but Conaust Ltd has not found it possible to enter into an enterprise-based agreement. The Industrial Relations Commission has sent it away to discuss the issues with the union and to have an answer by 15 January.

SPEECH.PARA: The reforms have taken place in three main areas. First of all, there has been a restructuring of the industry through the enterprise-based agreement mechanism. There has been a restructuring of 17 awards into one, and there has been a bringing together into one organisation of 25 or 26 unions that are now on the waterfront. But when this process has been completed-and it is expected to be completed fairly shortly-they will become one union. This is a lot of reform to have taken place within a year. It is in line with a long term process of reform on the waterfront.

When Charlie Fitzgibbon, a very famous man not only on the waterfront but also in Australian history, was the secretary in 1961, there were about 27,500 waterside workers in Australia. That number has now been reduced to about 5,000, including people who were not originally in the waterside workers union such as clerks, shipwrights and painters and dockers. The Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union of Australia, quite a famous union, is about to be absorbed into the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought they would kill one another off.

—I think that what Senator Parer would like to say is that, whereas Senator MacGibbon is proud to have been a member of the waterside workers union, Senator Parer would like to be able to claim to have been formerly a member of the painters and dockers union. I think that is to his credit.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a lot of criticism, and I see Senator Crane is in the chamber. He is a man who has struggled mightily for the farming community of Australia over the years. He would be pleased to know that there is a relationship in Melbourne, through the waterside workers down there, led by Mr Beggs, whereby when farmers have problems with the transport of their stock to the wharves and overseas-whether that problem arises through actions by the waterside workers themselves or through others-they are able to ring the executive of the waterside workers in Melbourne and that executive, led by Mr Beggs and Mr Cumberlidge, will see that the problem is solved. I think that this sort of thing, which has been going on for some years now, ought to be proclaimed more and more in this chamber when there is so much criticism of unionists and the union movement.

In conclusion, the wharf in Melbourne is an example of what can be done if a proper reform progress is pursued in the right way. I finish as I commenced by congratulating the Minister. There was some suggestion today that he ought to resign because he has not fulfilled his promise of having reform progressed on the waterfront within a particular period. I think that the amount of work he has already done on that more than justifies his staying. The Minister has been greatly helped in that by the people I have already named as the executive of the port of Melbourne. That has been borne out by the appreciation of people such as those that Senator Crane has represented in the past, and no doubt still represents, and the sorts of things that they now say about the way the waterside workers of Melbourne have acted over the years and how sensibly and progressively they have faced up to the reform and have brought it about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Notwithstanding the efforts of Senator Cooney over the last few minutes to talk up the success of the Government on waterfront reform, the sad fact remains that the legislation we are debating this evening is nothing more than an attempt by this Government to cover up the fact that it has failed to achieve any significant structural reform of the waterfront, or indeed any other aspect of reform in our economy. Despite years of inquiries and reports and the establishment of the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority, the Government is no nearer completing the reform, which even the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) himself has admitted needs to be achieved, than when it started. Although the Opposition is not opposing the Stevedoring Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 or the Stevedoring Industry Levy Amendment Bill 1990, the point must be made that this legislation is only one very small part of what needs to be done in the whole process of waterfront reform.

SPEECH.PARA: Last year the Inter-State Commission brought out a report on waterfront reform which reinforced the evidence of a number of earlier inquiries-that is, massive reform of the waterfront, and the whole transport industry in general, is a matter of utmost urgency for the survival of the Australian economy. Of course, the Government has since done away with the Inter-State Commission, presumably because it did not like what the Commission had to say.

The report laid down a detailed plan of action which, despite its shortcomings, pointed the way toward a more efficient and internationally competitive waterfront. This plan was more than generous to waterside workers whose rorts and work practices have for decades ripped off their fellow Australians. Yet what has the Government done so far? It has introduced this piece of legislation which is far from being a significant step towards eliminating the restrictive work practices, industrial disputes and high unit costs on our waterfront. This legislation only ensures that waterside workers retrenched under the rejuvenation of the work force scheme receive their more than generous redundancy packages.

No doubt the Government, as it has done over the last year or so, will continue to attempt to camouflage its lack of action. The Government will point out that it aims to achieve a 30 per cent increase in productivity over the next three years by cutting out overmanning, pensioning off waterside workers over 55 and introducing industry-based employment rather than pooled employment. This does not sound too bad as a goal when we consider that productivity on the waterfront in Australia has been going backwards for 50 or 60 years. Any sort of improvement has to be good. But when we look at how this goal compares with reforms in other countries, such as New Zealand and the United Kingdom, the level of productivity increase that the Government is seeking really starts to look like a bad joke. New Zealand managed to achieve a 100 per cent increase in productivity in just one year and it is now looking for even greater far-reaching improvements.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did they start from?
—It does not matter where they started from. Australia is starting from a very low base in terms of waterfront productivity.
—Percentage is the only thing that matters. Is that right?
—No, percentage is not the only thing that matters.
—Well, it does matter where you start from.

—Certainly it matters where we start from, but the point needs to be reinforced that Australia also starts from a very low base, and to aim at about a 30 per cent increase simply is not good enough. New Zealand's waterfront costs now run at about 60 per cent below ours, which simply reinforces the point I make, and it is an indication of how woeful this Government's productivity aims really are.

SPEECH.PARA: New Zealand has managed to cut overall stevedoring costs by between 20 and 40 per cent and in some cases by as much as 66 per cent. The number of waterside workers has dropped by as much as 50 per cent which, combined with improvements in work practices, has produced a saving of up to $10,000 per ship per call for roll-on, roll-off vessels.

Even in the United Kingdom, which had a similar, if not worse, situation on its waterfront than Australia's, it achieved a 65 per cent productivity increase in one year. The former director of the United Kingdom National Association of Port Employers, Mr Nicholas Finney, said in an address while visiting Australia recently that the United Kingdom terminal operators have achieved productivity improvements of between 25 and 400 per cent in all operations and they have improved ship turnarounds by up to 100 per cent.

The Hawke Labor Government should look at all aspects of micro-economic reform undertaken by both the British and New Zealand governments. It then might start to get an idea as to how it should be done. In New Zealand it was done essentially by decentralisation of employment and wage fixing on the waterfronts and the corporatisation of all its ports. The New Zealand Government, in one fell swoop, stimulated a drive for improved efficiency by introducing a profit motive among port authorities and did away with pooled employment arrangements-the bane of waterfront employment in Australia and elsewhere-introducing legislation under which individual employers employed their own workers.

In Britain the introduction of real competition between the ports was the key to breaking the stranglehold which the waterside unions had on their dockfront. British ports had suffered under the same rorts and restrictive work practices that we still have here. The unions dominated and controlled every aspect of employment of dock workers with a national dock labour scheme. It was only when some smaller, privately owned ports outside the labour scheme began to take more and more of the sea cargo in Britain that employers began to take a different attitude towards the unions. A long campaign to change public attitudes was undertaken, and eventually legislation was introduced to do away with the nationalised labour scheme. It was the determination of the Government and the employers to break the damaging power of the unions which eventually put the British waterside industry back on the road to prosperity.

Our productivity and unit costs on the waterfront are already way behind those of our international trading competitors. We have to improve at a much faster rate than anyone else just to tread water. On several previous occasions in debates on the waterfront I have given the Senate facts and figures as evidence of our abysmal record on the waterfront and with regard to shipping costs and productivity output compared to other nations.

TALK.START.PARA: —All of which were nonsense.

—They were not nonsense, Minister, they were right on the ball. Let me repeat that the Australian waterfront is only 50 per cent as productive as waterfronts in Europe and only 40 per cent as productive as waterfronts in Asia. It is obvious, therefore, that a 30 per cent increase in our productivity over three years will not make much headway.

SPEECH.PARA: The Inter-state Commission report estimated that reform of our whole transport system, including roads, railways, aviation, shipping and the waterfront, would boost gross domestic product by some $9 billion per annum. A mere 20 per cent improvement in productivity on the waterfront would improve gross domestic product by $1,100m per annum. Yet the only tangible piece of reform that this Government is putting into place is an agreement with the unions and employers as to how much they will pay the retiring wharfies-and a very generous payment it is too. A 55-year-old wharf labourer with 25 years' experience, who would probably be retiring soon anyway, will receive 247 weeks' pay. That is not bad-nearly five years' pay. That is a fine nest egg to retire on, if one can get it.

Some 3,000 retiring wharfies will get an average of $100,000 each in redundancy payments, a total of $300m-$150m of which comes out of the taxpayer's pocket with the other $150m being paid by industry, which will be passed on to the customers. Most significant among these customers are Australia's farmers, who simply cannot afford to continue carrying the additional expense, especially in the circumstance of the present rural crisis, which is utterly destroying their livelihoods. How many farmers who will have to walk off their properties because the source of their livelihood has been destroyed by this Government's failed economic management would like to walk away with $100,000 in their pockets? But there is no such handout for them.

Yet while all this largesse for waterside workers is being signed, sealed and delivered, the Government has not come up with any significant agreements to change work practices. We cannot afford one without the other. What guarantees do we have that improvements to work practices will ever be forthcoming once the redundancy payments have been made? No wonder the Government has been able to expend only $9.3m of the $40m allocated for waterfront reform in the 1989-90 Budget. I understand that that is because so far no-one has actually taken up the golden handshakes and that, on the contrary, the size of the work force on the waterfront has increased by some 200 or so. Therefore, less than a quarter of the amount it had budgeted for has been spent. That is a clear indication of its failure to keep pace even with its own meagre plans for reform. That Budget allocation in 1989-90 was to ensure that the Waterside Industry Reform Authority would be able to complete its reform program by July 1992. It is now budgeted to continue into 1992-93.

The Government rejected in the House of Representatives an Opposition amendment that would have put a time limit on its reforms-a three-year time limit which the Government originally imposed on itself, but which it has now blithely abandoned. Coupled with the Government's failure to keep up to its schedule of reforms in the shipping industry, this woeful performance can only cast serious doubts on the Government's ability to complete even the simplest plans. Next year I am expecting to see a new Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support in office because the incumbent Senator Collins promised to resign if he did not deliver significant reform in the shipping and waterfront industry within 12 months. On the Government's record so far, he has not a hope of doing so and there is very little time for him left to achieve that. We look forward to his resignation with some anticipation.

Time in this debate is limited, so I shall not put some of the details that I would have put to the Senate if we had had more time. I conclude by saying that this Government has admitted that shipping and waterfront reform is a vital element in any micro-economic reform, but it refuses to bite the bullet and do something productive about it. The Government continues to be more interested in keeping the unions happy than it is in fixing up the economic mess that it has created.

To summarise, when it comes to waterfront reform, this Government has been out on one long smoko because it is scared shipless by the union power of the wharfies, like the one called `Judge' because he is always sitting on a case. The fact is that this Government lacks the political will to recognise that we do not have the luxury of a decade for discussion and negotiation to work out what should be done. By that time, the opportunities will have evaporated and the International Monetary Fund will be determining our future. To achieve the changes that are necessary, this country desperately needs a coalition government which has the policies, the drive and the guts to implement them. The coalition is committed to change and our policies will bring about real reforms-reforms which, it is estimated, will bring about $850m in annual savings in waterfront costs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the Stevedoring Industry Legislation Amendment Bill, one cannot be critical of the fact that there is an attempt to make some improvements.
—Senator Chapman was.

—No, he was not. He said at the start of his speech that something was better than nothing, and I think that those were his exact words. I return to what I was saying, because I do not want to waste time. I think that it is an absolute tragedy that this Bill has been floating around on the Notice Paper for weeks and weeks and that it is hooked up in the adjournment.
—I hope it does not go that long.

—I hear what Senator Collins says. I refer to what was said by Senator Cooney in terms of cooperation between the farmers and the Waterside Workers Federation. The only time that I can remember any real cooperation was when we loaded live sheep at Esperance many years ago. Once we got rid of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union pickets, the waterside workers hopped in and gave us a hand to load the sheep. The interesting point was that those waterside workers were farmers and they were helping to load their own sheep.

SPEECH.PARA: Waterfront reform is the key to micro-economic reform. One has to conclude that what has happened is a shameful era in Australia's history. It has impeded our export performance enormously. It is interesting to note that since Federation there have been some 40-odd inquiries into the waterfront, but the real pace of inquiries has heated up since 1983.

I just want to refer to these particular inquiries because they have been used as a vehicle for non-activity. The first one was the Webber report. The second one was the report of the Crawford Committee on Revitalisation of Australian Shipping. The third one was an importer-exporter panel chaired by Ivan Deveson. The fourth one was the Stevedoring Industry Review Committee chaired by Sir John Moore. The fifth one was the Shipping Reform Task Force chaired by Ivan Deveson, and the next one was the culmination of these in the Inter-State Commission Waterfront Investigation report released in April 1989. Now, we have the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority (WIRA) with the supposed job of putting them in place. It is quite incredible, when we see all the inquiries and the report process, that we have actually had six inquiries in that time and the Government is now attempting to do something very minimal on the whole waterfront. I do not think that does the Government any good, and in my view it does not reflect a genuine effort to reform the waterfront.

Let us look at some of the reasons why it has to be reformed. We only have to look at the figures. In Asia approximately 60 containers per hour are moved; in Europe, approximately 35; on a good day in Adelaide, 20; and most of the other ports around Australia are significantly less than that. In Asian countries ships are turned around in 24 to 36 hours; in Australia they take between 8 and 14 days. In terms of the situation we have in front of us, it is absolutely crucial that we do more than has put in front of us now.
Let us look at the WIRA situation. It is my view that what has been put in place in terms of WIRA is really a cop out of what is required. The principal points of the WIRA agreement are:
(a) Negotiate and include the draft Stevedoring Industry Award 1989;
(b) determine Industry and enterprise based training arrangements to be offered to enable company standards to be met;
(c) process offers for early retirement to enable surplus watchmen to leave the Industry;
(d) complete the recruitment and training of 200 new employees;
(e) employers shall advise the Authority of their plans to change to enterprise employment;
(f) enter into negotiation of enterprise or port agreements;
(g) process offers for the progressive removal of 500 employees;
(h) develop enterprise/port training programs and establishment of industry training facilities;
(i) resolve issues related to intermediate/small ports; and
(j) resolve issues related to grain handling ports.
None of these are particularly momentous or require a lot of effort. Yet there has only been progress made on three of them-(c), (d) and (e).

I will go a bit further and highlight the lack of activity on the waterfront and where Australia finds itself today. I refer particularly to Ford Motor Co of Australia Ltd and Nissan Motor Manufacturing Co (Australia) Ltd, which are now contracting to have their motor cars shifted to New Zealand by Russian air cargo. These companies are going to achieve out of that a $350 saving per car and time. All one can conclude from that is that Ivan Deveson has obviously given up. That is an absolute disgrace and it is a reflection on the lack of activity and reform in this particular area.

I just want also, as Senator Chapman did, to raise the issue of redundancy payouts. There is no question in anybody's language that they are generous in the extreme. They will work out somewhere in the order of $100,000 per employee who takes redundancy or, at the top level, payouts of up to $250,000. Now we have the situation where these redundancy payouts are now being offered without any productivity gains in return. I find that absolutely incredible when one looks at the amounts of money involved.

I come back to the point that I made at the start and that is what waterfront reform is all about is whether or not Australia is going to become internationally competitive. The pace at which we have moved in this particular area has been abysmal, and it is not creating a situation where we are catching up to the rest of the world. Whether it be on a percentage basis or whatever measure one wants to place on it, the facts are that the other countries around the world that we compete with, particularly New Zealand, Great Britain, and those in Asia and America, are beating the pants off us when it comes to our performance on the waterfront.

The waterfront is the key to micro-economic reform in this country. We must start where the bottleneck occurs. We can have all the reforms in the other areas but if the product is going to be held up or interfered with at the point where it leaves the country, all the virtues and advantages that have been gained in the other areas are lost. They just slip down the drain. I emphasise that a little bit is better than nothing but it brings little credit to this Government and the Minister, in particular, that we have a Bill before us which has had so much noise made about it and which really is going to achieve so little.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: — I have followed this debate very closely, even though I was not in the Chamber. I listened to every speaker over the monitor and compiled pages of corrections to the utter nonsense that has been delivered by the majority of the Opposition speakers in this debate. But, as a lot of it was repeated by Senator Chapman, I will just confine myself to give the flavour of some of the nonsense that has been perpetuated by the Opposition in this debate and principally what Senator Chapman said. When that is combined with the rubbish that was delivered in the House of Representatives, particularly by the shadow Minister for shipping and waterfront reform, the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), it does really provide a pile of paper so deep that it would take an hour and a half, not 10 minutes, to respond.

SPEECH.PARA: I just turn to some of the things that were said by Senator Chapman. He repeated once again the complete furphy, which has been repeated by at least 10 Opposition speakers in the House of Representatives and in the Senate, that the Government has said that it has set a target of 30 per cent for productivity increases on the waterfront. The Government did not say anything of the sort. What the Government did say and I will quote from the then Minister, Mr Willis, who said that the agreement:
. . . provides the framework for an increase in labour productivity of around 30 per cent over the next three years . . .
The Government expects substantial additional productivity improvements from the introduction of enterprise employment, award restructuring and the phasing out of cross-subsidisation . . .

of stevedoring labour costs between the ports. These Bills-and Senator Chapman, of course, also totally misunderstood what they were about-underpin the need for that last part of the Government's undertakings to be delivered. They are important and essential legislation to the waterfront reform process.

To give an indication as to why the Opposition should in fact stop running this nonsense about 30 per cent productivity across the board being set as the target, one has to go no further than one major employer of waterfront labour in Australia, and that is National Terminals (Australia) Ltd, and what it has tangibly demonstrated about its confidence in the waterfront reform program. No company as efficient and as professional as National Terminals, in its right mind, would invest the sums of new capital in new investment in waterfront infrastructure if it did not have absolute confidence in what was finally going to be the substantial outcome of this process.

A month or two ago, National Terminals announced that it is about to embark on a $60m infrastructure upgrade of its port facilities in Sydney, of which $40m will be spent by the end of next year. No company engaged in waterfront would engage in that kind of capital investment, particularly considering the current downturn of trade, if it was not confident of achieving substantial productivity gains from the waterfront process. National Terminals knows that it can have confidence in getting those gains. After months of very detailed and tedious negotiation with the unions involved, National Terminals has substantially completed what will be, I think, the first enterprise agreement-and a major enterprise agreement at that-in this country after half a century of the existing work practices.

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't it a subsidiary of ANL?

—I do not quite know why that is relevant. It makes no difference at all. The Waterfront Industry Reform Authority will determine at the end of the day, with no pressure from me, whether agreements delivered in terms of these arrangements meet the Government's productivity targets. Whether Australian National Lines owns or has a significant participation in National Terminals is hardly relevant to the fact that this enterprising company has committed $60m to new investment in the very important container port of Sydney.

SPEECH.PARA: Once again Senator Chapman used-and I think he made a comprehensive fool of himself in his subsequent statements-comparisons between Australia and New Zealand. He said that it did not matter from what base one started in terms of comparing percentage increases. I must say that this would be an interesting piece of logic to apply in future debates on productivity.

We welcome the gains that have been made in New Zealand ports and on the New Zealand waterfront. We wish the new New Zealand Government well in continuing, as I have no doubt it will, the substantial reforms that were put in place by the then Labour Government of New Zealand. But in terms of making a valid comparison, we cannot ignore the fact, as unsatisfactory as it is, that the current level of productivity in Australia is running at about 4,000 tonnes of cargo per man per year. If we are to make a percentage comparison, it is essential that we compare starting points. New Zealand started in terms of that 100 per cent increase from a base of 2,600 tonnes of cargo per man per year-an abysmal record, even by the current unsatisfactory standard that exists in Australia. Of course, no member of the Opposition has bothered to put that on the public record. I do so now.

I want to say something with considerable conviction. I will tell the Senate this in respect of Senator Chapman's criticisms-and we have heard many from the Opposition-about the redundancy payouts for wharfies who have spent 40-odd years on the wharves: I will listen to complaints. It is a generous package-deliberately generous. The package was in fact set not by the Government but on the recommendations of the Inter-State Commission that carried out the substantive investigation and report on which this entire reform process is based. We adopted its recommendation on redundancy to encourage this process without industrial disputation and to provide a fair deal for people we are asking to voluntarily put their hands up and leave the industry.

I will listen to criticism of this package. I will listen to criticism from Inghams chicken pluckers or hospital cleaners. But there is one group of workers in this country that I will not even listen to in terms of criticism of that package and that is from politicians, especially Federal politicians.

Let me say that in terms of stresses, strains and particularly disabilities of our profession, I do not downgrade our superannuation situation. I just put it on the record as a matter of fact that if it is not the most generous scheme for workers in Australia, it is among the most generous. Not surprisingly, I have compared the two schemes because of the continuous criticism from Opposition Federal politicians about the redundancy payments. I can tell the Senate without going into actual detail that in rough terms a superannuation package, on equivalent basis of service, paid out to a member of the Senate such as Senator Chapman is about twice as generous as the redundancy packages that will be paid out to waterside workers. So that is one species of worker that I will simply not even listen to that sort of criticism from because it is hypocritical-and I might add, substantially so.

I am not satisfied with the pace of progress on the Australian waterfront. That is no great state secret. I must have said it at least half a dozen times in the last month at public or semi-public occasions, the last one of which was the annual dinner of the bulk commodities group in Melbourne. I would like to see the pace of change faster than it is.

In conclusion I would like to point out a number of facts-facts that have been confirmed by Opposition speakers. We are talking about radically changing work practices on the waterfront that have existed for half a century. In all of the years that these inefficiencies were perpetuated under coalition governments, not one single thing was done to address the problem. There was not a scrap of initiative from former conservative governments to change the system. Even though the arrangements are 50 years old, this is the first Government that has attempted to make this difficult change.

We hear only the employers' side from the other side of the House. This is even though the users, who are the biggest critics of the system, heap as much or more blame on the employers as they do the employees. But we never hear that from the Opposition. There is never an ounce of criticism of the employers from the Opposition. This approach has been perpetuated here again today.

Senator McLean read out very accurate statistics on the lack of recruitment on the waterfront and the average age of the work force. Workers on the waterfront who went into the industry straight out of school at the age of 15 or 16 years are now in their late 50s or early 60s and close to retirement. They have known no other form of employment or set of conditions for their entire working lives. A little fat politician from the Northern Territory turns up on the wharves and says, `Right oh boys, everybody out of the pool in six months'. That is the attitude that is being promoted opposite-we come in with a big stick, we do not pay anybody anything, we belt them over the head with a legislative club and we stand back and wait for the devil take the hindmost. That is the prescription put by the Opposition.

The fact is that the Government has embarked directly, in line with the recommendations of what I say and what I have said before is an excellent piece of work by the Inter-State Commission, on a program that will result in substantial productivity improvements on the Australian waterfront without any substantial losses to this country from serious industrial disputation.

Progress has been made. We are now very close to consummating our first major enterprise agreement. I knew at the start of this process-which is the reason I have quite openly expressed my dissatisfaction in the Senate tonight-that right now would be the most difficult time. I knew that all of the easy issues were going to be negotiated in the first six months and that the hard ones, in terms of jumping off the cliff, making this radical change, putting names on an enterprise agreement for the first time in half a century and breaking down the system of national employment, were going to be very difficult towards the end of the game. Despite that and despite my dissatisfaction about the pace of progress, I know that very shortly we are going to achieve a substantial breakthrough in this process and get some enterprise agreements up in the major ports of Sydney and Melbourne. Once that happens, the process will be accelerated and other developments and progress will rapidly follow.

The prescription the Government has offered and is asking the Senate to support tonight in these essential Bills to underpin this package is the only way to sensibly approach reform on the Australian waterfront. The prescription being offered by the Opposition would be one of absolute industrial and financial disaster for this country, were it to be followed. I urge all members of the Senate to support this legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: STEVEDORING INDUSTRY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990
Bill agreed to.
STEVEDORING INDUSTRY LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1990
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: — by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments:
Clause 7, page 2, proposed subsection 9a (1), lines 22 to 25, omit the subsection, substitute the following subsection:

`` `(1) The Minister shall notify in the Gazette a date (in this section called the ``finishing date''), being a date no later than 1 June 1992, after which the levy referred to in paragraph 4(1) (a) ceases to be imposed in respect of the employment of Division B waterside workers by an employer at a port.''.
Clause 7, page 2, proposed subsection 9a (2), lines 26 to 28, omit the subsection, substitute the following subsection:

`` `(2) The Minister may notify a finishing date only where he or she is satisfied that all employers at the port have changed their employment arrangements in accordance with the Reform Agreement.''.

We are constrained by time because of the guillotine which the Government has imposed upon this place, with the support of the Australian Democrats. It is my understanding that the Australian Democrats guaranteed in writing some time ago that they would never support the guillotine, yet they have done so. The Stevedoring Industry Levy Amendment Bill is a most important Bill. The reasons for the requests to clause 7 of the Bill have been canvassed in a speech during the second reading debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be equally brief. In response to Senator Parer's contribution, I must say that in the last 48 hours I have been listening to non-stop complaints about the guillotine, but I noticed, along with many others, that yesterday I had to come down to this chamber twice-not once, but twice-on quorum calls which were called purely for the purpose of allowing the Opposition spokespersons to come into the chamber to speak on legislation.

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. The reason quorums were called on those two occasions yesterday was that the pagers issued to the Opposition were not working. On one occasion I was the next speaker. I had my pager with me, it did not register when the call was put through to me and a quorum was then called to enable me to get to the chamber. The same applied to the second person. We have had the technicians at my office and they have now agreed that as the pagers are not recording calls, although they do receive the messages, in the recess they will be totally checked out. So some of these smart, off-the-cuff remarks are not really very smart at all. The Minister ought to get his facts right.

—Senator Reid, you ought to get your facts right before you stand up on a point of order. That was not a point of order; it was an explanation. This evening the President told another honourable senator who got up on a point of order that turned out not to be one that she was misleading the Senate.

— In response to that completely disorderly contribution from Senator Reid, I withdraw my comment. As I am in the lofty position of being on the front bench I do not use a pager so I had forgotten about the difficulties with pagers. The Government will be opposing these requests for the reasons that were quite succinctly outlined by Senator McLean. They bring forward an already existing intent on the part of the Government to phase out these levies by four months. It therefore achieves virtually nothing, apart from disrupting agreements that have been entered into between the parties concerned in this process to advance waterfront reform. On those grounds the Government will be opposing the Opposition requests.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the requests (Senator Parer's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.
