INTERJECT.PARA: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Chairman of Committees, Senator Colston, reports that the Committee has considered the Stevedoring Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 and the Stevedoring Industry Levy Amendment Bill 1990 and agreed to them without amendment or requests. The question now is that the remaining stages of the Bills be agreed to and the Bills be now passed.

DEBATE.TITLE: TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 November, on motion by Senator Collins:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 is an omnibus Bill. It contains a number of uncontroversial matters. I do not propose to detain the Senate for more than a moment. I simply say that, as far as I am concerned, we support the amendments, particularly the Broadcasting Act amendment which will enable the power to approve the text of medical advertisements to be delegated to the Proprietary Medicines Association of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments to the Telecommunications Act allow the Minister to give written directions to Austel regarding the variation and cancellation, in addition to the issuing, of customer equipment permits and cabling licences. It also provides penalties for non-compliance and makes it mandatory for a person selling customer equipment for which there is no permit in force to notify the customer of that fact. Austel will also be empowered to waive application fees for disabled persons and in the cases of registered charities and benevolent institutions.

These are all minor but constructive amendments. They strengthen the powers of Austel. The track record of that authority to date gives us confidence that it will continue to be vigorous in its scrutiny of the activities of the major players, particularly Telecom Australia. We therefore support these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I confine my remarks on the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 to concerns that relate to two of the regulatory bodies within this portfolio. The first is the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA). This Bill makes provision for the CAA to issue on the spot fines as an alternative to prosecution of operators who contravene a provision of the civil aviation regulations. As we know, at present, under the guidance of its Chairman, Mr Dick Smith, the CAA is considering removing around 200 safety regulations from its books in the name of-using that by now famous phrase- `affordable safety'.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have expressed on previous occasions, the Australian Democrats have some serious reservations about this move, particularly coming at the same time as deregulation of our airways when the stresses on the industry as a whole are bound to be greater. Since becoming Australian Democrat spokesman for transport, I have been approached by people of all sectors of the aviation industry expressing their concern at the many changes going on in this industry. I have seen pilots, cabin crew, maintenance engineers, airworthiness surveyors and air traffic controllers as well as some of the professional bodies representing these people. The overwhelming feeling I get from them is that, while many of the changes under way in aviation are necessary and desirable, the rate of change within the industry is cause for great concern. When the experts from the industry are concerned enough to approach us, we have a responsibility to examine closely these proposed changes.

It is acknowledged that there is a chronic staff shortage in the CAA. It has been accepted that this staff shortage is industry-wide and that there are no short term solutions to it. Dick Smith himself has expressed concern over the declining number of people in the air worthiness surveillance field. To quote from an interview he gave to the magazine Australian Aviation in September 1989, Mr Smith said:
I am personally concerned that we are going into a system of deregulation where we are going to need, I believe, a lot more surveillance and we really don't have the people to do it.

What we do have though is the deregulation of our airways, a regulatory body significantly underresourced, a staff shortage in the industry as a whole and a number of reports recommending the removal of some of our safety regulations-and all of these factors are coming into play at the same time.

A commonly given reason for removing some of our safety regulations is that they are unique to Australia. In my opinion, since we have what is internationally regarded as an excellent safety record, we should not be the slightest bit disturbed by having unique safety procedures. Indeed, given this record, we should be very sure before undertaking any major changes to it. Some, including the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) and the Chairperson of the CAA, will argue that any airline with a safety cloud over it will see a marked decline in passenger numbers. I am sure that this is correct. But the question I ask is: what has to happen for that airline to get that cloud over it? Until one of the operator's planes actually crashes, how is the public to know which are the safe operators and which are not? This argument seems to suggest a highly reactive, rather than a pro-active, approach to air safety. When it comes to an issue such as safety, we simply cannot afford to be reactive in our approach. High standards must be set and enforced vigorously.

In a recent speech on the deregulation of our airways, Senator Collins informed us that there were Australian operators, indeed in general aviation, falsifying maintenance records. I should not be surprised to know that. It is to some of these people that the CAA will be devolving some of its responsibilities. The many meetings I have had with industry representatives have led me to the opinion that if there is in fact no drop in safety from removing a costly regulation, so be it.

However, there must have been a good reason for installing that regulation in the first place and we should be very sure that this reason no longer exists. Let us err on the side of caution when making these decisions and when deciding which duties should be devolved to industry. If we are to remove some regulations, let us ensure that our safety watchdog, the CAA, is funded in such a way as to ensure that it can perform its surveillance duties assiduously.

The Democrats are specifically concerned with the provision before us today to allow on the spot fines to be issued for breaches of air safety regulations. There needs to be some accountability for regulation breaches. While the Minister may argue that such fines will be issued only for minor breaches, nevertheless they are breaches of our air safety regulations. I understand that regulations as to which records are to be kept in relation to these on the spot fines are currently the subject of discussion between the Department of Transport and Communications and the industry. I also understand, through contact my office has had with the Minister's office, that these regulations are to be subject to the scrutiny of Parliament. I ask the Minister whether he could give a commitment to the Senate that this is the case when he sums up.

I turn now to the broadcasting provisions of this Bill. We see that the Bill makes some minor amendments to the advertising of medicines in Australia. We have no problem with these amendments. However, we are concerned with the broader problems confronting Australia's broadcasting industry at present. We have two television stations in receivership and the third losing money. Ownership of our print media is the most concentrated amongst developed nations, with an American citizen controlling over 60 per cent of our print media outlets. We have television audience reach limits far in excess of those found in overseas countries and the Cabinet is currently considering raising these limits even higher. Further, under the policy of this Government, through networking agreements, actual audience reach can be much greater.

With the industry in this state, the Democrats believe that a powerful regulatory body is necessary to protect the public interest. Not only must this body be powerful; it must also be funded in such a way that allows it to adequately oversee the industry. This is particularly true given that broadcasters are basically in the industry for the purpose of making money or perhaps for some perverse form of ego gratification. I think we could ask whether it really is always in the public good.

Over the past 14 years, the power of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) has for purely political reasons been eroded by successive governments to the point where it has become, to quote the previous chairperson of the ABT, Deirdre O'Connor, a toothless tiger. We are concerned at the directions in which broadcasting in this country is heading. I just wanted to take a few moments in this debate to put that on the record. As such, having raised a couple of specific concerns, we have no major amendments to propose to the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable senators for their support of this legislation and in response I will simply address the concerns raised by Senator Kernot. So far as the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) is concerned, I am not only aware of but share Senator Kernot's concern about expressions that have been made about the rate of change in the airline industry in which the CAA is currently engaged.

SPEECH.PARA: It is perfectly understandable; the change is long overdue. The CAA and, indeed, those Federal Opposition members who have a keen interest in this matter have substantially supported the review that has been conducted and is still being conducted of all the regulations that govern the operations of the aviation industry in Australia. Because many of these regulations have simply grown up over decades of use, without any real examination of the actual purpose for which they exist, it has been discovered that many of them serve no useful purpose in a safety sense. They simply represent unnecessary paperwork. That is the root cause of most of the changes that are being made. The primary objective of the CAA has always been, is, and will remain-certainly under this Government-that of safety.

In terms of Senator Kernot's concern that in making these changes the organisation should always err on the side of caution so far as safety is concerned, that is a view I hold equally with Senator Kernot and it is a view that is substantially held by the organisation itself. It is said often but can bear repetition one more time that it is no accident that Australia has one of the most enviable safety records in the world in respect of the operation of large aircraft. We are very much on a par with other countries when it comes to the safety of light aircraft. That is simply the nature of the beast: the types of aircraft that are involved in that operation and the people who fly them.

When a tragedy occurs in terms of a light aircraft colliding with a hard object-usually the ground-and people are killed, the best safety regulations and procedures in the world will not stop situations where it is discovered that the reason for the accident was that the pilot, with several people on board the aircraft, was busy dropping flour bombs out of the aircraft at a height of 20 feet from the ground at the time. Unfortunately that happens in an area of aviation that, by its very nature, is far more difficult to police effectively in terms of individual pilots than is the rigorous supervision that can be given to commercial pilots who fly passengers in Australia. That rigorous examination is given.

In respect of that, I assure Senator Kernot that there will be no devolution of the supervisory role of the CAA in respect of, for example, the day to day administration of engineering checks and so on to the people who in the main actually carry out that work. The reason that it is being done is to enable the CAA to concentrate far more effectively on its supervisory role rather than having to carry out by rote the day to day examination of these issues. It will improve the efficiency of the supervision and not derogate from it. The CAA will be responsible for carrying out close supervision of the operators themselves rather than having to be engaged in the hands-on supervision of the actual maintenance.

So far as Senator Kernot's specific question about regulations is concerned, I can advise Senator Kernot that all regulations to the Federal legislation which govern aviation in this country are subject not only to the scrutiny of this Parliament but also to the disallowance by this chamber. Through that avenue, Senator Kernot will get an opportunity, whenever she desires it, to examine regulations as they are promulgated, passed through the various scrutiny processes of committees that are set up by this chamber to carry out that task and, eventually, scrutinised by this chamber in the final analysis.

On every occasion that Senator Kernot raises concerns directly with me-and she has done so on a number of occasions-or with people in the aviation industry, every one of those concerns is followed up with the CAA. In respect of one significant matter that the CAA is currently addressing-the new arrangements for the management of Australian air space, which have caused widespread concern within the industry, understandably enough because it is a substantial proposal in terms of change-I have been assured by the CAA that intense consultation within industry is being carried out.

I will give Senator Kernot and the Senate just one brief example of how that process is alleviating these concerns and achieving some results. I was recently in the city of Mount Isa. I had a very long meeting with a large number of people from the aviation industry in that community, which has a very extensive charter operation, of course, by the nature of the community, and operators within that industry in respect of CAA changes. I agreed that the concerns that were raised warranted a personal Mount Isa visit by technical officers from the organisation.

My office set those arrangements in place immediately. In fact, one of my own staff was to accompany those making that visit. The CAA contacted the people at Mount Isa in the industry in the interim and had preliminary discussions with them. I was subsequently advised by the very people who raised the concerns that the visit from the officers from my office would not be necessary because, as a result of the consultation that had taken place, their concerns had been alleviated.

I simply advise the Senate and Senator Kernot that that is the process I am addressing. I hold myself open-because of the responsibility that I have, ultimately, as the Minister-to have raised with me directly the concerns of any senator or, indeed, any member of the public about changes that are being brought about in the control of Australian airspace. I can assure all of them that those concerns will be followed up assiduously. In conclusion, I thank the Australian Democrats and the Opposition for their support for the legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 November, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aussat Amendment Bill 1990 makes a number of amendments to which we agree. I will also be moving some amendments during the committee stage which we think are clearly--
—We have not seen them. Where are they?

— They should have been circulated some time ago. They have got to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins), and I apologise that they have not been provided to the Australian Democrats. They certainly should have been. I see they are on my desk, so maybe they are on Senator Kernot's as well.

SPEECH.PARA: In any event, I do not propose to take a great deal of time and, in the process, I will explain the purpose of the amendments. In essence, they give effect to the assurance of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that Aussat Pty Ltd would be allowed to be a full competitor with Telecom Australia whereas, in fact, what will occur is that it will become substantially able to compete but in the areas of public telephones and first phones, Telecom retains the monopoly, and we seek to remove those impediments.

I do not have any great confidence that the Australian Democrats will be supporting us in that, and that is a matter of regret. I think it is consistent with the approach that the Democrats have taken in this area of blindly supporting Telecom, when the rest of the world has long since shown that competition in this area is absolutely vital if efficiencies for consumers are to be delivered and if, ultimately, we are to have lower prices for consumers.

The history of Aussat has probably been covered many times in this chamber. Suffice it to say that it would have been much better for all concerned if Aussat had been privatised when it was first established in the early 1980s. If that had occurred many of the problems that have beset it since that time would not have arisen. I am sure that most of us are aware of the compromise that resulted from Telecom, in the first instance, bitterly opposing the separate establishment of Aussat and then, ultimately, urging that it be kept in government hands, the ultimate sell-out being that it was then allowed to have 25 per cent of the shares.

Telecom was wrong on all counts. Certainly, there was no justification in my view for Telecom being allowed to get its hands on Aussat. Indeed, if it had been privatised in the first instance it would have had access to private sector funding. If it had been given room to breathe by the legislation it would have been able to be a viable competitor to Telecom, and to have taken its chance in the marketplace. I have no doubt that we would have seen many more variations on the competitive theme, many more efficiencies forced upon Telecom and lower prices delivered to consumers as a result.

In the end we achieved the worst of all possible worlds to the point where Aussat has now been a millstone around the neck of governments ever since it was created. It is still an albatross. I think it has gradually dawned on the Government, with its outrageous approach to competition in this area-or should I say, Claytons competition-that Aussat is not saleable. Nonetheless, the Government has persisted with its merger between Telecom and the Overseas Telecommunications Corporation (OTC) when they were clearly the two best potential competitors, as recognised from the outset by the Treasurer (Mr Keating).

Unfortunately, that rational view of the world did not prevail and we have ended up with this nonsense of OTC-clearly the most efficient telecommunications carrier in the country-being forced very unwillingly into bed with the Telecom giant and the alternative, Aussat, as the vehicle for competition. That is not something that any of the potential new entrants would willingly embrace but, of course, they have no choice because of the way the Government has gone about this whole exercise.

It is a grotesque nonsense and I am sure that everyone outside the Government recognises that. Certainly the industry itself watches with disbelief at the way in which these proposals have been put forward. Nonetheless we are stuck with it. The Government have to buy Aussat and pick up the debt burden if it is to get into the game as a competitor. If that is the case, that is the way it has to be until there is a change of Government.

We welcome this Bill to the extent that it will facilitate the sale of Aussat, and repeal the parts of the Act which prevent Aussat from becoming a public company, thereby limiting the number of its shareholders. It has been a continuing conflict of interest, in my view, to have had Telecom right at the boardroom table. That has no doubt been a very significant inhibiting factor for any commercial decisions that Aussat might have wanted to make or, indeed, if it had had the funds to do so, had been able to make.

In the result, I suppose, it has not made a great deal of difference because Aussat has been bound hand and foot from the outset and has not been able to generate sufficient income in order to deliver its services at a competitive price. As a result, it has provided very feeble competition for Telecom. I do not blame the management of Aussat for that situation. I certainly blame the management of Telecom and the Government for allowing that situation to be perpetuated. Nonetheless, we are finally seeing the departure of Telecom from Aussat and that is a good thing as well.

The second group of amendments will enable Aussat to undertake a wider range of activities than it is presently entitled to undertake. As I foreshadowed, our amendments would go a stage further. Indeed, as things stand at the moment, if this Government is in office for the next seven years-which of course it will not be-it will not be allowing a third competitor into the game until that time. That is quite unacceptable. It is a nonsense and I am sure everyone else knows it. The experience around the world has been that the more competition we can introduce, the better. The Government is acknowledging that fact, but saying not yet. It is taking a second best approach to this whole exercise by pretending that it is getting into the business of competition. But by delaying the introduction of real competition for a further seven years, it is ensuring that Telecom will retain not only its first mover advantage, but by all sorts of means, will be able to exercise its dominance in the marketplace to such an extent that it will be a very daunting task for a third entrant to come on the scene in 1997.

As a result, we will probably have a de facto duopoly and no doubt that is what the Government has always had in mind. Again, that is a Clayton's form of competition. I do not think it is defensible. It is explicable in terms of factional deals and national conferences; but it is certainly not defensible and it is seen in the industry as a nonsense. The Government will have to live with that. Nonetheless, to the extent that these amendments open up the game we welcome them. It is simply a product of the stranglehold that the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association has over Telecom and the Government that the first phone monopoly continues in existence. I think it is due for review by the end of June next year. I certainly would not want to be holding my breath that the Government will see reason in the matter. The overwhelming likelihood is that it will cave in and allow that outrageous monopoly to continue.

Certainly, as far as public pay phones are concerned, again I think we have seen the experience around the world of what can happen. When there is competition in this area, we will find public pay phones springing up all over the place. There may be some that need subsidies and to that extent the Government can advance the subsidies. We would find a telephone on every corner. In shopping malls we would find any number of telephones available at a number of the major areas where the public congregates, such as railway stations, airports and the like. We would see much more healthy competition than we have at the present time. We would have credit cards, which Telecom has been talking about for years and has not yet made generally available, and we would have a much more sensible approach to public telephones. But no, Telecom is going to retain that monopoly and therefore our amendments would enable those limitations to be removed. On 8 November the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) quite inaccurately said that Aussat:
. . . will have unrestricted rights to provide all telecommunications services.

That is fatuous nonsense and that is why our amendments are designed to give effect to the Prime Minister's own words. The Government will not accept that proposition. I will be interested to hear from the Minister how he can justify the Prime Minister's comments in the first instance but it is quite clear that the Government has no intention of giving effect to them.

We welcome the glimmer of recognition on the part of the Government that it is about time there was competition in the telecommunications industry. It had turned its face against that prospect until the last election, no doubt knowing in its heart of hearts that that was what had to be done but also knowing that a whole series of groupings upon which it relies for support would not wear it. Once the election was out of the way we had a small recognition of reality, but it is a very unsatisfactory outcome. I have no doubt that whilst this Government remains in office, it will continue to provide the most unlevel of playing fields.

Aussat can become a viable entity in the hands of a new entrant. Whilst it will not welcome having the lead in its saddlebags, constituted by the debt burden, it will at least have the opportunity to go offshore and generally make the best use of satellite services, which is something that Telecom has steadfastly refused to allow in this country, preferring that people waste Telecom's own good time for the introduction of services such as the digital radio concentrator system and, as a result, not maximising efficiencies in this area.

Hopefully, we will get to the stage where the use of the satellite will be determined simply on the basis of what is the most appropriate technology and what delivers the most efficient and effective service. We certainly have not reached that stage as yet and this Bill goes a small way towards what is undoubtedly a very desirable goal in the longer term; that is, the privatisation of Aussat. We welcome it on that basis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not, from the Australian Democrats' perspective, an uncontroversial Bill. Our view on the privatisation of the telecommunications industry is well known. Nevertheless--
—Nevertheless!

—That is right, nevertheless, I want to reiterate some of the important points in this debate. The first point is that I think there is a cynical motive behind the reason that we are even looking at this legislation. That motive is that in the Government's desire to be seen to be achieving some form of these buzz words, `micro-economic reform', it was probably better to choose an area in which it had some confidence that it could deliver than something more difficult such as the waterfront.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the financial situation of Aussat Pty Ltd and the need for the Government to dump it that is motivating the entire debate on privatisation of the telecommunications industry. We have to ask who took the decision to put the first generation of Aussat up there. Who, despite advice to the contrary, took the decision to go ahead with the second generation? Who ignored the success of fibre optic cable technology? Who took decisions to give Aussat a domestic charter only? Now, having such a debt, is that not just a backdoor way to find an excuse, particularly within Labor Party ranks, to say, `We have to get rid of this. The only way to do it is to offer the carrot of a licence to compete along with it.'? I believe that this will threaten the integrity of our entire telecommunications system.

I do not believe that all the creative options for the alternative uses of Aussat have been really explored. I am not denying that action needed to be taken in relation to the finances of Aussat but I do not think that rushing into it in this way was the way to go about it. If the Government's much flaunted reform process is to proceed, then there are several important structural reforms which have to be considered.

Firstly, if the new Telecom-OTC body-Austcom or whatever it is going to be called-is to have an international competitor, it must have efficient and flexible access to large amounts of capital. In order to achieve this we believe that the possibility of freeing this new entity of Loan Council restrictions needs to be explored. I would not like to see the sort of pincer movement which, I believe, was applied to Australian Airlines Ltd and Qantas Airways Ltd being used to achieve Mr Keating' s privatisation agenda by default. That is a well-known model now: to starve the government business enterprise of necessary funds and then use its poor performance as a justification for priv- atisation.

The second structural matter we should address is that Austcom's operational management should be clearly separated from government. In comparison to regulatory authorities in overseas countries, Austel is highly dependent on the Government, acting primarily in an advisory role to the Government. I think the Government needs to recognise the distinct role regulation must play in this restructured industry. Thirdly, I believe that the new, merged Telecom-OTC should not be constrained in competition with a new entrant. I am concerned that by attempting to bend over backwards to accommodate the new competitor we are being unfair to the existing body. One example of that is the solution proposed by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that Telecom-OTC will be subjected to Government-imposed price caps.

A strengthened Austel is essential, not only to protect the interests of residential and business consumers but also the providers of telecommunications equipment and services. We believe that Austel should assume responsibility for all consumer complaints and that mechanisms must be put in place to ensure that all complaints are adequately dealt with. I think it is also imperative that there be representatives from a range of major consumer groups on the Austel board.

I turn specifically to clause 6 of this Bill, which allows Austel to direct Telecom and OTC to make their networks available for Aussat's use. It will empower Austel, where the carriers are unable to reach agreement, to determine the terms and conditions under which this interconnection is to take place. I believe that the terms and conditions of the interconnect fee will largely determine the relative market shares of the providers. In this regard the Australian Democrats believe that Australia is getting not so much a new competitor as a privileged entrant to be granted access to Telecom's publicly funded, high quality, multi-million dollar network. It is absolutely vital that the interconnect fees determined set in place a competitive framework which encourages the most efficient allocation of resources. It would be inappropriate, for example, to set the fee on the basis of profit levels of the two organisations. This would simply remove any incentive for either party to attempt to run at the height of their efficiency, as this approach ignores the fact that the competing firms' profits will be greatly influenced by their relative efficiencies and technological advancements. To set fees based on profit levels would, I believe, be a disincentive to efficiency and development.

These are typical problems of a regulated duopoly. To establish an interconnect fee which provides a fair return to Telecom for past and continued funding of infrastructure development and community service obligations while not unfairly disadvantaging the new entrant will require a highly sophisticated technique. Interconnect fees must take account of the enormous investment the Australian public has made and will continue to make in our high quality telecommunications network. That investment is something like $3,500 for every household. There are a variety of means for establishing interconnect fees, and the debate over the appropriate means by which to calculate community service obligations indicates the controversy which is bound to emerge over the crucial issue of interconnect fees.

The Democrats would hope to be involved in discussions that will take place over the next few months on the future of this body, but I regret that in our rush to privatise-and knowing the parlous state of Australian financiers-we are opening up yet another avenue for foreign ownership of something which could be maintained in Australian ownership and which could be operated efficiently by Australians for all Australians. This is part of a complex package. I regret that we do not know the details of the other packages that go to make up this huge telecommunications jigsaw. I regret that we need to look again to foreign investment which will ultimately lead to foreign ownership as the solution to our woes in this industry as well.

In conclusion, I place on the record the fact that the Australian Democrats cannot support the changes the Government is proposing to the telecommunications industry. These changes are not urgent. Even the Business Council of Australia has said that, if we need to take action on micro- economic reform, it is not urgent to do this in telecommunications and we should start with the waterfront. The Democrats do not support this Bill. I guess I should foreshadow-and it will not surprise Senator Alston to learn this-that we will not support the Opposition's amendments either, because they go even further than this Bill does.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no need to canvass at length in this debate the philosophical differences between the parties on this issue, because that is legitimately what they are. In respect of the Australian Democrats' position in particular, there is a substantial philosophical difference between their approach on this issue and those taken by the Government and the Opposition. I will address briefly in response a number of matters raised by Senator Alston in his contribution and to some extent the concerns raised by Senator Kernot in her contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Alston raised substantive matters that relate very much to the purpose of the amendments which the Opposition will move shortly and which the Government will oppose. Senator Alston queried the first telephone connection, the pay phone situation and the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) when announcing this matter in the House of Representatives. As far as the first telephone is concerned, as Senator Alston is well aware, the monopoly which currently exists on that is sunsetted and will expire in June next year. It expires on 30 June 1991--

TALK.START.PARA: —Just remind me: I thought it was subject to review at that time. You had not given an absolute commitment.
— The commitment is absolute. I will check with the advisers, but to my recollection it was made as far back as 1988. The exclusive right ceases on 30 June 1991.
—But you have not given an undertaking not to extend.

— The Government does not propose to extend that first telephone monopoly. That is the response to the first matter raised by Senator Alston. The matter of pay phones is under review. The Prime Minister made this clear when he made the announcement. Indeed, when the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley), introduced this Bill in the House of Representatives, he made it clear that this was simply the first part of a major package of legislation that will be introduced next year and that it allowed the arrangements to be made to enact the Government's policies in respect of Aussat and to provide Aussat with the capability of providing some immediate competition in the interim. This relates to pay phones because the matter is currently under review by the Government. Its decisions on pay phones and Aussat's capability of providing that particular facility will be incorporated. I add that this is not categorised as a service: in that sense it is hardware at the end of a service. The Government will be considering what to do in respect of pay phones in the major revision to the Telecommunications Act, legislation for which will be introduced into Parliament next year.

SPEECH.PARA: The gravamen of Senator Kernot's position is a philosophical one, and one which I understand. The concerns which Senator Kernot has raised in previous debates in this Parliament are shared to a great extent by me and many other members of the Government, which is why, to the disgust of Senator Alston and the Opposition, we are taking the cautious approach to this matter that we are. It is not, I assure Senator Alston, being one of the lobbyists, as I am, and having been one for some years-I have made that clear in the Senate as a senator for the Northern Territory and formerly as a Northern Territory politician-simply a matter as Senator Alston would like to have it, and I understand the reasons why he is saying it, of buckling under to powerful Telecom unions. I can assure Senator Alston of that. This comes about as a result of widespread concern by members of the Caucus, particularly those who represent remote areas, as we do, to the potential results of the open slather approach that has been advocated by the Opposition to opening up competition. I think that the approach that is being adopted by the Government is the sensible course on which to proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It just takes longer to get there.

— That may be the end result of the exercise. But if that is going to be the end result, all I am saying is that this is the appropriate beginning of the exercise and not `the devil take the hindmost' approach that the Opposition is advocating with some support in other quarters.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of the matter that Senator Kernot raised about the division between Telecom, the Overseas Telecommunications Corporation Ltd and Aussat, principally that kind of division gives both organisations a satellite capacity and, of course, it establishes both organisations with considerable existing domestic and international expertise.

There is no need to delay the Senate any longer with the second reading stage of this debate. I understand that Senator Kernot will be moving for a division on the second reading. In consideration of the hour, I simply conclude by thanking honourable senators for their contributions to the debate.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 4-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 5.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 5, page 2, after proposed paragraph 9 (1) (b), add the following paragraph:
``(c) the provision of all telecommunications services without restriction.''.

Clause 5 relates to the objectives of Aussat. We accept that the two specified in the Bill are valid and that they will enable Aussat dramatically to expand its business, certainly beyond Australia, which is to be welcomed. But, as we indicated previously during the second reading debate, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) cannot have it both ways. We take the view that the Prime Minister should be held to his word and that, if he wishes to say in one breath that Aussat will be entitled to compete at all levels, this amendment would provide as an object of Aussat that it should be able to provide all telecommunications services without restriction. That principally applies to public pay phones and to the first phone monopoly, but to the extent that there might be any other limitations on its activities they should be removed. The object should specify that henceforth Aussat will be a full and complete alternative carrier to Telecom.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be opposing this amendment and subsequent amendments for the same reason, namely, we do not believe Aussat should be privatised. Having said that, we certainly do not believe any competitor should profit at the expense of a nobbled Telecom.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be brief. The Government, as I indicated earlier, will be opposing this and the other amendments. They are unnecessary and are not particularly helpful to the orderly introduction of competition, which has been carefully planned by this Government. As I have already explained, Telecom's exclusive right to supply the first telephone ceases on 30 June next year in any case, which is less than seven months away, but it needs to be properly managed. It is very important to provide the appropriate network termination points for both licensed carriers prior to the new carrier arrangements coming into place. Provision for Aussat as part of the second carrier to be able to provide pay phones is under consideration by the Government, and is part of a major revision of the Act which will be introduced into the House of Representatives next year.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of the Australian Democrats' position on this matter, Senator Kernot knows that that has already been canvassed. I understand very clearly the philosophical position from which the Democrats are arguing. Considering that these amendments advance the pace of carrying out these provisions, I hardly expected them to support the Opposition amendments. The Government also will be opposing them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do I understand that there will be further amendments next year?
— The answer to Senator Harradine's question is yes. There will be a major review of the Act which will be introduced into the Parliament next year.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Alston's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

Clause agreed to.
Clause 6.

``(d) to provide all telecommunications services without restriction.''.
