TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to put on the record the fact that Senator Peter Baume, Senator Teague, and Senator Chapman did miss a division-the third last division that we had. All three honourable senators were in their offices and unfortunately did not get to the chamber during the one minute ringing of the bells.

—by leave-As the Senate is aware, I was on the other side of the chamber when the counting of the division occurred, so my decision to vote in a certain way is obviously formally recorded in the annals of the Senate forever and a day. But, of course, my wish was for my vote to have gone to the other side and I want to record that at this stage. It is an indication of just how stupid it is to sit until this hour night after night. Also, I was not able to hear above the noise.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Friday, 21 December 1990
Motion (by Senator Collins) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take up just a few minutes of the Senate's time this morning. Christmas is a time for family and it is interesting to note that in this place today the Government's response to the report of the National Committee on Violence was brought down. Those two ideas provoked me to say a few words tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: I have heard much said in this session by honourable senators who claim to care for the family-I suspect they do in their own way-but I have rarely, if ever, heard any of them speak out against domestic violence and child abuse. The Government has put these issues on the public agenda and is addressing them. But they are too important, too tragic and too costly in human terms and dollars to be overlooked by our Senate. Why, I ask, is domestic violence a women's issue? Why is child abuse a women's issue?

Today's report said that the violence which is perpetrated against women and children in our society is usually committed by men. I know that most men here and most men in Australia do not beat their wives or assault their children. I look forward to when those men who care for the family, including churchmen in this society, are heard on the public record speaking out against domestic violence. To this point they have been largely silent. I hope that they will join with the Government and with women in protesting against this appalling damage and destruction in our society and that they will worry about the violence of guns and some of the violence in our sport. I hope that that worry about guns and the violence in our sport will become an issue of real concern which we will hear discussed here, rather than the arguments that we hear in this place about issues of concern for families.

Finally, it is often said that a man's home is his castle. I want the human rights that are here to protect people in our society to be assured for all who live in the castle-be it ever so humble-not only for the man whose castle it is, but also for the women and children in that home. This Christmas my wish is for a clear commitment to be made, by men as well as women, to opposing violence in our society, especially in our homes. A happy, safe, protected and peaceful Christmas to all is my wish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not detain the Senate tonight for very long on this issue, but I wonder how many honourable senators have read the latest issue of the Agriculture and Resources Quarterly, which points out various levels of gold production and the present level. In 1990 Australia was the Western world's third biggest producer of gold after South Africa and the United States of America. The statistics and the production forecasts to 30 June 1991 show that gold will reach an export figure of $3.588 billion. It is Australia's second largest export commodity-ahead of wool, but behind coal. As I said, gold is expected to earn that amount in 1991 and this is a 12-fold improvement on the figure for 1980 when 17 tonnes of gold was produced. It is now estimated that in 1991 there will be between 215 and 220 tonnes of gold produced. Yet it is the industry that we have heard the least about in this chamber or anywhere else during this time of economic downturn.

SPEECH.PARA: I wonder why everything is so quiet on that front. The reason is that the gold industry has been producing well, as is shown by the figures, but I believe that it has reached its zenith at this stage and from now on things may go the other way. I believe that a production slump will begin in the very near future. The Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Economics in its December edition of the Agriculture and Resources Quarterly predicts that gold exports will drop to about 155 tonnes by 1995-96 and if the present prices are maintained we will receive about $2.265 billion.

One of the problems I see ahead for the goldmining industry is the closure of small goldmines which have been high-graded-in other words, stripped-and will soon run out of gold. There will be a certain amount of easing of prices. The high level of interest rates has certainly damaged the industry in the last two or three years. I know that 70 per cent of drills are currently idle as there is no further exploration.

This is virtually the last week in which gold producers will enjoy the tax system that they have had. As honourable senators know, a tax on the production of gold will come into effect on 1 January 1991. I believe that that was the wrong decision to make at the time, but I will not debate that matter tonight because we have gone into it many times before. However, I still believe it was the wrong decision to make because it is an industry that has remained prosperous in the remote areas in the economic downturn of the last six months.

I believe that there is light at the end of the tunnel for the goldmining industry and certain other industries as in the last month or so the Government has been talking about security of tenure of the land on which mining takes place. Of course, it has also been talking about security of tenure for forests and all of that sort of thing. It is virtually a new term that has been added to the Government's vocabulary, and I welcome it. There has been security of tenure with regard to environmental issues for quite some time. When there is mention of security of tenure for the resources industry we hear the Australian Democrats and the green movement around Australia making a big noise.

I believe that that is the way for the Government to go so that there will be security in the years to come. Otherwise, our resources, which provide so much export income, will dry up. I commend the Government for doing that very small thing in the last month.

In conclusion, I commend the goldmining industry for what it has done for the economy and for exports over the last couple of years. I have cited the figures from 1980 to the present. The industry has certainly kept small towns in very remote areas alive. It is not feeling the impact of the economic downturn as much as the rest of the country. I felt that its performance over the last couple of years should be put on the record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise for keeping the Senate. I cannot remember the last time I spoke on the adjournment; it is such a long time ago. I should not have to rise, but there still remain unanswered questions that were raised with the Government and a number of Ministers in the Estimates Committee of the Whole. Seeing that the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) is at the table, I ask him to try to hurry up his counterpart, Mr Beazley, and the Department for answers. I acknowledge that Senator Collins is not the Minister.
—I am doing it.

— He did undertake to do it. I accept his undertaking. There are a number of other matters. One relates to the Tax Pack. I asked a question about the need for the Government to clear what was put in the scales in respect of decisions taken to contract out big publishing jobs such as the Tax Pack. That is important because the Tax Pack will be published again next year and we would like it to be published on Australian paper. I received an answer from the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, and I thank him for that.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I want to put a few things on the record. As the Senate will realise, three months after the Tiananmen Square massacre, I asked the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) at Estimates committee hearings for its comments on a range of material I provided. This material documented gross violations of human rights resulting from the population control program of the People's Republic of China (PRC), a program explicitly and enthusiastically supported by the United Nations Fund for Population Activities (UNFPA), and through it, implicitly supported by our Government.

The response from AIDAB was brief. It stated, `AIDAB has not produced any written evaluation of the material'. Twelve months later, in September 1990, again at an Estimates committee hearing, Senator Olsen raised the issue of the potential abuse by the State Family Planning Commission of China of ultrasound machines being supplied to China with AIDAB support. A suggestion was made subsequently that the ultrasound machines could replace X-ray measures currently being used to ensure that Chinese women had not had their compulsorily fitted IUDs `illegally' removed. I put forward that proposition.

I was asked in September to provide evidence supporting claims that systematic violations of human rights were occurring as a result of the PRC population control program. I referred AIDAB and the Minister to the fact that I had provided such evidence 12 months prior, but AIDAB had not taken the time to study it. Following my concerns expressed at Estimates and on subsequent occasions in this chamber, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade wrote to me on 17 December. I thank the Minister for his response. I would like the Minister and AIDAB to know that I consider the response to be somewhat shallow in the face of overwhelming evidence to what are widely held and profound concerns for the human rights of families, and particularly of the poor and powerless women who bear the brunt of state-sponsored population control violence.

The Minister's letter to me claims that the existence of compulsory abortion and sterilisation in the PRC is hard to verify. If they occur, the Minister claims, it is because of overzealousness on behalf of local officials, and not as a result of central policy. The Minister cites comments by the Minister in charge of the State Family Planning Commission that the PRC Government itself claims that coercion is not allowed. The Minister calls these comments `the most authoritative available statement on the present nature of China's population policies'. The Minister claims that much of my evidence is anecdotal and out of date. He claims that `there is no evidence of which we are aware that IUDs are imposed upon women by forceful methods'.

I do not wish to use the time now to respond to these assertions. I ask that AIDAB take the time to read the evidence. All of it is current, most of it is documented. It is clear from the Minister's response that this material has not been studied. How could AIDAB read pages 22 and 28 of the 1988 paper on China's population policies by the United States of America Bureau of Census and conclude that there is no evidence that IUDs are imposed upon women by forceful means? There is none so blind as those who refuse to see. One of the world's foremost experts on China's population program, John S. Aird, wrote to a senior United States congressman in September 1989 as follows:

Those who maintain that the Chinese program is not coercive, or that the question of coercion in the Chinese program is a `controversial' matter that is still in doubt, or that the program has been greatly moderated since 1983 so that coercion is no longer an issue, are simply not in touch with reality. The evidence bearing on this point, though not easily accessible, can be assembled with a little effort by anyone who really wants to get to the bottom of the matter. However, the apologists for the program have not sought it out. Their reluctance suggests that they do not want to know what is really happening with the Chinese program.

The Minister's response fails to reveal material relating to family planning regulations in the PRC which must be held within his Department. I know that a number of Government departments are aware that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade post in Shanghai reported on 2 August 1990 on new regulations which mandated that a couple who had a second unplanned child would be subject to a fine amounting to three times their combined average income as measured by their incomes two years before the unplanned birth. I interpolate here that that is also a violation of workers rights. I note that our Shanghai bureau saw such measures as clearly an attempt not only to standardise the regulations `in law' but also to tighten up the rules concerning birth control and strengthen enforcement. As John Aird wrote in 1989:

We can expect more central and provincial despatches reflecting the hardening line on family planning . . . They represent a trend that has been under way now for more than two years but with gathering force since the beginning of 1989.

The Minister's letter refers to such economic disincentives in the forms of fines imposed on PRC couples for so-called unauthorised pregnancies. I acknowledge the Minister's reference to such fines as `unacceptable coercion' and that the Government intends to take the matters up with China. I congratulate him on that.

However, the Minister has indicated in his letter to me that he will write to Dr Nafis Sadik, the Executive Director of the UNFPA, asking her to exert her organisation's influence to encourage the termination of such unacceptable practices. I doubt whether the victims of such oppression will find comfort in this. After all, the UNFPA representative in China said on 12 September 1990:
China's family planning program is the most successful such effort in the world.

Dr Sadik herself visited China in January 1989 and voiced her support for China's population policy. On 24 May 1989 she delivered a speech in Washington and said that the Chinese Government was running a totally voluntary program. Little wonder the United States Government continues to refuse to fund UNFPA.

I understand the difficulties being faced by AIDAB in coming to terms with the issue of population control and violations of human rights. Little attention has been paid to this subject for many years, and it is understandable that AIDAB finds itself surrounded by the alluring and sanitised pronouncements of foreign governments, and the shallow responses of organisations-international and local-with vested interests in population control.

The answers I have received following concern at violations in Indonesia and Bangladesh reflect this difficulty in successfully examining the evidence. Nevertheless, this historical reality should not be allowed to stand in the way now of a mature, deep and sensitive analysis of the facts.

The credibility of our aid program and the programs that we support directly or indirectly are at stake. I ask AIDAB to once again examine the material I have provided. Dr Aird's 1990 book entitled Slaughter of the Innocents: Coercive Birth Control in China, complete with detailed notes from recent Chinese sources, should be priority reading. I hope that the Minister will again consider these matters and respond. I seek leave to table the Minister's letter written to me on 17 December.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Harradine, I cannot remember when I last spoke on the adjournment. This is only the third time I have spoken in 9 1/2 years. I was stunned by an answer to a question today from Senator Robert Ray. In that answer to me regarding Mr Uren he said that he would consider a reply when the Senate Privileges Committee dealt with the matter, which means at least the middle of February next year. In ordinary circumstances I would have no problem with that. But I believe there are very special circumstances in this particular case.

SPEECH.PARA: Tom Uren has been a friend and political colleague of mine for over 30 years. Therefore, I am particularly upset with Senator Ray's statement that Tom Uren `regularly briefed former Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, on internal divisions within the Australian Labor Party'. It is the words `regularly briefed' that are so offensive because it implies great treachery. That is why I am so upset about this matter and why I believe that Mr Uren is so upset about it. If honourable senators have any question about the interpretation of the words, they only need to look at the headlines of the articles in the press the following day, including `Uren was Fraser's mole in Labor Party, says Ray' in the Sydney Morning Herald; `Ray names Uren as spy and groveller' in the Australian Financial Review; and `Uren rejects Fraser-spy claim' in the Canberra Times. All of the papers carried similar stories, with the inference being that Uren is a spy for his political opponents.

I believe under the circumstances it is intolerable that Mr Uren not be given the opportunity to clear his name and, indeed, to have a cloud over his head until February. Senator Ray is a senior Minister. I believe that he is wrong to persist with the position which he-and, by implication, the Government-gave in reply to Senator Loosley's original question. Indeed, Senator Ray has a responsibility to be fair in this circumstance.

I put to Senator Collins, who is sitting at the table, that he ask Senator Ray to bring forward an answer tomorrow. I tried to contact Senator Ray and I appreciate that he is not in the building at this moment and might not be present at Question Time tomorrow. I think it would be absolutely cowardly for this slur to remain on Mr Uren's character for another two months.

I will not go into all the circumstances, some of which I am aware of. Many people have referred to Paul Kelly's book on the matter. Incidentally, in 1982 I was informed by Tom Uren of the Fraser phone call when it happened. I will not go into that now because I do not have the time to do so. The important thing is that if people have evidence they should either front up with it or, as I said in the question, they should withdraw.

I believe it is essential that Senator Ray does this. If he cannot do it tomorrow, I hope that he will do the right thing and issue a press statement immediately after tomorrow, if he is not available, so that this matter is finalised. I only say that, if the matter is not finalised tomorrow, I will persist until this matter is rectified because I will not have a friend of mine called a scab-and that is what is implied in what has happened up until this moment. I have every confidence in Tom Uren's character and in his word. He said that he has not done what has been alleged. I believe that he is entitled to proper justice from Senator Ray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the moment there is a crisis of confidence in Australian securities. The reason for this is that investors simply cannot be guaranteed of getting a true and fair picture of the potential investment opportunities that are on the market. Investors, both Australian and international, now understand that the Australian share market is far more risk-laden than was previously thought. To many investors the share market has become nothing more than a lucky dip and the annual report nothing more than a deceptive, glossy wrapper which disguises the true nature of what people are investing in.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is that things have changed. The 1980s presented us with a changed scenario. Greed, management excess, ineffective auditing and creative accounting all prospered. They still do. It is a very ugly picture. We have the power in this place to change that and to turn the 1990s into much better times for investors. We can tear off the deceitful glossy wrapping of annual reports and force companies to present themselves for what they are.

Clearly, the disclosure and reporting requirements on companies and their directors were inadequate in this climate of greed. We can no longer consider them useful for the future. Caveat emptor is no more than a mindless chant if the buyer who wants to beware is bedevilled by deceptive annual reports and deceptive management practices hidden by deceptive annual reports. That is the situation which we are in.

The 1980s, a decade of greed, materialism, and conspicuous if not gluttonous consumption, began with Labor in opposition. The 1980s began with big business as Labor's biggest enemy. They ended up bed mates. The 1980s were the years when ethics stopped being something that the business community cared much about. More and more companies took up the practice of behaving and accounting for that behaviour under the `catch me if you can' motto. The concept of managing for the shareholders has almost become something of the past.

Now, more and more, we manage for the managers. The snouts are well and truly in the trough. Labor has been in power for eight years in the 1980s, for eight years of greed, for eight years of managing for managers and eight years of `catch me if you can'. The long list of corporate problems does not conjure up a very positive image at all. One only has to list some of them: Rothwells, Spedley, Bond, Independent Resources, Estate Mortgage, Unity APA, Qintex, Budget Corporation, Hooker, Interwest, Underwater Systems, Equity Corp and-in my State-Adsteam.

Still this behaviour goes on. Now we are finally reaping the reward for the decade of `catch me if you can'. The chickens are coming home to roost. What does that mean? It means that Australian investors have lost money-lots and lots of money. We can no longer say to investors, `Well, if you invested more wisely, you would not have lost your money'. How can investors invest wisely when they cannot get a true and fair picture of what a company is doing? Investors cannot get a true and fair picture of what a company is doing because the reporting requirements of the companies code are inadequate. I submit that the reporting requirements on banks and other non-banking financial intermediaries are also inadequate. The last decade and the recent collapses show just how inadequate the reporting requirements really are. It has been a very unfortunate situation.
Of course, these are not simply my views. One only has to go into the Australian community and ask others. One could go to the annual report of the Reserve Bank of Australia which states:
It is also the case that more prudent decision- making by lenders was not helped by the development during the 1980s of creative accounting practices and complex corporate ownership structures.

That is in the Reserve Bank's recent annual report tabled here not that long ago. The annual report of the National Companies and Securities Commission also tabled not so very long ago had this to say:

One of the most remarkable features of the year was the number of receiverships of large and sometimes prominent business enterprises. In several cases those collapses revealed behaviour that was, at best, highly unethical and damaging to shareholders and which may eventually be proved to be illegal. . .
It also stated:

The chance of prosecutions being conducted successfully in some very complex cases revealed in some recent collapses is small. In these instances many interrelated companies and many elaborately contrived transactions are involved. It is usual for sophisticated legal and financial advice to be obtained with a view to constructing devices that are either just within the letter of the law or which are capable of being defended in Court by skilful lawyers. It is often difficult for even the financially initiated to unravel these transactions and inevitably it will be extremely hard for juries or even magistrates to understand them.

We face a serious problem. This is not something that I have dreamt up myself. One can hear about it widely in the community, read about it in the Reserve Bank's report and read about it in the report of the National Companies and Securities Commission.

As I was saying, the last decade of recent collapses show us how inadequate the reporting requirements really are. Schedule 7 of the Companies Code can be described as a user-friendly guide to deceiving shareholders and potential investors. There is a raft of ways in which the reporting requirements are inadequate, but the most glaring inadequacy in reporting requirements is the opportunity for companies to hide their activities in off balance sheet companies, trusts and partnerships. Consequently, the annual reports and financial statements do not always give a true and fair view of the whole group's activities.

Nowhere is this more evident at the moment than in my State of South Australia. In the private sector the problems of Adsteam are only now, in the last few months, coming to the fore. Teams of accountants and lawyers are trying to work out just exactly what the situation is.

Even more surprising is the situation of the State Bank of South Australia. The State Bank is, I think, incorporated under State legislation under its own Act. It has a wholly owned subsidiary, Beneficial Finance Corporation Ltd. It has a web of off balance sheet entities which include 58 off balance sheet companies, 53 of them being operated by Beneficial Finance Company. Until recently, however, only four of them had been made known publicly. The State Government which has, in effect, ultimate control over the bank, was apparently unaware of the web of off balance sheet companies.

It is very hard to say who is at fault here. Has the bank, which enjoys government backing, been less than frank with the Premier or has John Bannon, the Premier, been less than assiduous? Would not any premier, after the problems with the State Bank of Victoria, the collapse of the Farrow Group and this decade of the 1980s, make full and complete inquiries about his State Bank's position and the assets and liabilities of its subsidiaries and subsidiary entities, if they are not legally subsidiaries? I do not know the answer to that, but I do know that we would not have the problem if the reporting requirements were more stringent. The Premier would know automatically what the situation was.

The device for avoiding consolidation of all these entities in which there is a very substantial interest, is deceptively simple. The holding company simply ensures that it does not have control as defined in the Companies Code. That simply boils down to this: either having less than 50 per cent ownership; not having control of the composition of the board; or not holding more than half of the issued share capital.

Company A can have a subsidiary company B. Each of these companies can-for example, through a trust-be de facto owners of a new company C. Company C could then own less than 50 per cent of any number of other companies in which A or B could own an equivalent amount. The trust could own the remaining, probably inconsequential, amount. We could have company A owning company B and both of them, through a trust, effectively being the owners of company C, and those three companies owning myriad other companies, effectively having control of them and bypassing the requirement to consolidate that group into their balance sheets. That is a very simple matter, and one does not have to be bright to figure it out. Of course, plenty of companies have been bright enough to figure it out.

There could be the situation where these two companies hold 49 per cent each-just less than 50 per cent-and a trustee, which could be a firm of solicitors, holds the remaining 2 per cent. It would be no surprise to find one or more of the partners of that firm conveniently on the board of company A or B. There would be nothing to stop one or more of them being on the board of all the other off balance sheet companies. The directors of companies A and B could, between themselves, divvy up the benefits by way of directors' fees, management fees and whatever for the off balance sheet companies.

We have to ask ourselves how much of these benefits is disclosed to shareholders in company A or company B. A government would have to be blind not to see the consequences of such a loophole. It would have to be blind or deceitfully indifferent to do nothing about it. I will make no further comment about the Government's blindness or indifference to this matter.

The accounting profession also has not been quick to adopt the accounting standards issued by an international accounting standards committee. Nor has the Accounting Standards Review Board been very mobile in issuing new approved accounting standards. Auditors have not been free of criticism. Questions are being asked. Are there mottos of integrity, and without fear or favour are they still applicable? What do auditors do when they believe a set of accounts, while strictly legal, nonetheless do not give a true and fair picture of a company's activities?

The question needs to be asked: who wants this situation changed? The Australian Accounting Research Foundation has been lobbying for some time to have the law relating to consolidation of accounts changed. Australian investors and international investors are entitled to a true and fair view of a group's financial position. Not the least of these investors are the superannuation fund managers; those who control the funds of all those people-workers, employees and self-employed people-trying to provide for their future by putting their money into superannuation funds. Those funds have managers who invest those funds. Those investors have a right to a true and fair picture of what the managers are investing in on behalf of the superannuants.

The Government sees the importance of superannuation and of workers, employees and employers providing for their future. Why cannot the Government see the need for the super fund managers to have a true and fair view of the entities in which those fund managers are investing? Without going into detail, it is quite clear, and should be to everybody, that State governments and Federal authorities also need clear and accurate information for banks, which may not be covered by the Companies Code to a certain extent, and non-banking financial intermediaries.

What is abundantly clear now is that none of these groups or bodies can rely on the annual reports and financial statements to get this information. When the annual reports and financial statements do not give a true and fair view of a company's financial position, and when we look at what happened in the last year in the last decade, how can we pretend that Australian investors, international investors, super fund managers, the Taxation Commissioner and the Reserve Bank have a true and fair picture of what is really happening? This is a detailed area of law. The law, in my view, is inadequate for our current situation. I have sought tonight only to raise the problem and the consequences for investors. They are disastrous consequences.

At a later stage, when the Parliament resumes, I will address the legal detail of these problems. However, the problem has been resolved in the United Kingdom. It has been resolved in Europe and we should get our own house in order. Let me conclude by repeating that we have the power in this place to tear off the deceitful glossy wrapping of annual reports and force companies to present themselves for what they are. I intend to see that we do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to conclude the remarks I was making last night when I was interrupted by a quorum being called and the Senate being counted out. It is very important that we recognise the selective nature of much of our indignation over Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. The Arab world is quite correctly bitter over the double standards applied by the world community to Israel and Palestine since 1967 and, of course, in many other examples that have been given in this place before of our very ready ability to ignore other instances where large countries have taken over small countries and invasions have taken place; for example, Indonesia in East Timor and the United States in Granada and Panama.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously, these double standards are causing some disquiet. It is also important to stress that the United Nations cannot be used only when it suits the interests of the five permanent members of the Security Council. The United States does not mind using the United Nations to endorse and legitimise its planned attack on Iraq-of course, I still hope that it will not come to that-after 15 January, but it was not prepared to accept the criticism of its own intervention in Granada and Panama, nor was it prepared to accept the jurisdiction of the International Court of Justice when Nicaragua complained about the mining of its harbours by the United States to that court. This is the country which is now using the United Nations for its own purposes. It is the same country which could not be bothered paying its dues and which also chooses to ignore many other United Nations resolutions when it suits it, particularly when they apply to its great friend Israel.

It is to Australia's shame that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) personally intervened to instruct our United Nations delegation in New York to support the United States when it was threatened by a censure motion on Panama at the United Nations-a motion that originally the Australian delegation was prepared to support. It was going to support it but the Prime Minister rang and said, `No, we are going to support the United States on that'. This was despite the fact that the United States had intervened in another country's affairs in Panama which was a similar sort of situation to what we are complaining about now.

We need to be honest about why we are supporting the situation as it is at the moment in the Gulf and why we are supporting the United States without all this hypocrisy over fighting for freedom and democracy and self-determination. They are hardly concepts which are familiar to the inhabitants of the Gulf states and certainly not to those workers who lived in Kuwait without any civil rights whatsoever. Rather than liberating Kuwait, the phrase that is being used by the United States, it would be a complete demolition job. Let us understand that a war after 15 January will do nothing to solve the long term problems in the region. In the long run, it will serve only to exacerbate those problems. That is why I urge the world community to choose the path already being advocated by a number of governments, as well as leading figures like Robert MacNamara in the United States; that is, negotiations backed by sanctions, rather than the war option. War should be taken off the agenda.

As I outlined last night, there are negotiating points and there is a formula for a peace conference. We must have a peace conference either before or after a war. If it is after the war, of course, it is a peace conference of the victors meeting with the vanquished. The Treaty of Versailles after World War I was so brutal to the vanquished that it sowed the seeds of World War II. (Quorum formed) We could, of course, cut out the slaughter phase, that is the war, and get straight on with the peace conference rather than continuing with war preparations. That is what I believe we should do. We have to have a peace conference either before or after a war. The human consequences of a war are something that the political leaders who are very heavily engaged in preparations for war are not acknowledging. I urge the Australian Prime Minister to withdraw Australia's forces while we still have the chance to do so. If we leave them there much longer it may be too late. There could well be a pre-emptive strike before the 15 January deadline. If there is a war, whether it is before or after that 15 January deadline, there will be blood on Mr Hawke's hands. None of us want that.

He is the first Labor Prime Minister in the history of this country to consider leading Australia to war and this is very distressing to the Australian Labor Party (ALP) membership around the country although we have not heard ALP members in here saying anything about that. It is a tragedy if the bully boys will never learn or listen to the wisdom of the people. For the honour of Australia as a good global citizen, in the long run we must take Australia out of the 23-nation United Nations sanctioned blood bath. It will not be to our credit that Australia rushed in to support the United States if it comes to a war. As I said earlier, I certainly hope it does not come to that.

I conclude with a remark that has been made by many people, not only in Australia but also in the 23 countries that are lined up with their huge forces of armaments against the Iraqis. People do not consider that we should be spilling blood for oil.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 12.49 a.m. (Friday)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 7 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many persons were employed by the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service (CRS) on a part time basis and a full time basis: (a) as at 30 June 1990; and (b) as at the date of answering this question.
(2) To any and what extent were any and which of the CRS services contracted out to the private sector: (a) as at 30 June 1990; and (b) as at the date of answering this question.

(3) What is the total value of property owned by the Commonwealth used as regional CRS offices and what is the location of each of these regional offices: (a) as at 30 June 1990; and (b) as at the date of answering this question.

(4) In respect of each regional CRS office as at 30 June 1990: (a) who owned the office; (b) what rent was paid during the financial year 1989-90; (c) how many clients were assisted thereat; (d) how many persons were interviewed thereat; (e) how many persons were employed thereat and in what capacities on a part time basis and on a full time basis; and (f) what were total employment costs of each person, including any and what wage or salary, on-costs, travel allowance, Commonwealth car charge and distributed administration costs.
(5) What was the total average number of visits to each CRS regional office by assisted clients during the financial year 1989-90.

(6) As to the clients assisted by the CRS during the financial year 198990: (a) what were the broad categories of disability for such clients; (b) what was the average cost of assisting clients in each regional office; and (c) in what manner and to what extent were they assisted.
(7) How is the assessment of the CRS program measured.

(8) Of the 19, 573 clients assisted by the CRS during the financial year 1989-90: (a) how many were in the workforce at the time they first came into contact with CRS; and (b) how many were in the workforce on a full time basis and on a part time basis for three months and six months after they ceased receiving assistance from CRS.

(9) What percentage or number of clients assisted by CRS during the financial year 1989-90: (a) were referred by any and what Commonwealth departments; (b) were referred by State Government departments; (c) attended a regional office, pursuant to a request therefrom; and (d) attended a regional office unprompted.
(10) Does the CRS employ any and what number and type of mobile assistance or treatment teams.
(11) How is the average salary cost of $31 905 for the financial year 1989-90 made up or calculated.
(12) How is the average salary cost of $39 748 estimated for 1990-91 made up or calculated and what is the reason(s) for the substantial estimated increase compared to the previous year.

(13) As to the: (a) 8600 females; (b) 400 Aboriginals; (c) 3050 NESB persons; and (d) 6000 rural and remote persons targeted for 1990-91, how are such persons to be identified or selected and what is the basis for such targeting.
(14) How many persons within the total CRS client target for 1990-91 of 21000 will not be targeted and how will such persons be identified or selected.
(15) During the financial year 1989-90, were any and what functions, activities or services of the CRS transferred to any and what community-based organisations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) As at 30 June 1990, 911 staff were employed by the CRS on a full-time basis and a further 40 staff were employed part-time.
(1) (b) The CRS currently employs 971 full-time staff and 43 part-time.

In providing programs to clients they access specialist community and private sector resources. The CRS purchases on a fee-for-service basis specialist assessment and other assistance for clients, including specialist psychiatric and clinical reports, neuro-psychological assessments, and the services of allied health therapists where it is more expensive to provide these services in-house. The CRS also purchases aids and appliances, vehicle modifications and home modifications from the private sector. In 1989-90 $9.4 million was expended on such contracted services.
(1) (b) From 1 July to 31 October 1990, $3.47 million was expended on contract services.

(5) The CRS does not collect client data on a basis that would permit the ready calculation of the number of client visits in a given period. Within an agreed program, activity on behalf of a client may include seeking out suitable work training scheme employers, agreement with employers on a graded return to work, arranging the modification of a workplace for a new disabled employee, a supervision role in initial employment, advocacy of a client's case with potential employers, visiting the client in his own home or work environment, or the negotiation with community agencies for a referral more appropriate to the needs of the client. Rehabilitation programs last on average 26 weeks. Visits of clients to units do not measure the intensity of activity undertaken on behalf of a client and represent a minor proportion of the time devoted to an individual client.

(6) (b) Readily accessible records at the unit level are not available to give an accurate per client cost for each regional unit. However, the average cost for the network over the last four years is:

(6) (c) The CRS provides direct social and vocational rehabilitation services in a community-based context. A professionally qualified case manager works with a client to plan, co-ordinate and monitor a rehabilitation program. The case manager takes full responsibility for a client's program from referral to completion and uses community and private sector resources as well as discipline specific resources from within the regional unit. The case manager co-ordinates and controls the rehabilitation process from initial assessment and the development of a rehabilitation plan, through to the monitoring of progress against plan to case completion. A typical rehabilitation plan that is vocationally directed will include assessment activities, job search activities, and workplace support in the initial phase of employment.
(7) End program circumstances are the major indicators of the effectiveness of the program.
(8) (a) Of the 19,573 clients assisted in programs in 1989-90:
* 283 were in active full-time employment, but with their jobs in jeopardy;
* 76 were in active part-time employment, but with their jobs in jeopardy;
* 3,977 had full-time jobs, but were unable to work;
* 657 had part-time jobs, but were unable to work;
* 309 were in supported employment arrangements under the Disability Services Act;
* 9461 were unemployed;
* 4792 were not seeking employment;
* 18 were not categorised.

(9) (b) Details of the 19,573 clients' workforce status at three months and six months after they ceased receiving assistance from the CRS are not available. Formal collection of this information is about to be introduced into CRS work practice and will be included in a redevelopment of the CRS management information system which is scheduled for implementation on 1 July 1991.
(9) (a) Of the 19,573 clients assisted in programs in 1989-90:
* 1,356 were referred from the Department of Social Security;
* 2,108 were referred from the Department of Employment, Education and Training;
* 1,221 were referred by other Commonwealth departments and agencies.
(b) 4,398 were referred by State Government Departments and agencies.
(c) Nil. The CRS does not independently request clients to participate.
(d) 5,138 of the clients assisted in programs were selfreferrals; a further 722 were referred by family or friends.

(10) The CRS has over 120 physical locations in a widely dispersed network of units and outposts. Its practice is to have permanent locations to provide on-going support to clients during programs. From these sites, CRS combines caseworker and client travel, where necessary, to provide comprehensive services to outlying populations. CRS operates an outreach team from Darwin which services clients from Tennant Creek, Bathurst Island, and Nhulunbuy, and provides additional professional services to the outposts at Katherine and Kununurra.
(11) The average salary cost is total salary payment divided by full-time equivalent staffing for the year.

(12) The figure of $39,748 shown in the Explanatory Notes to the Senate was inappropriately inflated, as a result of internal accounting adjustments associated with intra-departmental charging practices. The correct estimated average salary cost for the CRS is $33,655. The increase reflects national wage case increases.

(13) The CRS Charter offers equal access to all eligible Australians on the basis of their need for rehabilitation. This includes not only gaining entry to the service, but also to the appropriateness of programs to the cultural, social and other circumstances of the client and to the quality of outcomes. The CRS aims to deliver services to the identified target groups at a level which properly reflects their representation among people with disabilities in the general community, who are eligible for CRS services under the Disability Services Act, and has active strategies in place to achieve this. The CRS does not use target group characteristics as a criterion for eligibility to participate in programs. The targets are used to monitor ex-poste the effectiveness of CRS access strategies.
(14) See response to Question 13.
(15) During the 1989-90 financial year no functions, activities or services of the CRS were transferred to any community-based organisations.
